HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Satellite Company Is Trying Life on Its Own

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Like a spacecraft breaking free of the rocket it no longer needs to reach its final destination, Intelsat severed its ties last week with the governments that launched it nearly 40 years ago. 
 Intelsat, a communications satellite operator whose formal name used to be the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, has been transformed into a Bermuda-based holding company. The bulk of its operations remain at its longtime headquarters in Washington and at a marketing subsidiary in London. 
 As a fully private company, Intelsat has been stripped of antitrust immunities, tax privileges and automatic access to markets that had been its birthright since 1964 and a source of constant irritation to the private sector rivals that grew up to compete with it.
Over the years, those connections brought Intelsat such high-level jobs as providing the original hot-line phone link between the White House and the Kremlin and broadcasting worldwide Neil Armstrong's walk on the moon. Intelsat became so entrenched in global telecommunications that as of last year, 70 of its 146 member countries reported that they relied on it for all international telecommunications and 40 used it for domestic links, as well. 
But, after years of debate, Intelsat officials finally convinced all of the organization's members late last year that support for the old Intelsat was waning in wealthier nations with more telecommunications choices. Without a change, they argued, resources would shrink to the point that service everywhere would deteriorate.
In leaving behind its semiofficial status, Intelsat shed a ponderous decision-making structure and pricing constraints that prevented it from being nimble. The old Intelsat was governed by a 48-member board representing the diverse interests of 146 member countries. 
Intelsat's quarterly board meetings lasted a full week, in part because every issue had to be hashed out in three official languages. 
Ownership shares were based on use of the system, and no significant investments could be made without at least two-thirds of the shares voting in favor. Because every member had to contribute capital based on its ownership percentage, proposals for new satellites or services aimed at specific regions often ran into resistance from the many members that might not benefit directly.
Nor could Intelsat quickly cut prices in regions where it faced competition without cutting prices to all its members. To protect private competitors, regulators in various countries had shut Intelsat out of some lucrative new markets, like satellite television broadcasting in the United States. And unlike its private competitors, Intelsat was barred from offering ground-based communications services that could enhance the appeal of its satellite links.
No wonder Intelsat executives have become every bit as eager for privatization as any of the company's rivals.
"The fact that we needed to privatize became blatantly obvious in the early 90's," said Conny L. Kullman, a 51-year-old engineer who traded the title of director general for chief executive in the transition. His new board has a mere 17 members.
Rival satellite operators freely acknowledge that they may not always come out ahead on the newly leveled playing field they have been fighting for since the 1980's. 
"It will be a jump-ball market," said James W. Cuminale, executive vice president and general counsel of PanAmSat, a a satellite operator based in Greenwich, Conn., that is controlled by the Hughes Electronics subsidiary of General Motors. PanAmSat has long been the most vocal campaigner for ending Intelsat's special status. "Commerce has conquered space," Mr. Cuminale said. 
Intelsat's privatization marks the end of a grand experiment in using government to grease the skids for private enterprise in a sector in which many traditional customers have doubted that market forces should be trusted. At the time Intelsat began taking shape, only AT&T, which was still a regulated monopoly, had managed to launch a communications satellite successfully.
AT&T's satellite, named Telstar, began operating in July 1962. By the time it was silenced early the next year by radiation from nuclear bomb tests, feats like the first trans-Atlantic television broadcasts had fired the public imagination. An obscure British band called the Tornadoes shot to the top of the music charts with the instrumental "Telstar," its homage to the satellite (www .retrofuture.com/telstar.html). 
Governments around the world recognized the potential communications breakthrough, but with monopolies like AT&T controlling the industry in every country, there were concerns about how the new technology would spread and be regulated.
To accelerate investment in what President John F. Kennedy called "vital elements in the march of civilization," the United States and other governments agreed to form a collective organization. The designated American participant, created by Congress in 1962, was called the Communications Satellite Corporation, or Comsat. 
The administrative part of the experiment had its low points. In 1988, Richard R. Colino, Intelsat's director general for most of that decade, was sentenced to six years in prison for organizing the theft of $5.4 million from Intelsat, mostly in connection with construction of its Washington headquarters complex. Jose L. Alegrett, his deputy, was also convicted for his role in the illegal activities. 
But by then, the Intelsat model had already proved its worth. Starting with the 1965 launching of Early Bird, Intelsat built a steadily expanding network capable of reaching nearly the entire planet from so-called geostationary sites 22,300 miles above the Equator. Such satellites orbit so that they appear in a fixed spot in the sky. 
After the Intelsat example, the International Marine Satellite Communications Organization, or Inmarsat, was set up in 1975 in London to provide communications to ships, aircraft and other mobile customers. Not long after, a consortium of European countries set up Eutelsat, based in Paris, to speed development of satellite services in that region and provide competition for Intelsat. 
The privatization movement has now unwound all of those ventures. After years of negotiations, the logjam began breaking up in 1998, when Intelsat spun off 5 of its 24 satellites into New Skies Satellites, a start-up based in the Netherlands, as a first step in its privatization journey. In 1999, Inmarsat went private. 
The final phase of Intelsat's privatization came last week, just weeks after Eutelsat completed a similar transition. Eventually, shares of all the former collectives will be traded on public stock exchanges. New Skies had its initial public offering last October, and Inmarsat plans to follow by the end of the year; Intelsat and Eutelsat are aiming for 2002.
For now, Intelsat's largest shareholder is Lockheed Martin, the result of its acquisition of Comsat in 1999. The privatization agreements bar Lockheed from expanding its 22 percent stake before stock is sold to the public. Other private-sector companies that have inherited or acquired member-state stakes hold an additional 50 percent of the shares. Adopting an employee stock plan is among the first items on the agenda at the initial meeting of Intelsat's new board this week.
At the very least, the privatization efforts serve as a reminder to investors that despite the woes of start-up ventures like Iridium and Globalstar, there are solidly profitable segments of the satellite industry. Intelsat is a prime example. Last year, it had a profit margin approaching 50 percent, earning $505 million on revenue of $1.1 billion. 
The geostationary satellite operators' revenues reached $10.2 billion last year, according to the Futron Corporation, a technology consulting firm in Bethesda, Md. Customers included cable television networks, direct-to-home satellite broadcasters, phone companies, Internet service providers and companies that operate private data networks. 
Intelsat, PanAmSat, Eutelsat and Loral Space and Communications are all large players in the profitable geostationary sector. But the market leader in the near future will be SES Global, a Luxembourg-based company being formed by the pending merger of GE Americom, a unit of General Electric, and SES Astra.
SES will own a fleet of 28 satellites and have access to 13 others through investments in smaller players like AsiaSat and Brasilsat. Overcapacity, especially in Asia, has driven down prices 50 percent the last three years. Analysts and Intelsat executives agree that Intelsat is going private at a time that more mergers are likely in the near future.
"There are incredible economies to scale," said Joseph Corbett, Intelsat's chief financial officer. "You can fly more satellites with very little increase in operating costs. And customers want global connectivity."
Analysts say such pressures are likely to lead to a Eutelsat acquisition of New Skies in the near future. Another consolidation candidate is Loral's Skynet network. Loral's maneuvering room has been limited by the losses at Globalstar, a Loral-controlled constellation of satellites for mobile customers. Those satellites orbit closer to Earth than the geostationary satellites. 
Even without acquiring smaller players, Intelsat plans to add nearly 40 percent to its capacity over the next two years by launching nine new satellites. But the company's biggest selling point may be its track record on reliability. Last year, for instance, Intelsat satellites were in service for all but 32 hours of a possible 7.2 million, or more than 99.999 percent of the time.
"They are the gold standard for operating a fleet," said Michael French, an analyst at SG Cowen.

HEADLINE: Unhealthy Cuts for Head Start 

 BODY:
Buried in President Bush's budget message, released in April, is a plan to dramatically change Head Start, the federal program that promotes literacy as well as healthy and enriched lives for children from disadvantaged backgrounds. The president's strategy already needs rethinking.
 Mr. Bush's plan to reform Head Start begins with the admirable intent of improving literacy and easing the transition from preschool to elementary education. But vital parts of the program aimed at other facets of children's well-being -- social development, parental involvement, nutrition and physical and mental health -- could be headed for trouble. Mr. Bush wants to cut funding for 2002, in per child terms, by 2 percent. Inflation will further reduce the value of services received by each child. The program has not suffered a similar cut since the Reagan budgets of 1983 and 1986. 
 Head Start has traditionally come under attack by Republicans who question the qualifications of its teaching staff and its long-term effects on the social and educational outcomes of participating children. Both of these concerns have been addressed in the past few years. Roughly 90 percent of Head Start teachers now hold university degrees or state accreditation in early childhood education.
Recent research shows that Head Start has several positive effects on children's later lives. The government's own reports state that Head Start lifts children's chances of promotion through elementary grade levels and lowers the rate at which they enter special education programs. White children who were enrolled in the program are more likely to graduate from high school than peers from similar socioeconomic backgrounds. Black children, though no more likely to graduate from high school, are less likely to have been charged with crimes. Hispanic-American graduates consistently achieve better test scores and grade-level promotion rates than their peers, in part because of assistance in learning English.
Mr. Bush wants to strengthen the program's emphasis on education and is proposing a modest increase in overall financing. But with projected enrollment increases, the funding per child will actually fall, and any enhancement of education will have to be done at the expense of valuable health and social assistance. That seems shortsighted.

HEADLINE: To Be Young and in Search of the Higgs Boson 

BYLINE:  By JAMES GLANZ 

DATELINE: SNOWMASS VILLAGE, Colo. 

 BODY:
Real estate in this resort town, which cascades down a mountainside a few miles northwest of Aspen, can run over $1,000 a square foot. Compare that with the roughly $6 billion, without furnishings, that senior physicists at a meeting here this month said they needed for a new machine to track down exotic particles weighing about the same as a single silver atom left in the ground from the region's hardscrabble mining past.
 But in physics as in real estate, rising prices can be most painful for the young community members. Although young physicists would not have to pay for the project themselves, their careers could depend on whether world governments decide to heed the elder experts' advice and cooperate in building the machine. 
 With the demise of the cold war arguments for spending on the physical sciences, those soaring costs are creating a new class of highly educated workers now at the mercy of international currents. 
"Sometimes I feel like I'm a character in an independent film," said Dr. Kenneth Bloom, a 30-year-old postdoctoral researcher at the University of Michigan, "where there's some large conspiracy and I'm just some minor pawn in what's going on." Now, he is one of hundreds of physicists collaborating on a particle physics experiment at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory.
Scientists like Dr. Bloom, whose position, like that of all postdocs, is a temporary job that allows him to build credentials for a permanent spot, could be forgiven for turning permanently fatalistic. Projects in physics, astronomy, space science and related fields have become ever larger and more costly as budgets in those areas have declined in favor of biomedical and defense research.
But resignation is not what turned up in a brief canvass of the young scientists here, where over 1,000 particle physicists met from July 1 until Friday to plan their field's future. Instead, there were glimmers of a truly post-cold-war generation of physicists who are banding together in their own interest and making the case, politically and scientifically, that many reasons exist to build those big machines.
Those reasons include the expectation of spinoff technologies to help drive the economy, the scientists say as they work out their pitch. They also point to the light the research will shine on the deepest secrets of the cosmos and the large number of students the work will support.
"We have to sing for our supper, and that's something the young people are coming to terms with," said Dr. Robin Erbacher, 33, a postdoc at Fermilab. In spite of her field's introverted stereotype, she gives public tours of the laboratory, lectures in schools and has met with members of Congress to urge increased support for physics research.
Dr. Bloom and Dr. Erbacher were among the organizers here of a series of forums that are designed for young physicists to sound out their colleagues in the hope of eventually influencing the future of their field. A separate group called the Young Physicists' Panel was formed at Fermilab last year, said Sam Zeller, 29, a panel member who is a graduate student at Northwestern while doing research at the laboratory.
The idea, Ms. Zeller said, is to develop education and outreach programs so "you're not just sitting at your desk totally entranced in your own little world."
Being entranced in one's own little world was once almost a cultural imperative of physics.
Decades ago, individual universities could afford frontline particle accelerators to study the structure of matter. The masses were fairly low for the particles of interest, things like electrons, muons, kaons and pions. Reflecting Einstein's equivalence of mass and energy, particle accelerators could study them in the microscopic wreckage of fairly low-energy collisions.
Now, as construction begins on a new $4 billion accelerator, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Geneva -- and as physicists here make the case for a giant follow-on machine that could cost $6 billion or more -- no one contemplates building more than one of each type in the world.
As one measure of how high the ante has been raised, a pion has about one-seventh the weight of a proton, while a Higgs boson -- a particle the hadron collider will chase -- is thought to have a weight that is 100 to 200 times as great as a proton's and to be much harder to identify. A silver atom weighs about the same as 100 protons.
These days, no one knows where, or even if, the successor to the hadron collider will be built. That makes career planning difficult, even in a field whose allure has never revolved around financial gain, said Dr. Zack Sullivan, 29, a theoretical physicist who is a postdoc at Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois.
"I could have gone to Wall Street and made a ton of money," Dr. Sullivan said, referring to the strong demand for mathematically sophisticated analysts in the financial sector. "But instead I became a graduate student for $10,000 a year."
Dr. Sullivan is not crying in his beer; he finds it thrilling to go to work each day with a chance to discover something new about the universe. In fact, the young scientists are eager to point out that they are motivated not solely by a drive for job security but by indications from theory that a welter of discoveries may be nigh -- if the machines to make them are built.
"There are a lot of hints that there is new physics just around the corner," said Dr. Gudrid Moortgat-Pick, 31, a theorist who is a postdoc at DESY, a particle physics laboratory in Hamburg, Germany.
Naturally, the scientists are not averse to keeping their job prospects healthy, either. In that respect, the challenge that particle physicists face does have parallels in other parts of the high-tech economy, said Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, which represents 500 technology companies.
As examples of long-term projects with similar stakes for high-tech workers, Mr. Miller came up with projects like the space station, the missile defense program and even the projects required to develop new automobile designs.
Citing a highly successful push by biomedical companies several years ago to increase federal financing for their research, Mr. Miller said the young physicists had been taking the right steps in organizing to promote their cause.
"It wasn't just sort of individual, random scientists or biomedical researchers wandering around the Hill," Mr. Miller said. "It was a huge coalition."
Whether the scientists can change the degage habits of their field so drastically remains to be seen. But at Snowmass, where conference participants carried out a series of public outreach programs, there were hints that the scientists' message may be finding an audience among the people who pay the considerable bills for the science. 
When asked whether it was obvious that a condominium with a view would always trump a particle accelerator as the preferred way for the average person to part with a few dollars, Terry Morse, a real estate agent in Snowmass, hesitated for only an instant.
Even in a Rocky Mountain condo, Mr. Morse said, "you don't have a view of the entire universe."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Deflation of an Optimist, by a Young Writer

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 19 

 BODY:
If you're a frequent theatergoer, the sound of a new and singular dramatic voice is the sound you listen for. Hearing it is rare, of course, and you're never expectant but always hopeful, like a bird-watcher attuned to the trill of an endangered bird. The sound is loud and unmistakable, however, here at the Williamstown Theater Festival, where the work of a 25-year-old playwright -- a play called "The Man Who Had All the Luck" -- is surely the herald of an important career. 
 Well, O.K., that's a bit of a fudge. It was the herald of an important career, though critical prescience was absent in 1944, when the play closed after four performances on Broadway. Not until later in the decade did the author, Arthur Miller, have successes -- "All My Sons" and "Death of a Salesman" -- that would begin to make people remember him. 
 The compelling new production, which runs through July 29, has been lucidly directed by Scott Ellis, on a spacious, simple and handsome set by Allen Moyer (its most spectacular feature is a rare antique automobile, a 1930 Marmon) and performed by a glowing cast that had only three weeks to rehearse. Together they show the play -- Mr. Miller's first produced full-length work -- to be swelling with ambition and both flawed and gripping, and one question it leaves you with is how it could have been so easily dismissed 57 years ago. 
And given the subsequent career of the playwright, who is now 85 and whose work has been in resurgence the past few seasons, it's downright bizarre that until now the play has been almost entirely forgotten; this is its first major American revival.
The story of a young man in the Midwest on whom fortune regularly smiles even as it abandons everyone around him, "The Man Who Had All the Luck" is a play that creates the fraternal rivalries and filial conflicts that Mr. Miller revisited and honed, most famously in the Loman family. (Biff Loman's moment of disillusionment with his father and his violent response get a trial run here.) It introduces his penchant for allegory, foreshadows the playwright's career-long probe of American values and shows him as a pesty, contrarian national conscience.
The title character is David Beeves, an all-American boy in easy description and symbolic intent. A fresh-faced 22-year-old as the play begins, he is starting his own business, turning an old barn into an auto repair shop, with no more training or expertise than the founding fathers had in creating a nation. And he is also preparing to face down the father of the girl he has loved since childhood, a locally feared (and wealthy) man who hates David with particular unreason and has vowed to keep his daughter from him, violently if need be.
The threat is short-lived. Indeed, that obstacles tend to vanish from David's path is illustrated early on with shocking suddenness, and when an Austrian immigrant who just happens to be an expert mechanic moves to town just at the moment that an affluent farmer and mink breeder is about to bestow on David all the business of his farm machinery, it becomes clear that there is a fairy tale quality to David's life.
All that is missing is the success of his older brother, Amos, who has been training since childhood, under the obsessive eye of his father, to pitch in the major leagues. Automobiles, baseball, mink coats, childhood sweethearts, the timely contributions of immigrants: America!
Mr. Miller wrote the play in 1940, and set it in 1938, when the nation was grappling its way out of the Depression and Europe was tumbling toward war, and in David Beeves he was questioning, with the fervid earnestness of a young writer, our often smugly held presumption of being blessed. (One explanation for the play's original failure might be that by 1944, with the United States engaged in a world war, no one was in the mood for, or even attuned to, national navel-gazing.)
Like "Death of a Salesman," for example, which exposed the darkness under the sheen of American capitalism, and "The Crucible," which attacked in symbolic fashion the tyranny of American righteousness, "The Man Who Had All the Luck" is an admonitory work, one that pleads seriously for a national acknowledgment that we are not a chosen people but a fortunate one and that declares that our fortune must be wielded with responsibility and without clucking. Otherwise, watch out; there's nothing like the force of nature -- in this case a mammoth thunderstorm -- to illustrate how calamitous hubris can be.
There is a palpable precociousness in the play, particularly in the overly explanatory final act, which takes on a slightly tedious attitude of a goody-goody younger brother waggling his finger at you in warning. Perhaps in the optimism of youth, the playwright doesn't quite have the chutzpah to crank up the stakes to life and death, as he does in later plays. And there are one or two dramatic problems that the young playwright either overlooked or couldn't solve; the sudden demise of David's resistant father-in-law-to-be is received by all the characters with barely a shrug.
Already in place are Mr. Miller's dogged delineation of moral conundrums, his sturdy dialogue that is not without a kind of plebeian lyricism -- "He's got his whole life laid out like a piece of linoleum" -- and a sense of speechifying moment. Two soliloquies, one about the rigors of mink farming, delivered by Dan Dibble, the eccentric and entrepreneurial old farmer, the other about the mysteries of baseball, delivered by Augie Belfast, a grizzled scout for the Detroit Tigers, are beautifully detailed and mythically charged, enough to nourish actors with the fuel for great character turns.
In this production, Mason Adams as Dibble and David Wohl as Belfastprovide vivid, memorably idiosyncratic variations on recognizable American types. Indeed, Mr. Ellis's beautifully cast production is dotted with admirable performances, particularly given the limited rehearsal time. 
Especially to be noted is the young film actor, Chris O'Donnell, who is making a remarkable stage debut as David. Those who recall Mr. O'Donnell's innocently handsome appeal from a couple of "Batman" movies (he was Robin) and "Scent of a Woman" (with Al Pacino) will not be surprised that he is physically perfect for the part of David, but his comfort, solidity and easy charisma on the stage will be the envy of many more experienced players.
At times you can see Mr. O'Donnell thinking on his feet, but with the accelerated rehearsal schedule the same is true of many of the others here, and in a complicated role that moves him in gradations from golden boy to conscience-stricken brother and neighbor to a man on the edge of madness, Mr. O'Donnell never goes over the top, never loses the character's own sense that he is an ordinary man who has been visited by extraordinary circumstances. Being buffeted by the winds of fortune never empowers David, and it never overly emboldens Mr. O'Donnell either. One gets the sense that the character's innate self-scrutiny is a quality of the actor as well.
An early scene in which David meets and is rescued from an embarrassing failure by Gus Eberson, the Austrian mechanic (played by a marvelously warm Sam Robards), has to be one of the most naturally sweet encounters onstage anywhere right now. It reminds you how infrequent it is that friendliness and courtesy are dramatized, and even for the most cynical theatergoer Mr. O'Donnell makes the scene a winning one. His entirely ingratiating performance is propelled from here. Perhaps like the playwright, he has a grand future onstage.

THE MAN WHO HAD ALL THE LUCK
A Fable

By Arthur Miller; directed by Scott Ellis; sets by Allen Moyer; costumes by Michael Krass; lighting by Kenneth Posner; sound by Eileen Tague; original music by Tom Kochan; stage manager, Grayson Meritt; production manager, Amanda Mott. Presented by the Williamstown Theater Festival, Michael Ritchie, producer; Deborah Fehr, general manager; Jenny C. Gersten, associate producer. At Adams Memorial Theater, 1000 Main Street, Williamstown, Mass.

WITH: Chris O'Donnell (David Beeves), Richard Riehle (J. B. Feller), Dan Moran (Shory), Barbara Sims (Aunt Belle), James Rebhorn (Patterson Beeves), Ryan Shively (Amos Beeves), Jennifer Dundas (Hester Falk), Mason Adams (Dan Dibble), Edward James Hyland (Andrew Falk), Sam Robards (Gus Eberson) and David Wohl (Augie Belfast).

HEADLINE: Cleaning Our Waterways 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "E.P.A. Delays Further Rules of Clinton Era" (news article, July 17): 
 If 40 percent of America's waterways are not fishable or swimmable because of polluted runoff, that is unrealized economic potential of about $9 billion a year in freshwater sport fishing alone. 
Add to that other lost recreational income, diminished values of riparian real estate, reduced tax base, lowered public image discouraging tourism and development, public health concerns and higher treatment costs for public water supplies.
Water pollution is part of the cost of farming, land clearing, city streets, highways and precipitated stack effluents from power plants and factories. Resource economics can identify the costs, who benefits and who therefore should pay to bring back the potential of our polluted waters.

MIKE FREMONT
President, Rivers Unlimited
Cincinnati, July 17, 2001

HEADLINE: Pakistan Reckons With a Rising India 

BYLINE:  By Pankaj Mishra; Pankaj Mishra is author of "The Romantics." He writes often on Kashmir.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
 Earlier this month, in the small north Indian city of Agra, the leaders of India and Pakistan met to discuss the troubled relationship that has led them into four wars in the last five decades. The Taj Mahal, a symbol of eternal love, seemed an appropriate backdrop to their efforts: the marble monument was built by Shah Jehan, the 17th-century Mogul emperor, in memory of his wife, who had died young. There also appeared something reconciliatory in the choice of venue by India's ruling Hindu nationalist party, which is not known for its affection for Muslim-built cities and monuments -- the party rose to power after destroying, in 1992, a 16th-century mosque it thought expressed a Mogul invader's contempt for Hindus. 
 The India-Pakistan summit's failure now adds to the Taj Mahal's more melancholy associations. Shah Jehan spent the last years of his life gazing upon it from a small room in a nearby fort, where he was imprisoned by his son, Aurangzeb. General Pervez Musharraf, president of Pakistan, had a similarly clear view of the Taj from his hotel suite; but it plainly didn't much alleviate the "hurt" and "disappointment" he says he felt over the futile summit. 
His hosts may have been more commercially motivated in their choice of backdrop: India receives, despite the Taj Mahal, just .4 percent of the world's tourist traffic, and a concerned government has recently paid millions of dollars to a New York advertising agency for a campaign that emphasizes the soothing and peaceful nature of India. In this marketing plan, the serene possession of a great cultural and spiritual heritage goes together with the quick adaptability represented by India's information technology tycoons. The projection isn't just meant for foreigners. The Hindu triumphalist belief that India -- despite its gigantic problems of poverty, illiteracy and disease -- is advancing fast toward superpower status is widely shared among the Indian middle classes who have benefited most from the neo-liberal economic reforms of the last decade. The economic lives of the majorities in India and Pakistan are roughly the same; India's per capita gross domestic product is indeed higher, but not wildly so. However, for India's middle classes and elite the interest lies in whatever superiorities can be identified and concentrated upon. The growth of India's software and related high-technology industries is one such superiority; closer ties between India and Pakistan's old cold war ally, the United States, are another. 
To look, as many Indians do, at Pakistan from such heights of ambition is to look at a struggling neighbor, economically reliant on International Monetary Fund handouts and politically blocked by the unworkable ideologies of Islam and a hyperactive military. Some of the Pakistani newspapers themselves seemed to confirm this stereotype of a country unable to move forward when, in the hectic buildup to the summit, they referred nostalgically to the Taj Mahal and the long centuries of Muslim rule over India. 
Such a nostalgia, the dream of recovering lost Muslim glory, contributed greatly to the partition of India and the creation of Pakistan in 1947: it was the other side of the quite real fear among Indian Muslims of being reduced to a powerless minority in a Hindu-majority country. Unlike India, Pakistan had a self-image tied, from the very beginning, to religion. But as the secession in 1971 of Pakistan's Bengali-speaking province proved, a shared Muslim faith couldn't solve the problem of how people with different ethnic and linguistic backgrounds were to live together. 
The peculiar logic of the partition, however, dictated that the Muslim-majority state of Kashmir be part of the new homeland for Indian Muslims; and the civilian and military rulers of Pakistan have started two wars with India, and since 1990 have backed a popular insurgency by Kashmiri Muslims, in an attempt to force India into renouncing, or at the very least reconsidering, its possession of Kashmir. The Indian government has responded by declaring Kashmir an "internal matter" and denouncing Pakistan as a sponsor of "cross-border terrorism."
These accusations are not without basis. Nevertheless, they -- along with India's reputation as the world's most populous democracy -- have helped veil the appalling human rights record of the almost half a million Indian soldiers in Kashmir.
India's more recent intransigence on Kashmir also owes something to the growing closeness of the globalizing Indian elite to the United States. Indian traditions of anticolonialism and nonaligned foreign policy have been transformed with the end of the cold war and the rise of Hindu nationalism. India's rise has been acompanied by Pakistan's fall, as Pakistani help in fighting the Soviet Union and balancing Indian nonalignment has become correspondingly less important to America. This situation has caused anger and frustration among Islamic fundamentalists in Pakistan, the tiny but well organized minority that enjoyed Western patronage during the anti-Soviet war in Afghanistan. For these hard-liners, jihad, and not dialogue, is the way to deal with the arrogant and deceitful Hindus of India and their fair-weather American friends. 
Liberal Pakistanis have tried to hold on to the optimistic view that India, weary of fighting the Kashmir insurgency, will eventually negotiate. Few have been willing to confront the harsher possibility: that the Hindu nationalists may not be much inclined to make concessions on Kashmir to what they perceive as a weak and isolated state. This is the bitter lesson Mr. Musharraf learned in India, where he was reduced to arguing that the Indian side settle for calling Kashmir an "issue" if it isn't happy with the word "dispute." 
Some anxious American goading might bring the two governments together. Their ministries continue to arrange future meetings; the failure in Agra does not seem to have greatly surprised the participants or led to a sense that progress is impossible. India and Pakistan can at least talk about their (as yet undefined) nuclear arsenals. It might be easier to create some trust on this issue, since India and Pakistan have achieved a kind of parity with their weapons of mass destruction. Yet in all other ways the gap between the two countries grows, and this disparity -- in status, resources and self-confidence -- lay behind the failure of the India-Pakistan summit. It is likely to make the Kashmir problem even more intractable.

HEADLINE: Will U.S. Resume Aid? That Depends on Jakarta 

 BODY:
In the months leading up to President Abdurrahman Wahid's removal as president yesterday, American State Department officials and the National Security Council developed a contingency plan that calls for the quick resumption of economic aid to Jakarta if his successor, Megawati Sukarnoputri, begins to carry out economic reforms.
 "Things have been essentially frozen because of the incompetence of the Wahid government," one senior American official said. 
"Now the question is whether Megawati can execute promises that Wahid could not." 
 But the question, American officials say, is complicated by fears that Mrs. Megawati may use force to put down separatist movements. Several American officials have said in recent weeks that they are worried that the new president, to secure her position, will show less restraint when it comes to dealing with challenges to Jakarta's authority.
In recent months, the major International Monetary Fund program in Indonesia, begun during the Asian financial crisis, has essentially been in a state of suspension. Many private investors have fled. One senior I.M.F. official recently said, "We can't operate there efffectively until there is a government we can communicate with."
Speaking yesterday in Rome, where she was traveling with President Bush, Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said, "It is ours to try now to support the decision of the Indonesian people through their properly elected representatives." But she was not specific about what form that support might take. 
She said she would urge the new government "to find peaceful ways to resolve the separatist tentions within Indonesia, to be respectful of human rights in doing so, and to really undertake economic reform in a very aggressive way."

HEADLINE: From a Noxious Landfill to a Nurturing Colony for Artisans 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PENLAND, N.C. 

 BODY:
The lush peaks and valleys of this Blue Ridge community have long been home to some of the nation's finest craft workshops.
 But Penland, about 50 miles northeast of Asheville, N.C., is also home to a much less welcome landmark: the former Mitchell County and Yancey County dump. 
 "It always seemed a scary place to me," said Jon Ellenbogen, a potter who for 30 years hauled his trash up the winding roads to the six-acre landfill before it closed in 1994. "Without fail, whenever I ventured up there, my wheels would get stuck in the muck, forcing me to remain until one of the bulldozers pulled me out." 
Now, Mr. Ellenbogen and other artisans look forward to going to the old landfill site. In fact, they hope tour groups will visit.
Since May, the noxious fumes that once befouled the landfill have been creating power and incubating the careers of a small colony of artists in energy-intensive fields. The power project uses methane gas, a flammable pollutant and byproduct of decomposing trash, to fuel furnaces for glass blowers and metal workers, and potters' kilns.
Mr. Ellenbogen, board president of the nonprofit project, called EnergyXchange, estimated that the artists would save $1 million in energy costs during the 12 to 20 years the gas is expected to last.
John Geci, a glass blower at the site and a former student at the Penland School of Crafts, said he was grateful for that.
"Even though my work had begun selling," Mr. Geci said, "there was no way I could afford the $1,000 per month it would have cost just to run the furnace."
The artists, two glass blowers and three potters, will pay $200 to $350 a month during their three-year fellowships to work in two Quonset huts on a six-acre site on top of the old landfill, which has one of the best views in the area. A third building will be used as a gallery and visitors' center, and another will be used for offices and business classes that will be offered free to the artists.
"My perception of what it takes to be a successful artist has changed dramatically in the last five years," Mr. Geci said. "Initially, I thought all that was required was the ability to make nice forms. Now, I recognize the business skills I'm going to need to survive, and I'm glad it's part of the program."
In a greenhouse, heated by methane, seedlings of native plants like rhododendrons and azaleas are grown for sale to local farmers.
The project began when a Yancey County official read about a landfill recovery plan in Florida, said Terry Woodruff, the site's project manager and an employee of the Blue Ridge Resource Conservation and Development Council. Officials contacted the development council, an arm of the federal Agriculture Department, which set up EnergyXchange with Mayland Community College and HandMade in America, a nonprofit organization that fosters economic development with crafts. Organizers received several grants to start the project but are now trying to make it self-supporting with money from plant sales.
In addition to nurturing artists and the local economy, the project helps the environment, Mr. Woodruff said.
"If the gas weren't captured," he said, "an estimated 7,500 tons of methane gas would be released into the atmosphere over the next 10 years here and on a neighboring landfill in Avery County." The greenhouse gases captured by the project are "the equivalent of removing 21,002 cars from North Carolina roads," he said. "That's a pretty substantial figure."
More projects are planned, said Becky Anderson, executive director of HandMade in America.
"Once the buildings are finished, we'll be planting a heritage craft garden with plants that can be used for papermaking, basketry, dye and broom-making," Ms. Anderson said. "Ours is in large part a creative economy in Western North Carolina, which is why it's so important to show people just how creative we can get in enhancing our own economic situation in an environmentally friendly manner."
Mr. Ellenbogen, too, said he hoped EnergyXchange could be a model.
"There are some 900 small landfills around the nation like ours," he said. "We're the perfect example of how individual talents can be pooled for the greater good."

(Photographs by Robert Padgett for The New York Times) Map of North Carolina highlighting Penland: Until 1994, a six-acre county landfill sat in Penland, N.C.

HEADLINE: American Express Earnings Tumble, as Warned 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its profit fell in the second quarter, even without its $826 million loss on high-yield bonds, as companies tightened travel and entertainment spending.
 The company, which said last week that per-share earnings fell 76 percent from a year earlier, reported net income of $178 million, or 13 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, compared with $740 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 53 cents a share before last week's announcement. 
 The company also said last week that it would eliminate 4,000 to 5,000 jobs, or about 5 percent of its work force, to reduce expenses. The cuts, coming in the company's technologies group, corporate travel business, human resources and corporate lending operations, will require $310 million to $370 million in the third quarter to cover severance pay and related expenses.
"Business is lousy right now, there's no polite way of putting it," Charles White, president of the investment firm Avatar Associates, said before the earnings report. Avatar, which manages about $2.75 billion in assets, sold its American Express shares about six months ago on concern about the company's high-yield bond losses and a slowdown in consumer spending.
Shares of American Express rose 15 cents, to $38.13.
American Express, which issues credit cards and sells mutual funds, insurance, and financial plans, said weakness in the economy and financial markets cut into fees in both areas.
The company said net income would have been $714 million, or 53 cents a share, excluding the money it lost in investments in high-yield securities, also known as junk bonds, for a third consecutive quarter.
Net revenue fell 12 percent from a year earlier, to $4.91 billion.
Profit at the company's card and travel unit rose 3 percent, to $519 million. American Express Financial Advisors reported a loss of $307 million, in contrast to earnings of $275 million.

HEADLINE: Mississippi's Teacher Salaries 

 BODY:
For many years Mississippi has lagged far behind other states in teacher pay, even in the Southeast, making it difficult to hire and keep teachers. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove has been working since he took office last year for a big pay raise for teachers to make it easier to recruit them.
 Mr. Musgrove had worried about opposition from budget-conscious state legislators. But when lawmakers began considering the consequences of losing prospective teachers, they approved a $337.9 million bill that will increase average pay by more than 30 percent over the next five years. Initially the bill required the economy to grow by 5 percent annually before the raises could be granted. But yesterday the legislature voted in a special session to remove this "trigger." That was a smart move. A new report disclosing that 465 teacher positions in Mississippi remain vacant less than a month before the opening of school dramatizes the need to move forward on teacher recruitment. Figures from the governor's office indicate that under the bill the average salary will rise from $31,892 now to $41,445 by 2005, slightly above the projected 2005 Southeastern average salary of $41,199. 
 What is being done in Mississippi could also be done elsewhere. Teachers in New York City are paid about 20 percent less than those in the suburbs, an issue now at the center of salary negotiations between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the teachers' union. The mayor has offered raises of 8 percent over the next two years, in line with other city workers. But that is still not enough to entice the best teachers to come to the city and stay.
Negotiators have also been discussing other options -- longer hours for more pay, for example, as well as merit pay determined by the schools. While those are useful ideas, the city needs to move faster to establish a more attractive pay scale and better working conditions. 
New York's school problems are more complicated than Mississippi's. But with fewer resources and a smaller economy, Mississippi has developed the kind of attractive employment package that still eludes New York.

HEADLINE: A City Takes a Breath After the Dot-Com Crash; 
San Francisco's Economy Is Slowing

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 

 BODY:
In the two-room flat above the Infusion Bar and Restaurant near Second and Bryant Streets -- a most coveted corner during the dot-com boom -- an Internet start-up came, spent handsomely and closed up shop. Its change of fortune, and that of hundreds of other Internet companies here, was so sudden that perhaps even the new tenant would not have been able to foresee the downfall.
 The new tenant is Jade Miller, a psychic, who might have found the rents prohibitive six months ago, if there had even been a vacancy. But now this neighborhood, called Multimedia Gulch, has cooled considerably, and the clairvoyant's home office looks out onto vacant office buildings, abandoned by retreating start-ups. 
 "We've gone from dot-coms to palm readers," lamented Steve Schefsky, who owns the property and who charges Ms. Miller around $2,500 a month for rent, about $1,000 less than the departed Internet company. 
The summer of 2001 will be remembered here as the season San Francisco returned to normal, or at least its own version of normality. The change has come after three years in which billions of dollars in venture capital showered on the area -- luring tens of thousands of young workers, paying their salaries, driving up rents, supporting housing and commercial developments and other businesses, like new restaurants where stock-option beneficiaries could wash down scallop dumplings with an Absolut martini.
In the South of Market neighborhood most heavily populated by dot-com businesses, the change has been more dramatic, with commercial vacancies rising to 20 percent, from a record low of 0.6 percent only 18 months ago. In the rest of the city, "normal" means only that rents, commercial and residential, are tapering off -- remaining some of the nation's highest -- but at least apartments are available. Restaurants are cutting prices, and some are closing. At the same time, residents say the city is more habitable: parking has become easier and traffic thinner. In short, this is a city that has slowed -- to "fast" from "blur."
"People are selling computers; they are selling furniture; they are moving out of the area -- which is sad," Craig Newmark, founder of a widely used online classified site, Craig's List, said. "But it does mean that the Bay Area is returning to something healthier."
The average two-bedroom apartment in San Francisco still goes for $2,452, but that is down from $2,790 in December, according to Rent Tech, a San Francisco rental agency. The agency, which has 2,500 apartment listings, up from fewer than 1,000 last year at this time, puts the vacancy rate around 5 percent, up from less than 1 percent last year.
Commercial vacancy rates have risen to 10 percent, including space available for sublet; in all, there are five million square feet of space and a million square feet of demand, said Jeff Congdon, executive director of the San Francisco office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate company. The office-space market here "reminds me of the Road Runner cartoon where the Coyote runs into the wall," Mr. Congdon said.
But he argued that the economy remained in good shape, just not superheated, with the dot-com downturn providing a cool breeze that Mr. Congdon said he welcomed. "It's expensive to live here, and it was getting scary for a while," he said. "We were losing people to Arizona, Utah and other markets."
Others worry, though, that circumstances here could deteriorate a lot further. Not only are there a number of technology companies on their last legs that may still close shop, the effects are still rippling across the local economy to many other businesses that expanded to accommodate the boom. And now, the city appears to be losing a few workers formerly in the employ of dot-coms. Reflecting the change in fortunes, Craig's List on a recent day had 4,453 household, furniture and other items for sale, triple the number last Labor Day; 3,080 apartments, a sixfold increase; and 2,545 rooms for rent, up from 771. 
One room listing belongs to Courtney Vaughn, whose life is being drizzled on by the economic downturn in several ways.
Ms. Vaughn, 26, recently lost a roommate, who decided to attend graduate school rather than brave the cooled job market. Ms. Vaughn figured she could sublet the room for $800, but she figured wrong.
"A year ago, it would have been the deal of the century," she said, but she learned otherwise within five hours. "I listed the apartment at 9 a.m., but by 2 p.m., it was already on the second page -- that means at least 100 people had listed after me."
Ms. Vaughn, who has not yet rented the room, is also seeing the impact at the restaurant Azie, where she is a spokeswoman. Azie is a high-end Asian-fusion restaurant founded in December 1999 at the height of the boom. "When it was good, we could see the same people every other week -- especially the dot-commers," she said. "They'd come even for lunch a couple of times a week. Now we're not even open for lunch. And we see repeat customers every month or so."
Recently, the restaurant dropped all of its prices 10 to 20 percent and got rid of its signature $60 tasting menu. The butter-roasted lobster is now $27, down from $33; the salad of young greens is $7, down from $9.
"Everyone I talked to is seeing a 10 to 15 percent drop-off," said Jeffrey L. Freburg, executive chef at Kuleto's, a popular Italian restaurant in Union Square. Mr. Freburg said his June revenue was around $670,000, down nearly $200,000 from June of last year, and part of the reason the restaurant was cutting staff. Similarly, at Infusion Restaurant, the contemporary American restaurant below the home office of Ms. Miller, the clairvoyant, patronage is down 25 percent since the year began, forcing the restaurant to cut its staff to 15, from 24, Rob Robinson, the owner, said.
Meanwhile, at Azie, which is about five blocks away, Ms. Vaughn can see another impact from the downturn firsthand. Across the street is a new residential development -- the Yerba Buena Lofts -- scheduled to open in several weeks at prices ranging from $400,000 to $800,000. Alan P. Mark, who handles marketing for the developer, said those prices were 5 to 10 percent lower than the company expected to reap a year ago. He said the company still hoped to sell all the units by the end of 2002.
The idea that San Francisco's economy is slowing is not to suggest the city has come to a standstill. The unemployment rate for the metropolitan area during June was 3.7 percent, compared with the national average of 4.5 percent. But that was up from 3.1 percent in May and 2.4 percent a year ago.
The overall number of jobs is actually up from the last year, to 1,114,700 from 1,096,100, but that has not been enough to keep pace with a growing population looking for work.
And not everyone is troubled by the shake-out. Some residents and businesses report the fall in demand has enabled them to negotiate lower rents, telling their landlords the market will no longer bear the returns of a year ago.
Diane Putnam, a longtime cab driver, said the city was less tense. She gets fewer fares -- 25 percent fewer some days -- but airport and freeway traffic is lighter, and her neighborhood is more livable. "I can find parking on the street now," said Ms. Putnam, with no small degree of enthusiasm. "Sometimes I think it's because there are a lot fewer sport utility vehicles taking up a space and a half."
Webmergers.com, an Internet site that matches buyers and sellers of start-ups, reports that 330 dot-com companies have closed this year across the country, already more than the 220 that shut down in all of 2000. Tim Miller, president of Webmergers.com, said that of those that have died, San Francisco accounted for around 31 percent. 
In the Silicon Valley vernacular, Mr. Miller said the shakeout was complete for "B2C" companies, the so-called business-to-consumer concerns that sold goods and services online; and he said the shakeout was just beginning for "B2B" companies -- business-to-business concerns. 
"The end of the B2C shakeout is overlapping with the beginning of the B2B shakeout," Mr. Miller said. He remained hopeful that the bottom of the downturn was getting close. The "death, misery and destruction," he said, "appears to be plateauing."
In the South of Market area, though, dot-coms continue to give way to other types of businesses, including a law firm and the Tarot-card-reading Ms. Miller.
"It's a good spot," said Ms. Miller, who charges $10 a reading from her second bedroom. "But I wish it was a little busier."

HEADLINE: Bush Ponders Aid for Only Domestic Supplier of Reactor Fuel 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23 

 BODY:
With Soviet-era nuclear weapons now providing more than half the uranium that powers American nuclear power plants, the Bush administration is weighing whether to provide support for the only American company that enriches uranium for reactor fuel.
 The under secretary of energy, Robert G. Card, told Congress last week that the administration was evaluating whether it was "economically feasible or necessary" to produce fuel domestically for nuclear reactors, or whether the country could reliably import uranium from Russia and elsewhere. Another possibility is that other American companies will enter the business. 
 The only domestic company that carries out a crucial processing step that results in enriched uranium, the United States Enrichment Corporation, is plagued by high costs at its 49-year-old factory, and competition from Russia and Western Europe. The administration is facing a decision on whether it should subsidize development of new technology to ensure a domestic supply of the fuel. 
The nuclear power industry, which supplies about 20 percent of the nation's electricity, had used self-sufficiency in uranium fuel as a major selling point for years.
The existence of a healthy domestic uranium industry was a premise of the 1993 agreement to buy highly enriched uranium from Russia for use in American power plants, and of a law that privatized the government's uranium processing plants. That law requires the president to certify annually that the domestic industry is "viable."
But the United States Enrichment Corporation has closed one of its two plants and is threatened by rising prices for electricity, flat demand for its services and competition from more efficient plants in Europe.
"We've already lost self-sufficiency," said Representative Ted Strickland, Democrat of Ohio, whose district includes the plant that was closed by the company. "We're in danger of losing the capacity even to maintain a domestic industry."
Mr. Strickland is seeking federal money to develop new enrichment technology, but industry experts say the price may be too high.
John R. Longenecker, a consultant and a former deputy assistant secretary of energy, offered a dim view of the company's future. "They're stuck with the highest cost of production," he said, "the oldest production capacity and no proven advanced technology, even if they could borrow the money to build it." 
The United States has spent $7 billion on two advanced technologies that were deemed impractical. Company officials say they are exploring another advanced system.
Other experts suggest that the Bush energy plan, and public statements by Vice President Dick Cheney supporting construction of new reactors, will ring hollow if the fuel is imported. The domestic mining industry has been withering away for years, largely because of lower-cost producers in Canada, Australia and elsewhere, but the importance of mining has waned as prices of uranium ore have declined.
What is at stake is a processing step called enrichment. The two plants sold by the government in 1998 were built to accept uranium with the two most common forms, uranium-238 and uranium-235, and sort them to raise the proportion of uranium-235, which is most useful in nuclear reactors and bombs. The technology used at both plants, gaseous diffusion, was developed during World War II, to make the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. Newer systems developed in Europe and the former Soviet Union are cheaper to operate; some use only one-fifth as much electricity. 
One reason the market for enrichment is depressed is that the United States agreed in 1993 to buy highly enriched uranium from Russia, with a uranium-235 content of more than 90 percent, to be blended down to the 5 percent level used by nuclear reactors. The idea was to take weapons material out of circulation and give the Russian nuclear program hard currency to keep Russian scientists and the material itself out of the hands of other countries. 
The company said that by the end of March it had received the equivalent of more than 4,500 warheads in the form of uranium for power plants. 
But because of commercial disputes, Russia has interrupted shipments four times. Charles Yulish, a company spokesman, said he believed that Russia would be a stable supplier in coming years because the company's payments, about $500 million a year, were "a very big factor in Russian revenues." A long-term contract is awaiting approval by the White House, Mr. Yulish said.

HEADLINE: Household Announces Changes in Lending Practices 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Three days before a Senate committee is scheduled to hold hearings on predatory lending, Household International, one of the nation's largest consumer lenders, announced several changes it would make to practices that largely affect the lower-income families that are its main customers.
 Household, which operates the Household Finance and Beneficial lending operations, said it would reduce interest rates paid by some borrowers, eliminate some penalties for paying off loans early and lend as much as $10 million to people facing imminent foreclosure of their homes. The announcement came two weeks after Household said it would stop selling a type of loan insurance that consumer advocates have charged is little more than a tool for stripping the equity out of borrowers' homes. 
 Citigroup, the nation's largest consumer lender, said in late June that it would stop selling the same product, single-premium credit insurance. Last week, another big finance company, the American General Corporation, said it had also decided to drop the product, which requires a borrower to pay in advance for several years of insurance that would pay off the loan in the event of the borrower's death or disability. 
Household has been the prime target of criticism by some housing advocacy groups, including the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn. But company officials said the impending changes were unrelated to any pressure from those groups or Congress.
"It's not tied to hearings or activism or anything else in particular," said Craig Streem, a spokesman for Household, which is based in Prospect Heights, Ill. "We've been working on these for quite some time. So, it really is a coincidence."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has scheduled hearings for July 26 and 27 on the issue. Among those set to testify are four people identified as victims of predatory lending, including a Household customer. Other testimony will come from community activists and representatives of banking industry groups, but no representatives of Household, Citigroup or American General, said a spokesman for Senator Sarbanes.
Household said the package of changes it planned would cost the company $35 million, but Mr. Streem said the company did not expect any material effect on its earnings. He said the company planned to stop penalizing borrowers for paying off loans early after the third year. It also planned to increase the discount it gave after the first two years to borrowers who make timely payments.
In a new twist, Household said it would try to rescue people who were on the verge of losing their homes to other lenders that had engaged in predatory practices.
Maude Hurd, national president of Acorn, said the changes would not satisfy the company's critics. "While Household proposes a small amount of money for loans to rescue the victims of predatory loans, they do nothing to help the thousands of victims of their own practices," she said in a statement.
Mr. Streem said Household also planned to start offering loans with lower interest rates -- what he called a "primelike rate" -- to more creditworthy customers. But he said the company had no plans to reduce much higher "subprime" rates charged to borrowers with weaker credit ratings, a change that Acorn representatives have demanded.
"Price controls have never worked," Mr. Streem said. If Household cannot earn what it considers an appropriate return for lending in poor neighborhoods, he said, "we will not be funding loans in those neighborhoods."

HEADLINE: 1, 2, 3: Connecticut, New York And New Jersey Lead in Taxes 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Connecticut, New York and New Jersey rank first, second and third among the 50 states in state and local taxes, and New York is the runaway leader in local taxes, a new Census Bureau study shows.
 Connecticut residents and businesses paid $4,425 per capita in state and local taxes during the state's 1998 fiscal year, followed closely by New York at $4,318. New Jersey was a distant third, at $3,698. In New York and Connecticut, the total bill was more than 50 percent above the national average of $2,863, according to the study, released last week. 
 When the tax burden is figured in proportion to personal incomes -- which many economists consider a better basis for comparison than sheer dollars -- New York and its neighbors were closer to the norm in other parts of the country.
Nationally, state and local taxes totaled 11.2 percent of Americans' personal income. New York ranked second by that measure, as well, slightly behind Maine, at 14.2 percent of personal incomes, 27 percent above the national average. Connecticut ranked eighth, at 12.5 percent of personal incomes, and New Jersey was near the middle of the pack, at 11.5 percent.
New York was one of just two states, along with New Hampshire, where more was collected in local taxes than in state taxes. Local taxes in New York were $2,329 per capita, more than double the national average of $1,113, and far ahead of the second-place state, New Jersey, at $1,775. New Hampshire ranked third, at $1,565, and Connecticut fourth, at $1,556. 
Connecticut had the highest rate of state taxes, at $2,869 per person, while New York and New Jersey were not among the highest.
The District of Columbia had a much higher tax burden than any state, collecting $5,524 from each resident, an amount equal to 15.1 percent of personal incomes.
New Jersey easily topped the nation in property taxes, often a politically charged issue in that state, at $1,744 per person. Connecticut was third, at $1,533; and New York, where efforts at reducing property taxes came after 1998, was fourth, at $1,345.
New York ranked second in personal income tax, even after cutting its tax rates by 25 percent in the mid-1990's, with an average collection of $1,294 per person, slightly behind Massachusetts. That was nearly twice the national average of $650. Connecticut ranked sixth, at $1,040. New Jersey, which also cut income taxes in the mid-90's, was nearly average, at $693.

HEADLINE: Albany Ponders a Bare-Bones Bill to End Budget Gridlock 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 23 

 BODY:
After nearly four months of stalemate over the state's budget, Assembly and Senate leaders are considering passing a stripped-down version of the governor's spending plan and then resolving major disagreements in a supplementary budget later this year.
 The details of the proposal had yet to be worked out today, but the Democratic Assembly speaker and the Republican Senate majority leader both expressed strong support for the idea, suggesting that it is likely to happen. 
 Passing a bare-bones budget would relieve lawmakers of criticism that they have failed to do their jobs, and buy them time to see how much revenue comes in later this year. The main sticking point in negotiations has been a disagreement between Democrats and Republicans about the jittery economy and future revenues. 
The Democrats who control the Assembly also hope the gambit will entice Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, to become involved in negotiations, since the spending plan would not include many of his new programs and tax cuts. The plan could backfire, however, if the governor accepts the austere budget and spends the surplus it would produce during the coming election year.
"We will have to give him an incentive to engage in conversation," the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said of Mr. Pataki.
The governor was in Washington today for the funeral of Katharine Graham, publisher of The Washington Post, and had little to say about the idea of a scaled-back budget. His chief spokesman, Michael McKeon, said he was waiting to see details.
The governor has been saying for months that he did his job when he presented a $83.6 billion budget in January, and that it was up to the Legislature to act on it. But Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, has refused to negotiate and pass a budget with the Republican-led Senate unless the governor agrees not to veto many of Democrats' initiatives, as he did in 1998.
The scaled-back budget would continue state spending for most departments at last year's levels, including school aid, legislative leaders said. New programs, tax reductions and spending increases, however, would be taken out of the governor's proposed budget and dealt with later, in the supplementary appropriations bill.
Since the Legislature would be passing versions of the governor's own budget bills, state law would prohibit him from vetoing the plan. Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno said they hoped the governor would then enter three-way talks on a supplementary budget that would be a catch-all for all the big-ticket proposals left out of the initial package, among them school aid increases, various transportation projects and a fund to clean up toxic waste sites.
"What we want to do is to provide for the continuity of government and continue to battle for the things we thing are important," Mr. Silver said. 
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said the minimalist budget "creates some stability and some certainty" for school districts, cities and state workers while the Legislature and the governor try to come to an agreement on how much additional money can be spent this year. He pointed out that the revenues for the first three months of this fiscal year were at least $285 million more than the governor had predicted.
"We are also trying to buy some time," Senator Bruno said. "This gives us another month or two while we are debating these open items."
For the 17th consecutive year, the Legislature failed to pass a budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1, despite a 1999 law that docks the lawmakers' pay until a budget is approved.
This year, Mr. Silver has accused Mr. Pataki of grossly underestimating revenues to build up a surplus he could spend during his re-election bid. Mr. Pataki, in turn, has claimed that Mr. Silver has proposed more than $2 billion in irresponsible spending increases in a shaky economy. The Senate Republicans are in the middle, asking to spend an additional $1 billion above the governor's plan.
Mr. Pataki has refused to approve any spending above the 5 percent increase he proposed in January.
The Assembly Democrats have been holding out for more money for education, health care and environmental protections, while their Republican counterparts in the Senate have been advocating, among other things, tax incentives to help the biotechnology industry. The government has been limping along on emergency spending measures.
If the two houses were to pass a stripped-down budget, they would then, under the state's constitution, be free to send the governor their own appropriations bills. They may, for instance, pass a larger school aid package than the governor wants, putting him on the spot to either sign it or veto it. 
Democrats also hope that passing such a spending plan will shift the focus away from the chronic lateness of the budget and cast a spotlight on the issues being debated in the supplementary bill. The idea is not new. Thirty years ago, the Legislature, as a rule, passed the governor's budget in April and then spent much of the rest of the year arguing about a supplemental budget, one that was often chock-full of pork-barrel projects.

HEADLINE: The Federal Reserve Is Now Finding the Limits of Its Power 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23 

 BODY:
Despite six interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year and the possibility of more to come, analysts say that monetary policy is packing less of a punch so far than expected.
 The Fed's rate reductions work to the degree that they ripple through the banking system and the financial markets into the economy. And in this business cycle the three main vehicles through which lower rates affect business, investor and consumer behavior -- the stock, bond and currency markets -- have remained persistently unresponsive to the Fed's actions. 
 All year long, economists have predicted that the central bank's rate cuts would ultimately kick in with something like their usual force, stimulating a recovery from the economic slowdown. But one factor after another has conspired to dampen or delay the effects of the looser monetary policy on the markets and the economy. 
"Monetary policy has a major problem in reviving the economy by itself in the year ahead," said David Hale, chief economist for the Zurich Group. "The best the Fed can do for us is a modest growth rate. To do better, the technology recession has got to end."
Disappointing corporate earnings reports have kept stock prices in check all year, and only seem to have grown worse in recent weeks. Worries that inflation might make a comeback next year, and growing concern that the federal government might not be able to pay off as much of its debt as projected, have kept long-term interest rates in the bond market from falling below where they were when the Fed began cutting rates in January.
Increasing evidence over the last few months that global economic growth has slowed has pushed up the value of the dollar -- the opposite of what normally happens when the Fed is cutting rates -- making life harder for American exporters and multinational companies.
The potency of monetary policy is also being diluted by the nature of the slowdown, economists said.
The most powerful brake on the economy right now is not the portion of the economy sensitive to lower interest rates -- industries like housing, and consumer spending generally -- but the steep decline in spending by businesses on new factories, computers, telecommunications equipment and other capital goods.
Capital spending, especially on technology, is likely to remain weak for some time, even if the Fed continues cutting the short-term interest rates it controls. And until capital spending recovers, economists said, the economy will have trouble returning to the kind of robust growth it enjoyed until late last year.
Both Wall Street and Main Street are often impatient with monetary policy, which has always worked with long and unpredictable lags. It is not unusual for interest rate policy to be impeded by other forces. During the last recession, in the early 1990's, the Fed had to cope with crippling problems among banks and savings and loan institutions.
No one is saying that monetary policy is completely ineffectual. For one thing, economic conditions would probably be a lot worse if the Fed had not been so aggressive in cutting rates this year. And Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress last week that the central bank's rate cuts appeared to have set the stage for economic improvement later in the year. He is scheduled to give further testimony on Tuesday.
Moreover, the economy has other forces working in its favor. The tax cut signed into law last month by President Bush will help as rebate checks begin showing up at most households this summer. Energy prices are falling. Consumers have kept their wallets open.
The consensus among most economists is that the economy should bottom out in the next few months and begin a gradual recovery by the end of the year.
Still, economists said the Fed was clearly getting less bang for the buck than it would hope for with its rate cuts, suggesting that the rebound could be modest and drawn out. 
In the most rapid rate reduction on record, the central bank has cut its benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks by 2.75 percentage points this year, to 3.75 percent. Mr. Greenspan has left open the door to at least one more rate cut. But some analysts say the Fed may have to reduce rates further, and keep them low for longer than investors seem to expect.
Monetary policy, said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, "may need to be far more aggressive than currently anticipated."
Persistent moves by the Fed to ease monetary policy would be expected to push up stock prices, pull down longer-term interest rates in the bond market and reduce the value of the dollar. All those factors would stimulate economic activity.
This year, however, the overall stock market has remained flat to down by most measures. Long-term interest rates have not fallen. Against some currencies, the dollar has actually shot up in value, inhibiting efforts by companies to offset weakness in their sales at home by selling more of their goods abroad.
"Normally when you have this kind of easing, you would get more help from stocks, bonds and the currency," said William C. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs. "In this case, the stock market's gone down, the dollar has appreciated and bond yields are little changed. What it tells you is that it's not reasonable to expect a big lift from monetary policy."
Stock prices typically rise when interest rates are falling. Rising stock prices would help the economy by making consumers feel wealthier and allowing companies to raise money on favorable terms.
But some analysts say it may be hard to reignite stock prices through lower interest rates because investors are concluding that corporate profits will not fully recover soon.
Competitive pressure to hold down or cut prices is immense, they say, and opportunities for improving profit margins by trimming corporate fat or finding efficiencies in technology could be limited in the next few years. 
Cuts in the short-term rates controlled by the Fed typically help pull down the longer-term rates set in the financial markets. In this case, though, longer-term rates had already fallen substantially last year, when the economy was starting to decelerate. They have not fallen further this year.
To some degree, the bond market seems to be looking beyond the next few months and into next year. And given that long-term rates were relatively low going into this year, interest-sensitive industries -- especially housing -- have held up quite well as the rest of the economy has slowed. But since those sectors of the economy never weakened much in the first place, they will not be able to play much of a role in leading a comeback.
"The composition of the current downturn has important implications for the economy's growth prospects in the year ahead," Mr. Hale said. "It is doubtful that monetary easing will give a significant boost to residential investment and durable goods consumption because neither sector has experienced a major downturn."
The sector of the economy that most needs help is manufacturing. At this point in a typical business cycle, the Fed's rate cuts could be expected to have pushed down the value of the American currency by reducing the return on investments made in dollars. 
But with the rest of the world slowing -- and investors nervous about outbreaks of instability in places like Argentina and Turkey -- the dollar has remained a haven even as growth in the United States has ground nearly to a halt. The dollar has appreciated strongly against other currencies, especially the euro, making it harder for American manufacturers to compete in export markets, and reducing profits earned abroad when they are translated back into dollars.
