HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE 

BYLINE:  By Neil Strauss 

 BODY:
Still Wild, Wildly Talkative
 "How long have you got?" asked Reg Presley, the lead singer of the 60's band the Troggs, speaking by telephone from his hotel in Manhattan on Tuesday. His words were ones that every journalist wants to hear at the start of an interview: an artist implying he has all the time in the world to talk. 
 What followed was a nearly two-hour conversation that grappled with the mysteries of life, the universe and religion. And on occasion, the discussion touched the subject of the Troggs. The group formed in 1964 in Andover, England, where Mr. Presley continues to live (he was named Reginald Ball, but decided to adopt a famous rock 'n' roll name to spark rumors of a blood connection to the king). 
Impressed by the band's version of "You Really Got Me," Larry Page, an early manager of the Kinks, took the Troggs under his wing. He gave them a song written by an American, Chip Taylor, and the resulting single, the snarling, suggestive, ocarina-laden "Wild Thing," made it to No. 1 in the United States. 
"They tried to ban 'Wild Thing' in England because it was too sexual," Mr. Presley said. "It's like a nursery rhyme compared to what they get away with today. And I'll tell you what, nursery rhymes are vicious too. You have Humpty Dumpty falling off the wall and smashing to pieces."
Though "Wild Thing" remains the Troggs' best-known song, the band went on to record numerous classics of the era, ranging from rough, crude rock 'n' roll ("I Can't Control Myself," "I Want You") to gentle, beautifully orchestrated ballads ("Any Way That You Want Me" and "Love Is All Around").
The group's hit-making days ended with the decade, though the circulation of an unintentionally hilarious studio argument by the band gave them a new notoriety. With Mr. Presley telling the rest of the band that the music was lacking the requisite "fairy dust" that makes a No. 1 hit, the recording is said to have inspired the movie "Spinal Tap." Though the reputation of the Troggs is ultimately that of British punk precursors, they also have a lasting influence in the realm of treacly pop, thanks to the Scottish boy-band Wet Wet Wet, whose 1994 version of "Love Is All Around" sat at No. 1 on the British pop charts for 15 weeks.
"I'm now in the position where I don't have to ever work again in my life because I made so much money out of 'Love Is All Around,' " Mr. Presley said of the Wet Wet Wet success. "But you still want something to do and something to interest you."
And that is one reason that the Troggs, who never performed in the United States at the peak of their success, have become more regular guests on New York stages in recent years. Tonight, the band is to perform at the Village Underground in Greenwich Village as part of the Cavestomp garage-rock series.
As anyone who searches for Reg Presley's name on the Internet will find out, when the singer discusses doing something to interest him, he doesn't mean just music. In recent years, he has become known as an expert on U.F.O.'s, crop circles and other mysteries. He often appears at such conferences as a speaker and is working on a book, which he plans to call "Wild Things They Don't Tell You."
Much of his conversation involved the articulate elucidation of his current theories. They ranged from thoughts on white-powder gold and the Messianic bloodline of Jesus Christ, based on the writings of Sir Lawrence Gardner and the research of David Hudson, to his own proposal for creating a nonmonetary economy, in which people work for six months a year and then enjoy free time the other six months.
The seed for Mr. Presley's esoteric interests was planted before the Troggs, back when he was a bricklayer. "I never used to swear when I was a builder, believe it or not," Mr. Presley said. "I only started swearing when I got into the rock business."
On a job one day, Mr. Presley and an older worker were told to find an underground water pipe. The other laborer went to a hazel wood tree, chopped out a V-shaped piece of wood and began dowsing for water. Mr. Presley watched, mocking the process, until his colleague pointed to a spot in the ground. Mr. Presley dug and struck the pipe three feet down. 
Three decades later, in 1990, Mr. Presley read about a crop circle that had formed in a field an hour away from his home and decided to see what it looked like. While standing in the middle of the formation, he noticed a man dowsing with metal wires. Mr. Presley asked if he could try. He took the dowsing implements, and as he walked around the crop circle the wires kept crossing and uncrossing. This led him to believe that there was some type of energy in the formation, and he began to wonder where it came from. "If there's one thing I like, it's puzzles," Mr. Presley said. 
And so began a second career for Mr. Presley, who began looking at life anew and trying not to take everything he had been taught about religion, the human race and the universe for granted. "We're fleas living on a dog's back," he said of humans in this world. "And one day that dog is going to rub her back to get the fleas off."

Father Earth
Mr. Presley isn't the only one worried about the earth. So is Mike D. of the Beastie Boys. Soon, music fans will begin to hear about something called the New Power Project, an environmental organization he has founded. Also known as the Save Our Environment Coalition, the project includes the Dave Matthews Band, Alanis Morissette, Jackson Browne, Moby, James Taylor, Trey Anastasio of Phish, the Barenaked Ladies and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. 
The coalition plans to turn the fan bases of each artist into environmental activists and to stage concerts to benefit environmental organizations and spread the word.

HEADLINE: Siemens, Posting 3rd-Quarter Loss, Fires a Unit Chief 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 25 

 BODY:
Siemens, the German electrical engineering company whose products range from light bulbs to nuclear power plants, fired the head of its telephone networks division today and promised drastic cost-cutting after surprising investors with a worse-than-expected loss of $428 million in the third quarter.
 The chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said "there are no taboos" in the plans to scour Siemens divisions for cost reductions beyond the 9,700 layoffs already announced this year. 
 Like other companies, including Ericsson of Sweden and Nokia of Finland, Siemens, which is based in Munich, has been hammered by a slowdown in the formerly booming telecommunications business. 
The company's third-quarter results showed a sharp reversal of that trend, with traditional businesses like power generation, transportation and medical operations posting solid gains, while its mobile phone and phone networks units lost a combined 1.1 billion euros, or about $964.6 million, in the quarter. 
Analysts at the ABN Amro bank warned, however, in an investors' note that the gains in the industrial divisions "are miles away from being able to offset the bleeding in the technology divisions."
With the economies in the United States and Europe slowing, job losses and executive purges have become commonplace. ABB, Europe's leading electrical engineering group; Ericsson, the phone and telecommunications switch maker in Sweden; Reuters, the financial-information company; and Invensys, a factory controls maker in Britain have all announced job cuts recently. Both Invensys and Marconi, Britain's biggest telephone equipment maker, announced the departure of top executives as investors complained about falling share prices and earnings.
Part of the problem lies primarily with telephone companies that incurred vast debts last year acquiring new wireless licenses at a time when the demand for mobile phones seemed unquenchable. No one had apparently foreseen the depth of the economic slowdown in the United States and its rapid effect on European companies.
These days, by contrast, phone companies have pared spending on new networks just as consumers started to postpone replacing their mobile phones with new models.
The gloom that resulted from these developments had already pushed down Siemens shares by 7 percent on Tuesday in anticipation of today's figures. The stock rose $1.91, to $51.31, today as investors looked beyond the bad news and focused on the company's readiness to reduce costs and change its management, analysts said.
Mr. Von Pierer said the cost cuts would include a further 800 million euros at its networks business and 400 million euros more at its mobile phone business, which vies with Ericsson as the world's third-largest maker of telephone handsets after Nokia and Motorola.
Among management changes, Siemens said Roland Koch, the head of its networks unit, would step down and be succeeded by Thomas Ganswindt. The company, which said it lost money at 5 of its 13 divisions in the third quarter, also replaced the senior executives at its industrial services and automation units.
"Our third-quarter results are unsatisfactory," Mr. Von Pierer said. "Over the coming weeks we will define further measures to improve our results," particularly in the networks division, which lost 563 million euros in the quarter before interest, taxes and amortization.
While many analysts had been forecasting a far less radical decline in the quarter, they ascribed its losses primarily to the decline in the technology businesses and the higher-than-expected cost of earlier job reductions. The company said it spent 790 million euros to pare its work force.
In the period last year, Siemens posted a 592 million euro profit.
The figures did not take into account exceptional items, mainly a one-time gain of 3.5 billion euros from the transfer of a stake in Infineon, a chip maker, to the Siemens pension fund, or results from Infineon itself. Taking the pension fund transfer into account, Siemens made a profit of $1.4 billion in the quarter, the company said.
Siemens has a roughly 51 percent stake in Infineon, Europe's second-biggest chip maker. Infineon posted a 371 million euro loss in the same quarter and may also be considering job reductions. That would bring it into line with other companies, like Royal Philips Electronics, a Dutch company that is Europe's biggest electronics manufacturer.

HEADLINE: Meek or Masterly, A Challenger Awaits 

BYLINE:  By LISA SCHEER 

 BODY:
WHEN Kenny Salan isn't playing chess online, there is a good chance he is watching chess online, or checking out an online lecture on the game. "I try to play every day," said Mr. Salan, 22, who studies health fitness management at Midwestern State University in Wichita Falls, Tex. After midnight he logs on to observe games between grandmasters, studying opening gambits and mating patterns. "I watch all of them if I can," he said.
 Mr. Salan, who uses the screen name Artisan Haxan, learned to play chess at age 9 and joined a local chess club four years later. A year ago he played his first game on the Internet. Now he is one of hundreds of thousands around the world who play chess online, an accessible and convenient alternative to the local chess club or the action in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village. 
 Many players are drawn to the chess sites by the prospect of improving their game while making small talk with comparable players around the world. There is even a community of masters and grandmasters who regularly visit the Web to challenge one another before an online audience. Many top-level players offer private lessons online or play casual players for a small fee. 
The decorum usually associated with the game often gives way to the no-holds-barred nature of the Internet. With some players not above mocking their opponents or brazenly flouting the rules, the result may seem like chess as brought to you by the World Wrestling Federation. 
Mr. Salan started his online chess playing at the World Chess Network, a crisply organized site that reports 500,000 visitors monthly. After registering and downloading a small chessboard program, players can scan a roster of potential challengers with screen names like Fat Masta G, Mr. Slurpy and Swimsuit Model, classified by the game length they want (from one minute to a half-hour) and identified by their numerical rating, based on performance online. 
A challenge is announced by the sound of a race car revving, and the game begins with the sound of a bell clang in a prizefight. After the game, the winner hears a wave of gentle applause; the loser hears taps.
Ratings become quite important to some players. My 10-year-old son, Elijah, responds to a drop in his rating like a gambler pumping quarters into a slot machine: he compulsively seeks one-minute games with highly rated players, hoping for a big, quick payout in rating points.
Other players are so ratings-obsessed that they will cheat to boost their numbers. A common method is to crib moves from a desktop chess program, viewed elsewhere on the screen, during a match. Another is to disconnect from the Internet in the middle of a losing game. The World Chess Network recently stiffened its penalties for such behavior, forcing offenders to resume play within three minutes or forfeit the match, and has threatened to expel offenders. 
A code of civility is hard to enforce when players exchange real-time messages. Although most online conversation is fairly friendly, insults are also a staple, even among some highly rated players. "One guy I beat 20 times in a row called me an idiot," said Larry Christiansen, a grandmaster and former United States chess champion who lectures frequently online. 
I have been cursed at in several languages, goaded, flirted with and told by an opponent that my playing "stinks like stinky cheese." In the beginning it bothered me, but now I vent back, calling my challengers crybabies, losers and worse. Several sites have features to offer some protection against gross profanity, either by filtering chat or turning it off completely. You can also send the sore loser to Siberia by putting him or her on your "avoid" or "no play" list.
For stronger players, the Internet Chess Club is worth checking out. Home to the Web's oldest for-profit chess server, the club now claims 26,000 paid subscribers, said the company's president, Daniel Sleator, a professor of computer science at Carnegie Mellon University. He said that about 300 grandmasters and 500 international masters play at the site at no cost. 
For hard-core players like Ulrich Konig, 30, the Internet Chess Club is the place to go to play different chess variants. Mr. Konig, a researcher in the department of economics at the University of Vienna, favors an esoteric form of chess called Shatranj, which is thought to have originated in India in the seventh century. "This game is interesting because you want to know how people played chess before 1500," he said. 
Private lessons with top-level players are available at prices typically ranging from $20 to $100 an hour. My son recently took a one-hour lesson with Tim McGrew, an expert-level player who is an associate professor of philosophy at Western Michigan University. After playing a few quick games to assess Elijah's capabilities, Mr. McGrew introduced a concept called "flight square analysis," a fancy term for checking out the escape options of your opponent's king. 
Later he walked Elijah through the well-known Morphy vs. Allies game played in Paris in 1858, demonstrating with bright red arrows and blue circles how to sacrifice a queen to force a checkmate. Despite some glitches -- the text window was so narrow that Mr. McGrew's comments sometimes whipped past, unread -- the lesson was worthwhile.
One benefit of playing chess online is that it allows the timid to lose, and learn, with minimal humiliation. "Chess is a very private game, in a sense, because a lot of people don't want to be in an open setting when they lose," said Maxim Dlugy, a grandmaster and former president of the United States Chess Federation, which rates players and sanctions tournament chess. "When you play at home and lose a game, it's much easier to start a new one and learn that way because you don't feel that everyone in the world is laughing at you."

In Search of a Game or a Gambit
A sampling of online chess sites where people can play and learn strategy:

WORLD CHESS NETWORK: www.worldchessnetwork.com Users register and then download a small program containing a graphics interface. All the data required to match two challengers is crunched by the site's servers. Players click and drag pieces over a two-dimensional chessboard in timed games. Players receive numerical ratings that rise and fall based on the outcome of each game, with results weighted to reflect the strength of the opposition. Visitors can play eight rated games per day free. An annual subscription fee of $49 or monthly fee of $4.95 buys unlimited rated game play and extras like lectures by experts.

INTERNET CHESS CLUB: www.chessclub.com -- A site for stronger players, although its president, Daniel Sleator, maintains, "Our goal is not to intimidate." The cost is $49 a year ($24.50 for students), and seven-day trial subscriptions are available. The site also offers hundreds of chat channels where members discuss strategy and debate theory. Players can also chat while observing blitz, or speed chess, games between grandmasters. The site, based on the Unix operating system, is more difficult to use than the World Chess Network, but an online tech support staff usually responds to typed queries within minutes.

KASPAROVCHESS: www.kasparovchess.com -- Started up last year, the site allows users to register and play at no charge, or pay $4 a month for features including occasional tutorials by the world champion, Vladimir Kramnik, and the option to participate in blitz chess. The site is backed financially by Garry Kasparov and an Israeli investment group.

U.S. CHESS LIVE: www.uschesslive.org -- The official site of the United States Chess Federation, it is free to federation members. Nonmembers may log in and play free, unrated chess games or check out exhibition games by titled players and weekly lectures by experts. LISA SCHEER

HEADLINE: Need for Summer Jobs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Summer jobs (Economic Scene, July 19) offer many teenagers a first job experience, and give them money for school and other expenses. One should not underestimate the impact of $900 in earnings for impoverished families, and spending that money locally in community stores. 
 In New York City, nearly 50,000 teenagers have worked each year in summer camps, libraries and senior centers. Without them, many organizations would be forced to cut or cancel summer services, which provide supervised activity for children of working parents. 
Without jobs, teenagers would lose work force experience and access to mentors and future employers, and the self-esteem that comes from a paycheck. New York and the nation should work to preserve summer youth employment. 

EMILY MENLO MARKS
Executive Director
United Neighborhood Houses
New York, July 23, 2001

HEADLINE: Deep in the Desert, No Longer Far Out 

BYLINE:  By ALASTAIR GORDON 

 BODY:
IF tie-dye T-shirts and Volkswagen Bugs are back, Paolo Soleri can't be far behind. For those who remember him as a Woodstock-era guru of alternative architecture, Dr. Soleri conjures images of trust-fund hippies trekking to Arizona to cast bronze bells in his foundries or to pour the concrete walls of Arcosanti, his hivelike community 65 miles north of Phoenix.
 For most of his 60-year career, Dr. Soleri, 82, has been perceived as a cult figure on architecture's freaky fringe. But what was once dismissed as counterculture dreams seems to be up for reappraisal. 
 "Until the late 80's most people thought we were just a bunch of odd people out in the desert," Dr. Soleri said during a New York stopover last month. "We have been talking about a 'lean alternative' in this opulent society, and more people seem to be responding." 
In 1970, Dr. Soleri began building Arcosanti, a planned community with observation towers, sweeping concrete vaults and dwellings clustered along the steep basalt cliffs of the Agua Fria River. Dr. Soleri conceived it as a prototype that would show how other cities might minimize energy use and motor transportation while encouraging human interaction. By concentrating inhabitants in a sequence of partly submerged multilevel structures, he sought to preserve the wildness of the surrounding desert landscape. Greenhouses provide gardening space and tap warm air for heating. "Our mission at Arcosanti has been to bring the city up to date, socially and culturally," Dr. Soleri said, "to create an antidote to sprawl."
Thirty-one years after Dr. Soleri founded his desert compound, the rest of the world may finally be coming around to his environmental design and pedestrian-oriented planning -- even as his career winds down. "Soleri has always been there and people are just now rediscovering him," said Jeffrey Cook, a professor of architecture at Arizona State University. "He was part of a flock of utopian dreamers who designed megastructure cities in the 1960's, but he had more of a social and ecological agenda than the others. His arguments continue to hold water."
The Soleri revival is marked by the publication of four new books, including an English edition of a monograph, "Soleri: Architecture as a Human Ecology" (Monicelli Press). Last year, he was presented the Golden Lion Award by the Venice Biennale for a lifetime of achievement. "They rediscovered me 40 years too late," Dr. Soleri said, smiling. 
At a time when signature architects are attended by publicists, Dr. Soleri plays the role of enigmatic elder statesman, a desert Obi-Wan Kenobie who defies easy categorization. He is at once an architect, artist, builder, teacher, writer and philosopher. He is incapable of the snappy sound bites, speaking instead in elliptical bursts peppered with words like vegativity, vectoriality and stardust. Thoughts trail off, sentences double back. In recent years, urban planners have thought small, tending toward the diminutive paste-and-patch approach. Now efforts to take on big problems like urban sprawl and energy shortages are regaining credibility. 
Dr. Soleri has never been afraid of thinking big. Really big. In fact, he seems to operate on his own extraterrestrial scale. During the 60's and early 70's, he created a series of renderings for what he called arcologies, fantastical combinations of architecture and ecology. They were vast, vaguely biomorphic cities with spheres and towers built on the ocean or asteroids. "Unless we moderate, unless we reinvent the American dream, then it's not going to be a dream," he said. "It's going to be doomsday."
For all their sci-fi brilliance, Dr. Soleri's plans suggest to some an authoritarian hand, a drawback that may have contributed to his period of disfavor. "He still belongs to the tradition where everything gets designed from the micro to the macro and I think that's where people feel he may be a bit out of touch," said Moshe Safdie, the Canadian architect who designed Habitat '67, one of the icons of 60's architecture. "People today demand to determine their own micro environments and they react when life appears to be designed for them." 
Autocratic as they may be, Dr. Soleri's drawings showed a generation of younger architects an alternative to corporate modernism. Will Bruder, a Phoenix-based architect whose new work includes the Burton Barr Central Library in Phoenix, apprenticed with Dr. Soleri in 1967. "Paolo's mind was always going out into the cosmos," Mr. Bruder said. "I learned how much you can do with very little, the potential of simplicity and the ability to make unbelievable things from modest means, to dream huge dreams." 
While Dr. Soleri's plan for high-density communities may be best suited to crowded third world countries, Mr. Bruder feels strongly that Dr. Soleri's lessons can work here, as well. "My own work is driven by discovering the extraordinary in the ordinary, and this comes from Paolo, who knows how to take ordinary things to another dimension," Mr. Bruder said. "My design for the Burton Barr Phoenix Central Library would not exist without Paolo's precedent -- organic forms tied to a rigid understanding of structure."
Dr. Soleri's native Italy was the first to see his work in a fresh light. One of the country's leading architecture schools at the Universita Degli Studi Roma, in Rome, held a conference this May devoted to his legacy. "A thousand people showed up when we only had room for a few hundred," said Sandro Bignozzi, an urban planner who organized the event. "Soleri is so important to Italians now. It is a time to look to his ideas again because we are overwhelmed with environmental problems here." 
The surge of interest among his countrymen has brought Dr. Soleri full circle. He studied architecture in Turin. After getting his Ph.D. in 1946, he spent a year and a half working for Frank Lloyd Wright at Taliesin West in Arizona, and at Taliesin East in Wisconsin. His design for a sweeping bridge called the Beast was exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1948. (The bridge brought more attention to Dr. Soleri than to Mr. Wright, contributing to a rift that led to Dr. Soleri's departure.) One of his earliest projects was the 1949 Dome House in Cave Creek, Ariz., made from cast concrete and natural stone with a sunken living area and a glass dome overlooking the desert. Dr. Soleri would later marry the client's daughter Colly Woods.
On their honeymoon in 1950, he was hired to build a ceramics factory (now being restored) in the Italian hillside town of Vietri sul Mare. He then returned to Arizona and in the 1960's started his own version of Taliesen, a compound on the outskirts of Scottsdale called Cosanti, with rustic rock walls and cast-concrete vaults integrated into the desert landscape. To raise money, he cast bronze wind bells that were sold at museum stores.
With his lean good looks and Italian charm, Dr. Soleri had no trouble attracting volunteers. Lucinda Ziesing, now a film producer in Camden, Me., arrived at Cosanti in the summer of 1969, at 19, after driving across the country. "I woke up listening to the bells ringing, and I met Soleri and we started to talk," she said. "Here was a man who appeared to be extremely focused, a man with a vision. He had no shirt on and he was very tan and he was busy sculpting something. He obviously had a big vision but then there were all these little bells. He was into the big and the small at the same time."
While Cosanti's poured concrete arches rose from the desert, Dr. Soleri filled sketchbooks with sinewy lines, drawn like human musculature, into arcologies, his imaginary cities. By the late-1960's, Dr. Soleri's Cosanti, on only five acres, was too small for the ambitions sketched in his notebooks, and he purchased 860 acres of desert north of Phoenix, near Cordes Junction. There, in 1970, he began building Arcosanti. For a rotating band of loyal followers, it was an irresistible mission. "There was Soleri out in the middle of the desert looking back at the world," said Harry Fischman, a 52-year-old architect of Sag Harbor, N.Y., who visited as a student in the 1970's. "He took the materials and forms of the desert and transformed them into shelter and poetry."
Arcosanti has been under construction continuously since 1970; roughly $10 million later, it's only 3 percent completed, Dr. Soleri said. Today, the semifinished, semiruined spaces of Arcosanti resemble a sketch from Dr. Soleri's notebooks, complete with erasures and rough edges. It's easy to see the influence of Frank Lloyd Wright and Buckminster Fuller, plus vestiges of Romanesque architecture and Maya temples. Butresses bulge like giant insect wings. The inner curves of a large vault have been washed in bright colors, as if tie-dyed. This part of Arcosanti was built in its heyday, in a delirious burst of energy from 1970 to 1975, when 350 paying volunteers were working in five-week stints.
"There is something bittersweet about Soleri and the building of Arcosanti," Mr. Bruder said. "The meeting of resources and ideas never fully gelled. Arcosanti became labeled by its roots in the late 1960's and never fully grew to maturity." 
Thirty-one years after Dr. Soleri began his desert experiments, the surrounding desert is all but gone. Cosanti (now a headquarters for his nonprofit foundation) is engulfed by suburban-style development, and sprawl has begun to encroach on Arcosanti. "I feel a bit of sadness," Dr. Soleri said. "The market demands the high consumerism of suburbia. We at Arcosanti may be economically powerless, but we have been trying to develop an alternative."
Undaunted, Dr. Soleri continues to expand Arcosanti, which has 60 permanent residents. The East Crescent section, containing stores and residences, is under construction. A residential wing will be built in the coming year, in part to house students from Rome. .
Dr. Soleri himself seems only to thrive with age. While his energy has leveled off, he still bikes and swims every day. He also continues to write and think on a grand scale, and he remains enigmatic to the end. 
Does he have plans for more city schemes in the near future? "Yes," he said, "something like Paradise, or Nirvana."
Will those be built here on planet Earth or in outer space? "I'm not telling," he replied.

HEADLINE: Sales and Rising Prices Rouse Housing Market 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25 

 BODY:
Existing homes sold at a faster pace than expected in June, an industry report showed today, suggesting that housing will help buoy the economy. Home prices surged to a record.
 Resales fell 0.6 percent last month, to an annual pace of 5.33 million houses from a 5.36 million rate in May, the National Association of Realtors said. Analysts had expected sales to fall 1.3 percent, to an annual pace of 5.30 million. 
 Even with the decline, though, June was the fifth-best month on record, and the pace is faster than the record 5.2 million homes sold in 1999.
"This year and last year have been about the same, and last year was a booming year," said Carolyn Shamis, the president of Carsha Inc., a real estate company in Dallas that sells homes priced from $400,000 to $5 million. "I think it's going to get stronger."
Demand for more expensive houses drove up the median price of a home to a record $152,600 last month from $145,000 in May. The price was 8.8 percent higher than in June 2000, the biggest annual increase since 1991.
Previously owned homes account for 85 percent of all houses sold and are an important predictor of consumer demand. Home purchases typically lead to spending on furniture, appliances and decorations. Rising home values have also provided a source of cash for consumers who can refinance mortgages or take out home-equity loans.
By region, sales fell 4.2 percent in the Midwest, to a 1.14-million-unit pace; 2.3 percent in the South, to a 2.11 million pace; and 1.6 percent in the Northeast, to 630,000 units at an annual pace. Sales rose 6.6 percent in the West, to a 1.46-million-unit pace.
The supply of homes available for sale increased to 3.8 months' worth in June, the most in a year, from 3.4 months' worth in May. The supply is still lower than the 4.5 months average in 1999, the record year for sales.
The average rate on a 30-year mortgage dropped last week to 7.08 percent, the lowest since April. A year ago, the rate was 8.21 percent.

HEADLINE: Social Security's Stable Benefit 

BYLINE:  By Hugh Price and Julian Bond; Hugh Price is president of the National Urban League. Julian Bond is chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
A recent report by the Bush administration's commission to study Social Security claims that African-Americans get a bad deal from the Social Security program. The report says they would do better if the system included private individual investment accounts. But there are good reasons to doubt whether privatization would be as positive as proponents claim. 
 Advocates of privatization erroneously claim that because African-Americans have higher mortality rates than white Americans, they do not benefit as much from the Social Security system. 
 It is true that African-American men have a shorter average life expectancy than whites, but this is because they are more likely to die at dramatically younger ages. When black and white men reach 65, the gap in their life expectancy has narrowed to only about two years. And because African-Americans are more likely than whites to retire earlier, at 62, the actual difference in the number of years that blacks and whites receive Social Security benefits is less than two years -- contrary to what privatizers claim.
Moreover, the commission's report glides over the fact that African-American families are more likely to be dependent on Social Security benefits. In addition to providing retirement income, Social Security acts like life and disability insurance. It pays benefits in the case of disability of the contributor; or, in the case of death, it pays benefits to surviving spouses and children.
This guaranteed assistance is important in the African-American community. African-Americans are only 12 percent of the population, but they make up 17 percent of Americans receiving Social Security disability benefits and 22 percent of all children receiving survivor benefits. Because privatization proposals would divert large amounts of money from the current system, it's unclear just how these survivor and disability benefits would continue to be financed.
How do privatization proposals deal with the particular needs of the African-American community? Not very well.
First, the commission argues that African-Americans could bequeath their private accounts to surviving relatives in the event of an untimely death. But a recent study by the National Urban League found that a typical black man dying in his 30's would only have enough in his private account to cover less than 2 percent of the survivor's benefits under current law. 
Second, privatization proposals don't do much to help low-income earners, and African-Americans make up a disproportionate number of low-income earners. Social Security benefits are progressive -- that is, low-income people receive a larger percentage of benefits, relative to their earnings, than higher-income individuals do. That progressivity, combined with a cost-of-living adjustment that increases benefits every year, strengthens the safety net for the most economically disadvantaged.
The proposal to privatize would weaken the progressivity of the system. Low-income individuals would accrue interest (assuming a healthy stock market) only on their contributions, which would be based on their much lower wages. Even if low-income African-Americans earned the same rate of return on their accounts as high-income earners, they would have very different portfolios because of the disparate nature of their salaries.
Essentially, privatization changes Social Security from a program of social insurance to one focused on personal gain. Helping individuals accumulate wealth is not inherently bad policy, but Social Security's guaranteed benefits should not be sacrificed.
We must find another way to strengthen and enhance Social Security, ensuring that it remains a vital source of guaranteed support for generations of Americans.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Lloyd Miller)

HEADLINE: Six Are Dead, Many Missing, As Boat Sinks Off Bahamas 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 25 

 BODY:
A sailboat packed with perhaps as many as 156 Haitians trying to get to the United States ran aground on the reefs surrounding Great Inagua Island in the Bahamas during the past week, leaving six dead and possibly dozens more missing, American and Bahamian authorities said today.
 Helicopters and boats combed the waters off Great Inagua, the southernmost island of the Bahamas, on Tuesday looking for signs of life and evacuating 69 survivors from the island. Based on interviews with survivors, the authorities could be looking for as many as 81 others. 
 "The information is pretty scant right now," said Capt. Raymond Farquharson, a senior commander with the Royal Bahamas Defense Force. "We understand quite a number came on that craft, more than 69 in any event."
The authorities are unsure when the boat left Haiti, which is about 75 miles south of Great Inagua, but the survivors told rescuers that the vessel ran aground and sank on the second day of the journey. They said they had been on Great Inagua for up to a week after swimming to the island's northern coast and making their way to a town on the other side.
"They were in pretty bad shape suffering from malnutrition, lack of water and exposure," said Brian Bachman, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Nassau. "We don't have many details on what happened, other than it was a boat with migrants headed to the United States that went off course and ran aground."
Captain Farquharson said he doubted that the migrants had been on the island for more than a few days. He said that the Bahamian government was first alerted Tuesday by residents of Great Inagua and that a rescue operation was mounted with the help of a helicopter from the United States Coast Guard.
He said the survivors would be taken to Nassau and held in detention facilities until they could be returned to Haiti.
The Bahamas continues to be a popular destination and way station for illegal Haitian migrants fleeing economic hardship and political instability. Some 60,000 Haitians are believed to be living illegally in the Bahamas, where many of them work in menial jobs while trying to save money to travel to the United States.
Last year, when a boat carrying more than 250 Haitians was shipwrecked in the Bahamas, Haitian officials said they would take steps to discourage illegal migration. 
"It has gotten heavier over the last two years," Mr. Bachman said. "We have documented an increase. There is a sizable portion who stay in the Bahamas. Some stay temporarily until they find other means to get to the United States. It is a problem the Bahamians are very concerned about."

HEADLINE: Free Trade With Vietnam 

 BODY:
During Colin Powell's visit to Vietnam this week, the secretary of state found a nation whose economy has taken more strides toward the future than has its cumbersome, authoritarian government. Vietnam's people are dynamic and optimistic. Roughly 60 percent are younger than 30 years old, the product of half a century of war with France, the United States and China. Though their politically rigid government has yet to conquer corruption and poverty, it has encouraged entrepreneurial activity. Both countries can benefit from a closer relationship. The free trade agreement awaiting approval by Congress can help build those ties. 
 Outside capital began to flood into Vietnam after the country gave itself a new, economically progressive Constitution in 1992. The Vietnamese economy grew by nearly 9 percent a year in the mid-1990's, beating out some of the established Asian tigers. Per capita income grew by 50 percent between 1994 and 1997 alone. Trade came to dominate the economy, with exports growing by more than 20 percent a year. But the government, made shy by the region's financial crisis, stifled early enthusiasm with heavy-handed bureaucracy and postponement of structural reforms. Foreign investment fell by about 80 percent between 1996 and 1999, and economic growth slowed by half. 
 Congress can help to reverse this trend by ratifying the free trade agreement with Vietnam that was completed last year under President Bill Clinton. The agreement grants Vietnam the same "normal trade relations" that China has enjoyed for over a decade. It lowers tariffs on both sides and provides vital copyright protection to American intellectual property. American businesses and diplomats have been pushing hard for the agreement, which would confirm the Vietnamese government's wisdom in offering open markets a second chance.
Under the sponsorship of Senators Tom Daschle and Trent Lott, the Democratic and Republican leaders, a joint resolution to approve the deal passed the Senate Finance Committee last week. But the House has yet to decide whether to vote on the pact with Vietnam by itself. Some Republicans want to make it a bargaining chip in the bigger debate about the president's authority to negotiate trade agreements. Today the House Ways and Means Committee will indicate whether it plans to delay approval further. It would be shameful to hold Vietnam's 79 million eager workers and consumers, and American businesses, hostage to Congressional machinations.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Death in the Ashes

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
A counterpoint to the egregious Philip Morris report suggesting that the early death of smokers can benefit a nation's economy is an extensive study by the World Bank that details the chilling -- and very expensive -- toll that cigarettes are taking around the world.
 According to the report, called "Curbing the Epidemic," the only two causes of death that are huge and growing worldwide are AIDS and tobacco-related illnesses. 
 According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, tobacco is expected to become the biggest killer in most developing countries within the next 20 years, causing more deaths than AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis, automobile crashes, homicides and suicides combined.
If current patterns hold, a half-billion people who are alive today will eventually be killed by tobacco. More than half of those are now children and teenagers. By the year 2030, tobacco is projected to be the single biggest cause of death worldwide, accounting for about 10 million deaths per year. 
Big Tobacco ought to send thank-you notes to new moms and new dads around the world because their newborns are absolutely essential to Big Tobacco's strategy of addicting ever-larger waves of young customers to replace the ever-increasing loads of smokers lost to early death.
The World Bank estimates that in affluent countries, 14,000 to 15,000 children and young people take up smoking each day. In middle-income and low-income countries, somewhere between 68,000 and 84,000 take their first insidious puffs.
The idea that they know what they're in for, that they understand the agony that may well await them years down the road and have made a rational choice to risk it, is ludicrous.
And this is significant when you talk about the economics of smoking. According to the World Bank study (which was done before the recent study commissioned by Philip Morris), it appears that smokers' lifetime health care costs in affluent countries are "somewhat higher" than non-smokers', despite their shorter lives. It is not at all clear what the situation is in less affluent countries with less extensive health care networks.
But that, of course, should not be the issue. The first issue to be addressed is the non-economic value -- one would hope it would be a high value -- that we ascribe to human beings based solely on the fact that they exist. But even if the discussion is limited to economic matters, there is a problem with Philip Morris's contention that countries can derive benefits from the early demise of smokers. It flies in the face of accepted economic theory, which argues that the benefits of a free market flow from rational decisions made by consumers who, when spending their money (and only their money), understand the risks and rewards of the choices they make.
That is largely not the case with smokers. Despite all the warnings about the murderous effects of tobacco, it seems clear that, as the World Bank study noted, "People's knowledge of the health risks of smoking appears to be partial at best." That is especially true with young smokers and smokers in poorer countries, where information about the hazards of smoking is limited.
The study said, "In China, for example, 61 percent of adult smokers surveyed in 1996 believed that cigarettes did them 'little or no harm.' "
People tend to underestimate the addictive effects of nicotine and grossly underestimate the likelihood that they will contract a horrible disease from smoking.
Moreover, the health-related costs of smoking -- both physical and financial -- are never limited to the smokers themselves.
Was the Black Death a boon to Europe in the Middle Ages? Is AIDS a boon to Africa today?
Smoking a boon? I don't think so.
Some years ago I interviewed an anti-smoking activist named David Goerlitz, who had once been known as the Winston Man because he had appeared in Winston ads for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
He once asked a group of R. J. Reynolds executives if any of them smoked. They all said no. Mr. Goerlitz said one of the executives shook his head and said: "Are you kidding? We reserve that right for the poor, the young, the black and the stupid."
Not much has changed. That philosophy is now being played out on a global scale.

HEADLINE: OPEC Plans A Reduction In Daily Output Of About 4% 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided yesterday to reduce its daily production by about 4 percent, or one million barrels, to buoy crude oil prices amid fears that worldwide oil demand was weakening. 
 The move to decrease production to 23.2 million barrels a day, which would go into effect Sept. 1, is not expected to produce a spike in oil prices to last year's levels of $30 a barrel or more, industry analysts said. But they warned that OPEC, in its haste to bolster prices that have been falling rapidly in recent weeks, risks driving the price of crude oil higher in the fall and winter, just as demand for heating oil surges. 
 Yesterday's decision is the third instance this year of the 10-member cartel's having decreased its daily output. This time, OPEC is believed to be reacting to the fears of many speculative investors on the oil markets, mainly hedge funds, that have bet heavily that the price of oil will fall. Three years ago, speculative investors with such positions drove down the price of oil sharply, which throttled the flow of revenue to OPEC economies. 
"OPEC wanted to respond as quickly as possible," said Edward L. Morse, executive adviser at the Hess Energy Trading Company. "They had a lot at stake. They believe that speculators who have been shorting the market will learn a lesson."
OPEC leaders said late last week that they were considering a production cut before their scheduled meeting on Sept. 26 because prices had slipped badly. Before that announcement, the price of crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange had fallen $3.50 in 10 days of trading, to $24.78, according to the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting group. At the end of trading yesterday at the exchange, the price of oil for September delivery had risen to $26.84, or 53 cents more than the previous day.
OPEC members rely almost exclusively on oil revenue to fill their coffers, and most have stated that they prefer -- and believe consumers can handle -- oil prices of $25 to $28 a barrel. Moreover, the conflict in Israel has made it politically difficult for Western allies within OPEC, like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, to make concessions on the price of oil, some analysts say.
"The politics within these countries right now is such that they can do nothing but keep up higher revenues, challenge the West and act only in their own self-interest," said Amy Myers Jaffe, a Middle East expert and senior energy adviser at the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy at Rice University.
Despite its hands-off approach to OPEC, the Bush administration voiced concern over the cut, which would bring the total reduction in the cartel's output this year to 3.5 million barrels a day.
"Our economy is bumping along right now," President Bush said yesterday, "and a run-up in energy prices would hurt."
Many analysts pointed out that OPEC's decision yesterday may be unwarranted. At the heart of any appraisal of the oil markets is the balance between supply and demand. The speculative investors and some OPEC members have been concerned about a recent report by the International Energy Agency in Paris that demand had fallen significantly because of the lagging global economy. At the same time, inventories of crude oil, gasoline and heating oil in the United States have been robust. And Iraq, which withheld exports earlier this summer because of a dispute with the United Nations, is now supplying about 2.3 million barrels a day.
But many economists pointed out that demand may not have fallen as sharply as stated by the I.E.A., whose figures are regularly revised because of inaccurate or incomplete data countries provide it. Analysts expected the current high inventories of crude oil to start decreasing by the fall, even without the OPEC cut, as refiners gear up to supply more heating oil. As that increased demand converges with a loss of one million barrels of crude oil supply, prices could surpass $28 a barrel, some analysts said. That, in turn, would mean that if winter is typically cold, the price of heating oil could rise.

HEADLINE: Revenue Falls, But Xerox Sees Bright Spots 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation, trying to rebuild its ailing businesses in the face of a slowing economy, said yesterday that its second-quarter revenue was down 13 percent from last year, and that it had lost money for the fourth quarter in a row.
 While Xerox executives held out little hope that the company would show a profit for the year, they said sales in North America were inching back up, that it had plenty of cash and that it might show black ink by the year's final quarter. 
 "Our turnaround plans are on track, our liquidity is strengthening and our cost-reduction efforts are paying off," Paul A. Allaire, Xerox's chairman, told analysts in a morning conference call. 
Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., lost $281 million, or 40 cents a share, in the second quarter, in contrast to a profit of $202 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier. After one-time charges, the largest associated with ending its low-end printer business, Xerox lost 10 cents a share. 
That met analysts' expectations, and shareholders showed only mild disappointment. Xerox shares fell 40 cents, to $7.59.
Xerox is still in better shape than it was six months ago. At the end of last year, the company was battling rumors of bankruptcy. And questions about its accounting practices in Mexico led to an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and caused Xerox's own auditors to balk at signing off on its 2000 financial statements. 
Even after paying down considerable debt, Xerox has $2.6 billion in cash, up from $1.7 billion at the end of last year. The S.E.C. investigation continues, but Xerox's auditors did approve the company's numbers, with only slight restatements.
Skeptics about Xerox's prospects still abound. "They've got a decent turnaround story going, but it's still too soon to say whether they'll have solid long-term growth," said Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
But in past quarters, analysts have sharply criticized Xerox management, arguing that it botched a sales force reorganization and lagged on product introductions. This time, many analysts gave Xerox management high marks for maintaining research spending even as it cut other costs, for introducing new color copiers and filling in gaps in its line of black and white machines, for starting to rebuild its sales force and for making good on promises to farm out manufacturing and to get out of businesses that it could no longer afford to support. 
"They are on track in terms of cutting costs and getting the balance sheet in shape," said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. 
The worsening economy has caused most equipment manufacturers to face weak sales in the United States and plummeting sales in Europe and Latin America. But Xerox's problems have been worse than many. Xerox's revenues dropped 33 percent in Latin America, where the company has been backing away from what it calls unprofitable contracts. 
And, in the United States, Canon, Ricoh and others are still chipping away at Xerox's most lucrative product line: very fast black-and-white copiers. 
Jim Ivy, president of Ricoh's Office Products Group, says that once-loyal Xerox customers are increasingly inviting Ricoh to bid. 
"Our U.S. revenues are up 9 percent," Mr. Ivy said, "and roughly half of the products we sell are replacing older Xerox machines." 
Xerox's performance has been even worse in the low-end market. It finally pulled the plug on its once-promising line of low-priced printers for the small-office and home-office market. Such printers can be a source of lucrative sales of papers, toners and inks. But Xerox never sold enough machines to get that annuity stream flowing. Xerox lost 8 cents a share in this market in the second quarter. 
Xerox also took a $196 million charge to cover the costs of shutting down this business and expects to take additional charges next quarter. 
Anne M. Mulcahy, Xerox's president, said that if losses from this business and the cost of getting out were factored out, Xerox would show a profit for the year. 
Xerox is betting on color copiers -- one of its few truly profitable product lines -- and services. 
"Our revenue declines are manageable," Ms. Mulcahy said, "and we're already seeing improvements over last quarter."
In fact, she said in an interview, she was buoyed by Xerox's performance and prospects, at least in North America.
"It's starting to look like a well-run business," she said with a laugh.

HEADLINE: A Survey of Wall St. Finds Women Disheartened 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Women on Wall Street have a hard time arguing with the money to be made, but a survey released yesterday of men and women at seven major securities firms suggests that many women are dissatisfied with the extent of progress that has been made to help women advance in the securities industry. 
 The findings reaffirm an impression by many women on Wall Street that the industry remains inhospitable. 
 "It's extremely disheartening to see how far we have not come," said Alexandra Lebenthal, who heads her family's Wall Street firm and has been in the business for about 15 years. 
Most of the nearly 500 women who responded to the survey conducted by Catalyst, a nonprofit research and advisory organization in New York, say they are happy with their jobs, citing the challenging work and generous compensation.
But they also describe an industry where it is difficult to get ahead. Two-thirds say that they must work harder than men for the same rewards, and a third report a hostile environment where crude or sexist comments are tolerated, they are treated unfairly or are subject to unwanted sexual attention. 
The survey, which is the first extensive look at the experiences of women working on Wall Street, also suggests that many women are making significant sacrifices in their personal lives, similar to the ones made by lawyers and other professionals. Only half of the women surveyed have children, compared with about three-quarters of the men surveyed. In a 1996 survey of senior women at Fortune 1000 companies, about two-thirds had children. Two-thirds of the Wall Street women were married or living with a partner, compared with 86 percent of the men.
While women praise the efforts of the securities firms generally to promote an atmosphere of respect, they say this has not yet translated into a workplace free of harassment or one that can be seen as a true meritocracy. Fewer than half of both men and women said they thought that promotion decisions were made fairly at their firm. "Cultural change is very tough to make happen," said Sheila Wellington, the president of Catalyst.
Catalyst sent surveys to 2,200 women and men, both in senior and junior positions, at seven firms, the names of which it agreed not to disclose. All the findings were reported anonymously. Some 38 percent, 482 women and 356 men, responded. Catalyst also conducted nine focus groups in New York, Chicago and San Francisco. 
About a quarter of the women who responded held the title of managing director or higher, with the typical respondent having worked at her current firm for 10 years and in the industry for 14 years. 
The report is part of the settlement of a sex-discrimination lawsuit brought against Smith Barney, now part of Citigroup, in which women charged that there had been a "boom-boom room" in one of the firm's offices, where male managers would harass female employees. 
While the leaders of many Wall Street firms are committed to change, many in their organizations are not, Ms. Lebenthal said, adding, "I think there are a lot of people on Wall Street who do not see the need to change."
And only a fifth of the women surveyed say that the opportunities to advance have increased greatly in the last five years.
Given the resources many of the firms are pouring into efforts to diversify their work forces and given the large number of women on Wall Street, the lack of progress is surprising, said Dee A. Soder, an executive coach in New York who is managing partner in the CEO Perspective Group. "It's gotten much better," she said, "but there is still a glass ceiling with less reason for a glass ceiling."
There needs to be a greater commitment by the leadership at many Wall Street firms, agreed Janice Reals Ellig, an executive recruiter in New York and the co-author of "What Every Successful Woman Knows," which offers advice from senior women executives about how to get ahead. "The progress is so slow," she said. "By the year 3000, we're going to get there."
But some argue that the securities industry is difficult for both men and women. "Wall Street, in general I believe, is undeservedly maligned," said Cristina Morgan, a senior investment banker at J. P. Morgan, the investment banking arm of J. P. Morgan Chase. Many women, and men, choose to leave Wall Street because of the hours and the travel required, she said. The clients "pay us lots and lots of money to be at their disposal 24 hours a day, 7 days a week," she said.
And juggling the demands of a family with the work is extraordinarily hard, Ms. Morgan said, adding: "I am filled with admiration for my women partners who are successful and have children. I am mystified to how they do it." She indicated that she thought Wall Street was indeed a meritocracy. 
But many of the women who remain in the business are deciding to forgo having children. "I cannot imagine ever having children and doing this business," a senior-level woman told Catalyst. 
Men, of course, are also aware of the sacrifices required to rise on Wall Street, particularly in investment banking. "It's hard to be a middle-level vice president and not spend 90 hours a week at the firm," one man said. "That just doesn't jibe with trying to raise a family."
As a result, many women simply leave, as Janet Tiebout Hanson did when she departed from Goldman, Sachs to create her own firm, Milestone Capital Management. An adviser to Catalyst on the study, Ms. Hanson has also worked to improve the ability of women to network by creating 85 Broads, an Internet-based network of women who work or used to work at Goldman, Sachs. The name refers to the firm's famous address. 
Ms. Hanson, for one, is optimistic that securities firms will be forced to change as women, especially those coming out of business school, leave Wall Street for friendlier, if not greener, pastures. Many, she thinks, will go elsewhere in corporate America. "It's a much bigger problem than they think," Ms. Hanson said.
Ms. Soder, the executive coach, agreed, saying, "Corporations are now losing many of the best and the brightest."
Many of the women cited as a barrier to their moving up exclusion from important networks. "Well, it was every broker but me that got invited," a senior-level woman told Catalyst. "So they all got input as to maybe what they were doing wrong, or how they could improve their business, but me." 
The survey also offers a glimpse into the continued problem of sexual harassment on Wall Street, which continues to surface from time to time. While sexual harassment is difficult to define and to measure with any precision, with little comparative data in private industries, the survey suggests that many women think that inappropriate or crude comments continue to be tolerated where they work. Some men agree. "In my experience," one said, "brokers are the raunchiest people that you'll ever meet."
About 13 percent of the women surveyed say they receive unwelcome sexual attention at work.
The impetus now, according to Susan Chadick, an executive recruiter who works with Ms. Ellig at Gould, McCoy & Chadick in New York, is to take some of the findings and look deeper. "It requires a lot more probing," Ms. Chadick said.
And she worries that the downturn in the economy may make the future, especially for senior-level women, more bleak. "Not only hasn't there been any progress," she said, but "I'm concerned we're going backward."

HEADLINE: Auditors Doubt Amtrak Will Meet Profit Goal 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25 

 BODY:
Amtrak is unlikely to meet the date Congress set five years ago to break even or face the possibility of liquidation, two outside auditors told a House subcommittee today.
 But the head of Amtrak testified that he found the mandate to end the railroad's losses, while running unprofitable trains at the same time, irrational, frustrating and "wacky." 
 Amtrak said it anticipated that the slowdown in business travel that had hit the airlines would hit it, too, one of the reasons it was having difficulty meeting operational self-sufficiency. 
Congress voted in December 1997 to require Amtrak to generate enough profits within five years to meet all operating costs and ordered that if Amtrak failed, a newly formed council should create a plan for restructuring Amtrak, while the General Accounting Office should create a plan for liquidating it. 
George D. Warrington, president and chief executive of Amtrak, insisted that the railroad was making good progress toward self-sufficiency in operating funds. But Mr. Warrington added that a deeper question was whether Congress would supply capital funding, as anticipated in the 1997 law, and whether it would recognize that some service could not be profitably provided.
"I believe we will be very close, even in a downturned economy," Mr. Warrington said.
The railroad is considering laying off 15 percent of its managers and 10 percent of its unionized personnel.
Kenneth Mead, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation, said that the railroad could cut enough to break even but that the cuts would be so draconian that "such a victory would be hollow and have serious repercussions for the future of intercity passenger rail."
Mr. Mead also testified that the new high-speed Acela trains serving Boston, New York and Washington were lightly used and that the number of seats filled was declining on Boston-to-New York runs. He added, though, that this might simply be because the service was new.
Experts differed on the amount by which Amtrak was likely to miss the self-sufficiency goal. 
JayEtta Z. Hecker, director of physical infrastructure issues at the accounting office, a Congressional agency, said Amtrak had closed the gap between revenues and expenses by only $83 million in the last six years and had $280 million left to go. But Mr. Warrington said about $200 million a year that Amtrak paid for retirement benefits for employees of predecessor railroads did not count. 
Most members of the subcommittee were friendly to the railroad.
Robert A. Borski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, compared Amtrak with the French high-speed train, T.G.V. "It goes fast, it is smooth, they put a lot of money into it, and we just don't," he said.
But Representative John L. Mica, Republican of Florida, berated the railroad for "half-baked" efforts, including inadequate terminals at the southern end of the Auto Train in Sanford, Fla.
"The future of Amtrak is dismal at best," Mr. Mica said, adding that the railroad was "near death" and that "we should begin restructuring and liquidating now."

HEADLINE: This Time, Prospect of Pink Slips Makes Workers Grim at Lucent 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: MURRAY HILL, N.J., July 25 

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, long before Tuesday's announcement that Lucent Technologies would eliminate 15,000 to 20,000 more jobs, photocopies of fliers went up in a hallway of the company's headquarters here exhorting employees to keep their spirits high.
 "Don't give up!" the unsigned flier said. "Better days are coming!!!" Scribbled in a corner of one of the notices, an employee offered a response: "When?" 
 It is the same question that many of those at Lucent were asking themselves today. After a dismal year of layoffs, job buyouts and a falling stock price, many said they were numbed by Tuesday's avalanche of bad news, topped by the job cuts, a $3.5 billion quarterly loss and elimination of the dividend. Once the latest job eliminations are made, the company will have fewer than half the 155,000 employees it had a year ago. 
After Lucent began in 1996 as a $21 billion spinoff of AT&T's manufacturing and computer businesses and its stock price grew, employees relished their stock benefits and talked about how they would allow them to retire early. But today, after shrugging off the previous rounds of layoffs, many Lucent employees were less than sanguine, saying the nation's slowing economy and rising unemployment rate made the prospect of a pink slip somewhat more sobering than it had been in the past. 
One 52-year-old employee who ignored the earlier buyout offer said he now regretted the decision. He said management had told him those who remained at Lucent should not fear being laid off. 
"Now I have that sinking feeling that I'm not going to win on this one," he said. "The thought of starting someplace new at this point or the thought of not finding anything new is frightening."
The company said it had yet to decide at which of its locations it would make its job cuts. Here in affluent Morris County, where Lucent has about 4,000 employees, some business owners said they were already feeling the pain of a smaller, leaner Lucent.
Tom Taha, 38, the owner of the Village Cafe and Bagel Shop in New Providence, said his breakfast and lunch business had fallen by half since January, around the time the first Lucent employees began taking early retirement. Last Friday, he said, more than 100 customers who had accepted the recent buyout offer stopped by to say goodbye.
"It was sad," he said. "A lot of people moved into town to be close to work, but I hear that a lot of them are getting ready to move. If there is no work, why stay?"
Still, most economists said the company's rapid tumble would have little impact on the state, which has slightly more than 4 million jobs. Joe Gonzales, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said many companies are still crying out for skilled workers. "It's sad when anyone loses their job, but I think these people will land on their feet." While telecommunications and Internet companies in New Jersey are still bleeding badly, pharmaceutical corporations like Johnson & Johnson, Pharmacia and Merck have been reporting hefty profits, he said. 
After years of dizzying growth, however, New Jersey has lost 8,000 jobs since December, a marked contrast to the addition of 95,000 jobs in 2000. The state's unemployment rate, at 4.5 percent, has come up nearly a point since February.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said the job reductions at Lucent might have a small effect on businesses that serve the company and an even smaller impact on housing if former employees move away. "However, I don't think the loss is going to do permanent damage to the New Jersey economy," he said. 
In Hopewell Township, where Lucent plans to close a research facility, the mayor, Marylou Ferrara, said she saw no reason to worry. "Lucent didn't even own the property, so we won't even lose any taxes, although the landlord will lose a tenant," she said. "So I don't think it is perceived as having a large impact locally." 
For now, the cutbacks will inflict the greatest pain on Lucent employees and their families. Some employees, especially younger ones, said they were unconcerned.
"One door closes and another will open," said a 38-year-old man from New Providence. But one of his co-workers, a 34-year-old with children, said she was afraid for the future. "I moved here with my family with the dream of raising my family here, having a short commute to work and staying with Lucent until retirement," she said. "Now those dreams seem to get less realistic every day."
Employees said that spirits at company headquarters were palpably bleak. "We are all in a period of limbo," a 28-year-old man said. "We all want to know if we'll be here next week or unemployed." Beyond their concerns about job security, some of those nearing retirement said they had been fretting about Lucent's stock price since it toppled to less than $7 from its peak of $77 in December 1999. "My nest egg is looking pretty puny," a 57-year-old secretary from Irvington said. 
Then there are the now-reduced perks and services that made the workday so much more pleasant. The in-house fitness club, once free to employees, now costs $20 a month, it was announced today. The free bottled spring water and coffee have been eliminated. And a scaling back in security services means that many of the sprawling headquarters' side entrances have been closed, forcing employees to walk a greater distance from the parking lots. 
"We're looking at things that in the past might have been useful benefits and we're asking whether they're necessary in this new economic environment," said Bill Price, a company spokesman. "Everyone is being asked to tighten their belt." 
But for some employees the most pronounced changes have been showing up in the company's modern, glass-walled cafeteria. Gone are the custom-made wraps, the whole-grain Mediterranean salads and the wok station, a grill where stir-fried dishes were made to order. A soup counter, where soup was once ladled out by a server in a chef's hat, is now a serve-yourself affair. 
"The quality of food has really deteriorated meal by meal," said one employee, a 24-year-old software designer. "Not to sound glib, but it's really taken a toll on my morale."

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about employees who face layoffs at the headquarters of Lucent Technologies in Murray Hill, N.J., misidentified the affected county. It is Union, not Morris.

HEADLINE: In Loss, DuPont to Cut Jobs 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The DuPont Company, posting a second-quarter loss, said yesterday that it would eliminate more jobs and warned that its third-quarter earnings would fall short of estimates because of weak demand for chemicals and plastics.
 DuPont, which is based in Wilmington, Del., increased its planned job cuts by 1,500, to 5,500 workers, or 6 percent of its work force. An additional 1,300 contract workers will also be laid off, as previously announced, as the company combats high energy costs, a strong dollar and weak demand for its products. 
 "Industries important to many of our customers -- electronics, automotive, textiles and chemicals -- have been particularly affected by the economic downturn," said Charles O. Holliday Jr., the chairman and chief executive. "This has temporarily reduced fundamental demand for our products."
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, as it is formally known, posted a net loss of $213 million, or 21 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $688 million, or 65 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
Excluding one-time items, income fell 54 percent, to $432 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $949 million, or 90 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 12 percent, to $7 billion from $7.9 billion.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 40 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/ First Call.
So far in the current quarter, business has not improved, DuPont said, warning that its third quarter "will be substantially more challenging than the second quarter."
Earnings for the third quarter will probably fall at least 70 percent from results in the period a year earlier, the company said, a far bigger drop than the roughly 40 percent slide that analysts on average had been expecting.
Shares of DuPont rose 29 cents, to $43.21.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Second-Quarter Loss Hits $4.76 Billion at Corning
Corning said it lost $4.76 billion in the second quarter as the severe downturn in the telecommunications businesses caused demand to dry up for its cable and fiber, which is used to build communications networks.
 The company's stock rose 3 percent after hours, largely because the company had already announced most of its bad news. Sales increased 5 percent, to $1.87 billion. Page C5. 

Profit and Sales Decline at Compaq
Compaq Computer, suffering from weak demand and cutthroat pricing in the personal computer market, reported a steep drop in second-quarter earnings as sales fell 17 percent. "It's an understatement to say that we're in the midst of an extremely challenging global market," Michael D. Capellas, Compaq's chief executive, told analysts. C4.

Sale of Chris-Craft Is Approved
Federal regulators approved the News Corporation's acquisition of Chris-Craft Industries, paving the way for the company to gain unprecendented control over two of the main broadcast stations in New York. B1.

Pacific Bell May Face Complaint
A group of California Internet service providers, which rely on the Pacific Bell telephone network to offer high-speed service, plans to accuse Pacific Bell and an affiliate of engaging in anticompetitive practices. C4.

Stocks Rally After Two-Day Selloff
After two days of heavy selling, stocks rallied on a few good earnings reports despite a preponderance of bad ones. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 164.55 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,405.67. The Nasdaq composite index rose 25.08 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,984.32, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 18.84 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,190.49. C10.

E.D.S. Profit Increases 17%
Electronic Data Systems posted a 17 percent increase in second-quarter profit, reinforcing reports by I.B.M. and others that most of the information technology services sector is faring well in the economic slowdown. C4.

Siemens Promises Sharp Cutbacks
Siemens, the German electrical engineering company, fired the head of its telephone networks division and promised drastic cost-cutting. World Business, Section W.
