 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 4720 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"BEYOND THE EASEL: DECORATIVE PAINTING BY BONNARD, VUILLARD, DENIS AND ROUSSEL, 1890-1930," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 9.) The themes of the 80 or so French paintings in this show, created for bourgeois homes by artists who called themselves the Nabis, couldn't be more lightweight: city parks and country gardens, gift-wrapped tots and fusspot nannies, with the occasional nymph thrown in for tone. Yet the results, with their clotted textures and mildewy palettes of puce, mauve and brown, often look leaden and suffocating, trapped in nostalgia. Bonnard and Vuillard, unsurprisingly, come off best; Maurice Denis and Ker Xavier Roussel less well. Works that haven't been seen together for a century have been gathered for the occasion. Of most interest, though, is the concept of decoration that the Nabis promoted, one that was at once radical and reactionary. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"MARC CHAGALL: EARLY WORKS FROM RUSSIAN COLLECTIONS," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Oct. 14). When Chagall returned to Russia in 1914 after four years in Paris, he intended to marry his beloved fiancee, Bella Rosenfeld, and hurry back to the French capital. Instead World War I and the Russian Revolution kept him in his homeland for eight years, during which he did some of his greatest work. The 60 artworks here, most being exhibited in the West for the first time, form a series of intense Chagallian doses rather than a comprehensive overview. They are accompanied by nine paintings by Chagall's first teacher, the sensitive realist Yehuda Pen. The show culminates in the seven large, deliriously inventive murals Chagall made for the Jewish State Chamber Theater in Moscow during three feverish months in 1920. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ ($2 surcharge for "Chagall") (Smith).

* JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN GALLERIES, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5000 (continuing). These glorious new galleries display 50 French modern works, almost all paintings, drawn from the Gelmans' collection. In addition to the paintings here, the collection includes five sculptures, more than 30 drawings and a major work on paper: a Matisse cutout, the Met's first, which will be shown in a subsequent hanging. The standouts installed here include Matisse's Fauve masterpiece "The Young Sailor II"; a matched set of small, classic Cubist paintings, one by Picasso, one by Braque, both from 1911, arguably the high point of their collaboration; and a fantastically refined, sexually fraught 1929 Dali, "Accommodations of Desires." It is a selection that is not only consistent in its high quality but also, for all the big names and visual firepower, surprisingly personal. It makes the museum a modern art destination in a way that it has never quite been before. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "FRANK GEHRY, ARCHITECT," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Aug. 26). A full-dress retrospective that showcases history unfolding, even as we walk through it. Mr. Gehry has shown that even in architecture, a form notoriously resistant to creativity, it is possible not only to realize a personal vision but also to gain wide public support for it. The show is a tribute to the ideal of service: to an art form, to the city and to the continuous reconstruction of a democratic way of life. Nothing, not even familiarity with Mr. Gehry's buildings, can prepare you for the impact of seeing his work presented in Frank Lloyd Wright's magnificent rotunda. The energy hits you on entering the show and increases as you proceed. Hours: Fridays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Herbert Muschamp).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge uses searing images to address South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses in the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-11. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there are enough great things from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

"MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE SMITH COLLEGE MUSEUM OF ART," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Aug. 12). This selection of drawings spanning six centuries has compelling works on paper by some of the more resonant names in Western art history, names like Tiepolo, Boucher, Ingres, Gericault, Beardsley, van Gogh, Mondrian and others. There are works of only academic proficiency, but in far more cases the drawing sings: in the 15th-century Italian Rosso Fiorentino's near-orgiastic vision of a double martyrdom made with urgent sensuousness in red chalk, for example, or Seurat's studies for "La Grande Jatte," in which broad, deft swipes of a black crayon evoke the silhouettes of women who seem almost dissolved by watery light. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "MIGRATIONS: HUMANITY IN TRANSITION," photographs by Sebastiao Salgado, International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sept. 9). The show (there are two accompanying books) is the product of seven years in more than 35 countries documenting what Mr. Salgado calls "the reorganization of the human family," partly because of the shift from "majority rural to majority urban." His subjects are refugees, exiles, orphans, landless peasants, homeless families, boat people, internees and others. This is a sprawling, frequently gruesome story -- the scale and gravity of it should speak for themselves -- and if the suffering doesn't prompt guilt, indifference to it will. That's how emotional blackmail and effective moral photojournalism work. Mr. Salgado practices both as well as anyone does these days. Of course, the pictures are also exploitative, but that's also a feature of photojournalism. We respond despite the voyeurism and the manipulation because of the formal beauty. The good photographs are so stupendously gorgeous that, for better and worse, they can make you forget everything else while you are looking at them. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sept. 23). The world not being a perfect place, this show will be around only through the summer, so consider yourself forewarned. At the Whitney, as in life, happiness is fleeting. Meanwhile, you are free to bask in these pumpkin pies, meat and cheese deli counters, lipsticks, hot dogs and gum-ball machines, which, as Mr. Thiebaud has painted them for the last 40 years, have the aura of loves lost and too fondly recalled. Joy yielding to melancholy then yields to the less jolting but more durable satisfaction of being in the presence of pictures so lovingly and wittily made. These pictures provoke happiness if for no other reason than that they are content to be what they are, which is enough, this being the same message they convey about the modest objects and people they depict. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

"MINIMAL," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Aug. 10; reopens Aug. 27 to 31). This elegant show includes works of classic Minimalism like a box made of stainless steel and fluorescent red Plexiglas by Donald Judd; an iconic arrangement of red, pink and yellow fluorescent lights by Dan Flavin; and a gorgeous, glossy red, thick plank shape by John McCracken. It also embraces more Conceptually motivated works, like words on the wall by Lawrence Weiner that say "Around the bend"; a square of typewritten concrete poetry by Carl Andre; and photographs of framework houses by Bernd and Hilla Becher (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Aug. 31). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit of art into an art of their own (Glueck).

"SALT OF THE EARTH," Bettina Werner, Winston Wachter Mayer, 39 East 78th Street, (212) 327-2526 (through Aug. 15). With unabashed grandiosity, Ms. Werner calls herself the "Queen of Salt." Since the 1980's she has specialized in making abstract paintings using colored salt crystals in various grades, from sandy to chunky, as her primary medium. She evidently wants to be some kind of 21st-century alchemist, but her multipaneled pictures are formally generic. Maybe they should be saltier (Johnson).

"SERIAL THINKING," Kouros, 23 East 73rd Street, (212) 288-5888 (through Aug. 31). Zeuxis, an organization of still-life painters, presents works by more than two dozen artists, most represented by multiple versions of a single motif. Some impressive works stand out against the earnestly academic background, including Victor Pesces's iconic, subtly humorous pictures of isolated cups; Suzanne Biggins's small close-up studies of matches, which verge on grid-based abstraction; and Lucy Barber's hazy images of objects that seem almost dissolved by light and heat (Johnson).

"VOYAGES: A SMITHSONIAN LIBRARIES EXHIBITION," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through Aug. 4). Mostly a selection of mostly rare books with some curious objects also, "Voyages" offers a miniature cross section of the vast holdings of the Smithsonian Institution Libraries. Contents range from remarkable antiquities like "Mundus Subterraneus" by the 17th-century Dutch scholar Athanasius Kircher, thought to be the earliest printed study of geophysics and vulcanology, to a copy of Neil Armstrong's "Stroll on the Moon," which is signed by the author and the fellow astronauts Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

MORRIS GRAVES, "Still Life," Schmidt Bingham, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Aug. 17). This small retrospective honors a great American original who died in May at 90. Ranging from vigorously palette-knifed paintings of drinking fountains from the 1930's to exquisitely delicate pictures of flowers in transparent bottles from the 90's, the show gives a fine taste of Graves's craftsmanlike versatility and his modest yet intense poetic sensibility (Johnson).

ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, "Maquettes for Monuments," Ameringer/Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through Aug. 10). In the late 1960's, this Modernist sculptor and Conde Nast editorial director produced gigantic abstractions using old, unearthed gas pipes. On view here are sleek little copies of those monumental works, compositions of standing, leaning or tumbling cylinders finished in glossy red or matte rust-colored patina. Though not deeply consequential, they are appealingly precious (Johnson).

"MINIMALISM PAST AND PRESENCE," Galerie Lelong, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 315-0470 (through Aug. 15). For its final exhibition before moving to Chelsea, Lelong presents a retrospective of Minimalist or near-Minimalist artists who have exhibited here over the years, including Robert Ryman, Robert Mangold and Donald Judd. Alfredo Jaar's lightbox-lighted Social Realist photograph, Sean Scully's loose stripe paintings and Ana Mendieta's photograph of an archetypal earthwork undermine the show's coherence, but being definitive seems not to be the point (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

"CAMERA WORKS: THE PHOTOGRAPHIC IMPULSE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 10). Despite the encompassing title, this show focuses almost exclusively on photographs by 31 established artists, mostly in their 30's and 40's, who are not known primarily, if at all, for working with the camera. Usual suspects are in the majority, from Ross Bleckner to Lisa Yuskavage, with Peter Doig, Jessica Stockholder, Rachel Whiteread and Gregor Schneider in between. But there are still plenty of surprises and revelations, especially when you find yourself thinking that some of the assembled should stick to photography (Smith).

"ELECTRIFY ME!" Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9467 (through Aug. 10). This judiciously selected (by the curator Mark Fletcher) and beautifully installed exhibition of sculptures that use electric light includes a heart-shaped neon sign with a funny but unprintable message by Tim Noble and Sue Webster; a window of cool light by James Turrell; Jorge Pardo's lamps of thick glass scattered on the floor and looking vaguely like collapsing squashes; an elegiac string of bulbs by Felix Gonzalez-Torres; and a neon palindrome by Bruce Nauman. Only Rachel Whiteread's aluminum cast of an electrical switch box doesn't light up (Johnson).

ENEAS, "Thriller," Esso, 211 West 28th Street, (212) 560-9728 (through Aug. 16). Every canvas in this empty but archly sophisticated display of insider gamesmanship has the name Michael Jackson stenciled across the top above a skillful simulation of gesture or drip painting by Jackson Pollock, who shares a name with the mercurial pop star. These works so closely resemble George Condo's jazz album cover paintings that you can't help suspecting the sly Condo might have invented Eneas. (Johnson).

"FOUR ABSTRACT CLASSICISTS," Gary Snyder, 601 West 29th Street, (212) 871-1077 (through Aug. 25). This punchy time capsule of a show features works from the 1950's and 60's by four West Coast painters of hard-edged abstraction -- Karl Benjamin, Lorser Feitelson, Frederick Hammersley and John McLaughlin. The exhibition recalls a generational shift away from Abstract Expressionism toward the cooler aesthetics of the 1960's. Its title invites reflection on the paradoxical tension in reductive abstraction between historical avant-gardism and timeless formalism (Johnson).

RICHARD HAMILTON, "Prints, 1968-1998," Charles Cowles Gallery, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Aug. 17). James Joyce's "Ulysses" and tabloid subjects like Mick Jagger's arrest for drug possession are part of the huge print repertory of the English painter Richard Hamilton. Mr. Hamilton is wide-ranging not only in subject matter but also in print technique; while not dispensing with venerable practices like etching and engraving, he sets no limits on technical possibilities, fooling around with contemporary techniques from silk-screening to computer manipulation of digital images, sometimes using several in the same print. This wonderfully animated show illustrates his belief that images will always be more important than the manner of their execution. But it also reveals the role that technical innovation plays in the impact of his graphic work (Glueck).

"LARGER THAN LIFE," Center for Figurative Painting, 115 West 30th Street, (212) 868-3452 (through Sept. 28). The standouts in this five-artist show are two painters of opposite but equally ambitious sensibility: Leland Bell, whose large, perfectly composed figure compositions project an Appolonian love of order and clarity, and Paul Georges, a passionate hedonist whose big, recklessly vigorous painting of wild pink roses under a bright blue sky evokes a summer day to almost unbearably delightful effect (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* LOUISE BOURGEOIS AND YAYOI KUSAMA, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through tomorrow; reopens Aug. 21 to Sept. 15). Bringing Ms. Bourgeois and Ms. Kusama together for the first time in this illuminating drawing show was an inspired idea. Both have found inspiration in the wilder parts of consciousness, and both have long practiced repetitive mark-making. In a recent drawing by Ms. Bourgeois, nested ovals made in a scratchy red line create a primitivistic, enigmatically iconic image. Ms. Kusama's dot fields and allover linear networks produce, at their best, eye-buzzing opticality and cosmic transcendentalism (Johnson).

TEUN HOCKS, P.P.O.W., 476 Broome Street, (212) 941-8642 (through Aug. 10). For his large, funny and mysterious photographs, this Dutch artist constructs and paints his own sets, and, like Buster Keaton or Magritte's bowler-hatted Everyman, performs actions that prompt philosophical meditation on reality and illusion. The image of the artist concentrating on a burning candle in his hand while the sun blazes behind him might be a metaphor about the human limits of spiritual perception (Johnson).

"SURF'S UP! SURFING PHOTOGRAPHY FROM 1922 TO 1942," by Tom Blake and Don James," Ariel Meyerowitz, 580 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 625-3434 (through Aug. 10). Blake and James got into surfing and photographing surfers long before the Beach Boys made it a national craze. Blake's pictures from the 1920's and early 30's and James's from the late 30's and early 40's are shown here in the form of poster-sized digital prints made from original negatives. The warm-toned, often blurry images of men riding waves on long boards look at once nostalgically antique and fashionably contemporary (Johnson).

Last Chance

JOHN BALDESSARI, JEFF KOONS, TOM WESSELMANN, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through today). The big surprise is how shockingly uninteresting one finds Mr. Koons's dry, anonymously painted, Rosenquist-style montages. Mr. Baldessari's new photo-constructions offer the familiar conceptual impenetrability and visual enervation that have always characterized his least interesting works. But the unassuming hedonism of Mr. Wesselmann's three cutout steel works -- a rippling abstraction, a still life and a cartoon landscape -- is delightfully if not deeply seductive (Johnson).

JACQUELINE BOOTIER, "Basic Training," Lombard/Freid, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through today). This promising show of exuberantly painterly pictures based on old family snapshots is Ms. Bootier's first solo. The L.A.-based artist trowels swathes of thick paint this way and that, creating vibrant, fractured spaces around lumpy, gnarly figures. In "Potty Training" a sad little girl with her pants down seems overwhelmed by the inexplicable and chaotic pressures of her young life (Johnson).

JASON DUVAL, Marcello Marvelli, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through today). The small, blocky abstractions in this young painter's first solo exhibition have a painterly touch that veers from graceful to brusque and a finely tuned sense of color. At best, in two larger, more finished works that call to mind the paintings of Thomas Nozkowski, the circulating line, semi-transparent glazes and vibrating play of reds or greens reward extended contemplation (Johnson).

* "EL GRECO: THEMES AND VARIATIONS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sunday). This gemlike single-digit exhibition (just seven canvases) outweighs some of the more grandiose shows in New York museums at the moment. It brings together, mostly for the first time, four versions of the artist's tumultuous "Purification of the Temple," which provide a vivid time line of his transcultural development, and three versions of his resonant portrait of St. Jerome as a cardinal, which were all painted toward the end of his life when he skillfully copied -- always with interesting differences -- his works for private patrons. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

"FACES AND FIGURES: CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY IN SCANDINAVIA," Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, near 38th Street, (212) 779-3587 (through today). Nordic photography makes a good showing here with a mix of established and lesser-known talents using a range of approaches, from documentary to personal diary. The aim is to dispel stereotypes about "coolness, control and psychic remoteness" in the words of Ann Sass, chief curator. And the show succeeds, with a humanscape of transvestite haunts in Paris, high jinks in Swedish suburbs, hunting and farming in Iceland, plain folk at home in Sweden, Christmas in Finland, prostitutes plying their trade in Denmark and children frolicking in Norway (Glueck).

NEIL FARBER: NEW DRAWINGS, Clementine Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937 (through today). Children, cats, the Devil and hell are recurrent themes for this young Canadian artist, whose cartoony, vaguely "Peanuts"-like whimsies seem to proliferate like rabbits on the gallery walls. In his artfully artless drawings, sometimes mordant, sometimes terminally cute, animals morph into more unaccustomed creatures; children drink poison and descend to the netherworld; a pair of swallowed birds preen in the stomach of a smug cat. His free flow of the pen could use, if not quenching, a little editing (Glueck).

ADA GILMORE: "THE SUMMER OF 1915: WATERCOLORS FROM PROVINCETOWN," Mary Ryan, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669 (through Tuesday). All 22 paintings in this modestly radiant exhibition were made on the backs of official United States Postal Service postcards during the year after World War I drove this American Modernist from Paris to Provincetown. Gilmore's sunny, Impressionistic pictures of women gardening or doing laundry or views of houses among trees become more absorbing the more you look. Like her most obvious influence, Vuillard, she worked a fine balance between vibrantly patterned surface and evocative domestic space (Johnson).

"SUPERIMPOSITION," Caren Golden Fine Art, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304 (through today). This smart group show by mostly young American artists, organized by the critic David Hunt, focuses on art based on stacking, layering, volume or the illusion of depth. One sculpture is made from vertically arranged reels of film, another from painstakingly assembled stones. A painting is composed from layers of drizzled paint; a fabric relief from a free-associational network of words. The deep space of science fiction gets some play in a Minimalist wall piece that doubles as a star ship control panel. And a digital work weaves together personal references, abstract forms and music (Cotter).

JUDI WERTHEIN AND LEANDRO ERLICH, "Turismo," Kent Gallery, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500 (through Thursday). This photo-installation piece by two Argentine artists, a hit at the seventh Havana Biennial last fall, revolves around big color Polaroids of ordinary Cubans posing as they please in a loonily unlikely setting: a sparkling winter wonderland incorporating a bright Alpine backdrop, fake snow underfoot and props that include skis, a sled and Styrofoam snowballs. The original snow-scene set is also here -- pristine, carefully lighted and inviting. They exemplify the best kind of site-specific, political art, one that makes its points effortlessly and travels well (Smith).

"WET!" Luise Ross Gallery, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through today). Some summer group shows just want to have fun, and this one accomplishes the goal with admirable flair and ecumenicism. The slippery subject helps. Wetness is surveyed with a thoroughness that includes geography, food, sport and sex. The artists range from Sigmar Polke to Bill Traylor to Patty Chang and Nicole Eisenman, and the styles are just as various (Smith).

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
From Taipei, Snapshots Full of Atmosphere Show an Accidental Family

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT

 BODY:
The 1990's may well be remembered as a heroic age of Taiwanese art cinema, a period of creative ferment akin to the French New Wave of the late 50's and early 60's. Like Francois Truffaut, Jean-Luc Godard, and Claude Chabrol, a handful of directors -- among them Edward Yang, Hou Hsiao-hsien, and Tsai Ming-liang -- have been making films that simultaneously extend the formal possibilities of the medium and reveal the half-hidden facets and barely audible rhythms of contemporary life. 
 Unlike their French or Italian predecessors, however, these filmmakers have received very little attention in the United States. Their work has been shown mainly at film festivals, in museum and film society retrospectives, or during brief and underpublicized commercial releases. So American audiences --and a number of American critics, including this one -- are only now catching up. One hopes that the warm embrace of Mr. Yang's "Yi Yi" and Wong Kar-Wai's "In the Mood for Love" -- to say nothing of the blockbuster success of Ang Lee's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" -- will sharpen the curiosity of moviegoers and the resolve of distributors to embrace Chinese-language films. 
 In spite of the time lag, the moment seems right: as the American economy slides from exuberance to anxiety, we may be more receptive to the melancholy images of life in the wired, hectic city of Taipei that filter through "Yi Yi"; Mr. Hou's new film, "Millennium Mambo"; and "The River," Mr. Tsai's third feature, completed in 1996 and receiving its belated American opening today, at the Cinema Village. 
Whether or not "The River" is, as some critics have claimed, Mr. Tsai's masterpiece, it is an excellent introduction to his oblique narrative style, his favored themes and his careful, lyrical visual sensibility. The story emerges slowly, with virtually no exposition and minimal dialogue -- for long stretches "The River" resembles a silent film with ambient street noise instead of piano music -- through a series of long shots that are at once naturalistic and meticulously composed. You feel that Mr. Tsai is not staging the action so much as observing it, allowing small gestures and funny-sad coincidences to resonate like the words in a poem. 
The emotions that circulate through the film are as familiar as they are difficult to name. Mr. Tsai presents a tableau of three lonely people who turn out, as if unbeknownst to themselves, to be related -- a mother (Lu Hsiao-ling), a father (Miao Tien), and their son Xiao-kang (Lee Kang-sheng).
The father, when he is not trying to cope with the water that mysteriously floods into his room from the apartment upstairs, seeks out anonymous sex with young men in the city's gay bathhouses. The mother pursues a desultory affair with a pornographer. Their aimless son, after a brief, accidental film career (he plays a drowned corpse floating face down in the river), develops a crippling pain in his neck, which has no apparent cause, and no cure.
His infirmity, like everything else in "The River," wears an aura of metaphor: it might be an Eastern variant of the malaise that Julianne Moore's character suffered in Todd Haynes's "Safe." But though Mr. Tsai's characters are to some extent representative figures drifting in the existential void, they are also odd, lonely individuals grounded in the noise and clutter of their particular place and time, facing predicaments more often comical than terrifying -- or in the manner of silent films, comical to us and terrifying to them.
The father's struggle with the fallibility of modern plumbing (something of a motif for Mr. Tsai: in his first film, "Rebels of the Neon God," the water came up through the floor) and Xiao-kang's attempt to steer his motor scooter in spite of his neck pain are recorded with stoical absurdism.
A strong sexual undercurrent flows through Mr. Tsai's films, breaking through the surface with a shocking intensity that comes not from the explicit display of bodies, but rather from the naked, desperate longing the characters suddenly betray. The sex scene that comes near the end of "The River" is a beautifully shot chiaroscuro of half-concealed limbs and damp bath-house shadows that resolves into one of the most devastating and unassimilable images in recent cinema. 
It's worth waiting for. The pace of "The River" is slow, and Mr. Tsai's minimal camera movement and deliberate editing may take some getting used to, especially in an era of hectic cutting and hand-held hyperactivity. But he is one of those filmmakers whose visions, once encountered, are hard to shake, a rare director who seems, even at this late date, to be reinventing the medium and rediscovering the world.

THE RIVER

Directed by Tsai Ming-liang; written (in Mandarin and Taiwanese, with English subtitles) by Mr. Tsai Ming-liang, Yang Bi-ying and Tsai Yi-chun; director of photography, Lao Peng-jung; edited by Chen Sheng-chang and Lei Cheng-ching; art director, Lee Pao-lin; produced by Hsu Li-kong and Chiu Shun-ching; released by Leisure Time Features/Kimstim. At the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Running time: 115 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Lee Kang-sheng (Xiao-kang), Miao Tien (Father), Lu Hsiao-ling (Mother), Chen Chao-jung (Young man at sauna), Chen Shiang-chyi (Xiao-kang's lover), Chang Long (Mother's lover) and Ann Hui (CF Director).

HEADLINE: Stocks Relapse As Japan Waits For Changes 

BYLINE:  By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 26 

 BODY:
Japan's stock market, which rallied in the spring on hope that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi would be able to pull the country out of a decade-long slump, has slipped to pre-election levels as the premier has failed to explain how he would handle nonperforming bank loans and as the global slowdown curbs corporate profit. 
 After Mr. Koizumi took office in April, the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose from a low of 11,819 in March to this year's high of 14,529 in May. By Monday, the index had retreated to 11,609.63, the lowest point in 16 years. It closed at 11,858.56 today, down 33 points. 
 "The market does not believe the nonperforming loans can be cleaned up in just two to three years" as the prime minister has promised, said Naoya Orime, chief investment officer at Merrill Lynch Investment Managers in Tokyo.
"They have to show exactly how many bad loans there are," Mr. Orime said, "whether the government will inject capital into banks -- and if they do, what will they do about the management" to prevent the problem from recurring.
When Mr. Koizumi became prime minister, his maverick image and reformist talk fascinated people so much that his popularity ratings soared as high as 90 percent in some polls. Investors, particularly in Europe and the United States, were swept up in the enthusiasm. "Investors began to buy on expectations," Mr. Orime said.
But optimism waned, and the market fizzled, as the government failed to say specifically how it would clean up bad loans, analysts said. In recent months, those concerns were compounded by the slowdown of global demand for electronics and other consumer goods that underpin Japan's export-oriented economy.
Banks have been among the biggest losers. Mizuho Holdings, the world's largest bank by assets, is trading at about half the price at which it started trading last September after its creation by the merger of the Industrial Bank of Japan, Fuji Bank and Dai-Ichi Kangyo.
Analysts said that the parliamentary election on Sunday could reverse the tide if the Liberal Democratic Party wins by a wide enough margin to give Mr. Koizumi a mandate to pursue change.

HEADLINE: Alcatel Reports a Profit But Plans More Job Cuts 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 26 

 BODY:
Alcatel, joining other telecommunications-equipment makers worldwide, said today that it would pare its work force by about 18 percent this year to reduce operating costs, even as it posted an operating profit of 136 million euros, or about $120 million, in the second quarter.
 The company, which earlier this month outlined plans to shed 3,500 jobs, said it now intended to lay off 20,000 of its 110,000 workers by the end of the year. Alcatel said its goal was to reduce its operating expenses by one billion euros, or about $882 million. 
 The company, which failed in a bid to buy Lucent Technologies two months ago, also announced the resignation of Krish Prabhu, its American chief operating officer and the architect of its strategies in the United States. Mr. Prabhu, 46, who was considered a possible successor to the present chairman and chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, 63, said he was leaving to have more time for personal pursuits.
As expected, Alcatel reported a net loss of 3.1 billion euros in the quarter ($2.73 billion), most of it related to one-time reorganization charges, including the layoffs, and to write-downs of inventory. The write-downs were in response to a glut of installed fiber optic capacity in the United States and Europe and hundreds of millions of dollars of fiber optic equipment in warehouses that probably cannot be sold.
The operating profit, which focuses on regular business activities, declined from 592 million euros a year ago ($521 million). The figures did not include those of a cable affiliate, Nexans, which Alcatel floated on the stock market in June. Alcatel, based in Paris, said revenue in the quarter fell to 6.7 billion euros, about $5.9 billion, from 7.6 billion euros, or about $6.70 billion, a year ago. 
The announcements are the latest examples of the turmoil shaking telecommunications. A drop in spending by telephone companies and data-transmission services has recently hammered the stocks of companies like Alcatel that supply equipment to the industry. Shares of Alcatel rose 4.6 percent today, to close at 17.70 euros in Paris, but the company's stock has fallen 70 percent in value since the first of the year.
On Wednesday, the big German electrical and electronics group, Siemens, pledged cutbacks and fired the head of it telephone networks unit, after reporting a loss in its fiscal third quarter.
At Alcatel, Mr. Tchuruk said the company, whose main North American site is in Plano, Tex., is scrambling to cope with the industrywide slump. 
"Due to the effects of reorganization programs that are under way and will have an effect, particularly in the fourth quarter," he said, "Alcatel expects to make an operating profit in the full year."
Mr. Tchuruk (pronounced CHOO-rook) played down the departure of Mr. Prabhu, saying that he would retain a seat on Alcatel's board and would continue to be the company's technology adviser. In recent newspaper articles in which he hinted that he might resign, Mr. Prabhu has said he will consider returning to Alcatel if the top job is offered.
Mr. Tchuruk said he did not expect to see any improvement in the United States economy before the end of the year, at the earliest. The slowdown in the United States, he said, risked spreading to parts of Europe, as is already the case in Britain.
He said the absence of a recovery in the United States meant that revenue in the third quarter would be weak, though he expected revenue for the year to be close to that of last year.

HEADLINE: Sony Posts Loss, Citing Weak Sales And a Recall 

BYLINE:  By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 26 

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation said today that weakening worldwide sales of electronics products and costs arising from a large recall of cellular handsets caused it to lose 30.1 billion yen, or $243 million, in the first quarter. It also cut its profit forecast for the year by 40 percent.
 "The business environment surrounding Sony in the first quarter was characterized by clear economic slowdown in such primary markets as the U.S., Europe, Japan and Asia," the company stated. 
 "It has become much more challenging as demand falls, supply builds up and price competition intensifies."
While group revenue for the three- month period rose 4.6 percent year on year, when measured in yen, the company acknowledged that the depreciating value of the Japanese currency artificially inflated the figure. Sales would have been 3 percent lower in local currency terms, Sony said.
Sales of electronics goods fell 15 percent in Europe compared with the quarter last year. Sales in the United States showed a decrease of 10 percent.
The game division, which makes the PlayStation console, lost 3.1 billion yen on an operating basis during the quarter as high operating costs more than offset rising sales of its PlayStation 2 hardware and software.
Adding to earnings troubles was the decision to recall more than one million faulty mobile handsets in Japan between May and July. Sony took a charge of 13.1 billion yen during the quarter for the recall.
The company is now bracing for gloomy results for the coming fiscal year. Where it forecast 150 billion yen in group net profit for the fiscal year 2001 as of April this year, it now foresees a net profit of 90 billion yen. And where it predicted 8 trillion yen in group net sales, it now expects 7.7 trillion yen in revenue.
"In many product categories, sales during the quarter were below our projections as of April because of slower demand and price falls in major markets," the company's statement said.
In New York trading, shares in Sony fell $5.95, or more than 10 percent, to close at $51.86.
In the last two months, the stock has fallen more than 35 percent. The earnings were released after markets in Japan had closed.

HEADLINE: Conspiracy Indictment Over Construction Bids 

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
A big American construction company and an affiliate were indicted yesterday on charges of participating in a vast criminal conspiracy to cheat the government out of tens of millions of dollars for Egyptian water projects undertaken as part of the Camp David peace accords.
 The indictment, filed in Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., accuses Bill Harbert International, which is based there, and a foreign affiliate, Bilhar International Establishment, of participating in the scheme with an array of other companies. Also charged were the former president of Bilhar, Elmore Roy Anderson, and Peter W. Schmidt, a former official with Philipp Holzmann A.G. of Frankfurt. Philipp Holzmann pleaded guilty to a criminal complaint last year. 
 According to the indictment, the conspiracy lasted more than eight years and involved the rigging of contract bids submitted in the late 1980's and early 1990's to the Agency for International Development, which was financing Egyptian water projects that resulted from the Middle East peace accords reached during the Carter administration.
Contracts were supposed to be awarded through competitive bidding. But the companies subverted the process through payments of bribes and kickbacks to other possible bidders, fraudulent billings to the government and the laundering of cash through Swiss bank accounts, court records show.
The conspirators included at least six international construction companies, which collectively referred to themselves as the Frankfurt Group, according to people briefed on the case. The companies were either American or American subsidiaries of European concerns.
David Rubinger, a spokesman for Harbert, said that the company's lawyers were still reviewing the legal documents and had no immediate comment. Dr. Ralf Neubauer, an executive at Holzmann in Germany, said that Mr. Schmidt had resigned from the company several years ago and that the company did not have a telephone number for him.
Charles Murphy, a lawyer who represents Mr. Anderson, said that his client planned to plead not guilty to the charges. Mr. Murphy said he had not yet read the indictment and could not discuss it in detail.
He said Mr. Anderson, 74, had retired in 1996. "This investigation has been going on for six years," Mr. Murphy said. "Mr. Anderson is anxious to get this matter behind him and clear his name." 
The investigation has already resulted in three other guilty pleas, including one from a division of ABB Ltd., the Swiss engineering giant, which agreed to pay $63 million in fines and restitution.
At the center of the scheme, as described in the indictment and related court records, was an unincorporated joint venture between Harbert and the J. A. Jones Construction Company, a subsidiary of Holzmann in Charlotte, N.C. The Harbert-Jones joint venture submitted some of the winning bids for the contracts and paid other participants to inflate their proposals, the records show.
The indictment describes illegal bid-rigging on three water projects, known as Contracts 20A, 29 and 7. The defendants began their participation, the indictment says, about May 1988, when they flew to Frankfurt to meet with Holzmann executives for the purpose of discussing bid-rigging on the contracts. Over the next few months, Holzmann held discussions with other companies, agreeing to pay them for inflating their bids on the project or for not bidding at all. 
According to court records, companies involved in the conspiracy were able to obtain profits of as much as 60 percent on the Egyptian water projects -- a return that would be almost certainly impossible to obtain under competitive bidding. Indeed, some of the companies went to great lengths to hide their profits, charging fictitious expenses from related companies to decrease the returns shown on their books. 
The investigation began almost six years ago after a top financial officer at one company noticed improper wire transfers and other transactions. That executive then brought those matters to the attention of the Justice Department.

HEADLINE: Powell, in Hanoi, Pauses To Put the Past to Rest 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, July 26 

 BODY:
From the moment his plane first flew over Vietnam on Tuesday to his performance at a foreign ministers' cabaret tonight in the last hours of his visit, memories of fighting a war here more than 30 years ago have crowded in on Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.
 As his official Boeing 757 descended into the airfield here, he said today, he moved into the cockpit to watch the familiar landscape and hear the echo of voices he once knew well. 
 "We came over Thunder Ridge, which is well known to all of our Air Force pilots," he told reporters, referring to a craggy peak that poked dark and tall through white clouds. "And then to hear the voice of the air traffic controller in the tower, greeting our pilot and giving him instructions and to hear that voice, that accent, brought back lots of memories from years ago." 
Secretary Powell had returned to Vietnam as part of a five-country tour of the region, to attend the annual foreign ministers' conference of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. On Friday, he travels to South Korea, before proceeding to China.
But this morning, on the last full day of his visit here, he found himself attending to matters touching on his years in the Vietnam War. The secretary drove through the steaming streets of the capital, his black Chevrolet Suburban slicing a path through the motorcycle rush hour, to preside over a ceremony commemorating United States efforts to recover the remains of American soldiers missing in action.
While chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Powell helped create the group that has been conducting the searches for eight years.
His duty this morning was particularly haunting, because it was to honor seven Americans and nine Vietnamese who died in an air crash this year while searching territory where Americans were believed to have been killed many years ago.
"All of my buddies came home," the secretary said, after placing two incense sticks at the base of a marble plaque engraved with the 16 names. "Even those who died, we got the remains. But for the ones who did not, there is a longing in the hearts of their family members, their fellow veterans."
The most recent losses served to illustrate, he said, that the "casualties of the war continue to be legion." 
On a lighter note, the secretary broke away from the Asean conference this afternoon to stroll through Hanoi.
"It reminded me of my days in Hue and Quang Tri," he said, referring to cities in the former South Vietnam. "Same kinds of shops -- smiling people, happy people."
Had he not been trailed by cameras and pressed by diplomatic matters, the secretary said, he would have liked to sit down somewhere and have a cup of tea or a swig of what he called "ba-ba-ba," the Vietnamese beer brand 333. 
Even with his limited exposure, the secretary seemed to catch the essence of this humming city, where from dawn well into the night, trade, manufacturing, eating and socializing spill out into the streets.
"Just the movement and the shops and the sense of small entrepreneurial activity is pretty exciting," he said.
A stage show of foreign ministers performing for their peers has become something of a ritual at the closing Asean dinner. Tonight, the secretary found himself once again drawing on his Vietnam experiences.
In his first tour in the early 60's, Captain Powell entertained his Vietnamese colleagues with his rendition of the country-and-western song "El Paso." 
On stage this evening, accompanied by a chorus of what were billed as "eight unnamed senior officials," the secretary sang the song again. Clad in a blue shirt and a red bandana, he played the role of the cowboy who falls in love with a Mexican girl. Keeping to the song's story line, General Powell the cowboy was challenged in his love by a wild young man who moves in on his girl, called Makiko tonight because she was played by Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka of Japan.
The show was off limits to reporters. But according to a description provided afterward by one of the unnamed senior officials, the secretary, who in real life can be a bit of a ham, did a mean job of the cowboy, wielding a gun and shooting the interloper. The unnamed officials formed a posse that stormed on stage to hunt and shoot him down. As he fell to his knees, Secretary Powell was blessed with a last kiss from the Japanese foreign minister. There was much applause, an official from the chorus said. 
Asked how the secretary performed as a singer, the official replied, "O.K., but there is no danger of him losing his day job." 
The secretary faced stiff competition from other countries' representatives. A highly rehearsed Australian delegation, outfitted with a surfboard, roared on stage with a boisterous rendition of the Beach Boys' tune "Kokimo," with new lines sending up the audience. The Russians, with Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov playing a czar on his way to Hanoi, were apparently an especially big hit.
At one point, Czar Ivanov received a telephone call from Washington. The caller? "Mad, but all right," said a voice, playing on the name of former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who reveled in performing at Asean galas. 
Her message to the czar? "Colin Powell will not have the guts to go on stage."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Unfazed by Earnings News, Traders Push Shares Higher

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, as traders and investors looked past bad news from Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard, hoping that tax refund checks, on top of the six interest rate cuts, would spur economic growth and corporate profits.
 "Some are pessimistic about earnings two quarters out, but they're probably taking a naive stance," said Dan Rivera, chief investment officer at the large-capitalization growth division of American Express Asset Management. "We've got interest rates and fiscal policy on our side." 
 Some traders said that yesterday's rise in stock prices in the face of sour earnings reports suggested that sellers might be moving aside. "The market continues to shake off the newest developments," said Keith Gertson, head of Nasdaq trading for Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "Every day the resistance continues, it builds conviction that the market is building a base. Most people anticipate a rally of 3 to 5 percent because the market has absorbed the bad news so well." 
All three main market indexes rose yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average erased an early decline to close up 49.96 points, or 0.48 percent, at 10,455.63. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.44 points, or 1.04 percent, to 1,202.93. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite gained 38.64 points, or nearly 2 percent, to 2,022.96. Market breadth was positive.
Seven of the 10 most active Nasdaq stocks rose, including Cisco Systems, up 68 cents, to $19.38.
Wall Street economists and analysts today will be watching a vital indicator of the economy's health, when the government provides an initial reading of gross domestic product figures for the second quarter. Economists polled by Reuters forecast growth of 0.9 percent.
Despite negative earnings reports and projections, some on Wall Street are betting that technical indicators point to a rebound in stocks. Lance Zipper, managing director of equity trading at Brean Murray & Company, saw "some bottom-fishing, some short covering" yesterday.
"People are beginning to feel the worst is behind us," Mr. Zipper said.
Trading was active with 1.21 billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, slightly more than June's average volume.
Compaq erased an early loss to gain 38 cents, closing at $14.50. The Houston-based company, a leading producer of personal computers, reported sharply lower profit late Wednesday and also said that revenue would keep sliding.
A sales warning and job cuts from Hewlett-Packard limited the Dow's gain, after the company, a leading printer and computer maker, forecast yesterday that revenue for the current quarter would fall 14 percent to 16 percent from the period a year earlier. Hewlett said it would cut 6,000 jobs. Its shares slumped $1.68, to $24, a 52-week closing low.
Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer at New Amsterdam Partners, noted that the market "sells off when the reports hit the tape, so I would expect things to stay fairly sloppy for a while."
In regular-session trading, before an announcement by JDS Uniphase of a damaging restatement of earnings, stocks of optical networking companies and data storage manufacturers, two badly battered sectors, were having a strong day. Big movers included Corning, up $1.79, to $15.56, and Brocade Communications Systems, which surged $3.80, to $32.70. --------------------

Treasuries Are Higher
By The Associated Press
Bond prices rallied yesterday, spurred by data showing a drop in orders for durable goods. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 11/32, to a price of 99 2/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.13 percent from 5.17 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32, to 97 4/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.57 percent from 5.59 percent on Wednesday.

PERSON: Robert O. Lowery 

HEADLINE: Robert Lowery, First Black Fire Commissioner, Dies at 85 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Robert O. Lowery, the city's first black fire commissioner who served at a time when arson-fueled blazes raged through the city's minority neighborhoods, died on Tuesday in Manhattan.
 He was 85 and had homes in Washington Heights and on the island of St. Vincent, his daughter Trudy Erwin said. 
 Mr. Lowery, the first black to head the fire department of a major American city, was also the first commissioner appointed by Mayor John V. Lindsay after his election in 1965. "It was a huge appointment," said Charles J. Hynes, who was fire commissioner in the Koch administration and is now the district attorney in Brooklyn. 
Former Mayor David N. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, said, "He opened doors for all of us."
Mr. Lowery said that Mayor Lindsay "put it on the line" with his appointment. "Let's face it," he said in a 1965 interview with The New York Post several weeks before taking office, "there will be people watching, both white and Negro, simply because I'm a Negro."
Mr. Hynes said the Fire Department had a history of "the most vile kind of segregation." When Mr. Lowery joined the department as a firefighter in 1941, blacks were not allowed to use the kitchen utensils and had to sleep in separate areas.
Despite Mr. Lowery's persistent efforts to improve race relations, he said in a 1970 interview with The New York Times that the bitter racial tensions that persisted in the newly integrated environment might have been worse than under the earlier segregation.
"I think maybe we should go back to the old ways," he said, arguing that putting out fires, his pre-eminent concern, had been easier before integration.
Three years later, when Mr. Lowery resigned, his friend Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President, charged that he was forced out of office because "John Lindsay never really shared any meaningful power with black people." Mr. Lowery immediately endorsed Comptroller Abraham D. Beame, the Democrat who succeeded Mr. Lindsay as mayor.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Sutton specified that the "hostile environment" Mr. Lowery confronted was not the fault of Mr. Lindsay, who died last December, "but the people he worked with." 
Mr. Sutton said the first minority or woman to serve in a major post is often "a lonely person." He said, "He just got tired of it."
It might have made anybody tired. During his time as commissioner, Mr. Lowery had to deal with an epidemic of false alarms, labor disputes and an increase in deadly fires, many as a result of arson.
An alarming problem was the attack on firefighters with bricks and other weapons, by residents who saw the presence of the mostly white firefighters as an intrusion, as they battled fires in black and Hispanic neighborhoods. The firefighters then began to carry blackjacks, according to articles in The New York Times in 1968.
In interviews, Mr. Lowery professed not to know about the blackjacks, but strongly criticized those who attacked his men. "If we can't get better cooperation from the citizenry in the areas where we're having these problems," he warned, "there is the possibility that fire service there and the protection will diminish."
Robert Oliver Lowery was born on April 20, 1916, in Buffalo, and moved to Harlem when he was 9. He started courses at the City College of New York hoping to become a lawyer, but economic hardship forced him to take a job in 1934 as an usher at the Alhambra Theater in Harlem for $10 a week. He stayed six years, becoming head usher for $17 a week.
After he passed several civil service exams, he worked as a subway conductor for a year before the Fire Department offered him a job. "Had the police department called first, I am sure I would have become a cop," he said.
There were only 50 blacks in the department then, and he quickly became a protege of Wesley Williams, one of the first black fire chiefs. Through Mr. Williams, he became active in the Vulcan Society, an organization of black firefighters.
He was promoted to fire marshal in 1946, and that same year won commendation for arresting a man for 30 acts of arson and burglary. In 1960, he was cited for capturing an armed arsonist, and the next year became an acting lieutenant in the Bureau of Fire Investigation.
In 1963, he was appointed Deputy Fire Commissioner. When Mr. Lindsay later called to interview him about fires, and he made a strong case for forceful fire prevention, but his only ambition was to be retained as deputy commissioner.
The announcement of his appointment to commissioner, as the Republican mayor's first appointment, startled many besides Mr. Lowery, a lifelong Democrat, and went well beyond extending a hand across party lines.
"New York had known commissioners who were persons of color before Lowery, but their chances had been limited to departments like welfare, where the majority of those they served were persons of color, too," Murray Kempton wrote in Newsday in 1991. "A black fire commissioner had been heretofore inconceivable."
He suddenly headed a department of 13,500 of whom 600 were blacks. He addressed the racial issue straightforwardly, striving to increase the proportion of blacks and the sensitivity of whites. He also raised the number of black firefighters assigned to black neighborhoods, as well as the number of blacks in leadership roles.
At the same time, the city's own investigation commissioner was looking into a rumor campaign against Mr. Lowery that turned out to consist of unsubstantiated claims that he sold narcotics and answers to promotion exams to black firefighters. Mr. Lowery contended that the rumors were circulated by a small minority of firefighters of "John Birch or Minutemen philosophy."
His overwhelming concern, however, was dealing with the city's epidemic of fire. "He lived and breathed it 24 hours a day," said Ms. Erwin, who remembers ceaseless fire alarms sounding in the family's apartment. "It was life and death."
After retirement he stayed active in civil rights causes. In 1991, he wrote a letter to Newsday strongly protesting a cartoon depicting Clarence Thomas, whose nomination to the Supreme Court he opposed, as a shoeshine boy. 
Mr. Lowery is survived by his wife, Viviane; daughters Ms. Erwin and Leslie Lowery, both of Washington Heights; a sister, Florence Washington of Baltimore; and a granddaughter.
He once summed up his philosophy in a speech to the Vulcan Society. "Always remember that America -- including many white firefighters -- will never let you forget that your recognizable ancestors were brought to this country in chains and that they believe you are inferior," he said.
"It is up to you to keep proving over and over again that they were wrong."

HEADLINE: New York's Sewage Was a Texas Town's Gold 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY

DATELINE: SIERRA BLANCA, Tex. 

 BODY:
There is not much here anymore, if there was ever much of anything to begin with. The town's main street is coated in dust, and the old movie house is long shuttered. The one sign of activity -- the traffic moving along elevated Interstate 10 -- is a reminder that the modern world rarely stops here.
 The other reminder can be found on the outskirts of this tiny town, where freight cars are being unloaded for the last time. The last sludge train from New York City arrived this month, leaving its last shipment of what officials describe as "bio-solids" but what others call treated sewage. 
 The dump in Sierra Blanca, one of the biggest sludge dumps in the world, is going out of business. 
"We've survived before without it, and I'm sure we still will," said James A. Peace, the Hudspeth County judge and the area's highest elected official.
The news came unexpectedly in June and was greeted with a mixed response in this town of 600 people in the vast, empty country about 90 miles southeast of El Paso. For local critics and environmentalists who have fought the sludge operation and recent efforts to build a nuclear waste dump here, it is a long-awaited victory. For others, it is an economic blow, resulting in the loss of 40 jobs and the planned closing of the town's biggest private employer.
"A lot of people are going to be hunting jobs," said Kay Scarbrough, the county tax assessor, "and there are not any jobs here."
It is hard to imagine places more different than New York and Sierra Blanca, and the contrast has always underscored the mercenary marriage between the nation's largest city and the small town where it has dumped its sewage since 1992. That year, after Congress had prohibited the city from dumping its sludge in the Atlantic Ocean, New York signed contracts with several companies to treat and transport its sewage. One of them was a Long Island joint venture, which began shipping up to 250 tons every day on the 2,065-mile journey to West Texas. The Texas Observer, the political journal, recently called it "the poo-poo choo-choo."
The Long Island company, Merco, had first sought a site in Oklahoma, but after meeting resistance there learned about a failed resort called the Mile High Ranch in Sierra Blanca. The company purchased the 81,000-acre area so that the treated sludge could be spread on "application areas" as if it were fertilizer. The company rotates the areas of land chosen to absorb the sludge.
Environmentalists and critics immediately accused Texas officials of ramming the project through approval. They have long argued that the sludge has exposed the area to health risks and other problems. Texas Tech University has studied the project and has found no evidence of contamination.
"If there was ever a case of environmental injustice, Sierra Blanca was it," said Bill Addington, an outspoken critic who also runs a general store in town. Two years ago, Mr. Addington helped fight plans to build a nuclear waste dump in Sierra Blanca, and he considered the closing of the Merco operation a bittersweet victory. "This material has polluted a very large area that used to be pristine," Mr. Addington said.
But Tom Gillane, Merco's local operations manager, said all the sludge shipments had been carefully tested to prevent contamination and had met environmental standards under New York law. He dismissed the local stories of three-legged deer as the rural equivalents of urban legends and even said the project had helped the environment.
"We're enhancing the natural grass growth," Mr. Gillane said. He added that two nearby ranches leased parts of the land so that cattle could graze on the grass. "The majority of the people are very proud that this operation is here."
There is an odor, although exactly how bad is a matter of interpretation. "If we get a little rain and then a north breeze, then you can smell it here in town," Ms. Scarbrough said. "It smells like a hog farm." 
Wayne West, who once shipped livestock for a living and now runs a local garage, was more charitable."You're asking somebody who's been in the livestock transportation business all his life," Mr. West said, "so to me it smells like money."
No one in Sierra Blanca had any warning that after so many years and so much controversy, the sludge train would soon make its last stop.
Geoffrey Ryan, spokesman for the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, said the decision was based on economics and would save the city about $3 million a year. He said the city had exercised an option to cancel the Merco contract because New York could not generate enough sludge for all five of the companies that were contracted to handle its sludge. Merco, he said, was tied for the most expensive rate.
"It is simply a case where maintaining the five contracts was costing us $2 million to $3 million a year," Mr. Ryan said.
Merco will shut down in Sierra Blanca on Tuesday. Mr. Addington worried that the company could win another contract to store another city's sludge, but Mr. Gillane, the Merco manager, was skeptical.
Mr. Peace, the county judge, said the local school may lose 14 of its 120 students. He went to New York once and found it too big for his liking. But it speaks to the economic desperation of small, rural towns like Sierra Blanca that he would not mind if the sludge train kept coming.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Amid Jingles And Slogans, A Sober Mood

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Hear that plaintive noise emanating from Madison Avenue? That is the sound of the national advertising economy still bumping along the bottom far longer than industry executives had feared.
 When the economy suddenly slowed late last year, most advertisers, advertising agencies and media companies took it in stride, estimating that a recovery would begin by the second half of 2001, or right about now. Certainly by the fourth quarter. 
 But now, after repeatedly scaling back their expectations, even the optimists do not expect a comeback in the advertising business until the second quarter of 2002 -- or maybe the second half.
Some pessimists do not anticipate a return to normal growth and spending until -- brace yourself -- 2003. 
"That's a long way away," said Susan Friedman, president of her own executive recruiting firm for agencies.
The implications go well beyond Madison Avenue. Advertising spending in the United States, which set a record last year at $243.7 billion, has not declined from one year to the next since 1991, when spending fell 1.2 percent from 1990. But now, with estimates that spending by marketers in 2001 will decline 2 percent to 3 percent from 2000, that means about $4.8 billion to $7.3 billion less. And even though this year should still turn out to be the second best on record, well above 1999, that shortfall from the pace set in 2000 is likely to have significant consequences.
For instance, many favorite consumer brands and stores may disappear as marketers and retailers consolidate or go out of business. More advertising agencies could close, and those remaining could lay off more employees in addition to the thousands already let go.
Television networks could cut back production of series pilots for coming seasons, potentially jeopardizing their appeal to viewers. More magazines and newspapers may close or reduce the resources devoted to editorial content, potentially weakening their appeal to readers.
"Everybody has been somewhat blindsided by how quickly things fell apart and how long it's continuing," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, the industry trade organization.
"We're not seeing a lot of optimism out there," Mr. Drake added. That is a sobering note from a field where an optimistic outlook was once standard issue along with a gray flannel suit.
Already, the industry's bible, Advertising Age, declared in its July 2 issue that this year has turned into "a bust" with no relief in sight until "well into" 2002.
"We're all shaken by the steepness of the decline," said Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive at Conde Nast Publications in New York, the unit of Advance Publications that owns familiar magazines from A (Allure) to V (Vogue).
"It's very difficult to keep everyone focused and innovative and to have the same level of tenacity," Mr. Florio added, "when you go into a publisher's meeting and someone holds up Advertising Age and the cover says 'Write It Off.' " 
Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst who follows the advertising industry for Morgan Stanley in New York, turned to a twist on a familiar metaphor to describe the current mood.
"The problem is, there's no light at the end of the tunnel, just a belief the tunnel can't go on forever," Mr. Russell said. And when the tunnel's terminus actually comes into view, he added, "it's likely we'll get a muted recovery, rather than leaping back." 
That is because consumers, who have kept their wallets and purses relatively open even as corporate America hunkered down, are likely to be more cautious in their spending.
"People are holding their breath at what consumers will do," said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst who follows Madison Avenue for Merrill Lynch in New York. But the pessimism within the advertising and marketing world could also become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
"If advertising is at a tepid level," she added, meaning that major marketers decide to trim their ad budgets or keep them flat, "the result is a fairly modest recovery instead of a robust recovery" because the stimulus to encourage consumers to spend will be muted.
In a survey last month by Myers Reports in New York, the most frequent estimate of when the recovery would arrive was mid-2002. Just three months earlier, respondents in a similar study pegged the recovery's arrival at early next year.
"If anything, you could argue we're not being conservative enough" in pushing back the arrival of the upturn, said Jack Myers, chief economist at Myers Reports, which publishes media and research newsletters. "I think there will be no real improvement, no real growth, in the market until 2003, maybe 2004, when the Summer Olympics, the presidential election and a recovery in technology and new media will all be factors."
Putting aside the differing views of when advertising will stop bouncing along the bottom, everyone agrees on one point: Though the current economy is not technically in a recession -- generally considered two consecutive quarters in which the overall economy declines -- it is affecting everybody very much like one.
"What's surprised me is how uniform the downturn is," said David McMurry, an analyst who follows the advertising industry for Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. "There's really no part of the business that is less susceptible to it or hasn't been affected."
One reason for that, Mr. McMurry said, is that "since the recession, the fantastic 10-year period of growth we enjoyed was driven not so much by Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola and General Motors increasing ad spending but by new categories of marketers like financial services, telecommunications, technology, pharmaceuticals that weren't advertising much or at all 10 years ago."
But now, he added, "they're slashing ad spending, sometimes by 75 percent, and when they're such drivers of the growth, their putting on the brakes really slows everything down." 
So, Mr. McMurry has already reduced his 2002 earnings estimates for three giant worldwide agency holding companies, Havas Advertising and the Publicis Groupe, both in Paris, and the WPP Group in London.
Another reason Madison Avenue and the media world feel like they are in a recession is the large number of layoffs and closings affecting thousands of workers.
Agencies shutting their doors include three in New York -- Dweck; Favara & Raffle Advertising; and Warwick Baker O'Neill -- and one in Middletown, Conn. -- KGA Advertising. In addition, agencies are closing offices; among them are the Boston office of Deutsch, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the San Francisco offices of Lowe Lintas & Partners, also owned by Interpublic, and Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Publicis. Publications being closed or absorbed into others include Business 2.0, Family PC, Institutional Investor, Jump and Walking magazines.
More agencies "are owned by holding companies" than a decade ago, Mr. Drake of the agency association said. They are more likely to be publicly traded and run by executives who tend "not to put up with income shortfalls very long" because Wall Street expects them to react rapidly in an effort to restore profit growth.
By comparison, "privately held agencies could try to ride things out," he added, without making so many layoffs so quickly.
That was evident yesterday when Interpublic, the publicly held agency company that is the world's largest, reported a second-quarter loss of $110.2 million. "Aggressive cost cuts" are required, said Sean F. Orr, chief financial officer at Interpublic in New York, including the closing or merging of about 75 facilities.
Then, too, there has not been a slowdown or downturn for a decade, meaning that many top managers are used to only good times and were not around -- in any capacity -- during the last squeeze.
"It doesn't have to be bad," Ms. Friedman, the executive recruiter said, "to be bad."
By the same token, Madison Avenue is not waiting until it gets good to try to make it good. Agencies and media companies are moving to remind marketers that they ought to keep advertising in tough times to prepare for the inevitable recovery -- whenever it may arrive.
Right after the Ad Age headline, "Write It Off," Mr. Florio at Conde Nast said, "I wrote a memo to all my people that we will not throw in the towel in the middle of the year."
"While certainly being sober about the business realities," he added, "we need to continue to work hard."
The Magazine Publishers of America, the magazine industry trade association, sponsored a seminar in New York for members on "Advertising in a Soft Economy," which may be repeated in other cities.
"Brands that continue to spend do better in the long haul," said Nina B. Link, president and chief executive at the magazine association. "This is the time we're really pushing that."
The newspaper trade group, the Newspaper Association of America, is taking steps that include a partnership with the Zyman Marketing Group in Atlanta to introduce a marketing initiative to help increase advertising revenue.
"We're hopeful we've bottomed out," said John F. Sturm, president and chief executive at the newspaper association in Vienna, Va., "but at our annual marketing conference this week in Washington, our whole focus was on revenue-generating ideas like special programs to package advertising to make it more attractive to smaller advertisers."
Can all those moves help turn the tide? Well, the industry can certainly hope so.
"Just as nobody saw the rapidity of the slowdown, and it slowed down very quickly, it can turn around very, very quickly," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at West End Communications/Consulting in New York.
After all, "companies that sell goods and services have to keep telling consumers why they need to keep buying those goods and services," he added. "That isn't going to change."
