HEADLINE: Freed Chinese Scholar, Still Defiant, Returns to the U.S. 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER

DATELINE: STERLING, Va., July 26 

 BODY:
After five months in a Beijing jail, an American-based Chinese scholar returned to the United States today and promptly defied the very Chinese authorities who had convicted her of spying and sentenced her to 10 years in prison two days ago.
 "Before I departed Beijing, I was warned not to talk about anything, not to talk about my time, my experience, in China in any form, which includes meeting with you guys here, writing articles, writing books in the future," the scholar, Gao Zhan, said at a news conference upon arriving at Dulles International Airport. "But with America standing behind me, with these fine people standing behind me, I'm not scared." 
 Ms. Gao, a sociologist and a fellow at the School for International Service at American University in Washington, was arrested by the Chinese authorities in February and held in isolation for several months. She was not allowed to meet with her lawyer until July 10, two weeks before her trial on charges of collecting intelligence materials for Taiwan. 
Flanked by her husband, Xue Donghua, and Senator George F. Allen, a Virginia Republican, who was on hand to welcome home the resident of his state, Ms. Gao said that, despite the Chinese authorities' prohibition on discussing any aspects of her time in custody, "I believe that you will see my story in my article or my book." Today, however, she sidestepped some politically sensitive questions on the advice of her husband and Senator Allen.
She was also reunited with her 5-year-old son, Andrew.
"It broke my heart when I was thinking that I couldn't tell a bedtime story to my son every night when I went to sleep," she said about her time in detention. "It broke my heart."
Ms. Gao, a Chinese citizen who has permanent resident status in the United States, was released after intense pressure from Washington, including a telephone call from President Bush to China's president, Jiang Zemin. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is in Vietnam for the annual meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, took up the matter with Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan of China. 
Ms. Gao's release comes two days before Secretary Powell is scheduled to arrive in Beijing.
Speaking in Hanoi today, the secretary said human rights would be high on his agenda when he meets with Chinese leaders on Saturday.
While clearly happy over the release of Ms. Gao and Qin Guangguang, another Chinese with United States residency who was convicted at the same time, Secretary Powell said the focus should be on the political conditions that led to the arrests.
"It is not so much individual cases that should be our principal focus and concern, but the system, the system that occasionally might go after people who perhaps should not be gone after, or who are not being given the full protection of law, and their universal human rights might be trampled upon," he said. 
Mr. Bush was asked today why he thought China had released Ms. Gao and Mr. Qin. Both had been granted medical parole, though Mr. Qin is thought to still be in Beijing, where he works for an American pharmaceuticals company.
"Perhaps," Mr. Bush said, "China is beginning to realize that as she begins to deal with Western nations, she's going to have to make better decisions on human rights."
At her brief news conference, Ms. Gao was asked what she felt about Beijing's being awarded the 2008 Olympics. She paused, and appeared to be searching for the answer, when her husband said: "We don't want to talk about political issues here. This is our family reunion."
A moment later, however, Ms. Gao came back to the question.
"That day was very special day for myself also," she said. "At 10 o'clock, I was called out, out of my cell, and on that moment, right at the announcement of Beijing's sponsorship for the Olympic Games, I was formally accused of being a spy for Taiwan."
When she was asked how she had been treated during her detention, Senator Allen stepped in.
"First of all," he said to Ms. Gao, "I'm glad you're violating your rules of parole right off the bat and meeting with a free press, something that is missing in China."
He added that he, too, wanted to know the answer to that question. But now was not the time, he said, because Ms. Gao and Mr. Xue have relatives back in China.
"I'm very concerned about my family back there," Ms. Gao said. "So I've been very careful in selecting the words that I'm using."

HEADLINE: Ford Gives Its Chairman A Bigger Role 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company tweaked the delicate relationship between its chief executive and president, Jacques A. Nasser, and its chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., with a move intended to increase Mr. Ford's formal role in decision making.
 Even with the new bureaucratic wrinkle -- the establishment of an office of the chairman and chief executive -- Mr. Nasser will retain his titles and remain in charge of all day-to-day decisions. Mr. Ford will still be referred to as a nonexecutive chairman. The move comes as Ford struggles with a host of challenges. 
 "Jac and Bill discussed this jointly and brought it to the board," said James Vella, a Ford spokesman.
"The timing makes sense because the competition is strengthening and the economy is weakening," Mr. Vella added. "It's increased the pressure on decision making."
Yesterday, Ford stock slipped 41 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $25.09. The shares are down 6.2 percent over the last 52 weeks.
Under the current management structure, Mr. Ford, 44, presides over the board while Mr. Nasser, 53, runs the company, with 14 senior Ford executives reporting to him. Mr. Ford has sought a more active role, however, as the company attends to pressing matters, chiefly lagging auto sales and the continuing fallout from the dispute with the Bridgestone/Firestone Company over the failure of tires on the Ford Explorer.
Under the new arrangement, effective immediately, the senior executives will continue to report to Mr. Nasser but will periodically brief both him and Mr. Ford on a range of issues, with employee, dealer and supplier relations of particular interest to Mr. Ford. Though the move is expected to increase Mr. Ford's role in decision-making discussions, how great a change there will be is not clear.
The two men ascended to their current positions together in 1999, and have presented a unified front. But Mr. Nasser has both set the company's agenda and been its public face while Mr. Ford has kept a low profile.
Many analysts and management experts say the development underscores an already existing ambiguity in the relationship of the two men at the top of the world's largest family-controlled company. But they differed on whether the arrangement was good or bad for Ford.
Power-sharing arrangements "are fragile things and a sign of weakness," said Gerald C. Meyers, a University of Michigan professor specializing in management issues and a former chairman of the American Motors Corporation, now a part of DaimlerChrysler.
"Ordinarily," he added, "it means a company doesn't know what to do."
Mr. Meyers pointed to Citigroup's co-chief executive experiment between Sanford I. Weill and John S. Reed, which ended with Mr. Reed's departure.
"It indicates an unhappiness with what is, without coming up with a clear-cut answer," he said.
John Casesa, a Merrill Lynch analyst, said in a research note that "these changes increase the potential for management distraction at a bad time for Ford."
In his research note, Stephen J. Girsky, the auto analyst at Morgan Stanley, called the move positive. "It will allow Nasser to focus on developing, building and marketing cars, something he is very good at," Mr. Girsky wrote, adding that "the net result will be that Ford will be more involved in the business but Nasser will still be running it."
David A. Nadler, chairman of Mercer Delta Consulting, which specializes in management issues, said that because the arrangement did not mean a sharing of the chief executive role, it could work.
"The theory is that if you have two guys with different strengths, one plus one can equal more than two," Mr. Nadler said. "But if they can't work well together, then it can lead to chaos. It will be interesting to watch how it is executed."
The arrangement comes on the heels of a series of high-level personnel changes after a board meeting two weeks ago. Nicholas V. Scheele, chairman of Ford Europe, was named head of the huge North American operations, and I. Martin Inglis was named chief financial officer.
Many analysts say those changes, which become effective next Wednesday, and the latest development, are aimed at increasing the support around Mr. Nasser, who has had too many responsibilities and has lacked a strong No. 2.
"It looks to me like Nasser's gotten his wings clipped a bit," said David B. Healy of Burnham Securities. "My guess is that it will work. Nasser was spread thin."
Besides the Firestone dispute, Ford faces an aggressive move by foreign automakers, including Toyota Motor and Honda Motor, into the sport utility vehicle market that has contributed to overall erosion in vehicle sales for Ford, as well as weakening economic conditions and some quality and productivity concerns.
Mr. Ford is the great-grandson of Henry Ford, the company's founder, and also, through his mother's side, the great-grandson of Firestone's founder, Harvey S. Firestone. When he assumed his current title, it was the first time since 1979 -- when Mr. Ford's uncle, Henry Ford II, stepped down as chairman and chief executive -- that a Ford held the post of chairman.
Mr. Ford and Mr. Nasser declined to be interviewed yesterday. But in a statement, Mr. Ford said that "we face challenging times and this new structure allows both Jacques and me to work hand-in-hand to lead the company forward and meet these challenges."
And Mr. Nasser said in a statement that "this new office strengthens our working relationship and allows us to react even more quickly to address the key issues facing the business."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Prices Up in Manhattan, But Fewer Co-ops Sell

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
The economy may be on a bumpy trail these days, but the Manhattan residential real estate market appears to be on solid footing, even as it sends out some mixed signals.
 According to two new statistical reports, prices fetched by co-ops and condominiums rose in this year's second quarter, but sales declined compared with the same period last year. The number of days properties remained on the market dropped slightly from the first quarter but remained higher than a year ago. 
 In both reports, the gap between asking and selling prices grew over the year. And even if there were fewer prospective buyers, brokers across the board lamented the lack of inventory. 
The Real Estate Board of New York prepared the data used in the quarterly findings on co-op sales it will distribute next week. Gregory J. Heym, vice president and chief economist for the board, said the data were inconsistent in some aspects.
"Layoffs are continuing to mount, with companies announcing them on a weekly basis, but the unemployment rate is still low enough so that at least here, we think the economy is O.K.," he said. "Real estate has held its value slightly better than most other investments, especially prewar buildings that are still very much in demand. 
"A lot of new home buyers are still entering the market, people whose incomes have risen dramatically in the last few years."
Compiled from figures provided by 26 firms belonging to the Real Estate Board, the report was based on data about 469 co-ops that changed hands in April, May and June, up from 441 in the first quarter but distinctly down from the 618 sold in the second quarter of 2000.
The median sales price for apartments increased in the second quarter, going to $475,000 from $440,000, but remained lower than the $530,000 reached in the third quarter of 2000.
Pointing out that sales of a handful of high-end luxury apartments could skew the totals, Mr. Heym said that prices per room were a more accurate barometer. In the second quarter, studio and one-bedroom apartments commanded a median price of $105,000 per room, up from $90,750 a year earlier; two bedrooms, $158,500 a room, up from $154,250 last year; and three bedrooms, $252,500, up from $227,273. Only in the small category of four or more bedrooms did prices fall, to $335,476 per room from $352,361 last year.
The same trends -- higher selling prices paid by fewer buyers -- surfaced in the Manhattan Market Overview released last week by Douglas Elliman and prepared by Miller Samuel, a residential appraisal company. Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, said the findings showed that the market had resiliency, although he noted that it tended to be a lagging economic indicator.
For co-ops, the median was $417,000, a 14 percent increase over the same period last year, Mr. Miller said. The median price was $365,000 in the first quarter.
In the market for condominiums, which tend to be more expensive, he said the median price was $701,500, up 11 percent from $630,000 in the previous three months and almost 10 percent more than in the same quarter last year, when the median was $640,000. "But," Mr. Miller added, "I believe the median somewhat overstates the size of the increase, since we had a falloff in the sale of smaller apartments. For the first time in the 11 years we've been tracking this, two-bedroom co-ops and condominiums comprise more than 50 percent of total sales at the expense of smaller apartments."
Mr. Miller said the most important change of the quarter was a significant drop in the number of sales, a 19 percent drop, to 1,829 apartments, from 2,257 a year earlier. Sales dropped 10 percent from the first quarter, when 2,039 apartments were sold. The figures combined both co-op and condominium sales and drew from a larger pool of data than the Real Estate Board study.
Both studies detected a tendency toward more negotiation between sellers and buyers. The average discount doubled to 4.1 percent compared with this time last year, Mr. Miller said. "But during the recession of the early 1990's," he said, "the average discount was between 15 and 20 percent, so we consider this normal."

HEADLINE: Ferrer Defines the 'Other New York,' and He Discusses His Plans to Help It 

 BODY:
 Here are excerpts of an interview with Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and a Democratic candidate for mayor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. The Times plans to hold similar sessions with each of the other major candidates.

Q. You've defined your constituency as something you've called "the other New York." I wonder if you would talk more about what the other New York is: Who is "the other New York"? And how is it defined? Is it defined geographically? By ethnic group? By income? By attitude?

A. In fact it's all of them. And I really appreciate the question. Because there are so many who would define "the other New York" only in terms of color. Or only in terms of class. Or only in terms of geography. In fact, it's a place where all of those things intersect. So, for example, people who find themselves unable to find a decent place to live in this city at a price they can afford live everywhere. They live in Woodside. They live on the West Side of Manhattan. They live in Throgs Neck. They live everywhere. One-point-one million children in the school system. They are not exclusively of one color, of one class. And too many of them of all colors and classes and boroughs and communities are trapped in schools that can't work, for a host of reasons. One out of four New Yorkers doesn't have health insurance, therefore no reliable access to regular health care, live everywhere. Most of them are working. They are largely white New Yorkers.
And when fear really is the defining element of the relationship between people and the police in too many places with too many people, the impact of that is widespread. It is frightening how many jurors disqualify themselves when asked the question: Do you believe police testimony? More frightening: how many jurors still harbor grave doubts but remain silent and seated and end up exonerating people who may well be legitimately bad people and should have been convicted. 
So we're paying a price for this all the way through. 

Q. You've defined this often in terms of Giuliani. And people who do not like him or do not think that he has solved their problems, addressed their needs. He won the last election by a large margin. It sounds as though you are addressing a constituency that almost by definition is a minority. Clearly you don't think so or you wouldn't be running. Would you address that?

A. Sure. If this is a tactical discussion, I'm the wrong guy to talk to about this. I can only say it from the vantage point of what I believe. So that, one, the discussion of the policies as we find them and exist now, today, can only be discussed, I think, in the context of the policymaker for the last eight years. Much in the same way that Giuliani discussed the policies of the four years that preceded him. Much in the same way that Dinkins discussed the policies of the 12 years that preceded him. And much in the same way that Koch discussed, not really the policies of the four years that preceded him but the eight years that preceded the four years. That does set the table for at least a discussion.

Q. Do you think jurors are right to distrust police testimony?

A. In some cases I think they have ample justification. Because there has been ample reason to be skeptical. And in other cases, I'm not equipped to evaluate. But I do know this: The skepticism exists. And that is undeniable. I mean that is beyond debate. That it exists is a fact. That it exists in an almost widespread way today is a fact.

Q. But do you think police routinely perjure in the cases?

A. No.

Q. What is the other side of the other New York? In other words, not, in your view, the other New York? Is it Giuliani supporters or who?

A. No, I don't define them that way. There's a New York that works very well and it exists everywhere too. No, this works for me. I have health insurance, my child is getting a great education either in a public school or in a private school, I can pay the rent, I can pay the mortgage.

Q. I think you suggested . . . raises, you want to have after-school programs. . . How do you -- it seems that what you're hinting at is to make life better for the other New York, you're going to tax the other-other New York.

A. I'm not hinting that. And ----

Q. Well, then how else do you pay for it?

A. Well, that's a good question that I hope you will ask everyone because I haven't proposed any initiatives -- any -- where I haven't said where this money will come from. I have not said, for example, I will do this. And how will you pay for it? I'll find the money. That's trying to have it both ways and I think that's -- that's simply singularly lacking in candor. So that, for example, when I propose an after-school program I would tell people how I'd pay for it. When I propose a radical change in negotiating the teacher contract, which includes three essential principles: One, The reform of due process such that the system now and its supervisory personnel may say goodbye to unfit and unqualified teachers, two ----

Q. I don't understand that. You want to make it easier to do that?

A. Oh yes, absolutely. Immediately.

Q. How could you justify taking out 30 percent for however much is needed to raise salaries?

A. Well, it's not the whole 30 percent out of that budget. But I've -- here's where I think Giuliani is more than partially right. There are enormous opportunities for savings in the central administration and in the administration of community school districts. I, for example, have proposed for 18 years the elimination of community school boards. That is truly redundant.

Q. But to send teachers to school during the summer and to give them 30 percent raises, do you have a cost estimate of how much that's --

A. Yes. We laid it out at about $1.1 billion.

Q. Do you think over a billion, or how much of that, do you think, could come from savings in the central administration.

A. In fact, I've laid that out. I believe that there are opportunities in the central administration to pull out about 250 or even more million dollars. Now, in conversations with people at the board, their budget and number and program people, since I made that speech, all of them privately admit to me, you're not wrong. But I know their budget. And in fact, it has bloated.
I believe the mayor also has to be a leader in securing funds, more state aid as a result of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity lawsuit. That's why I was a party to the lawsuit. It didn't strike me as a shock that our system's been cheated over 20 years. We have known that. And in fact, when you compare our system to suburban systems, the facts are pretty clear even though they are widely deniable, but they are clear. They're demonstrable and they're beyond dispute, really.
And then finally, there are economies we have to wring out of this budget. Now, let me give you an example of -- and I put the economies systemwide to over -- a little over $300 million, and here's where I would get it from: from personnel as well as from contracts for service. It would be zero-based. A complete bottom-to-top evaluation of every contract for service. 

Q. You used the word radical ----

A. Yes.

Q. ---- to describe your ideas about schools. But listening to you they sound quite modest compared to proposals that are around elsewhere, and I mean from other candidates.

A. Is reforming due process for teachers not radical?

Q. Well, sure, I don't think so. I think it's an adjustment ----

A. Oh, good, why hasn't it been done?

Q. Well, that's a fair question. But many more radical things are in the air in the national education debate: vouchers ----

A. I'm glad to talk about those things as well.

Q. Tell us where the radicalism is in your -- --

A. I tried. Maybe it's not -- maybe it's not -- maybe it is not radical to reform due process for teachers, to impose teacher accountability, to extend the year, to really make sure that we get qualified and trained -- a consistently trained teacher. Maybe it's not. But if it is not and if it's pretty commonplace and hackneyed, it certainly hasn't been done in this city before.

Q. Merit pay.

A. Yeah, merit pay. Well let's examine merit pay for a second. I'm very happy to do that. You know, it sounds good and everybody tells me: merit pay. Oh, yeah, that's intuitive, isn't it. Except for one thing: it presupposes the retention of poor performers. So what do you do about the poor performers? Oh, we reward the big performers. It's an economic free market incentive here. Huh? Well, no. What do you do about the poor performers? Well the poor performers will get the idea and then leave. O.K., what happens, then, to the truly marginal who were in front of class after class of New York City public-school children? What happens to those kids? That's not radical. That's dumb.

Q. Freddy, what about housing? You've said that in 10 years . . . 150,000 new units of housing are built. Which would be revolutionary if you were to manage that. I mean, where do you find the money to do that and isn't that billions and billions of dollars?

A. I think we are going to need a 10-year program with a payout of a lot less than that in order to give our capital budget some degree of credibility and so that we can continue to respond to capital needs in this city over the longer term. So here's what I believe is necessary. I got the original agreement between Cuomo and Koch on the Battery Park City proceeds. That has to be redirected toward housing. And everybody else has come up with the same thing about the property tax anticipated revenues in the sale of the World Trade Center. And I think that has to be segregated toward housing. And there are other things that I have proposed as well. But those two together make for over a billion dollars in working capital on an annual basis, pay for administration of the program. And this is very serious stuff that it leverages. And it also gives us the ability to re-stream revenue that generates from this back, keep it in housing, to bring down, to prepay principal and interest. So this is not a 10-year production program with a 40-year price tag.

Q. How is it that you're going to be able to do what you want to do with the Board of Education, with housing at a time when city revenues appear to be slightly declining or at least flat, and you potentially would become a mayor at a time when there's retrenchment and sort of what Giuliani first inherited? I mean, are you prepared for that kind of a potential situation?

A. Of course, the Financial Control Board has warned of that. They have said, at the risk of introducing yet a new theater in this operation, the Financial Control Board has warned that as we're shrinking in revenue, for two reasons -- one, we're cutting it ourselves, but the other reason is the market simply will not generate all of this excess revenue to the city.
Then we're going to be faced with interesting choices. That's why I said almost at the outset of this conversation that if someone's going to propose an initiative, you've got to say how you're going to pay for it. And if the choice is going to be raising taxes or cutting services, you better say which. Now, I have in every initiative that I've discussed with you. Now, some might say, oh, that's irresponsible to say that. Well, then what do you want? Do you want somebody to say, yes, I believe in this and I'm for it, but I'm not going to tell you how to pay for it, trust me.

Q. Do you support a tax increase for either your education initiative, the $1.1 billion, or for the housing . . . we're talking about?

A. I don't think it is necessary.

Q. You ruling it out?

A. I don't think it is necessary. And The Times story got it right about what I was proposing for the personal income tax surcharge. It's a one-and-a-half-point reduction in the surcharge, easy to figure out what it means to a family in a certain income group, and easy to figure out -- this is -- and by the way, I've been saying it for months, since the mayor proposed it, as you know. All of you have heard me say it at mayoral forums, this is not new. I said it ----

Q. Go ahead.

A. ---- I said it at the Crain's breakfast. So when I said it at Wall Street everybody was reaching for oxygen. You know, I mean, excuse me? I've been consistent in my criticism of that tax reduction: One, it is trivial. If someone's going to make the case to me that four pennies a day for the average working family is really going to stimulate the economy, I have yet to hear the argument. Although, four cents a day, and then going up the scale -- I mean, if you make a half a million dollars a year, it's $1.47 a day -- will more than twice over pay for an afterschool initiative. And I believe in asking people, what would you rather have? And people overwhelmingly tell me, whether they're parents with kids in the schools or not, I'd rather have after-school programs in this city.

Q. Could you give us, to ask a question another way, some insights into what your priorities would be for cuts if, in fact, the economy dictated that you either had to raise taxes or cut, or maybe a combination of both? You don't want to talk about raising taxes so tell us what your priorities would be if you had to do what Ed Koch had to do and what David Dinkins had to do, you had to come out with a budget proposal and say, all right, here's what we're going to cut.

A. I think a --

Q. It could happen.

A. Yes, it could and I've been around for a few of those. One, you cut contracts for service, you begin to look at all of them. Zero-based. What services are we contracting out for? What can we do in-house? What should we be doing in-house? What contracts for service are absolutely necessary?

Q. Give us an idea.

A. Yeah, I was going to do that. From agency to agency and the Human Resources Administration do we really need a $300- or $400-million contract to tell us how to train people leaving welfare and trying to enter the world of work, or should we just train them?

Q. May I ask a political question here? You had sort of an interesting and rocky time four years ago when you were running. I'm wondering what lessons you learned from that and whether or not you're paying a price for your withdrawal from that race in this year's race, politically speaking.

A. Well, the lesson I learned from it is you can't run for mayor without raising all the money you need. That's the essential lesson. Other than that, the conditions are pretty much as they are. I had, I think, the money to take me to the final stages of the primary, but not to the finish line. And I would have been completely broke for the main event. And, as you know, people were just not coming across with the kinds of resources that you needed to run, especially to face a refreshed Republican incumbent who was sitting on $11 million. We didn't have a campaign finance law in place then that evened the playing field. This one does. I like it.

HEADLINE: Council Approves a Zoning Plan To Revitalize Long Island City 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
The City Council approved a rezoning plan for Long Island City yesterday to allow high-rise development within a 37-block area of low-slung buildings and to attract commercial tenants that might otherwise be tempted to move their back offices to Jersey City.
 The central business district proposal, passed on a vote of 31 to 0 with 10 abstaining, drew opposition from manufacturers that fear being squeezed out by rising real estate values. As a compromise, city officials agreed to come up with a program to help preserve Long Island City's 17,000 manufacturing jobs. 
 Joseph B. Rose, the director of the Department of City Planning, said the rezoning plan was carefully drawn so as to have a minimal effect on existing manufacturing operations. To protect manufacturers, the city turned down a number of property owners who wanted their buildings to be in the new district, he said.
The new district, which would allow a mix of commercial, residential, community and light manufacturing uses, is in western Queens. It is bounded roughly by the Sunnyside railroad yards on the east, 23rd and 21st Streets on the west and 41st Avenue on the north. The Planning Commission said that as much as five million square feet of new space could be created. The city recently began offering incentives to companies moving there from Manhattan.
One company that is considering moving most of its Manhattan employees to Long Island City is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which is negotiating for the site of a former automobile factory at 27-01 Bridge Plaza North. Also ripe for development are a municipal garage at Jackson Avenue and Queens Plaza South and a large vacant warehouse at 23rd Street and Jackson Avenue, said Walter L. McCaffrey, a City Council member from Queens and the chairman of the subcommittee on zoning and franchises.
Mr. McCaffrey said that only about 1,000 manufacturing jobs fall within the newly rezoned area. He said that the manufacturers had been assured that they would get some form of aid. The program for the manufacturers will be included in the October modifications to the city budget, said Mr. McCaffrey, who would not disclose how much it was likely to cost.
Dakota Jackson, a manufacturer of upscale furniture who has operated a plant within the new district since 1977, said that the rezoning would not affect him because he has a 10-year lease. But he said that his company had had good relationships with small subcontractors in the neighborhood that it called on for everything from metalwork to wood supplies.
"A lot of these companies are going to go out of business," he said. "We'll be forced to deal with companies in other places, where these types of relationships won't be in play."

HEADLINE: THEATER GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.
+ means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.
++ means tickets were at the booth for last Friday night only.
+++ means tickets were at the booth for last Saturday night only.

Broadway

++ "42ND STREET" (Tony Award for best revival of a musical). There's nothing like precision tap-dancing to turn an audience into a lab full of case studies for Dr. Pavlov. Witness this opulent revival, directed by Mark Bramble and choreographed by Randy Skinner, in which every other production number has us beating our flippers together like the seals at feeding time. A largely labored resurrection of the last musical staged by the fabled Gower Champion, inspired by the classic 1933 movie, the show features Harry Warren and Al Dubin's priceless Depression-era songs, Michael Cumpsty as a tyrannical director, and an extremely enjoyable Christine Ebersole (Tony winner for best actress in a musical) as his tyrannical star. Otherwise the evening's charms are largely limited to its full-strength tapping. Those seeking a backstage musical that wears its personality above its ankles may want to revisit "Kiss Me, Kate" (2:30). Ford, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $90 (Ben Brantley).

* "MAJOR BARBARA." The Roundabout Theater Company's elegant, eloquent and very funny production of Shaw's 1905 play sending up the societal worship of money -- and the convolutions of logic that defend it -- is less of an interpretation than a celebration of the playwright's winking, topsy-turvy didactics on the subjects of politics, poverty and faith. In a world where spin-doctoring has become the rule in public discourse, inoffensiveness is prized and forthrightness has become suspicious, Shaw's notion that the rhetoric that protects a system of Darwinian economics is a hypocrisy has only gained in relevance. And the director Daniel Sullivan, whose strength is in crystallizing the dramatic voice of the playwright, has made Shaw's tasty ironies crystal clear, so that with a first-rate cast led by Cherry Jones, Dana Ivey and the British actor David Warner, making his American stage debut, the star of the show is the playwright himself (2:30). American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, (212) 719-1300. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $40 to $65 (Bruce Weber).

* "THE PRODUCERS" (winner of 12 Tony Awards). How do you single out highlights in a bonfire? Anyone who sees this sublimely ridiculous show is going to be hard pressed to name a favorite moment. (Is it the singing pigeons? Adolf Hitler doing Judy Garland?) Mel Brooks's wildly energetic stage adaptation of his 1968 cult movie is as full of gags, gadgets and gimmicks as a master vaudevillian's trunk. But the production is so much more than the sum of its gorgeously silly parts. It is, to put it simply, the real thing: a big Broadway book musical so ecstatically drunk on its powers to entertain that it leaves you delirious, too. With the assistance of the director and choreographer Susan Stroman and the happiest cast in town, led by Nathan Lane (Tony winner for best actor in a musical) and Matthew Broderick in the performances of their careers, Mr. Brooks has put on a show that is a valentine to every show there is, good and bad, about putting on a show (2:45). St. James, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $100; extremely limited (Brantley).

* "PROOF" (Tonys for best play and direction of a play). An exhilarating, assured new play by David Auburn that turns the esoteric world of higher mathematics literally into a back-porch drama, as accessible and compelling as a detective story. A mystery about the authorship of a particularly important proof, it is also about twin enigmas: genius and love. Without any baffling erudition, the play presents mathematicians as both blessed and bedeviled by the gift for abstraction that ties them achingly to one another and separates them, also achingly, from concrete-minded folks like you and me. Perhaps most satisfying, it does so without a moment of meanness. Directed by Daniel Sullivan with the pace of a psychological thriller and performed by an exemplary cast, most notably Mary-Louise Parker (Tony winner for best actress in a play), the play reaches into the most competitive and difficult intellectual terrain and finds -- guess what? -- good people (2:00). Kerr, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets, $19 to $69 (Weber).

+ "STONES IN HIS POCKETS." Watching Sean Campion or Conleth Hill take a step forward is an exercise in suspense: when his foot touches the floor, it is entirely possible that he will no longer be the sex, age or nationality that he was a second before. These two human Etch-a-Sketches, the entire cast of Marie Jones's play about an American film crew in an Irish village, offer overwhelming evidence that there are special effects the movies will never do better than the theater does. It should be noted, however, that the pleasures of "Stones" are less literary than kinetic. Its satire of those superficial, egomaniacal folk who make movies is awfully familiar stuff. And Ms. Jones burdens an essentially comic play with a thudding tragic center. The evening's joys come from its two actors splitting like amoebas into different personalities (2:20). Golden, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $70 (Brantley).

+ "A THOUSAND CLOWNS." Herb Gardner's comedy about Murray Burns, an eccentric in rebellion against the social conformity bred in the Eisenhower 50's, is a painfully dated work. But that is not the only reason this revival is very nearly unendurable. Directed with a surprising paucity of invention by the gifted and ordinarily energetic John Rando ("The Dinner Party," "Urinetown"), this is a by-the-numbers production paced at a dogged slog. Usually these are characteristics of a show constrained by inexperience, and the guess here is that Mr. Rando is a victim of the problem he was saddled with: what to do with Tom Selleck, the once-hunky, once-mustached television detective making his stage debut at age 56, wildly miscast and out of his league in the central role (2:30). Longacre, 220 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $40 and $77.50 (Weber).

Off Broadway

*+ "BLUE WINDOW." A discomfiting but finally touching revival of Craig Lucas's 1984 play, an achy comedy that considers the notion that the deepest kind of loneliness may well be inescapable because it has a lot to do with bad luck and bad timing. A well-acted ensemble piece, it has at its center a disastrous dinner party, the sort of oil-and-water gathering that many New Yorkers will recognize and hope never to attend again. Most of the guests don't know one another, everybody's social timing is off and all the individual temperaments run askew. In the scene that sets the tone of the show, just before the guests arrive, Libby, the hostess, suffers a misfortune that is as hilarious as it is humiliating, and watching her cope with it during the party makes you giggle with heartbreak. The result for the audience is a "there but for the grace -of God" experience (1:30). 28th Street Theater, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-1515. Mondays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m. Tickets, $40 (Weber).

* "FOUR." Despite its rap as the hottest of the deadly sins, lust can be a chillingly lonely feeling. Like the randy teenagers of summer make-out movies, the quartet of likable, confused people in this short, pungently acted drama by Christopher Shinn are all out to score on one steamy Fourth of July. They all, as the phrase goes, get lucky, though lucky is clearly not how they're feeling as the evening ends. Mr. Shinn was just 23 when "Four" first opened at the Royal Court Theater in London several years ago, and the work throbs with an adolescent anguish and self-consciousness. But it is also tempered by a sober, precocious empathy that can embrace a varied scope of humanity without turning characters into types. "Four," a Worth Street Company production directed by Jeff Cohen, has its raw spots. But Mr. Shinn, an American whose work has been lauded in London but rarely seen in New York, has a confident hand for pattern and structure that doesn't smother spontaneity (1:30). TriBeCa Playhouse, 111 Reade Street, (212) 206-1515. Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 5 p.m. Tickets, $45 (Brantley).

"A LIFE." When people are driven to describe Desmond Drumm, they call this severely repressed lifelong Irish civil servant things like "a bitter old pill." In Hugh Leonard's comic drama "A Life," Drumm has a habit of correcting people and telling them exactly what he thinks of them. That, he tells himself, is because he is honest, unhypocritical, a man of superior intelligence who maintains standards. But as this wisely entertaining play by the author of "Da" begins at the Irish Repertory Theater, Drumm, played by Fritz Weaver, leading an excellent cast, has reason to reassess his life. He has just been told that cancer has condemned him to six months to live. Drumm may be a man who tends to alienate all around him, but amid the colorful characters and wit in "A Life," he is the catalyst for an enjoyable evening of theater (2:15). Irish Repertory, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $35 and $40 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

* "MUSIC FROM A SPARKLING PLANET." Watching Douglas Carter Beane's nimble escapist comedy about escapism is like sinking into a frozen margarita. This sentimental satire about three aging young men in search of a television star from their childhood is sweet and mildly inebriating. If you find that it eventually turns to mush, that probably won't stop you from enjoying it until the last syrupy drop. "Planet," a Drama Dept. production, reunites the key players from Mr. Beane's popular "As Bees in Honey Drown," including the director, Mark Brokaw, and its delightful star, J. Smith-Cameron. The evening's chief pleasures are its fine-tuned pacing and its verbal agility. Scratch the surface, and you may find something like a heart-tugging sitcom episode beneath. But hey, it's high summer, a time when the scratching of surfaces, especially as attractive as this one, is unwonted labor (2:00). Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 239-6200. Wednesdays through Fridays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $35 (Brantley).

+ "TICK, TICK . . . BOOM!" Two round numbers, 30 and 90, glare ominously in this chamber piece from Jonathan Larson, the creator of the rock musical "Rent." Mr. Larson turned 30 in 1990, and in this self-conscious self-portrait in song he gave vent to his concern that time was running out on him. Given that the composer died of an aortic aneurysm at 35, you might expect a slightly prurient morbidity. As directed by Scott Schwartz and performed by Raul Esparza, Amy Spanger and Jerry Dixon, the show emerges as an amiable public exercise in soul searching. Compared with "Rent," it feels small and conventional. But if you look at it as a sort of sketchbook for that Broadway hit, "Tick" has its gentle fascination, while reminding us of what an infectiously tuneful composer Larson could be (1:30). Jane Street Theater, 113 Jane Street, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 7 and 10 p.m.; Sundays at 7 p.m. Tickets, $30 to $50 (Brantley).

Last Chance

+ "CHAUCER IN ROME." Portraying a pair of guilt-crippled American tourists in Rome in John Guare's new play, Polly Holliday and Dick Latessa give off the harsh clarity of certain black-and-white photographs. (Think of Walker Evans's Depression-era portraits filtered through Diane Arbus's eye for the inner freak.) What surrounds these sharp characterizations, however, feels like a disproportionately large, garish frame, the kind made out of shellacked seashells, perhaps. Unless you look closely, you can't see the pictures, which are truly haunting, for the gaudiness. Much of "Chaucer" is a flashy, lazy satire on the contemporary art world. And though the production has been staged with elegance and efficiency by Nicholas Martin, there's the unmistakable feeling of old circus tricks being dragged out by its author. Jon Tenney, Carrie Preston and Bruce Norris make the best of the sketchily drawn central roles (1:45). Newhouse, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets, $55 (Brantley).

+++ "ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST" (Tony for best revival of a play). Resurrecting this adaptation of Ken Kesey's novel about wild and crazy guys cutting up in a mental institution would seem perfect for Steppenwolf, the Chicago-based theater company with the kick of a triple espresso. Yet despite a full-throttle performance from its leading man, Gary Sinise, this show mostly feels just cute instead of confrontational. It painstakingly restores the fablelike, schematic simplicity of Dale Wasserman's script, an aspect largely erased from Milos Forman's 1975 film version. And under Terry Kinney's direction, the assorted inmates are as cozy a coterie of eccentrics as the barflies of "Cheers." The talented Amy Morton has the thankless role of the emasculating Nurse Ratchet, while Mr. Sinise becomes a white-hot perpetual-motion machine as McMurphy, the anarchic role model for adolescent boys of all ages (2:35). Royale, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $30 to $75 (Brantley).

+ "WORLD OF MIRTH." Sweeney the clown, the central figure in Murphy Guyer's vinegary melodrama, belongs to one of storytelling's time-honored tribes. Presiding over the midway of a run-down carnival, he's a bitter Bozo, a compulsively condescending philosopher drunk, with a bilious wit and a strychnine laugh. The carnival is known as Kaspar Kelly's World of Mirth, and all the unsubtle ironies apply. The workers are desperate, the management is corrupt and the business itself is besieged with problems, not the least of which is that one of its employees and attractions has just drowned himself. The circumstances of the death are fraught with perverse hilarity, and so, at its best, is this play, which is, alas, more often concerned with proving a self-evident dictum: life is not a carnival (2:20). Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, (212) 239-6200. Through Sunday. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7 p.m. Tickets, $50 (Weber).

HEADLINE: Moody's Lowers Argentina's Credit Ratings 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 26 

 BODY:
Argentina's credit ratings were lowered for a second time this month by Moody's Investors Service on concern that the country will not be able to erase its budget deficit to help ensure debt payments. 
 Moody's reduced Argentina's foreign and local currency debt ratings to Caa1, seven levels below investment grade and the same as Pakistan and Moldova. 
 The downgrade is the latest setback to the efforts of the economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, to restore investor confidence that the country can meet payments on its $130 billion debt by balancing the budget. The government's plan to shore up finances through salary and pension cuts has met opposition from legislators and union workers. 
"The measures put in place so far by the government are all temporary," said David Rossmiller, head of global fixed income at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. "Default and devaluation is the most likely scenario." 
The Senate delayed a vote Wednesday night on the spending cut plan until Tuesday, renewing concerns that the government lacks the support to pass the cuts into law. The benchmark stock index fell 8.2 points, or 2.5 percent, to a one-week low of 322.08.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Issues Apology For Czech Study on Smoking 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies officially apologized yesterday for a study commissioned last month by an international affiliate that found that the Czech Republic benefited financially from the premature deaths of smokers.
 "For one of our tobacco companies to commission this study was not just a terrible mistake, it was wrong," Philip Morris said in a statement. "All of us at Philip Morris, no matter where we work, are extremely sorry for this. No one benefits from the very real, serious and significant diseases caused by smoking." 
 Last month, company officials distributed an economic analysis in the Czech Republic that concluded that cigarettes were not a drain on the country's budget, in part because the government saved money on health care, pensions and housing when smokers died prematurely. The study was prepared by Arthur D. Little International.
Though the report has been met with outrage in the United States, reaction in the Czech Republic was nonchalant.
Philip Morris, based in New York, has sent a letter of apology to the Czech Republic's health minister and to the head of Parliament, a company spokeswoman said yesterday.
The report, which was commissioned to examine the economics associated with excise taxes, continues to garner public attention. An ad speaking out against the report, sponsored by a Washington-based anti-smoking group, the American Legacy Foundation, has appeared in newspapers across the country.
The ad depicts the foot of a cadaver with a toe tag that reads: "$1,227 -- That's how much a study sponsored by Philip Morris said the Czech Republic saves on health care, pensions and housing every time a smoker dies."
Matthew Myers, the president of the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, said in a statement, "Without action to back up its words, one has to question what Philip Morris really regrets: the report's callous conclusions or the damage done to Philip Morris's efforts to portray itself as a reformed, responsible company."
Philip Morris said that it sincerely regretted the report and that the financing and release of the study "exhibited terrible judgment as well as a complete and unacceptable disregard of basic human values."
Similar studies were done in Europe about 10 years ago, but other studies in the planning stages have been stopped.
"This is not something that we should be doing, and we won't do it again," the spokeswoman said.
The study was commissioned by the Czech affiliate of Philip Morris International. Philip Morris International and Philip Morris U.S.A. have said that their headquarters were not notified of the report.
The spokeswoman said that the president of Philip Morris International, John R. Nelson, planned to communicate formally with his management team on the issue.
"I regret this mistake and I ask our entire management team to be more vigilant on these issues in the future," Mr. Nelson said in a memorandum issued to the unit's employees at the end of last week.
Shares of Philip Morris ended yesterday down 48 cents, at $44.20, after dipping as low as $43.25 earlier. The shares have fallen less than 1 percent since news of the report first appeared on July 16.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Requires Prudential To Refund $25 Million to Drivers 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 26 

 BODY:
The Prudential Group, which insures just under 325,000 vehicles in New Jersey, has been ordered by the state to mail $25.1 million in refunds this fall to its policyholders. An audit of the company's returns showed that it had exceeded the state's 6 percent profit cap for 1998, 1999 and 2000. 
 The refund proved that the complaints of many insurers that they cannot make money under state regulations are unfounded, said Karen L. Suter, the state commissioner of banking and insurance, in a statement announcing the refunds on Wednesday. 
 "What we are seeing is the reflection of renewed competition among insurers, where some are winners and some are losers," Ms. Suter said. "Insurers point to losers as evidence that the market is failing and, through fear tactics, they hope to cut back on the protection designed to help consumers find insurance."
A Prudential spokeswoman said the company did not dispute that it had exceeded state-set profit limits, which require that a company's combined margin over three consecutive years not exceed an average of 6 percent.
"We consider the excess-profit regulation to be part of doing business in New Jersey," Laurita Warner, the spokeswoman, said today. "We are here, we are committed to staying here, so we are getting ready to send out those refunds." 
The refunds will be mailed out in September, Ms. Warner said, and will average $77.
Prudential's acquiescence to the state rules, and its commitment to remaining in the state, stand in contrast to the experience of the State Farm Indemnity Company. According to a spokesman for the Department of Banking and Insurance, Peter Hartt, State Farm repaid $41 million in excess profits in 1997 and $38 million in 1998. Shortly afterward the company began negotiating with the state for a rate increase. The talks ended in June with the company announcing that it would stop writing policies in New Jersey. 
The company's Web site criticizes New Jersey's heavily regulated market and includes a quotation from a 1991 book on auto insurance reform that said of New Jersey's system: "Even the Soviet Union would be hard pressed to match this economic disaster."

HEADLINE: A Senator's Own Brand Of Seven-League Boots 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
His daughter Jessica tells him not to get hit by any cars. His wife, Iris Weinshall, perhaps out of love and perhaps because she is the New York City Commissioner of Transportation, orders him to put on his safety helmet.
 With a smile as big as Brooklyn, Senator Charles E. Schumer wheels his bicycle from its home in the family living room. He is on one of his almost-weekly adventures: tooling around the city he loves, turning left when he sees something in one direction, right when something else catches his eye, going straight ahead just to feel the sun and wind on his face. He wheels through neighborhoods and boroughs, seldom glancing at his crumpled map -- not that he doesn't need it. 
 But in this he follows a hallowed Brooklyn tradition. In his short story "Only the Dead Know Brooklyn," Thomas Wolfe wrote: " 'Map or no map,' I says, 'you ain't gonna get to know Brooklyn with no map.' " 
In Mr. Schumer's home, an expansive apartment on Prospect Park West in a building where former Gov. Hugh L. Carey once lived, bicycles occupy the most prominent spot, the living room. It is used almost solely as a parking lot for the family's four bikes.
The senator's is a handsome, shining blue mountain bike with an imperfection or two: he picked it up for $75 four years ago at Toys "R" Us. Who cares if there is no water bottle holder or a gauge to tell what gear you're in?
"This is a reject," he said with the pride of a New Yorker who thinks he got a deal. (Mind you, this is a man known to cut his own hair to save money and time.)
Bicycle riding has become the middle-aged passion of the 50-year-old senator, who, except for attending Harvard and working in Washington, has lived his whole life in Brooklyn. He measures the stages of his youth by the sizes of his bikes, and counts the English bicycle that he was given in the fifth grade as one of his life's true blessings.
Bikes continued to be his chosen mode of transportation in college, but then he kind of forgot them ("I guess when I got married and had kids"). He switched to basketball for exercise. But then his knees started hurting. He tried to jog, but that hurt even more. A couple of years before he was elected to the Senate, in 1998, he began venturing into Prospect Park to do some loops around the main drive. Felt good.
Mr. Schumer next rode his bike over the Brooklyn Bridge, something he had always wanted to do ("Exhilarating!").
Next he rode down the bikeway on Ocean Parkway, the oldest urban path in the nation built expressly for bicycles, to Coney Island. Then he almost doubled that 13-mile round trip by returning on the bikeway adjacent to Shore Parkway along Upper and Lower New York Bay, loving the salty air.
It was good exercise, though his enthusiasm for finding perfect hot dogs and hoagies balanced any possible weight reduction. It was a way to talk with people -- read "voters" -- although he quickly realized he would need to bicycle hundreds of miles to meet the number of people he could address at a single event.
This tireless self-promoter may still regret not campaigning as he cycles. But he found something even more important. "This is my island of peace," he pronounced.
A couple of Sundays ago, Mr. Schumer set off on his favorite kind of ride, one where he picks a neighborhood or two and selects a general direction. A cardinal rule is never to set a rigid time frame in advance. "You'll ruin it if you try to do it in 45 minutes or an hour and a half," he said.
It is an approach he learned inadvertently as he rode to see his parents, who live in Glen Oaks, Queens, near the Nassau County border. He got lucky and got lost. He discovered he loved cruising through neighborhoods he had never seen. Other times, when exercise is the main thing, he will choose a destination and just ride and ride. Not uncommonly, the goal is food: the destination of his rides to Breezy Point, on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, is invariably Kennedy's, a seaside restaurant.

Well-Worn Tire Tracks
Mr. Schumer has actually latched on to a great New York tradition. The velocipede, an early bicycle with a large front wheel, was the fad of 1886, and in the 1890's biking was so popular that 53 bicycle clubs sprouted. In the Depression, affordable two-wheeled vehicles returned to Park Avenue for the first time since the 90's.
But gradually and all too relentlessly, the conditions for biking deteriorated, and by the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the city could not even afford to fill potholes, much less promote new bike lanes. In 1990 Bicycling magazine named New York one of the nation's three worst cycling cities.
But this summer may bring a rebirth of the bike. Bike lanes now makes it possible for people to ride from the tip of Manhattan to the George Washington Bridge, a dazzling ride that Mr. Schumer has already taken a half-dozen times. Bike paths have been built or repaved from the Bronx to Jamaica Bay: 126.5 miles are being added to the existing 51.5 miles of trails exclusively for bikes.
Moreover, the city's vast subway system allows cyclists to return from their trips for the price of a $1.50 token. Mr. Schumer likes to ride north on Broadway through Harlem to 207th Street in Inwood and take the A train home. The wonderful bottom line is that riding a bike is becoming one of a tough city's real treats.

The Lure of a Sandwich
As the senator set out for northern Brooklyn the other day, he had only one specific destination, Mamma Maria's Salumeria, a superb Italian deli in Williamsburg. Jessica had begged him to pick up her favorite, a prosciutto hero. While we were wheeling our bikes to the street, a woman scurried up. She had recognized the senator and immediately launched into a sad story about the bad care her father is receiving in a veterans' hospital.
He was appropriately sympathetic, but afterward insisted that he was grateful that many people did not recognize him in his helmet. Sometimes, the politician further insisted, he did not even identify himself. On one occasion a few miles down the road, when he asked directions of a pedestrian, this was proved true. 
Mr. Schumer proceeded down the Eastern Parkway bike path, which was rebuilt about five years ago and is characterized by beautiful shade trees. He turned left on Bedford Avenue, heading north through Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Just as the senator was saying how much he liked dropping in uninvited at black church services, exuberant gospel music exploded into the sunshine. The Church of the Nazarene, at the intersection of Bedford Avenue and Madison Street, was having an outdoor tent revival across the street. He stopped to watch the arm-waving, swaying, joyous worshippers.
"I spend more time in black churches than I do in synagogues," he said happily.
Soon, a woman emerged to shake his hand. Upon figuring out who he was, she mentioned that the church needed a new basement. "We used to have a soup kitchen there, and we can't have it anymore," she said.
Her elected representative promised to get on the case. Everybody hugged him. "Let's roll," the senator said.
"Isn't this great?" he said as we again glided along. "This is what I love to do."

On Familiar Ground
He spoke about politics, his beloved Yankees and his two daughters. (Jessica is 16 and Alison 12.) He talked about the time he played former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in basketball and won, an assertion guaranteed to be disputed. At Park Place, he pointed to Jack Prezant's auto repair shop and said that was where his dad had his car fixed. He said he had forgotten to point out his father's own office a few blocks back, one of many geographic touchstones to his life that he often passes by bike.
That brought up his reason for going into politics. His father, Abe, had hated his job as an exterminator. Sunday nights would find him in a nervous sweat as he dreaded going to work the next day. Mr. Schumer said he felt a similar squeamishness after accepting a job as a corporate lawyer upon finishing Harvard Law School. So he went into politics, which he correctly predicted he would love.
"I have two great things in my life," he said. "I love going to work on Monday, and I love coming home on Friday."
But during his workaday life in Washington, he doesn't bicycle, though he is thinking he might start. If he can find another $75 bargain bike, he suspects that it might hasten the process.
But Washington will never be like this. We are now going through the heart of Williamsburg's Hasidic community, made up largely of members of the Satmar group who fled Eastern Europe after the Holocaust. Just three blocks earlier, the neighborhood was African-American; for six more it will be Hasidic, and then it will be Spanish and then Polish.
"The enormity of the city is amazing," Mr. Schumer said.

Even Room for Yuppies
We went in circles under the Williamsburg Bridge, then passed the Peter Luger restaurant, which Mr. Schumer says makes the planet's best steaks, bar none. He wavered, but decided to press onward to Mamma Mia's, recalling Jessica's hero need. He delightedly spots well-dressed young people out for a stroll.
"Hasidim, Hispanic and now this," he exclaimed. "Yuppies!"
For a long while, he circled around the tree-lined blocks of Williamsburg. Could he be lost? He spotted people standing in the middle of the street and correctly assumed it was a block party. It turned out to be people celebrating the last day of the Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel and the Feast of St. Paulinus of Nola.
These occasions have become famous because of the 80-foot-tall giglio that participants carry through the streets. Mr. Schumer announced his arrival by saying, "I'm just biking around north Brooklyn today."
Msgr. David Cassalo answered, "God bless you."
The participants ate sandwiches, sipped wine and seemed happy. Benny, known as Capo No. 1 for his role as chief organizer, held the stub of a cigar and was in charge. He thought it was a good idea for the senator to eat a sandwich. He did.
"The feast has held the neighborhood very strong," Benny said.
Mr. Schumer answered, "You bet."

To the Deli at Last
Armed with directions, he rolled directly to Mamma Maria's at 357 Graham Avenue, at Conselyea Street. He was known to one and all even before he took off his helmet, which he is somehow convinced does not make him look like Michael Dukakis driving a tank. The guy behind the counter handed him a sliver of Genoa salami.
He is named Cono, as is almost everybody in the immediate neighborhood, for reasons both geographic and obscure. Some people spoke Italian. A picture of the 1990 Italian soccer team was on the wall. A woman asked Mr. Schumer to say hello for her to Trent Lott, the Senate Minority Leader.
"Trent is a lovely guy," he answered.
They gave him his sandwich for nothing, so he thrust a handful of bills into the counterman's hand, insisting that they be given to a Catholic charity.
The heroes were truly enormous. "They ask me why I don't lose weight on this job," he said. "I'd have to bike 5,000 miles in a week to lose weight."
He was back on the street, half trying. Williamsburg turns into Greenpoint, which spurred the senator to recall his efforts to aid immigration. "Probably none of them know I'm responsible," he said regretfully, referring to the streets chock full of Polish immigrants. Combined with the tenements, the visual effect of being on Manhattan Avenue is like seeing a movie set of 19th-century New York.
Mr. Schumer was clearly having a ball. "I never saw this church," he said. "I never saw that park. Look at this little street."
The sheer size of the new Polish community became apparent at Greenpoint's largest church, St. Stanislaus Kostka, at Humboldt Street and Driggs Avenue -- also known as Pope John Paul II Square. The doors of the church were all open so the scores of people on the street could hear the priest's prayers. Even across the street, people, most quite young, were kneeling.
An altar boy came outside to pass the basket.
"Most of these people probably don't know it, but they're here because of the Schumer visas," the senator said, hitting on what politicians call "the talking point."

Getting Happily Lost
The subject changed, most likely because we were again lost. It made absolutely no difference. We curled through the streets and checked out the debris left from the implosion of Keyspan Energy's two mammoth gas tanks from Maspeth Avenue.
Mr. Schumer suggested the once-Irish neighborhood was the birthplace of the celebrated New York accent in which tree is the number between two and four. Jeintz as the name of the pro football team is also, for good or ill, a Greenpernt legacy, by senatorial theory.
We found ourselves on Metropolitan Avenue crossing Maspeth Creek into Queens. This was a long straight route of long blocks filled with industrial buildings. The sun was hot. Finally, the senator stopped at the intersection of Metropolitan Avenue and Fresh Pond Road. He said this was an important place. Four Queens neighborhoods converged.
To the immediate southwest was Ridgewood, to the southeast Glendale, to the northwest Maspeth and to the northeast Middle Village. He likened the intersection to the point where four Southwestern states -- Utah, Colorado, New Mexico and Arizona -- come together.
He said each member of the Schumer family stood in a different state and held hands during a vacation. He considered the possibilities of doing the same thing here. After studying the whizzing traffic, he concluded, "You would probably have to do it at midnight."
It wasn't midnight and there were no other Schumers around, so he led the way to Glendale, a neighborhood of yellow brick buildings and luxuriant trees. "This was the place where the old German fraus would sweep the street," he said. "Not the sidewalks, but the actual streets."
He pointed to a couple of big, strong, sensibly dressed older women who might not ever have stopped. But the neighborhood is clearly now more than just German-Americans. A Lutheran church on Catalpa Avenue shares its space with a Romanian Orthodox Church and a Hispanic Methodist Church.
He stopped at St. Matthias, a Roman Catholic church at 38-15 Catalpa Avenue. He had never been there before. There were breathtaking stained glass windows, powerful columns and one woman praying.
"This is nothing that I knew of," said Mr. Schumer, who used to represent the adjacent congressional district. "It's just a beautiful church."
Lunchtime was long past, and we were carrying around those fabulous Italian sandwiches. Angling back to Brooklyn, heading south on Bushwick Avenue, we happened upon Maria Hernandez Park in Bushwick. It is named for a woman who had been a strong advocate against neighborhood violence and then was killed by what was apparently a stray bullet as she sat in her own home.
The park is one of hundreds of medium-size refuges throughout the city. Hundreds of people played different kinds of ball games, conversed or just sat outside on a pleasant afternoon.
Bushwick has become much safer, a resident said. The men's room in the park was open.

Picturesque! Who Knew?
Mr. Schumer looked admiringly at the surrounding row houses. "If this were in England, they'd be writing a brochure about it," he said. "Notice the arched windows."
The ride back was pretty much a straight shot going west on De Kalb Avenue. Not much traffic. After almost veering into a mammoth pothole, the senator called his wife, the transportation commissioner, to report it. "Hi, my dear," be began.
The ride might have been 20 miles, Mr. Schumer suggested. Or, he thought again, maybe 30. In any case, it was not one of the really long ones on which he carries the music tape, with selections ranging from Chopin to the Jefferson Starship, that Jessica makes for him each Father's Day.
"What I like about these rides," Mr. Schumer said, "is that you never know where you'll end up."
This day had not been a Tour de Brooklyn, much less de Greater New York. It had been a delightful dance with serendipity.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Russia a Blueprint for Talks on Nuclear Weapons 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 26 

 BODY:
Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, offered President Vladimir V. Putin an American blueprint today for talks on building a new nuclear-weapons framework, a process she cast as part of a broader White House plan for "transforming" the relationship between Washington and Moscow.
 Ms. Rice said that President Bush hoped to meet Mr. Putin twice this fall, in Shanghai and in Washington, and that members of Mr. Bush's cabinet were planning trips here in the coming months. Two of them -- Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans -- were in Moscow today, meeting with Mr. Putin and other senior officials. 
 "What we are trying to do is to change the nature of the strategic relationship, but also to change the nature of the political and economic relationships," Ms. Rice said. 
Russian enthusiasm for the American embrace was mixed. Mr. Putin, who met with Mr. Bush last weekend at the summit meeting of industrial nations in Genoa, Italy, expressed hope that the talks would imbue the two nations' relations "with new content free from the problems inherited from the past." In Hanoi, Vietnam, where he was meeting with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and other Asia-Pacific foreign ministers, Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov solidly endorsed the new dialogue.
But the Kremlin's chief arms negotiator reacted coolly, saying Russian opposition to upsetting the existing arms-control framework was unchanged. And unidentified Russian officials told Russian news agencies that the meetings produced nothing new.
Ms. Rice said that in meetings with Mr. Putin and his top security aides, she discussed a schedule for talks on winnowing stockpiles of nuclear weapons and developing limited defenses against nuclear missiles.
Mr. Putin and Mr. Bush agreed last weekend to link the two issues while seeking a new basis for strategic relations between Moscow and Washington. Russian officials said the Kremlin expected to receive the first substantive proposals from American experts next month.
Ms. Rice said today's meetings dealt far more with missile-defense issues than with the Russians' principal concern -- reducing nuclear arms. The Kremlin has long proposed cutting the number of warheads held by each side to 1,500 from the current level of about 6,000.
Ms. Rice said the Joint Chiefs of Staff were still preparing a report for Mr. Bush on how few nuclear warheads the United States could hold and still maintain a deterrent. 
In a news conference, she was alternately tough and flexible in laying out the United States' hopes for a new partnership with Russia.
Ms. Rice said the White House's central demand in any weapons talks was all but nonnegotiable: the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which effectively prevents the United States from building a limited defense against missiles, must be scrapped. She called the treaty a cold-war artifact, an accord drafted in an era when "the only thing the two sides had in common was a desire not to blow each other apart."
"The U.S.-Russian relationship is considerably different now," she said. "We are not strategic adversaries."
But the treaty remains so restrictive, she argued, that it has become a hindrance rather than an aid to security in a post-Soviet world.
The White House insists that a limited ability to knock down incoming ballistic missiles will not upset the balance of nuclear power among major nations, but that it is essential to counter emerging threats from terrorists or rogue states and to protect against accidental missile launchings by other nations. Russia and China have strongly opposed those plans, accusing the Bush administration of dragging the world headlong into a new arms race.
Today, Ms. Rice said those fears were overblown. While the Pentagon has reported that its research program is just months away from technically violating the ABM treaty, the terms of the accord make almost any work on a missile defense a potential breach, she said. 
Whatever the legalities, she argued, a workable defense system remains many years away, and there is ample time for the world's nuclear powers to agree on its specifics. "At this stage, we are just talking about a robust testing and evaluation" of a defense system, she said. "There is no system that the United States can just pull off the shelf and deploy."
In an era when superpowers suspected each other of plotting surprise attacks, Ms. Rice said, suspicion of a missile-defense plan like the one offered by Mr. Bush might have been justified. But today, when neither Moscow nor Washington considers a nuclear attack to be a likely prospect, such fears only block a basic restructuring of the American-Russian partnership, she said.
Ms. Rice said that despite the Kremlin's remarks against changes in the arms-control framework, Russia was moving closer to that view. "There is a recognition that the United States intends to move forward with missile defense," she said. "You've got a discussion now about how you move forward, not if you move forward. That's considerable progress in the last several months."

HEADLINE: Bush to Speak Freely on Dollar 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26 

 BODY:
The White House said today that although the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, has jurisdiction over the nation's dollar policy, President Bush will feel free to speak out on the dollar as he sees fit.
 The comments by Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, were the latest in the "who speaks for the dollar?" question that began when Mr. 
Bush confused traders last week by saying that markets should determine the dollar's value. 
 Mr. O'Neill restated the strong-dollar policy in London on Monday and said he was the one who should be listened to when currency policy was discussed. Government officials insisted afterward that he was not referring to the president.
"I think what the secretary is saying is accurate, that the Department of Treasury has jurisdiction over matters monetary about the dollar," Mr. Fleischer said. "But obviously the secretary is not speaking for the president when he says there is only one spokesman."
"It's a given in everybody's eyes" that the president can speak out as he wishes, he said. "But it's clear that the Department of Treasury is the cabinet-level agency that has jurisdiction over the dollar."
Some experts believe that the dollar is too strong and that the United States should relax its policy in support of a strong dollar and allow it to weaken to make exports to Europe cheaper and help American businesses through the sluggish economy.
Currency traders have said that the persistent headlines over the direction of dollar policy keep alive suspicions that a subtle shift may be under way to abandon the strong-dollar policy to help United States industry. Analysts said they had not been reassured by Mr. O'Neill's comments.
