HEADLINE: Members of Congress Begin Effort to Get U.S. to Join in Fighting Global Warming 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26 

 BODY:
With the United States now alone in the world in opposing the treaty to combat global warming, some lawmakers are pressing for Congress to take the lead toward reducing emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, the issue on which the Bush administration has so far kept to the sidelines.
 Both Democratic and Republican Congressional aides say it is now likely that Congress will pass one or more measures this year calling for cuts in emissions of carbon dioxide, a main provision of the Kyoto global-warming treaty. But it is less clear whether majorities would back the mandatory restrictions spelled out in the treaty and rejected by the administration, or whether they would favor a voluntary approach. 
 Still, when Christie Whitman, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, arrived on Capitol Hill this morning, she heard calls for Congress to make up for the administration's inaction this week in Bonn, where the United States opted out of an agreement on the Kyoto treaty that was backed by more than 180 countries. 
"The administration can refuse to commit the United States to the Kyoto accord; that is their choice," Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont told Mrs. Whitman at a hearing on power plant emissions that was his debut as chairman of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, a job he won in May by shifting his party affiliation to independent from Republican.
"But this Congress, this Senate, and especially this committee will not let our international partners down," Mr. Jeffords said. "We plan to take steps to reduce our nation's contribution to this growing problem by working with industry to reduce carbon emissions." 
The White House has criticized the Kyoto treaty as "fatally flawed," saying its provisions are unfair to the United States. This morning, Mrs. Whitman defended the administration's go-slow approach in offering any alternative to the treaty, saying it would be premature to present any plan for carbon dioxide reductions until further studies are completed.
"We're still a long way from knowing how to solve the problem," she said.
Emissions of carbon dioxide are widely regarded as the main contributor to global warming, and the United States is the world's largest source of that gas, about one-third of which comes from old coal-burning power plants.
The Bush administration's refusal to adopt mandatory limits on carbon dioxide has put it at odds not only with Europe and Japan, but also with senators like Mr. Jeffords, who has introduced a bill requiring power plants to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. The bill is also sponsored by 2 Republican senators from Maine, Susan Collins and Olympia J. Snowe, and 12 Democrats.
Other measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions are also floating around Congress, including some, like one that Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, is expected to introduce next week, that would stop short of mandatory restrictions in favor of voluntary measures.
Even as the administration scrambles to come up with its own stand on the issue, the Congressional aides and several senators said, the pressures of public opinion and concern over international fallout appear to have added to a view that Congress would be irresponsible to do nothing.
"Very few of us up here want to have America seen as not participating in something that's important," Mr. Hagel said in a telephone interview. He said that what happened in Bonn had redoubled a sense of broad support for doing something.
Senator Jeff Bingaman, the New Mexico Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, said, "I certainly feel that leadership's got to come from somewhere. It's not coming from the administration." 
"And I think it would be a failure for us," Mr. Bingaman said, "to just sit by idly and let the rest of the world work on this problem while our scientists tell us that the problem is very real."
Today's hearings on the subject were the first since the breakup of the Bonn meetings, and a sense of frustration over the administration not offering an alternative was evident even among Republicans who have been supportive of the White House position. Their comments may have reflected recent opinion polls showing that increasing numbers of Americans see the problem as serious.
In the months before the Kyoto treaty was framed in 1997, the Senate voted 95 to 0 for a resolution opposing any treaty that would reduce carbon dioxide emissions unless developing countries were also made subject to the rules that would bind industrialized countries like the United States. 
The Bush administration has often pointed to that vote as an indication that a treaty requiring mandatory cuts in carbon dioxide emissions could never win Senate ratification. But supporters of mandatory measures point out that the mounting evidence of the scope and potential severity of climate change problems that has emerged in the last four years has significantly altered both the political and the scientific debates.
Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, told Mrs. Whitman, "The fact of the matter is that we need to deal with the carbon issue, substantively and politically." 
In a telephone interview, Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts and a leading critic of the administration's policy, was more explicit, saying: "What happened in Bonn has reinvigorated the notion that the United States is in a very unfortunate position, which encourages many here to think that we've got to take some steps to respond domestically, to put the United States in better graces."
President Bush has said that his administration takes the problem of climate change seriously and is determined to address it. But he has criticized the Kyoto treaty because it does not require immediate action from developing countries and because, he has argued, the steep cuts it would require in carbon dioxide emissions would exact a heavy cost to the American economy.
The administration has said little about its plans since last month when Mr. Bush promised more money for research into causes and possible solutions to global warming.
Administration officials now say that the White House hopes to come up with an alternative to the Kyoto plan in time for the next meeting of the Kyoto group, in October. 
Today's hearing focused on emissions from power plants. Mr. Jeffords, whose bill would rein in power-plant emissions of four problem-causing gases said it was wisest to address all four of the gases at once.
But Mrs. Whitman, advocating the administration's three-pollutant approach, said it would be more prudent to move now to tighten restrictions on three undisputed public health problems -- nitrogen oxide, sulfur dioxide and mercury -- while deferring action on carbon dioxide until its role in global warming was better understood.
"It would be a shame to deny people an important public health goal while we await consensus on carbon dioxide emissions," she said.

HEADLINE: Ferrer Envisions a New Era Of Activism by Government 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who wants to be mayor, is waging a campaign to revive what he says is a tradition of activist government abandoned by Rudolph W. Giuliani and bolster "the other New York" left out of the city's economic boom. 
 Mr. Ferrer, a Democrat, sketched the broad outlines of his mayoral vision yesterday, including an array of expensive government programs the size and cost of which recall another era in the city's politics. Mr. Ferrer said that he hoped to pay for most of his new programs with taxes already collected and requests for more state aid, and by weeding out fraud and abuse. He said he did not think raising taxes would be necessary to cover expansion of programs and services, but favored reinstating an income tax surcharge that was recently rolled back by Mr. Giuliani and the City Council. 
 Mr. Ferrer also signaled that he would be more likely to discipline police officers, too many of whom, he said, have lost the trust of New Yorkers. 
Among the many proposals Mr. Ferrer outlined yesterday in a 90-minute interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, those that he highlighted have been part of his campaign. Mr. Ferrer said that if elected mayor, he would raise teacher pay by 30 percent, oversee the construction of 150,000 units of housing and ban the practice of racial profiling by the police. Excerpts, Page B6. 
In carrying out his agenda, Mr. Ferrer would be reasserting the role of the city government in areas where it has pulled back in recent years. Mr. Ferrer promises to use the government to help the millions of New Yorkers who, he said, have scarcely benefited from the robust economic growth of recent years. 
"Not everything has gone well," he said. "Not everything has been addressed appropriately. There are real mortgages on the future of this city that someone has to talk about. We've got to acknowledge some harsh truths about this in order to deal with it." 
Mr. Ferrer, a 51-year-old native of the Bronx and its borough president since 1987, is hoping that his call for renewed government activism will propel him past his three major rivals for the Democratic nomination: Mark Green, the city's public advocate; Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller; and Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the City Council. 
Mr. Ferrer's calls for increased support for education and housing contrasts sharply with the administration of Mr. Giuliani, who came into office almost eight years ago on a message of austerity as he faced deficits. Though the city's brisk economy has since helped fuel new spending by City Hall, Mr. Giuliani began his first term by cutting spending for housing and social services -- some of the same areas where Mr. Ferrer is now pushing for increases. In his first term, Mr. Giuliani also privatized some services. After cutting the payroll by more than 15,000, the mayor has invested the growing revenues into rebuilding the city's payroll, especially in police and teacher ranks, to the point where personnel has reached an all-time high.
As an example of how agency responsibility should be restored, Mr. Ferrer said he did not understand why people moving off welfare were being trained by private companies rather than by employees at the Human Resources Administration. He said he would restore the agency's role, which he contended would save money because the contracts to private companies for job training and placement amount to hundreds of millions of dollars. But he did not say whether employees would need to be added to accomplish the same goals. 
While some of Mr. Ferrer's rivals for the Democratic nomination have been quick to praise the Republican mayor, Mr. Ferrer has consistently billed himself as an "anti-Rudy" -- both personally and politically. In his interview, Mr. Ferrer described his relationship with Mr. Giuliani as "famously nonexistent" and said the two men had rarely spoken in the last several years. 
"The only instance of that was when he was having his existential moment over a year ago, when he called me up," Mr. Ferrer said, referring to the time last spring when Mr. Giuliani, facing a deteriorating marriage and treatment for prostate cancer, quit his United States Senate campaign and briefly tried to make peace with his political enemies. 
Mr. Ferrer said they had a pleasant discussion, about health insurance and other matters.
Mr. Ferrer asserted that he stood alone among the four Democrats seeking their party's nomination in enumerating how he would pay for each of the new programs he has promised to deliver. As an example, Mr. Ferrer offered his plan to set up after-school and weekend programs in middle schools across the city. He said he would pay for the program with the $800 million gained from restoring the city's income tax surcharge. 
"I haven't proposed any initiatives -- any -- where I haven't said where this money will come from," Mr. Ferrer said. "So that, for example, when I propose an after-school program I would tell people how I'd pay for it."
Yet aside from the after-school program, Mr. Ferrer was distinctly less specific on his plans for paying for the other programs he is proposing. Apart from restoring the income tax surcharge, Mr. Ferrer is not advocating any new taxes, and says that most of his new proposals can be paid for by squeezing waste from existing programs or redeploying taxes already collected. He said he was confident that he could pursue his agenda despite a slowing New York economy. 
In one of his most ambitious proposals, Mr. Ferrer advocated giving all of the city's 80,000 teachers a 30 percent raise, which he said would help ultimately improve the quality of teaching. "If we acknowledge that the important relationship in a school takes place in a classroom between teacher and student," Mr. Ferrer said, "how can we say we want our kids to do better but throw our hands up on the ways to make that happen?" 
Mr. Ferrer says his proposal would cost about $1.1 billion a year. In return, he says, he will insist on speeding up the process by which teachers can be fired, and will require that all teachers take courses during the month of July. He says he will also require that certain teachers -- new recruits, for example -- teach summer school. 
Mr. Ferrer provided few details on how he reached the $1.1 billion figure. Later in the day, his spokesman, John Del Cecato, said that Mr. Ferrer had arrived at $1.1 billion by using the average teacher's salary of $47,000. Other estimates have put the cost of a 20 percent raise at $1 billion. Mr. Ferrer provided few details on how he would pay for his plan. He said the $1.1 billion pay increase could be financed almost entirely through the existing Board of Education budget. Mr. Ferrer said that substantial savings could be realized -- as much as $300 million -- by cutting back on contracts for outside services. As much as $150 million, he said, could gained by tapping the state treasury. "We've got to find ways to make this happen," he said. 
Mr. Ferrer also provided the outline of a plan to build 150,000 units of housing, which, if realized, would make it the city's most ambitious housing program in more than a decade. Again, the sweeping nature of his proposal suggests a return to a city that took more of an active role in providing for its citizens, in this case, homes.
In his interview, Mr. Ferrer said he was taking a page from the administration of Edward I. Koch, who set aside billions of dollars to rebuild the city's dilapidated housing stock in the late 1980's. Mr. Ferrer said he wanted to alleviate a housing shortage for thousands of New Yorkers, particularly those in the poorer precincts. 
"It made the biggest difference in people's lives, individually and broadly, by changing their neighborhoods and their neighborhood circumstances," Mr. Ferrer said of the Koch program. "We have added value by ramping up neighborhoods all over the city." 
Mr. Ferrer provided few details of how he would pay for and carry out his housing plan, which he estimated at $13 billion over the next 10 years. Later in the day, his aide, Mr. Del Cecato, provided a brief list of revenue sources. Under the plan, the bulk of the financing -- about $150 million a year -- would be paid for over time from the rents and mortgages on the buildings themselves.
Mr. Ferrer reserved some of his most caustic criticisms for Mr. Giuliani in his stewardship of the police. While he conceded that the current administration had succeeded in drastically lowering the crime rate, Mr. Ferrer suggested that that victory had come at the price of the public trust and confidence in the police. 
Mr. Ferrer said, "Fear is the defining element of the relationship between people and the police in too many places with too many people." 
Mr. Ferrer suggested yesterday that he would put stricter controls on the police. Later in the day, he offered a specific proposal to ensure that. At Police Headquarters downtown, Mr. Ferrer outlined legislation to ban racial profiling and punish officers who engage in it. "I want the pendulum to swing back to the middle," he said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Digital Defense

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
With many dot-coms blowing up, it is now fashionable to dismiss the Internet as just another tulip mania. That Internet stocks were a classic bubble is without question. But the Internet isn't just tulips, and if you think it is, well, let's talk in five years. By then it will be clear that the Internet is a business evolution -- reshaping how businesses communicate, educate and purchase materials; a social revolution -- connecting people who have never been connected before; and, for both of these reasons, a strategic dilemma that we are just beginning to understand.
 Recently I wrote a memo that the Saudi terrorist Osama bin Laden might have written to his men, after the Bush team hastily withdrew a contingent of Marines exercising in Jordan following death threats from the bin Laden gang. One day after the column appeared in The Times and on its Web site, I received e-mails from two Marines who had been part of the exercise in Jordan. They were upset about what I had written and they e-mailed me from their ship, the U.S.S. Harpers Ferry, as it sailed away from Jordan, to scold me for suggesting that they were retreating. 
 As one of them, a lance corporal, wrote: "We have not been driven out of the Middle East. We are not in port, but believe me, we are here. . . . Marines do not retreat, Mr. Friedman. . . . Semper Fidelis. @harpers-ferry.usmc .mil."
That's the Internet social revolution, connecting people who have never been connected. In 2001, the use of the Internet by companies to reach customers, suppliers and employers will triple to about $260 billion worth of business worldwide. That's the Internet business evolution.
The strategic dilemma flows from both: the more tightly connected we become, socially and financially, the more vulnerable we are to any breakdown in the system. Did you see that train tunnel fire in Baltimore last week? It burned some key network cables that used the same tunnel, which knocked out part of the Internet in Baltimore and slowed Internet service in regions across the U.S.
In five years, with the Internet being used to run more and more systems, if someone is able to knock out the handful of key Internet switching and addressing centers in the U.S. (until recently, a quarter of all Internet traffic passed through one building in Tyson's Corner, Va., next to Morton's steak house), here's what happens: many trains will stop running, much air traffic will grind to a halt, power supplies will not be able to be shifted from one region to another, there will be no e-mail and your doctor's CAT scanner, which is now monitored over the Internet by its manufacturer, won't work if it breaks.
Why? Because corporate data, telephone calls and e-mail, which 10 years ago ran on separate networks, are now all running together on the same fiber-optic cables through the same routers. This is called the "I.T. cloud" -- a huge complex web of lines and routers, where, like a cloud, you see your voice, data or e-mail going in one side and coming out the other, but never quite know how it works in between.
The Bush missile defense plan is geared to defending the country from a rogue who might fire a missile over our walls. But the more likely threat is from a cyberterrorist who tries to sabotage our webs. The more tightly we get woven together, the more we become dependent on networks, the more a single act of terrorism can unleash serious chaos.
What compounds this Internet strategic dilemma is that the web is largely in the hands of the private sector. The U.S. Army can't protect our webs as easily as our walls. What the government can do is to cajole every industry in the private sector to improve its network security, backups and information about cyberattacks to make our relentless integration less vulnerable to a systemic failure.
To his credit, President Bush will soon unveil an upgraded program to defend against cyberterrorism. But so far, the U.S. government spends only $1.8 billion a year to protect our webs, which, the F.B.I. will tell you, are already under daily hack attack by cyberterrorists. Meanwhile, we are considering spending $100 billion on a missile shield to defend our walls from missiles that terrorists don't yet possess and may never use. It will probably take a cyberattack that causes real chaos for us to see that our big threat is not a mushroom cloud but the I.T. cloud, and that threat will come up the web, not over a wall.

HEADLINE: A Financial Push for Peace in Ireland 

BYLINE:  By Richard Freeman; Richard Freeman is a professor of economics at Harvard and co-director of the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
The major deterrent to making the Northern Ireland Good Friday peace agreement effective has been the unwillingness of the Irish Republican Army to decommission its weapons. Is there a way to make decommissioning more palatable to the I.R.A. and more certain for the Unionists who demand the relinquishing of the I.R.A.'s arms as a part of the peace?
 There may be an economic solution: Pay for each weapon that the I.R.A. and Protestant paramilitary groups turn over to authorities, giving the money not to the paramilitaries themselves, but to a special development fund to implement the peace agreement and to invest in the well-being of the people of Northern Ireland. 
 Far from being a sign of defeat, this sort of decommissioning would be a way for the I.R.A. and other armed groups to turn their weapons into resources that would benefit their communities. The money to buy the arms could come from three sources: the British government, which could finance the initiative in part from reduced spending on military forces in Northern Ireland; the Irish government; and the Irish abroad who want to see peace in the old country. 
As in any bargain where money is involved, the parties would have to bargain over the price of each decommissioned weapon. The Catholic and Protestant communities in Northern Ireland would have the same goal -- to obtain a high price for weapons -- while the two governments and the overseas Irish communities would want to pay a lower price.
The parties to this exchange would also have to agree on the purposes for which the money could be spent -- perhaps for schools, hospitals and funds for families that have suffered from the violence. Money for I.R.A. decommissioning could be spent primarily on projects that would benefit the Catholic community while money for Protestant paramilitary decommissioning could go to the Protestant community. Better yet, all the money might go into a single fund and be allocated jointly by the political leaders of both communities.
Paying people to turn over guns has been tried with limited success in the United States and Australia. But the money has typically gone to the individual gun owners, who could use it to buy new guns, legally or illegally. Putting the money into a fund for communities would prevent its being used to buy new guns. The American and Australian schemes did not greatly reduce the number of guns held by people. Similarly, an Irish buyback would probably leave considerable weaponry in the hands of the I.R.A. and paramilitaries, as well as in the hands of other citizens. The value of the scheme would not be in removing all weaponry from Northern Ireland, but in giving the Catholic and Protestant communities a new and different stake in getting the guns decommissioned. For the first time, the paramilitary groups would be able to make an immediate contribution to the well-being of their communities -- alleviating poverty, improving economic opportunities and helping the families of victims of violence.
Would the I.R.A. and Protestant paramilitary groups accept an offer like this?
They would face a stark choice: Keep the arms or help their communities. At a sufficiently high price for the weapons, it is difficult to see how the paramilitaries could turn down the money-for-guns plan. Local communities would place pressure on them to give up their weapons when failure to do so would have a real financial cost. At a low price, the paramilitaries might continue to view the risks of decommissioning as exceeding the benefits. The task for both sides would be to find a price that can support a satisfactory agreement. The virtue of economic solutions is that money can be bargained over to the last pound: a little more spent for good purposes can help move people in the right direction.
Economists, some say, know the price of everything and the value of nothing. They can monetize all sorts of things -- life, love, honor -- with little concern for moral judgments. But in this case, price and moral value move together. Paying for decommissioning arms by putting money into a development fund may help dissolve the impasse. Offering the parties in Northern Ireland a way to link the turning over of weapons to tangible benefits for the communities could be just the extra push that will salvage the Good Friday agreement.

HEADLINE: Niagara Mohawk Plans Deal to Curb Prices 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Niagara Mohawk Holdings, which is selling its power plants to focus on distributing electricity, announced a plan yesterday that is meant to prevent widespread spikes in consumer bills upstate.
 The company, which distributes power to 1.5 million customers across 24,000 square miles of upstate New York, has signed a tentative agreement that will lock in prices for more than 90 percent of the power it transmits annually to residential and small-business consumers. 
 The deal, which needs approval from New York State Public Service Commission, calls for the company to buy 35,000 to 36,000 gigawatt hours each year from Tractebel Energy Marketing, a Houston-based subsidiary of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, a Paris utility that is among the largest in the world. 
Under the deal, Tractebel will assume Niagara Mohawk's approximately 100 existing contracts with power generators and then sell most of the power to Niagara Mohawk.
The prices that Tractebel could charge Niagara Mohawk would be fixed from 2001 to 2003, and capped for the following three years. 
The agreement comes at a time when many are concerned about electricity price spikes in New York State. 
In California, several power distributors were driven to financial collapse this year as electricity prices rose and they were barred from passing on the costs to consumers. In New York State, many are concerned that there could be sharp price increases because the number of new power plants being built will not accommodate demand. Unlike California's, New York State's regulators allow the power distributors to pass on the full cost increases to consumers.
"What we tried to do was reduce the risk that our customers would face in the open market," Michael J. Kelleher, the vice president for financial planning at Niagara Mohawk, said in an interview yesterday. "And we think we were able to do that at a price that is lower than what we forecast we would have paid on the open market."
In the New York City area, customers of Consolidated Edison, which has bought power on the open market for the past two years, have had their summer bills jump as much as 40 percent per kilowatt hour.
In 1988, Niagara Mohawk agreed to sell all of its fossil, hydraulic and nuclear plants as a part of deregulation the company shifted its focus from creating and transmitting power to just sending it to consumer's doors. Con Ed made the same shift.
Last September, Niagara Mohawk officials announced an agreement for the company to be acquired by National Grid Group, a power company, in a deal valued at $8.36 billion. That deal is still awaiting regulatory approval.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Jaded Wall St. Barely Budges on Poor Economic News

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street mostly held still yesterday, with just a smattering of selling on news that the economy grew at its weakest pace in eight years and on worse-than-expected results at JDS Uniphase.
 Analysts said the muted response reflected how accustomed investors have become to bad news, given the dismal second-quarter earnings of recent weeks. They also said the market was reassured by indications that the outlook for semiconductor stocks could be improving. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average declined 38.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 10,416.67. Broader stock indicators advanced. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.89 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,205.82, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 6.11 points, or 0.3 percent, to 2,029.07.
For the week, the three indexes made little progress, despite a huge sell-off Monday and Tuesday that sent the Dow down 335 points. The Dow ended the week off about 1.5 percent, while the other two indicators fell less than 1 percent.
"There's no catalyst on the earnings side short term to give us a strong headwind, so we're stuck," said Robert Harrington, co-head of listed block trading at UBS Warburg. "The only good thing I can say is that the negative news is not bringing the whole market down."
Investors continued to pore over earnings reports, looking for indications of where business was headed. JDS Uniphase was pummeled, falling 95 cents, or 10 percent, to $8.55, after reporting a wider-than-expected quarterly loss and warning of revenue shortfalls ahead. The company, a maker of optical network components, also announced 7,000 more job cuts, bringing the total for the year to 16,000, or more than half of its staff.
The Dow's losses came from a handful of stocks, including the technology bellwethers Intel, which fell 61 cents, to $29.22, and Microsoft, which was down $1.14 at $65.47. DuPont, which released disappointing results early in the week, also suffered, falling $1.06, to $42.13.
The news was better in semiconductors, a technology subsector whose recovery is considered a precursor to any technology turnaround. Investors sent LSI Logic up $1.70, to $20.85, after the company said it expected business to bottom out in the current quarter.
But Wall Street had little reaction to a Commerce Department report that showed the economy's growth slowed to 0.7 percent this spring, its worst performance in eight years, as businesses cut investment spending by the largest amount in nearly two decades.
"There was some relief that the number wasn't negative, that we're not in a recession, and we're closer every day to interest rate cuts helping the economy," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
Still, most companies are unable to say when business will improve. That inability has translated into uncertainty on Wall Street that has kept many investors away. The three major stock indexes -- the Dow, Nasdaq and S.& P. 500 -- have all made little progress since mid-April.
Treasury debt prices rose yesterday, with the 10-year note up 9/32, to a price of 99 11/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.09 percent from 5.13 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32, to 97 20/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.54 percent from 5.57 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Bogota Journal; 
Soccer Provides a Tonic For Nation's Glum Mood

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 27 

 BODY:
Many said the Copa America the premier soccer event in the Americas, a tournament that leads storekeepers to shutter their shops and lures tens of millions of fans to their television sets -- would be a bust.
 After all, the 12-nation tournament, due to be held in this nation of strife, was nearly suspended when a Colombian soccer official was kidnapped by leftist rebels in June. 
 Then, after South American soccer officials ruled that Colombia would remain the host as planned, Argentina promptly dropped out over concerns that its powerhouse team could be placed in danger. Canada also canceled. And some of Brazil's top players, fearing the worst, stayed home. 
Some commentators wondered if it had not been irresponsible for Copa in Colombia -- the most prominent of them the president, Andres Pastrana -- to lobby for a tournament to be staged in a country where terrorism is a part of life.
But now, with the finals to be played on Sunday in this Andean capital after 15 games in 18 days of play, Colombians are rejoicing. First, their team is in the finals. Second, the tournament went off without incident, and third, presented the world with memorable, even spectacular play. 
And that is sometimes all that people ask in a region of the world where no matter how bad things get, soccer is always there to provide relief.
"This has been spectacular, since no one gave Colombia a peso's worth of credit," Victor Perez, 57, a civil engineer, said late Thursday night on a Bogota intersection swamped with fans celebrating the latest Colombian victory.
"We have shown the world that although we have plenty of problems, we are capable of achieving big things," Mr. Perez said. "I know and we all know soccer does not fix all that is happening, but it is so good for us Colombians to enjoy ourselves.
The world is left with the image of a nation bigger than its problems."
The Copa, played in seven cities, was indeed filled with lasting images.
Small countries like Costa Rica, which depended on a bruising star named Paulo Cesar Wanchope, made it to the quarterfinals on the strength of his five goals. Honduras, which replaced Argentina and is not known for soccer prowess, knocked off normally mighty Brazil. Other surprises abounded, like Chile's victory over an Ecuadorean squad that had been expected to advance.
And perhaps the sweetest gift for Colombians is that their team, an untested collection of young players, dominated all five of its games and is now playing for the championship on Sunday against Mexico.
Colombians had become accustomed to unpleasant surprises when it came to their team. In a World Cup match in Los Angeles in 1994, a heavily favored Colombian squad lost to the underdog United States team. Colombian defender Andres Escobar, who inadvertently scored a goal for the Americans, was later shot dead on his return home.
But the only surprise in this Copa has been the Colombians' dominance. The Colombians, in fact, have not given up a single goal, a rarity in the Copa's 85-year history.
For Colombians, weary of a worsening conflict and mired in a four-year recession and 20 percent unemployment, the tournament was a chance to put the country's myriad problems behind them, at least for a bit.
"We can forget a little about such much conflict, about all the differences that divide us, about all the craziness in the streets," said Gabriel Moyano, 47, a vendor, as he watched Colombia beat Honduras 2-0 on Thursday night to reach the finals. "Colombia, at least, will be in the championship. That fills us with emotion. You want that. You want a little happiness in your life, not sadness, not hostility."
Colombia, which last played host to a Copa in 1947, seemed to be an odd choice for a tournament, given the deteriorating conditions here. A conflict with leftist guerrillas, who have been waging war for nearly four decades, continues to intensify. 
The media recently reported that two and a half years of peace negotiations with rebels had gone worse than believed. Paramilitary gunmen, fiercely opposed to the rebels, have killed nearly 1,300 people in massacres this year.
Then, in the weeks leading up to the tournament, a series of car bombs in Colombian cities raised fears that players or fans would be attacked. The bad news was capped off with the June kidnapping of Hernan Mejia, vice president of the Colombian Soccer Federation.
It looked as though Colombia had lost the tournament, but then Mr. Mejia was released and a fierce lobbying effort by Copa sponsors and Colombian officials began. Soccer officials relented.
Mr. Pastrana, who has been criticized for making little progress in peace talks, said the tournament would showcase Colombia not as a land of war, but one where most people are warm and hospitable. He started calling the tournament the "Peace Cup." And Colombians, elated with the good news on the field of play, began to feel giddy.
"I dedicate the goal to this beautiful country we have," Victor Aristizabal, the Copa's leading scorer, said after his sixth goal of the tournament helped knock out Honduras. "We had never experienced this. I dedicate it to a happy people that could be one of the best countries in the world."
At the Parque Nacional, Bogota's most venerable park, on the edge of the mountains that ring this city, fans gathered on Thursday night for the match against Honduras on a 20-by-20-foot screen, one of several set up around the city so people could watch outside.
Dressed in the yellow, blue and red of the Colombian flag, the fans rejoiced with each goal and with each save by Colombia's dominating goalie, Oscar Cordoba. 
The fervor for their team was so pitched that even when the screen went blank, because of mechanical problems, the cheering and horn blowing continued.
"This has been a chance for us to have a fiesta," said Raul Angulo, 28, an actor and stage director. "Here, there is no difference in race, no difference in culture. Nothing else that divides us. We are all just one country now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the Parque Nacional in Bogota, Colombian soccer fans celebrated their team's triumph over Honduras in the semifinals of the Copa America on Thursday. Colombia will face Mexico in the finals tomorrow. (Carlos Villalon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Duane Reade Registers a 16% Profit Gain 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The regional drugstore chain Duane Reade Inc. posted a 16 percent rise for second-quarter profit, in line with Wall Street's estimates, helped by strong sales of items like skin-care creams, vitamins, toothpaste and dietary products. 
 The company, based in New York, said earnings in the three-month period ended June 30 rose to $5.7 million, or 30 cents a diluted share, from $5 million, or 27 cents a diluted share, in the period a year earlier. 
Sales increased 20 percent, to $292 million. 
 Excluding a one-time charge for retiring debt, the company earned $7.2 million, or 36 cents a diluted share.
Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn 35 cents a share; its stock rose $2.51, to $34.64, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"We continued to achieve industry-leading same-store-sales growth in both the front-end and pharmacy portions of our business, reflecting the successful execution of our strategies to drive top line growth," the chairman, Anthony Cuti, said in a statement. 
Mr. Cuti said Duane Reade's New York focus was shielding it from increasing competitive pricing pressure from food and drug mass merchandisers. Those retailers are cutting general merchandise prices to go head-to-head with national drug chains as the economy slows. 
Mr. Cuti said Duane Reade's results also benefited from increased cost savings from its central prescription filling operation, which he said was helping the company withstand the rising shortage of pharmacists faced by the drug retailing industry. 
Duane Reade said sales at stores open at least a year, or same-store sales -- a leading measure of retailing performance -- rose 8.6 percent, and comparable pharmacy sales rose 19.1 percent. Sales in the general merchandise category, were up 3 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Economic Growth Slows To 0.7% Rate in Quarter
Economic growth nearly halted in the second quarter, as businesses made severe cuts in investment and consumer spending grew less quickly than it had at the start of the year, the government said.
 The economy grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 0.7 percent, the Commerce Department said, leaving it in its weakest condition in a decade. Page A1. 

Dow Jones Declined 1.5% This Week
Wall Street held steady, despite light selling on the government's weak gross domestic product report. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 38.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,416.67. The Dow ended the week down 1.5 percent, even after a sell-off on Monday and Tuesday when the index lost 335 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.89 points, to 1,205.82, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 6.11 points, to 2,029.07. For the week, the two gauges lost less than a percent. C4.

E.P.A. Rules Against Modified Corn
The Environmental Protection Agency has decided not to let even trace amounts of genetically modified StarLink corn into human food, officials said. An agency advisory panel concluded on Thursday that there was not enough evidence to rule out possible allergic reactions, even from small amounts. C4.

House Bars Easing of Water Rules
The House voted 218 to 189 to bar the Bush administration from easing rules on the amount of arsenic allowed in drinking water beyond those set under President Clinton. A1.

The Bush administration wants Congress to collapse several of the most contentious air pollution control programs into a more flexible and less intrusive system strongly favored by leading electric utilities. A8.

Regulators Close Superior Bank
Federal regulators have closed Superior Bank, a Chicago-area savings and loan that has had huge losses on loans to high-risk borrowers. The institution, half-owned by the Pritzker family, is expected to cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation $500 million. C14.

Thailand Ponders Time Zone Change
The government of Thailand is considering whether to set clocks ahead. By doing so, financial markets in Bangkok would operate in closer harmony with larger markets in Singapore, Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur, attracting more foreign investment. C3.

Campbell Soup to Bolster Marketing
In an effort to turn its business around, Campbell Soup will increase marketing spending and investment to raise sales of its soups, sauces and snacks. It warned that earnings next year would be below current expectations and cut its dividend 30 percent. C3.

HEADLINE: Badillo Outlines Plans to Resolve Shortcomings With Police and Schools 

 BODY:
 Here are excerpts from an interview with Herman Badillo, a Republican who is making his fourth attempt to become mayor of New York City. The interview was conducted by reporters and editors from The New York Times, and is the second in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates.

Q. What, in your view, are the stakes in this election? What is this election about?

A. This election is about whether we want to continue the progress that the city has made under Giuliani or whether we want to go back to the situation as it was in 1992, and those are very high stakes. Because I campaigned with Rudy, 1993 I ran for comptroller with him. People were telling us that it was essential for Rudy to be elected if they were to stay in the city. And Rudy has proven that the city is manageable. Rudy has proven that standards can be changed. And I've proven that we can have standards at the City University.

Q. And what's the unfinished work?

A. The unfinished work is to, first, to continue what has happened so we don't go backwards. Want to continue having standards at the City University, continue having the enforcement of the law at the Police Department and then to bring about the same changes that I brought at the City University to the Board of Education. . . . We can make sure that children begin to get help at age 4, when they're in preschool, and that they get their standards evaluated at every grade. . . .

Q. Is there anything that, in your opinion, was wrong about the past eight years, things that the mayor did wrong, that you weren't happy with?

A. Well, yeah, but, you know, he has a different style than I do and it's a question of style. I think that the people of New York City give him overwhelming approval on his job performance. They don't necessarily give him overwhelming approval on his style of doing things, but everybody has a different style.

Q. There's no policy difference that you can think of between a Badillo administration and a Giuliani administration?

A. There aren't significant policy differences, carrying out the policy differences, but the policies themselves, which require performance by every department.

Q. What is your view of bilingual education?

A. My view is that it's good if done the way I wrote the bill. The bill was for bilingual education for a limited period of time, maybe two years, in some cases even three.

Q. What is the default position if a parent does nothing? Does the kid then go in or not go in?

A. Then the child should be evaluated. I mean, many of the kids you can tell by talking to them whether they need bilingual education or not. When I came here I couldn't speak English at all. That's not a big test. But there are some kids who do speak English fluently and really only speak what we call household Spanish, to give you an example, which is a very limited thing. . . .

Q. But when you came here there was no bilingual education.

A. Naturally. That's why I supported bilingual education, you see, because I came here, I came to live in East Harlem. I was looking at the teacher, the teacher was looking at me and we looked at each other for a few months. And I was able to move ahead. . . . But a lot of my colleagues dropped out of school because they couldn't move as fast.

Q. Do you believe that there's racial profiling going on in New York by the New York City Police Department?

A. It has not been proved. I know that the Justice Department conducted a very extensive study; they found no evidence of it. . . . And racial profiling is illegal and unconstitutional, and I would certainly want nothing to do with it.
 But I support the idea of having what the Police Department does be verified. . . .

Q. Could you foresee any policy changes that you would push in the Police Department?

A. Policy changes are as follows: Police need better training and we have to move to change the racial composition of the city. We have developed, at the City University, a program in sensitivity training. . . . So far 5,000 policemen have participated in that course. As mayor, I would require every single one of the 40,000 policemen to take that course and I would pay for it, it would be free of charge to them.
 But in addition to that, I obviously would like it if Albany would pass a bill to have the policemen live in the city, but they're never going to do it.
 So what I would do is I would expand the program, which we also developed at John Jay . . . and there would be several advantages to that. That program I would expand to 3,000 police cadets a year. Because the people who go to CUNY are overwhelmingly black, Hispanic and Asian, and a majority is women, you automatically have out of the graduating class a large number of blacks, Latinos, Asians and women, which would begin to change the racial composition.

Q. Are you saying that the tension between the police and the community has little to do with police behavior and a lot to do with the racial composition?

A. Oh no. It has to do with police behavior. But it also has to do with racial composition.

Q. Has that gap between the neighborhood and the police grown over the past eight years or has it always been the same since the days . . .

A. That gap is huge. And it's come more to the attention of the public because of the problems with Amadou Diallo and Abner Louima . . . But those of us who know these neighborhoods know that those problems exist. And, you know, cops are people like everybody else.

Q. So many of your accomplishments have been as a Democrat.

A. Yeah.

Q. I'm wondering -- your view on that party now, I mean, looking at it from all the years that you've been affiliated now with the Republican Party after running with Mayor Giuliani . . .

A. Yeah.

Q. What's wrong with the Democratic Party?

A. What's wrong with the Democratic Party is that a lot of the programs that we supported in the 60's and 70's did not work, unfortunately for me. I said then that they did not work. And I tried to change them. And my Democratic colleagues would not agree to any changes.

Q. What are your thoughts on the teachers' contracts and what would your top priorities be when negotiating that? What would you ask for?

A. Well, Randi Weingarten and the teachers agree with me on the need for standards. And then, as I said, I agree that we have to reduce class sizes. For example, I'm a C.P.A. . . . but you don't have to figure out -- be a C.P.A. -- to figure out something doesn't count properly, because if there are 1,100,000 students in the schools and 80,000 teachers and you divide that it comes to about 14 students per teacher. So how come my wife and all the other teachers in the school have 36 kids? Somewhere teachers are not in the classroom. I would require that there be a written explanation to the mayor and the City Council for every teacher who is not in the classroom. . . .

Q. Would you also require summer school starting in first grade instead of waiting until third?

A. If the individuals are not able to perform, instead they have a choice of going to summer school or taking the course -- back, which is what I said up at CUNY. We have the largest summer school program in the City University today, which no one has reported on. And it works and a lot of the kids pass and go ahead. But if they don't pass, they don't get promoted. In other words, there has to be a reality to the enforcement of standards, which Chancellor Levy has not done.

Q. You've identified public safety as the most important thing. Maybe by implication, education is the second most important. Tell us third, fourth and fifth. And what you want to . . .

A. Well, health is a huge problem. Including health, by the way, for immigrants. Because we have one-quarter of the city that has no health insurance. And that's because they're too young for Medicare. And they work, so they don't qualify for Medicaid. But they work in little jobs -- in bodegas, restaurants and other places where there's no program for insurance. So we have to maintain the city hospitals. We have to expand the Child Health Plus programs. We have to take advantage of the new program that Governor Pataki just got implemented: Family Health Plus.
 Because look at what's going on in the city today. My father and mother died of tuberculosis when I was a child in Puerto Rico. My father, when I was 1; my mother when I was 5. But in those days tuberculosis was incurable -- it was an epidemic. We are in danger of having an epidemic of tuberculosis in New York City when tuberculosis is curable because the people don't have access to medical care. That's outrageous. . . . It's important that everyone get adequate health care because many of these diseases are contagious and they're a danger to all of us. And so health care, to me, is an equally urgent priority because of the need. And it's not difficult to give it a priority because basically it should be the school system -- I mean every child should be enrolled in Child Health Plus and the chancellor and the principals and the superintendents should ensure that every child in the district is enrolled because if they have no money they don't have to pay.

Q. The city's been losing jobs in the last couple of months, revenues are now looking like they're not going to be so robust. How serious a problem do you think this is going to be? And what do you do, cut programs, raise taxes?

A. No, you don't raise taxes because you raise taxes, you lose jobs. That's what happened under Dinkins where we lost 400,000 jobs which now have been restored. You lower taxes. The best example is the hotel tax where the hotel tax was lowered, you had more people coming into New York because New York City was no longer blacklisted by hotel associations. And the result was more people in hotels, more income for hotels.
 We should lower the sales tax. We should get rid of the commercial rent tax.

Q. How do you pay for ----

A. I was saying -- no, you can't pay for it. I just told you, get more revenue. See, we have to encourage the development of jobs for people who are in the city.

Q. ...if you're not going to raise taxes, give us an idea of what your priorities are for cuts. What goes first?

A. Well, I told you, I'm a C.P.A., I also told you I was deputy mayor. When I came in as deputy mayor with Ed Koch, all the projections for the next 20 years were even worse than they are today, because it always is that way. The next year budget is always a deficit. But you find, if you look at it, that somehow that's met. Why? Because without giving away too many secrets, there's always some money stored away, there's always a rainy-day balance. When there is a problem, as we had with Koch, you reduce the budget of every department by 5 or 10 percent, you provide for early retirement. You do a number of things ----

Q. You would do that across the board?

A. Yeah, you do it ----

Q. Including the Police Department?

A. Well, it depends. Some more, some less, depending on the department.

Q. Would you be O.K. with the level of police going down?

A. It depends -- it's like negotiating raises, depends. You call in each commissioner -- which Ed Koch did, he met with every commissioner -- and you evaluate how much you're going to cut. You ask the commissioner, what harm is this going to do you?

Q. I'm looking for specifics here. You've already mentioned that you admired or at least liked some of the things in the Giuliani administration. But how, specifically, your administration will be different from that of the Giuliani administration. And similar to it.

A. Well, I've given you very clear specifics. I mean, on education I said I would do what I did when I was deputy mayor, change the system. I told you what I did at CUNY. I told you about health care. I mean, there's a whole new approach and more aggressive strategy to bring about changes, but it's not having more government, it's bringing about less government and bringing about more benefits to the people. . . .
 And I want to say on housing . . . We know that middle-income housing works because people own their housing. I believe in low-income housing being owned by the people.

Q. The Giuliani administration has been criticized for having an economic development policy -- to the extent they have one -- that favors subsidies to large corporations -- the New York Stock Exchange and possibly building a stadium. Would you continue on that line? Would you do something different?

A. Oh, I would do something different. For example, I think it is outrageous that Michael Bloomberg, to this day, insists that he wants $14 million to enable him to stay in the city as he moves from 59th Street and Park Avenue to 58th Street and Third Avenue. Does anyone believe that Michael Bloomberg is going to leave the city? I mean, that's a rip-off. But he says "Oh, I took advantage of the benefit. And then he says I'm not going to give it up until I'm elected because if I'm not elected, I'm going to keep the benefit." A guy with $4 1/2 billion still grasping at $14 million. I mean that's greedy. . . . I think that's just an example of the kind of thing that I would be against. There are legitimate situations where you have a stock exchange which needs to expand. And you've got to help them because that's important to the life of the city.
 But stadiums are something that is not urgent.

Q. On the subject of Bloomberg, before you get to November you have to make it through September. Why do you think the Republican establishment hasn't been warming up to your campaign?

A. Well, it's only part of the Republican establishment. It's simple: money, money. After all, he gave $150,000 to the state Republican Party. He gave $30,000 to Sal Fontese. I don't know and I don't care how much money he gave to the others. Some of the Republican leaders love money.

Q. Are there any commissioners in the Giuliani administration that you would keep on?

A. Yeah. I would keep Scoppetta -- Nick Scoppetta. I think he's doing a great job. Because he has lived through the experience of the kids he deals with there.
 I would keep Bernie Kerik because Kerik, I know from the Department of Correction, did a wonderful job.

Q. Would you keep Chancellor Harold O. Levy in some role?

A. No. I would abolish the Board of Education and bring in a new commissioner. . . . I have a problem with Chancellor Levy, as I told you. Because I believe in real social promotion and I don't see it. In today's papers, about the Moreland Commission . . . I agree with the newspapers that a capital budget overrun of almost $2 billion is outrageous. Because that could be a hell of a lot of schools that are not being built. And Chancellor Levy says he knew about this. It is unconscionable to do that. I would have private enterprise build the schools with the same penalties that private enterprise exercises.

HEADLINE: For Albany, the One Constant Is a Late Budget 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
You would think no one had ever enacted a state budget before.
 Over the last several years, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and legislative leaders have repeatedly put new obstacles in the path to budget deals, found new reasons to jettison the way things were done before, and set records for lateness. The result is an annual, fruitless search for a new approach they all can live with. 
 "I've started saying lately that New York State does not have a budget process, because whatever you think the process is, next year you're wrong," said Frank J. Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Group, which studies state finances.
The latest twist was this week's announcement by Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly speaker, and Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader, that the Legislature will pass a budget next week that is stripped to the bone. They plan to leave out most everything they and the Republican governor care deeply about -- increased aid to schools, tax cuts, money for toxic-waste cleanups, pork-barrel projects. All of that would be decided later, in a supplemental budget.
Will that supplement be negotiated with the governor? Will it be one bill or many? Will lawmakers wait until after September's quarterly revenue report? All involved admit wearily that they do not know, raising the prospect that this fight could still be under way when the maple trees around the Capitol lose their leaves.
"It gets more convoluted each time," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "It's like they come up with new ways each year to mess it up, and then they need to come up with some new trick or threat each year to force themselves to make a budget."
Though the state is on a 17-year streak of late budgets, the national record by far, it was not until the mid-1990's that the process spun out of control. Lawmakers set a new state record for being dilatory in 1994, completing the budget on June 8; the next year they went to June 7.
In 1996, Mr. Pataki became the first governor in memory to hold up a budget over a nonbudget issue -- reform of worker's compensation insurance -- and a new record was set, July 13. In 1997, Mr. Silver held up the budget to win renewal of rent control laws, producing another record: Aug. 4, 126 days late, by far the tardiest any state has been since the Depression, if not longer.
In 1998, for the first time, the Senate and Assembly met in conference committees to work out a budget publicly. They largely ignored the governor, increasing spending far more than he wanted to, and Mr. Pataki retaliated with more than 1,000 line-item vetoes. Ever since, Mr. Silver has insisted that the governor take part in budget talks.
In 1999, Mr. Pataki said his work was done when he proposed his budget in January, and he refused to negotiate with the Legislature, another departure from tradition. He eventually relented, but lawmakers still managed to tie the Aug. 4 record. Of the last eight years, only last year produced a relatively rancor-free budget, completed on May 5.
This year, Mr. Pataki has again said that he would not negotiate, this time holding fast to that position. The Assembly Democrats, who want to exceed the governor's plan by more than $2 billion, refuse to convene conference committees without reassurances that the governor will use his veto power sparingly. Legislators concluded this week that they faced the prospect of no budget at all, only a series of stopgap spending bills.
The budget follies are an extension of New York's unique, long-running brand of government dysfunction, where deep partisan divisions and personal animosities between governors and legislative leaders have been taken for granted since the 1970's. And there, some observers think, lies the problem.
For 26 years, the Democrats have controlled the Assembly, while the Republicans have held the Senate. No state has ever had divided control of its Legislature for so long.
"In most states, you'll see divided control when a dominant party temporarily loses one house, or because there's a gradual transition from one party dominating to another," said Robert Kurtter, vice president for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. "Only in New York is this a permanent condition. That has allowed them to become more and more entrenched in their positions."
But what has changed is the way governors interact with the Legislature, partly because of conference committees and Mr. Pataki's insistence on standing outside the process. Until the 1970's, legislative leaders tended to be more deferential to the governor. But under Govs. Hugh L. Carey and Mario M. Cuomo, Democratic Assembly speakers often made common cause with the Senate and defied governors of their own party. Mr. Bruno, though sometimes tempted, has not turned his back on Mr. Pataki in that way.
Practical considerations have added to New York's woes. Democrats and Republicans are, in fact, far apart on spending for schools and health care. And budget analysts point to structural safeguards that some other states have, like requiring the comptroller to set the official revenue estimate when the governor and Legislature cannot agree.
"But if you think those kinds of things are the problem, you're fooling yourself," Ms. Fortuna said. "There's obviously something deeper that's wrong here. I mean, 49 other states manage to pull it off without making such a spectacle of themselves."

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A SNAIL'S PACE IN SPRING QUARTER 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27 

 BODY:
Economic growth nearly halted in the second quarter, as businesses made severe cuts in investment and consumer spending grew less quickly than it had at the start of the year, the government said today.
 The economy is now in its weakest condition since early 1993, although most economists say that companies' swift responses to the slowdown, combined with a tax cut and declining interest rates, have made an improvement likely in the coming months. 
 The economy grew at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 0.7 percent in the three months that ended on June 30, the Department of Commerce reported in its initial estimate of the quarter's economic activity. Overall spending by businesses and consumers actually fell slightly, but a surge in spending by state and local governments allowed the nation's longest recorded expansion to extend into its 11th year.
Still, from the middle of 2000 to the middle of this year, the economy grew just 1.3 percent, less than a third the rate of the late 1990's and the slowest 12-month pace in nearly 10 years. 
"The economy is puttering along -- it's not nearly as strong as it should be," President Bush told members of the Future Farmers of America today, adding his expectation that the tax cut he championed would provide "an incredibly important boost to economic vitality and economic growth."
Stocks fell slightly today, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 38.96 points, to 10,416.67, on moderate trading. Bond prices rose slightly, as analysts said the new data further increased the chance that the Federal Reserve would encourage more borrowing and spending by lowering its benchmark interest rate at least once more this year.
The most encouraging sign in today's report, analysts said, was a decline in business inventories of $26.9 billion, or roughly 0.5 percent, nearly the same size as the first-quarter decrease. Having cut prices to sell the excess goods that began piling up last year, many companies will soon be able to increase production again, economists said. 
"Companies have been pretty aggressive, getting rid of inventory, cutting back on capital spending and firing people by the bucketful," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "It's not a process that's finished, though I think it will slow."
The current slowdown began last year amid rising energy prices and interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve to ward off inflation. Many executives and investors, meanwhile, had decided that they were overly optimistic about the profits that the Internet could bring. Their newfound pessimism caused stocks to fall, hurting consumers' balance sheets, and led companies to halt new investments almost immediately.
From December to March, business investment in new buildings, equipment and software fell slightly, but it plummeted in the latest quarter, falling at an annual rate of 13.6 percent. As recently as a year earlier, it had grown more than 10 percent, as it did for much of the late 90's.
But the country appears to have avoided a recession so far, largely because consumers continue to increase their spending on new homes, cars and other items even as companies eliminate thousands of jobs. The long shopping spree has been financed by growing incomes, rising levels of household debt and housing values and stock prices that on the whole remain significantly higher than in the late 90's.
A separate report published today by the Commerce Department showed that new-home sales rose 1.7 percent in June, to 922,000 units at an annualized rate. 
Overall consumer spending increased 2.1 percent in the second quarter, down from 3 percent in the first quarter; that was the smallest rise since 1997, the Commerce Department said. But because consumer purchases account for more than two-thirds of the gross domestic product, the small increase nearly canceled out the corporate cutbacks. The rise in government spending -- a result of projects started in headier times -- enabled the economy to grow slightly.
Most economists on Wall Street and at the Fed expect the second quarter to be an economic low point. This month, the government started mailing nearly $40 billion in tax refund checks, and it has also started taking less money out of the paychecks of many Americans, particularly those with high-paying jobs. In addition, energy prices have fallen in recent weeks, and the Fed has lowered a crucial interest rate by 2.75 percentage points since January.
As a result, consumers should be able to continue increasing their spending even as unemployment rises in the coming months, most economists say. The economy will grow at an annual rate of about 3 percent over the next year and a half, according to a survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter based in Kansas City, Mo.
For now, though, there are few signs of strength, and analysts said that further slowing remained a significant risk. 
The 13.6 percent decline in business spending was the largest since 1982 and has become more broad based than it was earlier in the slowdown. In addition to reducing their spending on new equipment and software for the third straight quarter, companies cut spending on new warehouses, factories and other structures by 11.2 percent. In the first quarter, such spending rose 12.3 percent. 
While old-line manufacturers have grown somewhat more optimistic in recent weeks, technology companies continue to announce cutbacks, and their executives say they still do not know when business will improve. This week, Alcatel, Hewlett-Packard and Lucent Technologies announced more layoffs.
If job reductions do not begin to slow in coming months, consumer spending could decline as it did in 1991, rather than merely grow slowly, as it has in recent months. Further stock market declines are another risk, analysts said.
Today's Commerce Department report also included the government's annual revisions to earlier data, and they showed that the economy actually grew 4.1 percent, not 5 percent, last year. Corporate profits grew 6.2 percent, not 10.5 percent, during the year.
Based on the new numbers, said Dean Baker, the co-director of the Center for Economic Policy and Research in Washington, "price-to-earnings ratios in the stock market are still close to double their historical level, even after the decline of the last 15 months."
A survey released today suggested that consumers remained wary of the economy's health, though they were more upbeat than they had been in the spring. Conducted by the University of Michigan, the poll showed that its index of consumer sentiment -- which is calculated from answers to questions about the economy's current state and expectations for the future -- fell slightly, to 92.4 this month, from 92.6 in June. 
The 49-year-old index reached a record high of 112 in January of 2000 and dropped to a low of 88.4 in April of this year. 
The Commerce Department report also showed that a broad measure of inflation -- one that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has called important -- fell to 1.5 percent in the second quarter, from 2.7 percent in the first three months of the year. Exports fell 9.9 percent, compared with a 1.2 percent drop in the first quarter; imports decreased 6.7 percent, down from a 5.0 fall.
As more detailed data arrives in government offices over the coming months, the Commerce Department will adjust the quarterly statistics, and the period could eventually show an overall economic decline. 
As it stands, the 0.7 percent growth rate was the lowest since the first quarter of 1993, when output fell 0.1 percent. That decline was too small and too brief to be considered an interruption of the current expansion, which began in early 1991 after three consecutive quarters of contraction.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
China Feud Has New Risks For Taiwan

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 27 

 BODY:
In a sign that Taiwan's political standoff with China is starting to alienate its corporate customers, Dell Computer has criticized the reluctance of the authorities on Taiwan to establish direct trade and transportation ties with the Chinese mainland.
 Max Fang, Dell's senior representative in Taipei, the island's capital, said he told senior economic and trade officials last week, "How can you expect to be an Asia-Pacific procurement center if you are isolated from the biggest market in the region?" 
 The president of Taiwan, Chen Shui-bian, has been under increasing pressure from industrialists there to establish direct links with China. But this is the first time that a foreign company has joined in the call. 
Dell, based in Austin, Tex., is no ordinary foreign company. It is the largest buyer of laptop computers from Taiwan's suppliers, ordering 3.5 million to 4 million machines this year.
Taiwan has built its economy over the last two decades by becoming the subcontractor of choice for the global computer industry. Companies there make 53 percent of the world's laptops and 25 percent of desktop PC's. Most are sold under American brand names like Compaq, Gateway and Dell.
"Dell is just looking for the best way to do business," said Horace Tsiang, chief executive of First International Computer, a PC maker in Taipei. "They've been the price leader; they want to stay the price leader."
As if to underline its point, Dell moved its top procurement executive to Hong Kong earlier this year. The executive, Robert Shanks, said he wanted to be closer to plants on the Chinese mainland, most of them owned by Taiwan companies, that manufacture Dell desktop and laptop computers.
"The lack of a direct flight between Taipei and Shanghai is a big disadvantage," said Mr. Shanks, who scouted Taipei before settling here. "They will lose out over time if they don't change the situation."
The political gulf between Taipei and Beijing means that travelers from Taiwan to mainland China must go through Hong Kong. That turns a 90-minute hop into all-day travel. Similarly, components made in factories in China must be routed through Hong Kong, on their way to Taiwan.
Officials in Taipei acknowledge that direct trade and transportation links with China are inevitable. The question is when, and the answer depends on political rather than economic calculations.
China is eager for such links, expecting that this will stimulate its economy and accelerate the integration of Taiwan and the mainland. But the Chinese leaders, who call Taiwan a renegade province, insist that Mr. Chen recognize a single China, governed in Beijing.
In January, when Mr. Chen authorized trade and transportation between the mainland and two outlying islands -- Kinmen, known in cold war times as Quemoy, and Matsu -- Beijing dismissed this as an empty gesture. Mr. Chen is reluctant to make a grander gesture to Beijing, feeling that the Communist officials have scarcely acknowledged his existence.
"If the P.R.C. is willing to talk to us, the links can happen," said John C. C. Deng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council of Taiwan. "If they stick to their current position, they won't happen."
For the last few months, Mr. Deng has been making the rounds of Taiwan and foreign technology companies, listening to their concerns about relations across the Taiwan Strait. Today, he had lunch with Mr. Fang of Dell.
"Dell is our customer and we treasure that relationship," Mr. Deng said. "But on the issue of direct links, I think we recognize that there are some things we can control, and other things we cannot control."
Within two weeks, Mr. Deng said, Taiwan will relax its restrictions on trade with the mainland to allow cargo shipped from the south China city of Xiamen to be unloaded in southern Taiwan, transferred to the Taipei airport, and exported to the United States or Europe by plane.
The rules are aimed at foreign computer companies, which use air shipments for components that are needed quickly in their home markets. Mr. Deng said routing air cargo through Taipei instead of mainland airports would save two days.
Direct flights are a thornier issue, he said, because they involve granting landing rights to flag carriers. That raises the dispute over sovereignty involving Taipei and Beijing, separated since Mao Zedong's victory over the Chinese Nationalists in 1949.
Dell executives show little patience for the diplomatic nuances. They are laboring in a fiercely competitive industry, during an economic downturn, when extracting the lowest prices from contractors is critical.
"Nobody talks about Communism versus capitalism," Mr. Tsiang of First International Computer said. "They just think of where they can get the lowest cost."
The risk for Taiwan, he said, is that it will lose not just low-end manufacturing, which is gravitating toward the cheap labor market in China, but research and development. Companies might prefer to keep such operations on Taiwan, but their bosses are put off by the roundabout trip across the Taiwan Strait.
Mr. Shanks of Dell would not say how much of the company's manufacturing is done in mainland Chinese factories. But companies like First International are building plants near Shanghai to produce laptop computers. Already, the bulk of scanners, and half the disk drives, sold by Taiwan companies are made in China.
"We're migrating more and more to China," Mr. Shanks said. "The soft economy may be accelerating that."
Dell's decision to put its procurement headquarters in Hong Kong is a little triumph for the city, a special administrative region of China and until 1997 a British crown colony.
But it may be a fleeting one. Mr. Shanks said that Dell had set up offices in other cities, including Shanghai, where much of the investment in technology is flowing. As Shanghai becomes even more of a technology magnet, Mr. Shanks said he could foresee relocating from Hong Kong.
"This is business, so we don't let emotion get in the way," he said.
