HEADLINE: Architectural Superstars Tackle Three Hartford Attractions 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
IF one measure of a city is its architecture, Hartford is poised for a growth spurt as three of the city's major cultural institutions have announced multimillion-dollar building projects by high profile architects.
 The Wadsworth Atheneum, the Connecticut Historical Society and the Mark Twain House are in the planning stages for major expansions to enhance their presence, and with the proposed $1 billion Adrian's Landing project, they may help increase the economic fortunes of the city. 
 "Taken together, these projects provide jobs and economic opportunity, but they are also giving the city a new face," Gov. John Rowland said. "After a long period of stagnation, Hartford needs to feel good about itself again." 
The most extensive of the three projects is the expansion and redesign of the Wadsworth, the nation's oldest public art museum and recognized as the crown jewel of the city's cultural institutions.
The current space allows for the display of 2,500 of the museum's 45,000 holdings in various galleries set up in five separate buildings around a courtyard.
With the expansion, the space would increase by 40 percent, a special exhibits gallery would be included and the entrance would move from the castle-like facade on Main Street (which the museum director describes as "forbidding") to a side street across from the Traveler's Tower.
A public concourse would begin there, travel through the spine of the museum and open at Burr Mall, just steps from Hartford City Hall.
Maya Lin, the artist who designed the Vietnam Memorial in Washington, has been commissioned to design a work for the Main Street exterior.
Ben van Berkel and Caroline Bos, a husband and wife team based in Amsterdam, were selected last February from among 70 architects for the Wadsworth project.
Kate M. Sellers, the museum's director, said the 36-member board deliberately chose a firm whose work is considered experimental. 
"We weren't looking at the list of architects always associated with big projects," Ms. Sellers said. "If you look at the history of the Wadsworth, there's a tradition of innovation."
The cost, size and appearance of the project will be completed in early fall, Ms. Sellers said.
Susan Hood, public relations officer for the museum, said the state had committed about $15 million, adding that an additional $20 million had been raised through private sources.
A public fund-raising campaign will begin next year and the project will get under way in 2003.
Perhaps the most ambitious of the three projects is the new building commissioned by the Connecticut Historical Society on city parkland near Trinity College.
The historical society has hired Frank Gehry to design an estimated 115,000-square-foot Connecticut History Center with a 200-seat theater, exhibition space and restaurant.
Mr. Gehry's design of curving swaths of titanium steel for the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain was credited with boosting tourism, and David Kahn, the director of the historical society, has similar hopes for the Hartford plan.
Mr. Kahn said the new center would act as "a gateway to the state's history" by unifying historical information from the state's 169 towns.
Although visits to the historical society have tripled from 10,000 to 30,000 visitors a year since Mr. Kahn became the director four years ago, he said he thought as many as 100,000 people will visit the new history center each year for the interactive exhibits and to see its historical treasures, which include a chair made from the Charter Oak.
Staff members at the historical society said they have long outgrown their space on Elizabeth Street, a quiet, tree-lined road next to the University of Connecticut School of Law and a few blocks from St. Francis Hospital.
The new building would expand the exhibit space from 6,000 square feet in a warren of low-ceilinged rooms to more than 30,000, enabling the display of many items currently in storage because of a lack of space.
Computers for the interactive exhibits, a cafeteria and gift shop are also included in the plan. The cost of the new building has not been determined, but Mr. Kahn estimated it may cost $40 million.
He said that Governor Rowland had asked the Bush administration for $25 million in federal funds for the project.
How this institution for scholars and school children managed to retain Mr. Gehry can be traced to Evan Dobelle, the former Trinity College president, who upon meeting Mr. Gehry asked him if he would be interested in designing a building in Hartford.
Mr. Dobelle, who is now the president of the University of Hawaii, masterminded the Learning Corridor, a complex of schools for children ages 3 through high school, a block from Trinity and in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods. The new history center will also be in the Trinity neighborhood but on Zion Street at its western edge, where new development has been virtually nonexistent.
But the exact location of the center is clouded. The land, in Rocky Ridge Park, is a 13-acre site owned by the city. Under the terms of its deed (Trinity gave the property to the city in a land exchange in 1891) if the land is sold, it must be replaced with similar property.
Potential parkland, however, is scarce in Hartford, Maxine Stewart, chairwoman of the city's parks and recreation advisory committee, said. 
"We were concerned about replacing all this green with asphalt and putting a huge building here that would stick out like a sore thumb," Ms. Stewart said. 
In the late 1980's, the city agreed to maintain the land for public outdoor recreation, thus any changes to the property would need the approval of the Hartford City Council and would be regulated by the state's attorney general.
But Mr. Kahn said he was not concerned because extensive legal research has already been done on the land. He said he planned to approach the city after Mr. Gehry visited the site later this year.
Mr. Kahn, however, said he would be thrilled by the specter of an about-face for the project, but acknowledged that some people, particularly those associated with the historical society when it was housed in the Wadsworth before the 1950's, were skeptical of the change.
"It is a major change," he said. "But it isn't a nutty scheme. Models of historical societies of our size scaling up to much larger facilities have been very successful."
The revamping of some of the city's cultural institutions coincides with the development of Adrian's Landing, a massive building project that will include a 500,000-square-foot convention center, a mix of residential and retail space and an entertainment center loosely defined as "science-based."
How to travel between all of the attractions when walking is not feasible?
One facet of the Hartford project, known as "Six Pillars," will address inadequate parking and poor public transportation, said Patrick L. Pinnell, a Higganum architect and the local planner for a 1998 development strategy study of the city.
Although R. Bartley Halloran, chairman of the Capital City Economic Development Authority, estimated the number of parking spaces for Adrian's Landing -- which he said the Wadsworth can share -- to be "in the thousands," Mr. Pinnell said he thought it still will not be enough spaces.
As for the city's public transportation, Mr. Pinnell said a range of transit strategies, including a light rail line and a jitney system that would ultimately connect cultural institutions and Adrian's Landing, has been considered. 
"With all three of these projects and Adrian's Landing, transportation is nobody's job to do right now," Mr. Pinnell said.
The Mark Twain House may not be an easy walk from downtown, yet some 52,000 people visit the writer's home each year. When a 35,000-square-foot visitor's center is built, the historic house will be able to accommodate more tours.
Robert A. M. Stern, an architect, was commissioned last spring to design the center, which board members and the staff said they believed will expand a typical one-hour visit to a half-day outing.
Ground will be broken this fall on the $11 million to $13 million project to house rotating exhibit space, an orientation film on Twain commissioned by the documentary film maker, Ken Burns, lecture hall and restaurant.
About $13 million has been raised through private donors, although a portion is earmarked for endowment and other capital projects. About $5.5 million dollars of state and federal financing was secured for house restoration.
Samuel Clemens, whose pen name was Mark Twain, lived with his family at the 19th-century house on Farmington Avenue from 1874 to 1891.
It was here, in rooms decorated by Louis Comfort Tiffany, he wrote his best-known books, including, "Huckleberry Finn," and "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer."
Before its major restoration in 1974, the house was used variously as a branch of the Hartford Public Library, a school, and private apartments. 
The challenge of the new building is its narrow and severely sloped site. Mr. Stern, who is the dean of the Yale University School of Architecture and in private practice in New York City, was hired with three criteria from the Mark Twain board: the new structure had to "resonate but not compete with the historic building," meet the needs of a revamped program for the house and maintain the historic landscape of the property.
The Mark Twain House sits in an area once known as Nook Farm, a literary enclave that also includes the home of the 19th-century writer Harriet Beecher Stowe.

HEADLINE: Cleaning Up the Stables, But Not With a Shovel 

BYLINE:  By LISA SUHAY 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSTOWN 

 BODY:
The barrels of drinking water were coated with green algae, and the stench of ammonia billowed from the barn, which had not been cleaned in months. Bill Lombardi, director of the Gloucester County Animal Shelter, began to gag.
 Leslie Toner of Holmdel, publisher of the online Horse and Farm Magazine and the founder of Horse Helpers R&R, said this was a scenario that had become more and more commonplace in recent years, resulting in a push for state legislation. 
 In fact, Ms. Toner said, New Jersey had more horses per square mile than any other state, while at the same time it had the nation's worst horse welfare system. 
There are more than 50,000 horses in New Jersey, and the four largest rescue operations here take in an average of 200 horses each year, Ms. Toner said. "There are approximately 300 rescues nationally. These nonprofit groups are staffed by volunteers and will take in starving or mistreated horses to be rehabilitated and adopted out to new owners."
At the petting zoo here, the owner was only given a warning, something Mr. Lombardi said was the norm in a state where local animal shelters, S.P.C.A. facilities and the police are not geared to handle anything bigger than a large dog.
Experts in the field of horse rescues say it is a combination of economics, ignorance and pride that is causing an increase in the number of rescues each year. People either underestimate the cost of owning an animal that spends 20 hours a day eating and requires constant veterinary attention, or they do not know enough about equine nutritional and medical needs, which are vast.
New Jersey has four nationally recognized horse rescue operations: Horse Helpers R&R in Holmdel; Mylestone Equine Rescue in Phillipsburg; Standard Bred Retirement Foundation, Freehold; and Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation Inc. in Shrewsbury. In addition, there are a handful of private individuals with farms who perform the same function.
These organizations, plus a dozen veterinarians and breeders, are trying to do through legislation what they have not been able to do any other way.
"I started my rescue and this legislation push out of rage," said Ms. Toner. "I have seen horses in this state starved and in condition that it would make your heart break just to look at them."
Ms. Toner said the case in Williamstown was classic, and one she intends to use in a package of information that she is putting together to approach state legislators.
"In this case the horses were starving because the farm owner had an economic problem," Ms. Toner said. "But it does not take a lot of money to clean and bleach out a water barrel so the horses do not dehydrate. That's neglect. That's where uniform standards would give local authorities some help and guidance."
To that end, Ms. Toner met recently with Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for governor, to discuss the future of the legislation that would charge each of the state's 76,000 stables and boarding facilities $100 a year for a license, raising more than $700,000 a year to assist in horse rescues.
Ms. Toner and a group of New Jersey breeders, veterinarians and rescue operators are working to create legislation that would mandate a uniform care standard for horses, following the lead of Georgia and Maryland in making the state Department of Agriculture, not local S.P.C.A.'s or animal control, responsible for the relocation of abused horses.
In the Williamstown case the owner, Debbie Mullen, had fallen on hard times after a divorce last winter, and the animals' welfare was put on a back burner, Mr. Lombardi said.
"She couldn't keep up the animals, and she was too proud to ask for help," Mr. Lombardi said. "She is embarrassed and angry that this is out in the open now. Just refused to tell anyone how bad it really was there. Believe me, it was bad."
On a lane where most homes have a paddock in the backyard and chickens pecking at the front walk, the sight of Ms. Mullen's five horses (two she owned, and three were boarded there), three ponies, a zebu -- an oxlike animal -- two goats, two sheep and one burro was not unusual.
Ms. Mullen and her daughter came to the chained and padlocked gate of her small, rundown farm, situated in a residential neighborhood where horses grazed in several back yards and chickens roamed the front walkways.
When asked about the complaints and the investigation, Ms. Mullen said: "The people who complained are just troublemakers. There is no problem here. Never was. The people who complained were just trying to harass me. My animals are nobody's business but mine."
Yet Mr. Lombardi said that Ms. Mullen had signed over two of the malnourished ponies to a local horse rescue organization.
In Ms. Mullen's case, the remaining animals that Mr. Lombardi examined and deemed also to be malnourished and poorly cared for remained with her and were receiving food and medical attention.
One horse boarded there, Jack, was returned to his owner, Marcia Samero, who said she placed Jack with Ms. Mullen because she was undergoing cancer treatment and could not care for him.
"I was horrified when I saw Jack," said Ms. Samero, who chose not to sue Ms. Mullen because she felt there would little chance of monetary satisfaction. "This made me wish stables were licensed so you could at least have the satisfaction of revoking it."
Mona Kanciper, founder of New York Horse Rescue, based in Manorville, on Long Island, said the problem of well-intentioned owners and boarding facilities starving animals was a nationwide problem.
"I think these people go into denial, then shame," Ms. Kanciper said. "I often wonder who we are rescuing -- the horses or the owners."
Kathleen Schwartz, founder of the Days Inn Horse Rescue in Lisbon, Md., said S.P.C.A.'s and local animal control could not afford to handle horses. Also, when a horse was seized in an abuse case, it was property -- and evidence -- that the police must hold on to until the case goes to court.
Agatha Abruzzo, who will only admit her age to be somewhere in the 80's, has run the Gloucester County S.P.C.A. since 1972 in addition to her own farm in Swedesboro.
"I don't get paid a dime to do this job," Ms. Abruzzo said. "If I get more than one call, if a couple of animals die, I try and get out there. But it's getting pretty tough at my age, and I just got out of the hospital and all. I rely on Bill Lombardi to help me out when he can."
Given a week to comply with a list of changes that included more hay, grain, clean water, clean stalls and veterinary treatment, Ms. Mullen had to turn to neighbors for help, according to Mr. Lombardi.
"She finally broke down and let people help her," he said. "There are plenty more people in her same situation in this state. Plenty of animals starving to death with owners too proud to ask and not enough of us to go around protecting them."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Pat Hancock, inset, with Jack, a horse that was boarded at a farm in Williamstown. The owner, Marcia Samero, said she was "horrified" when she saw the condition of Jack. A lone horse, left, at the Williamstown farm. (Photographs by Tim Shaffer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Reinventing the Golf Course, With Quality and Price in Mind

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
IF you are hooked on golf, chances are you have played a few of the many courses around Myrtle Beach, S.C., or Scottsdale, Ariz. Perhaps you have even visited the luxury resorts at Pinehurst in the hills of North Carolina or Pebble Beach on the rocky Monterey Peninsula of California -- or dreamed of doing so.
 But if you blanch at the thought of another visit to the overbuilt, ticky-tacky atmosphere of Myrtle Beach or paying, say, $600 for a room at the Lodge at Pebble Beach just to assure yourself a $350 tee time at the most famous course in the country, don't despair. 
 Golf will never be cheap, but there are a number of great new courses that any golfer can aspire to play. In the past, nearly all good courses were built for costly, exclusive country clubs near major cities, but many of the best new courses today are found at public resorts or in out-of-the-way destinations where beautiful unspoiled land is still available. 
"In the last decade or so, we've witnessed a second golden age of golf course design, and we're all the beneficiaries," said Joseph Mark Passov, author of "The Unofficial Guide to Golf Vacations in the Eastern U.S." "At the old-style resort, golf was more of an amenity to go along with everything else."
At the new destinations, Mr. Passov said, "you've got to have a spectacular-looking layout and provide a few thrills in the course of a round or the players just won't come."
"People will accept a few lost balls for that kind of experience," he added.
Indeed, as the standards of public golf have risen, some merely good courses are struggling to survive and many are cutting prices. Best of all for golfers, the modern look, while often highly stylized, harks back to the game's origins. 
Most of the stunning courses of recent years were inspired more by the wild, treeless landscapes of the links courses of the British Isles and the rugged, sand-filled challenges of the ultraprivate Pine Valley in southern New Jersey than by the lush, green-carpeted country club look brought to its highest polish at Augusta National, where the Masters tournament is played.
So where should you go to try a new-style course?
After the 1990's economic boom, golf meccas can be found in almost every region of the country, from northern Michigan to the Mississippi coast. Many of the best require some sort of trip from major cities: the Boulders, with its two moonscapelike courses north of Scottsdale, is luring vacationers away from the Phoenix sprawl; World Woods, north of Tampa, is a magnet for golfers looking for out-of-the-ordinary courses amid the flat Florida landscape.
Even places like Bismarck, N.D., with the stark Hawktree Golf Club featuring prairie-grass rough and black sand traps, and Anaconda, Mont., where Jack Nicklaus has built the inexpensive Old Works Course through the Superfund site of an abandoned copper smelter, now can boast of first-class golf, drawing players from far afield.
But the place that may be generating the most talk among golfers is the truly remote Bandon, Ore., where two courses have opened on a windswept bluff above the Pacific Ocean. Already, they are being compared to the best in the world.
The first course, designed by an unknown Scottish architect, David McLay Kidd, opened in 1999. Threading through sand dunes, wild grasses and wasteland, Bandon Dunes has seven holes along the ocean; all the others have ocean views. The second course, known as Pacific Dunes, opened this month. Designed by Tom Doak, a golf course architect who prides himself on avoiding artificiality, it appears even rawer.
I haven't been there, but Jaime Diaz, a contributing editor to Golf Digest magazine who has played most of the world's great courses, has tried both. 
"I'm convinced," Mr. Diaz wrote recently, "it won't be long before Bandon and Pacific -- given their public accessibility, unspoiled environment, dramatic setting, thoughtful design and true golf spirit -- are considered the best tandem of courses in the world."
THIS is golf for purists. There is little to do at the resort -- 100 miles north of the California state line and a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Eugene, Ore., the nearest city -- but play golf amid some of the most magnificent scenery in the country.
"Maybe you can't get farther from the Scotland-Ireland axis in the contiguous United States than the Oregon Coast," Mr. Diaz said, "but give or take a few pubs, you also can't get any closer to the cradle of the game."
By the standards of upscale golf, the Bandon courses are relative bargains. A round costs $120 in high season; add $70 to play a second round the same day. Walking is required; caddies are available.
Back from the ocean, there is a small lodge with 21 rooms and several outbuildings with rooms and suites at rates from $165 for two to $850 for a four-person cottage. The huge cedar-sided clubhouse has a modern look that nonetheless evokes the spirit of Sanford White's architecture. It offers a spa and exercise room; the resort has three restaurants. Other lodging and dining is available in the town of Bandon, but that is all simply a backdrop to the natural stage. 
"The courses look old even though they are new," Mr. Diaz said. "As a golf experience, these are as satisfying as anything anywhere. And once you get there, it's affordable. At Pebble, you're talking about $1,000 a day; at Bandon you can have the same thing for perhaps a little more than $200."
Perhaps. For those seeking a more complete resort experience (at significantly higher prices), but one where golf is still the prime attraction, there is probably nothing better than the American Club in, of all places, Kohler, Wis., home of the Kohler Company, the plumbing fixtures maker.
How do you get there? Fly to Milwaukee, the hub city of Midwest Express, and drive about an hour north on Interstate 43. Kohler is a classic company town; the luxury hotel was once a dormitory for immigrant men who arrived in the early decades of the 20th century to work at the factory.
Since 1988, Pete Dye has built four courses near the resort -- two along Lake Michigan, two wandering through a pristine river valley. 
The resort has a first-class spa and health club and excellent facilities for fishing, swimming and tennis. Seven restaurants are available.
The River Course and Meadow Valleys Course at Blackwolf Run evoke the classic parkland style though with diabolical touches: visually intimidating views from the tees, a number of tree-lined fairways yet many elevation changes that produce majestic vistas, trouble on most approach shots, tricky putting greens.
At Whistling Straits, by contrast, the three-year-old Straits Course, with eight holes directly along the shoreline, was modeled, like the Bandon courses, after the rugged, mostly treeless Irish and Scottish links of Ballybunion and Turnberry. Just inland is the more sedate Irish Course.
Walking is required on the Straits Course. And in a rare honor for such a new course, the Professional Golfers Association championship will be played there in 2004.
"It's very difficult, but not unfair," said Peter Jacobson, the professional golfer, who played there on his own last year. "To me, it's one of the most significant courses built in the U.S. in the last 50 years."
What if you don't want to go all out at a faraway resort? Golfers who live in the Northeast might want to think about Maryland as a closer alternative to the many resorts in Florida and the Carolinas.
Ocean City may be a honky-tonk beach town with its busy boardwalk, but it has also become almost a year-round golf destination where at least one new course, the Links at Lighthouse Sound, can lay claim to being among the best and most attractive marshland courses in the country.
Just across the bay from the barrier island strip, the course, designed by Arthur Hill, preserved hundreds of acres of pristine marsh and wooded wetlands. Certified as an Audubon Sanctuary, the course features a 1,500-foot elevated cart path, the longest in the country, to protect the marsh.
It is the best in an area that now features several highly rated courses like Rum Pointe and Eagle's Landing. 
Even closer to the population centers are a couple of new courses that are just off I-95 in northeastern Maryland. Bulle Rock, built by Pete Dye on the site of an old horse farm, has already received the maximum five stars from Golf Digest, and Beechtree, another natural layout by Mr. Doak, deserves better than the three-and-a-half stars it received. A long-neglected area, best known for the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground, it has little to offer visitors who want to stay the night. But when Bulle Rock opens a resort hotel in two years, along with an additional 18 holes, it should become a prime golf destination.
TO keep up with the new golf jewels, some traditional resorts have been forced to recut their aging courses to produce a fresh sparkle.
For example, the Sea Island Golf Club, in Georgia, which dates to 1927, has transformed a collection of 9-hole layouts into two different 18-hole courses. The new Seaside Course, by Tom Fazio, is a links-style course that extends the original design by Harry S. Colt and Charles Alison of London, who created or remodeled some of the greatest courses of the 1920's and early 1930's. The other, known as Plantation, was rebuilt by Rees Jones as an updated but classic tree-lined design. A third redesigned course is scheduled to open this year.
And the resort, known for the Cloister, the traditional hotel nearby, has built a luxury lodge and clubhouse amid the golf courses.
Indeed, for all the economic troubles of the golf business, the best of the old and the new appear to be coming together as never before.
"I believe," Mr. Diaz said, "the best courses ever designed are being built right now." 

How to Find the First-Class Fairways
HERE are a few reliable guides to golf resorts and other places to play:
* "The Unofficial Guide to Golf Vacations in the Eastern U.S.," by Joseph Mark Passov (IDG Books Worldwide, 2000, $16.99). Although limited mainly to the East Coast, it provides detailed information about courses, lodging and packages.
* "Fodor's Golf Digest's Places to Play" (Fodor's Travel Publications, 2000, $25). An extensive thumbnail guide to more than 6,000 public courses, based on comments from readers of the magazine. Courses are rated on a five-star system.
* "Golf Magazine's Top 100 Courses You Can Play" by Brian McCallen (Harry N. Abrams, 1999, $49.50). It provides an introduction to the best public courses in the country, with excellent photographs. 
* "The Confidential Guide to Golf Courses" by Tom Doak (Sleeping Bear Press, 1996, $45). While not restricted to public courses, it offers an insightful and opinionated view from an up-and-coming architect of golf courses.
* On the Internet. Many courses and resorts have Web sites. Among the sites are bandondunesgolf.com, beechtreegolf.com, bullerock.com, destinationkohler.com, hawktree.com, ocean-city.com/golf/,
oldworks.org, seaisland.com and
worldwoods.com.

An article last Sunday about the proliferation of new golf courses omitted the name of the publication in which Jaime Diaz, a contributing editor to Golf Digest magazine, wrote that the Bandon Dunes and Pacific Dunes courses in Oregon would in time be "considered the best tandem of courses in the world." It was the July-August issue of T & L Golf.

HEADLINE: Playland: Treasured Spot Or Money Pit? 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: RYE 

 BODY:
THE waves lapped against the shore, almost in rhythm to the lilting fox trot played on the boardwalk by the Milt Gerver Orchestra. Dozens of elderly people danced in front of the bandstand as Mr. Gerver smiled in his crisp white blazer.
 Nearby, teenagers squealed with excitement as the high-flying Sea Dragon ride propelled them high into the noisy night. Well-dressed couples with strollers watched fireworks splashing Technicolor memories across the evening sky. 
 It was another Friday night at Playland and all seemed right with the world. Problems were as distant as the twinkling lights across Long Island Sound. 
But all is not right with Playland. Tomorrow morning, the Westchester County Legislature will meet in special session to discuss problems facing the park.
When Playland opened in 1928, it was called "the crowning achievement of the Westchester County Parks Commission." Praised for its sophisticated design, it once attracted four million visitors a year. But this golden age is long gone, and for decades the park has drawn complaints from neighbors, upset about traffic and the behavior of parkgoers, and charges from critics that it is mismanaged. 
These days especially, Playland is showing its age.
The colonnades that frame the park's main mall, as well as the 14 towers, have deteriorated and are sinking into the sandy soil. The structures are considered a crucial element in the park's landmark status. So park officials want to build replicas.
But last month, the county's Board of Legislators voted against allocating the entire $10 million needed for the project. Playland officials reacted by saying that this would bruise the park's historic integrity and might endanger its standing as the nation's only amusement park registered as a historic landmark.
County Executive Andrew J. Spano had requested the funds for the colonnade project. The board had already approved $3 million for park infrastructure repairs and had approved $6.2 million for the colonnade project. But when the cost rose to $10 million, many legislators called it exorbitant and voted to send the proposal back to the budget committee for reconsideration.
The board also refused to allocate an extra $1.2 million for a new performance stage.
Some legislators called Playland "a money pit," and said that instead of spending millions on a park that loses money every year, the county should use the money for ball fields, day care centers or tax breaks.
"The park should be a business and stand on its own," said Michael B. Kaplowitz, a Democrat from Somers, a legislator and vice chairman of the board's budget committee. "I have no problem with the park not turning a profit. I don't want to bring in Six Flags and turn it into a mega-amusement park and ruin the history of it, and I certainly don't want to be the legislator who finished Playland.
"But we have to do it cost-effectively and I find it difficult to accept having to spend $10 million to restore these pillars. We don't have a bottomless pit of money. Think of what that money could buy in terms of baseball fields or social services or open space."
Katherine S. Carsky, a Republican from Yonkers, suggested rethinking the county's position on the park: "We're spending a disproportionate amount of our parks funding on Playland," she said, "and we want to be assured that we're not spending good money after bad."
But Mr. Spano and some legislators called the board's actions a threat to Playland, which they consider an irreplaceable county treasure, one that has survived as a family park even as others, including Asbury Park, Freedomland and Palisades Park, have deteriorated.
"To deny money to a place like Playland because it's not making a profit as a public park, I find ludicrous," Mr. Spano said. "The parks are for the enjoyment of the people. These new legislators have to understand the significance of Playland."
He added, "This county has enough money to fix Playland and to build things like ball fields, and we're going to do both."
Of the $35.8 million that the county spent operating its parks last year, some $13 million was allocated to Playland. But, as Stanley G. Motley, the county's parks commissioner, pointed out, gross profits from Playland constitute almost half the $25 million in total annual revenue the county makes from the entire parks system.
And park officials argue the amusement park itself is no burden on taxpayers. In fact, they said, it makes a profit of about $50,000. Of course, running the rest of Playland -- the ice rink, the beach and the pool -- costs the county over $1 million a year.
Playland's director, Joseph G. Montalto, said Playland has had a resurgence over the last few years, attracting more than a million people a year since 1998. The recent denial of funds, he said, would work against the park's comeback.
He called Playland "an economic engine" that helps local businesses and draws tourists. The park is the largest single provider of summer jobs in Westchester, he said, offering roughly 1,000 seasonal positions.
Mr. Montalto said the colonnade structures continue to deteriorate and that "at some point, it's sink or swim," for them. 
Much of Playland's niche as a quaint family park, he said, comes from its historic structures and removing the colonnades would "wreck the feel of the park."
"This is a hands-on, living, working museum," Mr. Montalto said. "When people come here, it's like they just stepped back into the 1930's, and they like it that way."
Repairing Playland will only increase its profitability, he said. For example, building a new performance stage would enable the park to hold evening concerts by high-profile performers, attracting up to 10,000 paying customers. He called the current stage outdated and "held together with spit and rubber bands."
When Pat Benatar played there last summer, she parked her tour bus behind the stage to provide bathrooms and other space the stage lacked.
George S. Latimer, chairman of the Board of Legislators and the legislator representing Rye, defends Playland and said it was wrong to expect it to turn a profit.
Unlike privately run amusement parks that can focus on making money, he said, Playland has other obligations, including being a good neighbor, being environmentally conscious and providing affordable family-style entertainment.
He said the county's money is well spent on Playland, especially because many park users come from lower- and middle-income families with fewer leisure alternatives.
"Playland is an anachronism," he said, "but to call it a money pit and say it has to pay for itself is an immature response."
Playland may be Westchester's most renowned spot. It has been seen in films like "Big," "Fatal Attraction" and "Sweet and Lowdown," as well as music videos, including Mariah Carey's "Fantasy."
"You talk to some people around this country, and if they know one thing about Westchester County, it's Playland," said Mr. Motley, who has held parks commissioner positions throughout the country.
Playland replaced a ramshackle seaside resort that included, according to an old newspaper article, "bawdy hotels and rowdy amusement areas attracting unsavory crowds."
The City of Rye petitioned the county to buy the area and develop it. County leaders built the park along with a lattice of parkways to draw potential homebuyers to Westchester. Playland Parkway was built, "insuring a middle-class clientele arriving by car," noted one newspaper account.
Designers had the lofty goal of creating "an amusement park possessing artistic merit to attract a class of people who before resented going to summer amusement resorts of the 'Coney Island' type and to educate the habitual amusement parkgoers to an appreciation and a desire for things beautiful."
"Playland is not an amusement park," declared one 1928 advertisement. "It is a greater, finer, better thing. Playland is the start of a modern recreation center such as the world has never known."
The park opened on Memorial Day weekend in 1928 with the hoopla of a World's Fair. The only amusement park designed in Art Deco style, Playland was called the "the poor man's country club."
The park was unique in that it was county-designed, built and operated.
Admission to Playland has always been free, and when the park first opened, parking cost 25 cents and rides cost 15 cents. 
The park featured a circus, aerial acts, human cannonballs and live organists. The sound system piped "restrained harmonious music" through seven wooden speakers, 40 feet long and 7 feet wide.
Playland draws nowhere near the crowds it did in its earlier days. A typical hot Sunday would find some 20,000 people on the beach, according to newspaper articles. Playland now gets less than 100,000 beach and poolgoers over the entire summer (65,843 last year because of rainy weekends and 97,192 in 1999).
Although Rye residents were eager to see Playland replace the colony of hotels, restaurants and slapdash carnival attractions that had occupied the site, the City of Rye has never exactly embraced Playland.
Before the park opened in 1928, The Rye Chronicle warned that Rye "may not relish the idea of having its fine shorefront monopolized by great hordes from New York," but added that marketers would book group excursions that would "bring a desirable class of business to Playland."
After Playland opened, another article reported that residents were complaining that "the amusement park was noisy and attracted undesirables, and Playland officials countering with charges that enforcement of Rye's petty ordinances was interfering with the operation of the park."
Neighbors complained about overflow parking that interrupted local baseball games and parkgoers who changed their clothes in their cars.
Even today, Playland is still one of the most important issues in Rye.
"There's almost a love-hate relationship here," said Arthur H. Stampleman, a member of the Rye City Council, who explained that complaints about traffic, fireworks and rude patrons seem to be an inevitable result of Playland being in the middle of an upscale bedroom community.
"All you need is something bothersome to happen once or twice a year, and that's what people remember," he said.
Rye has never tried to draw parkgoers to its shops. There are no stores along Playland Parkway and no signs indicating that Rye Village, a thriving downtown of boutiques and sandwich shops, is a minute's drive away.
"Capitalizing on the park by pulling its clientele into the shopping area has just never been done," said Barbie Haynes, a real estate agent at Merritt Associates, an agency in Rye. "Rye has always kept them two separate entities. The main objective of the Playland clientele is to get to Playland, and then leave and go home."
Ms. Haynes said that a property near the Playland tends to be "at a little lesser price point than if it were in a quieter neighborhood in Rye."
But some buyers, she said, enjoy the prospect of living near Playland. "We tell them, 'It's not like one of those new parks over in Jersey. It's an amusement park that's been here forever, and it's something you have to do once a summer with your kids.' "
Many residents are still seething over an incident earlier this month. Playland booked an outing for some 11,000 corrections officers, but traffic flooded the park early on and the park had to close its gates, causing traffic backups along Playland Parkway and onto Interstate 95.
Michael Klemens, chairman of the City of Rye's Planning Commission who lives just off Playland Parkway, said that such backups plague local residents because some park-bound drivers pull over and start their partying roadside, often drinking and urinating and "making out" in his yard.
"There have been times we've had to retreat into the house," he said, adding that it is also unfair to parkgoers. "I've seen families sitting in three-hour traffic jams with kids screaming and crying.
"It's a very deep and complicated issue, and it's been a major source of tension in the community," he said. "People have said, 'Close it down,' and there's a hysteria: people want to pull up all bridges, but you can't. The reality is that we both need to be good neighbors. We should not shut our community off just because they come from 'outside areas,' whether it's Scarsdale or the Bronx."
Mayor Steven Otis called Playland "a mixture of benefits and burdens for our community" but added that things have improved and that Rye has been working with the county to address the main problem of weekend traffic congestion.
The park has stopped running garbage trucks in the early morning, and when residents complained that Playland's Wednesday evening fireworks show was waking their children, park officials removed louder rockets from the show and moved that starting time to 9:15, from after 10.
"It's a fantastic place 10 months a year -- it's the two summer months that are the problem," said Lillian Candreva, who lives near the park on a block that she says is used as a shortcut by parkgoers. Some have, on occasion, parked in front of her house and barbecued on her lawn, she said, leaving behind trash, including disposable diapers.
Another nearby resident, Orna Nahor, had similar complaints. Ms. Nahor takes her children to Playland about twice a week. Still, she said, problems arise when the parking lots fill up. Then users park at Rye Town Park and damage its lawns. They also spill out onto Playland's fringes, starting ad-hoc picnics and parking lot parties.
"Here you have one of the richest places in the world and it looks like a third world country," she said. "If you come from Harlem and the Bronx, great. But take care of it. Don't leave trash all over."
In the past, the park was plagued with urban problems, like gang-related fights. But things have improved, with fewer park users getting into trouble. 
"The people come here off 95 and they go right back onto 95," Mr. Montalto said.
Certainly, Playland's clientele has changed over the years.
For one thing, it has gotten more difficult to attract suburban families who can take more upscale vacations.
Mr. Montalto said it was difficult to say where visitors are from, but on weekdays the park is used more by Westchester residents, including many camps. On weekends, there are more people from outside Westchester, mostly from New York City.
"There's always been a relationship between Westchester and the city," he said. "It's not a foreign country."
There has been much debate over whether to modernize Playland to attract thrill-seekers from far and wide or to preserve its older elements and protect the park as a historic treasure serving more of a local family clientele.
Park officials say the decision is at the heart of the future of Playland. A successful strategy, they say, requires a delicate balance between attention to the old and the new.
Over the last few years, the county has intensified its marketing -- largely in New York City -- touting its exciting new rides. 
But Playland cannot compete with larger amusement parks, Mr. Montalto said. It can only survive, he argued, by maintaining its niche as a family amusement park.
Overloading the park with newer rides could both threaten its landmark status and drive away customers who enjoy Playland's quaintness.
Of course, many Playland patrons care little about the historic structures. Last Wednesday, the temperatures were in the 90's, and the Rivera family stood on the boardwalk enjoying the 73-year-old bathhouse tower more for the shade it offered than its Spanish Revival art deco style.
Carlos and Maria Rivera had taken the train and bus from the South Bronx, bringing their three young children.
'It's nice to have the beach and the rides in one place," Ms. Rivera said. "Plus, it's nicer than Coney Island."

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON; E-mail address: westarts@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Following the Hudson River School
 A summer's day, a river view, a sketchpad. Historic Hudson Valley is inviting artists at all levels to share in the landscape that inspired Hudson River School painters like Thomas Cole. The place is Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills, where a two-day drawing class, "The Artist's Eye," will take place Aug. 9-10. 
 You provide the drawing board, sketchbook and other supplies; Historic Hudson will provide transportation from Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown, a box lunch and the landscape. The course is limited to 20 people and costs $70 ($55 for members of Historic Hudson). 
Susan Greenstein, who directs programs at Kykuit, said the class was something new for Historic Hudson. "When you're up at Kykuit, you're surrounded by Governor Rockefeller's painting and sculpture collections, the gardens and the same view of the river that inspired all those 19th-century artists," she said. "So often, visitors say it would be wonderful to have some time to relax here. This is a real opportunity to give people a chance to do some of their own drawing on the grounds." 
To set the mood, Gillian Greenhill Hannum, a professor of art history at Manhattanville College, will begin with a lecture on the Hudson River School. The next day, she will read from Emerson, Thoreau and Washington Irving. The drawing instructor, Francis Sprout, will demonstrate Hudson River School techniques.
Mr. Sprout, who teaches at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and at Manhattanville, is a conceptual artist who began as a landscape painter. Why will the students sketch and not paint at Kykuit? To be true to 19th-century methods, Mr. Sprout said.
Information: (914) 631-8200, ext. 618.

Widening an Orchestra's Appeal
Michael Shapiro has what every conductor hopes for -- his own orchestra to shape. Mr. Shapiro is the new music director of the 42-year-old Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra, a semiprofessional group with many volunteer players that performs at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua.
"Under me this orchestra will be different," Mr. Shapiro said, promising to bring in new audiences by programming "the music of our common heritage."
This means music from Broadway and Hollywood as well as a concert in memory of Holocaust victims. (Mr. Shapiro, a 16-year Chappaqua resident who is also a composer and pianist, was a music consultant to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.) The season will open on Nov. 17 at 4 p.m. at Horace Greeley High School auditorium with a family concert called "Storybook Hour."
"We're concerned with breaking down the old barriers, so the choice of repertoire is very important," Mr. Shapiro said of his mission to attract teenagers, in particular. "We want to be a compelling choice." Information: (914) 238-1373.

For Arts, the Economy Is Booming
Alvin H. Reiss sees the big picture when he views the American art scene. From his perch, the arts in America are "in a stronger position than ever before."
Mr. Reiss of Somers teaches, lectures and writes about arts management, has been monitoring the health of arts institutions for 40 years. He also edits the periodical Arts Management and has written books like "Don't Just Applaud, Send Money." 
He accentuates the positive when he counsels arts groups on approaching businesses for money. "They've got to learn what resources they have, and not undersell themselves," he said. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

LENGTH: 1993 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Belmont; 
Close-Knit Bronx Area With Italian Aura

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
FOR hundreds of thousands of Italian-Americans in the metropolitan area and beyond, it is "the old neighborhood," a hallowed place remembered at family gatherings, the setting for countless stories told to children and grandchildren. It is Belmont, the Little Italy of the Bronx.
 "We didn't know what grass was; our ballparks were the streets," said Salvatore Addeo, 68, a co-owner of Addeo & Sons bakery at Hughes Avenue and 186th Street in Belmont, who returns to the neighborhood most weekdays to bake the bread. "But the best days of my life were here." 
 Mr. Addeo moved to Ardsley in Westchester County in 1960, but he continues to run the bakery that his father, Gennaro, founded in 1930. The staff still adds up an order by hand on a paper bag, but Addeo's was ranked as the No. 3 "Best Buy" in Zagat's 2000 Guide to the New York Marketplace . Many other restaurants and groceries in the neighborhood are ranked high by the guidebook, including Borgatti's Ravioli, the Calabria Pork Store and Dominick's restaurant, which does not provide menus. 
Finding real estate in the area is difficult because most buildings are sold through family and friends. The handful of real estate agents and building management companies in the area advertise mainly rentals. "Everything that is sold here is sold by word of mouth," said Frank Franz, president of the Belmont Small Business Association and a lifelong resident.
Belmont has remained popular in part because of its lively commercial district, its strong ethnic flavor and its proximity to the Bronx Zoo, the New York Botanical Gardens and Fordham University. St. Barnabas Hospital is on the edge of the neighborhood. 
In recent years, demand for housing in the area has escalated. Mr. Franz said he received more than 40 phone calls from people asking about availability of apartments in a tenement building with nine apartments that he is rehabilitating. "There never would have been that kind of interest 5 or 10 years ago," he said. Mr. Franz attributed the increased interest to the Bronx's improved image in recent years.
Most of the neighborhood is made up of tenements built from the turn of the last century to the Great Depression. Most tenement buildings, which usually have between 15 and 25 apartments, sell for about $500,000 to $700,000, said Joe Cicciu, executive director of the Belmont-Arthur Avenue Local Development Corporation, which builds low- to middle-income housing in the area.
Most of the apartments are rent stabilized, and as a result the rents are low, according to Mr. Cicciu and Catherine Macri, who manages tenements in the neighborhood for Cosmopolitan Property Management. Rents for the one-bedroom apartments range from $500 to $600, while two bedrooms can go for $600 to $800, they said.
There are also many brick and wood-frame houses for one to four families. The most common are two-family homes, which cost $150,000 to $175,000, Mr. Cicciu said. "It's good immigrant stock housing."
The immigrants, first Germans and Irish, began arriving in the 1880's. In the 1890's and thereafter it was Italians, who began moving into the neighborhood when the Third Avenue elevated train was built as far north as Tremont Avenue, said Lloyd Ultan, the Bronx borough historian. When newspapers that circulated in Little Italy and East Harlem, both of which were also served by the Third Avenue El, began advertising apartments for rent in Belmont, many immigrants made their way there, he said.
Long before the immigrant influx, during the colonial days, the area was farmland that covered most of the western Bronx. When the land was divided into estates in the mid-19th century, the Belmont area was given to the Lorillard family, tobacco producers. They lived on a mansion on the hill where St. Barnabas Hospital now stands and named their area "Beautiful Mountain" or the Latin version, Belle Mont.
When the city began to build streets in the area in the late 19th century, Catherine Lorillard, an admirer of the 21st president, Chester A. Arthur, asked that the main street in the area be named after him, Mr. Ultan said. (Hughes Avenue, one block to the east, was named after John Hughes, the founder of Fordham University and first Roman Catholic archbishop of New York.)
With the exception of some city subsidized towers that were built on the neighborhood's eastern fringe during the 1970's, little was constructed in Belmont from the late 1950's to the mid-1990's. But during the 1990's the area experienced a rebound along with much of the rest of the Bronx, and low-rise buildings designed for Fordham students began to sprout up north of 188th Street.
The Third Avenue el was demolished in 1973, and now the closest subway lines are the B and D under the Grand Concourse, a 15-minute walk away. The best way to get to Manhattan, residents say, is by Metro-North, whose station at East Fordham Road is 20 minutes from Grand Central.
PARKING is scarce, especially in the evenings, when the restaurants are filled. Much of the neighborhood's business comes from visitors -- including celebrities like Joe Pesci, Robert De Niro and Joe Torre -- who come from the suburbs, from Manhattan and from around the world to eat in one of about 10 Italian restaurants or shop in dozens of specialty food shops on or near Arthur Avenue. 
The exodus of Italians who lived in the area may have changed the residential character of the neighborhood, which is increasingly heterogeneous as Albanians, immigrants from the former Yugoslavia, Mexicans and Dominicans have moved in, but the commercial feel is still overwhelmingly Italian and old New York.
"In other parts of the city there are individual businesses that are nearly 100 years old," said Peter Madonia, 47, owner of the Madonia Brothers bakery on Arthur Avenue, "But nowhere else are there 12 of them on the same block, all with the same families still running them."
Most of the owners of the shops have moved to different neighborhoods or to the suburbs. But some have stayed, including Joe Liberatore, who sells plants, fruit and vegetables from a stand in the Arthur Avenue Market, an open market inside a building at 2344 Arthur Avenue that was built in 1940. Mr. Liberatore, 83, arrived in the neighborhood in 1936 and began by selling potatoes and onions from a pushcart for 5 cents for three pounds. "I've been here since I got off the boat," he joked.
"It's not that people moved away," said Mr. Liberatore, who lives in one of the few high-rise towers, Keith Plaza."The younger generation, as they grew up and got married, they moved up to Connecticut, out to Jersey and up to Westchester," he said.
Still, the pace of turnover is slow. Vanetta Wilson, a 26-year-old lifelong resident, who lives in a one-bedroom apartment on Hoffman Street, said, "The same people have been here for so long that everybody knows everybody." She said the neighborhood was convenient for any kind of shopping she needed. "People come from upstate to go to the bakeries, and we're right next door."
But her friend, Erin Rimmer, 18, noted that heavy "tourism," as it's called in the neighborhood, does not necessarily make the neighborhood much more livable. "That's nice that they come here, but once it turns dark, it's dangerous," she said.
Once ubiquitous graffiti have been removed, and murder and robbery rates are down from what they were 10 years ago, but Ms. Wilson said the neighborhood was more dangerous now than when she grew up there. "You can't let the kids walk to school alone," she said. "When I was a kid, we always walked to school alone."
Ms. Wilson, a stay-at-home mother, attended Public School 32, the Belmont School, on East 183rd Street, where slightly more than a quarter of the 1,094 students read at grade level or above, a rate well below the citywide average of 42 percent.
The neighborhood's other public elementary school, P. S. 205, the Fiorello H. La Guardia School, is a few blocks away on Southern Boulevard. Last year it had an enrollment of 1,043. One third of its students read at or above grade level, according to the Board of Education statistics.
Most children from the local public elementary schools continue on to Middle School 45, the Thomas C. Giordano School, on Lorillard Place, where the extracurricular activities include a competitive chess team, a yearbook and a school newspaper.
There are also two Roman Catholic elementary schools in the area: Our Lady of Mount Carmel Parish Elementary School on Bathgate Avenue and St. Martin of Tours Parish Elementary School on 182nd Street. Both cover kindergarten through eighth grade, and tuition is about $1,700 a year.
THERE are also two Catholic high schools in the area. Aquinas High School, for girls, has an enrollment of 788 in Grades 9 through 12 and has been recognized by the United States Department of Education and by U.S. News & World Report as one of the top performing high schools in the country. Its tuition is $3,950 a year. Nearby is Fordham Prep, an all-boys school, where tuition is $8,530 a year. Located on the Fordham University campus, many of its 875 students commute by Metro-North from Westchester.
The public high school for the neighborhood is Theodore Roosevelt High School, on Fordham Road across from the university.
Belmont is home to a number of cultural institutions, including the Belmont Italian-American Playhouse, the Enrico Fermi Cultural Center, a library and center for the study of Italian American culture, and the Bronx Dance Theater, a studio that will celebrate its 25th anniversary in December.
"For an arts organization, that's a long time," said Neil Goldstein, the director of the studio, "but for an institution in this neighborhood, it's chopped liver."
As an example, the Teitel Brothers specialty grocery shop has been on Arthur Avenue and 186th Street since 1915, when Jacob and Morris Teitel, tailors who had recently arrived from Austria, set up their grocery. "There was a stable across the street," said Jacob's son, Gil Teitel, who owns the shop. "We used to deliver orders by horse and wagon."
While Belmont weathered some tough economic times during the 70's and 80's, the close-knit community has provided stability not found in most city neighborhoods. "We could have taken our businesses and gone up north to Westchester and probably done O.K.," Mr. Madonia said. "But there's just sort of an aura about the place and a sense of community here."

GAZETTEER

RUSH-HOUR COMMUTATION TO MIDTOWN: 10 to 15 minutes on the Bx12 to Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse, then 30 minutes on the B or D trains. 20 minutes from the Fordham station on Metro-North's Harlem and New Haven Lines ($4.75 one way, $108 for a monthly pass).
GOVERNMENT: City Councilman Joel Rivera (Democrat).
CODES: Area, 718 and 347; ZIP, 10458.
THE STUFF OF LEGEND: In 1958, Dion DiMucci and a group of his neighborhood friends formed Dion and the Belmonts, probably the most famous white doo-wop group. The group had three top-10 hits, "I Wonder Why," "A Teenager in Love" and "Where or When." The group helped put the neighborhood on the map and Hollywood has done so also. The 1993 movie "A Bronx Tale," produced by Robert De Niro, was set in Belmont. The main character, a boy named Calogero Anello, grew up on East 187th Street next to Chez Bippy, the club where the local gangsters hung out. The movie describes what happens after Calogero meets Sonny, the local crime boss. "I could live anywhere I want to," Sonny says to Calogero. "You know why I live in this neighborhood? Availability. I want to stay close to everything."

HEADLINE: For Sale: Minimalist Condos, No View 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
IT wasn't until Michael Friedman bought a car a year or two after moving from Manhattan back to his native Brooklyn in 1981 that he remembered how his schoolteacher father, Louis, had circled the block again and again hoping to find a parking spot on the street. And after he finally found one, he hesitated to move the car from its space rather than repeat the ordeal.
 Not so Michael, a lawyer. He parked his car in a garage in his Park Slope neighborhood so that he could come and go when he wanted. But in 1986, with the garage steadily raising its parking rates, he read about a free-standing six-story garage whose parking spaces were to be sold as condominiums. Since buying a parking space essentially meant having it as long as he wanted, Mr. Friedman took out a bank loan and bought one of the condo spaces for $29,000. 
 "I figured that if you plan to live in the area long enough, you'd come out ahead buying the space," said Mr. Friedman, who with his wife, Ruth Witztum, also a lawyer, has lived in Park Slope almost 20 years. Yet to this day incredulous acquaintances still sometimes ask, "What do you mean, you have a condo for your car?" 
They might be more surprised if they knew that instead of driving to his law office in the Empire State Building, he commutes by subway. Or that his car is in the garage most of the time except on weekends. And still more surprised to know that numbers of condominium or co-op parking spaces in New York cost far more than the price Mr. Friedman paid for his. 
For example, at 429-35 Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, where an 1897 lantern factory was converted into 28 condo apartments five years ago, the asking price for the 18 indoor condo parking spaces ranges from $45,000 to $80,000. One prospective buyer asked whether the $80,000 space included a new car. 
The asking price for one of the 400 outdoor co-op parking spaces at Lincoln Towers on West End Avenue, ranges between $30,000 and $40,000, on the rare occasions that any become available.
In addition to the purchase price, owners of condo parking spaces pay a common charge, which at 429-35 Greenwich Street ranges from $75 to $130. And owners of parking spaces at co-ops pay a monthly maintenance, which at North Shore Towers in Queens ranges from $46 to $103.
North Shore Towers, which is on the Nassau County border in Floral Park, has 2,400 underground parking spaces for its 1,844 apartments and another 125 spaces outdoors. Robert Serikstad, the site controller with the Charles H. Greenthal Management Corporation, which manages the property, said that some parking slots are still available under the co-op sponsor's offering plan, at price tags ranging from $8,000 for an outdoor space to $10,000 for an underground space to $15,000 for an underground space big enough to accommodate two end-to-end full-sized cars. 
Resales of parking spaces in condos and co-ops are negotiated between buyer and seller and are often less, sometimes substantially so, than the sponsor's asking price. 
An explanation for this decline in price is that spaces for sale at a co-op or condo can usually be sold only to tenants of those buildings. An important reason for that stipulation is security, according to Jim Bennett, a real estate lawyer in Manhattan. "They only want people in those spaces who live in the building," he said. "They don't want strangers wandering around." In addition, he added, the certificate of occupancy for the building sometimes prohibits outsiders from using the property, which therefore limits the sale of parking spaces to residents. 
A letter in May from the ACP Realty Group in Manhattan to tenants of 180 West End Avenue in Lincoln Towers said that an outdoor space was available for sale to current shareholders for $40,000. However, Polly McLeod in ACP's sales office said vacancies come up rarely, usually no more than three or four times a year. "But I still get people calling all the time saying, 'I live here; what can I do to get a space?' " she said.
IN downtown Brooklyn, on a five and a half acre site at 175 and 191 Willoughby Street and 122 Ashland Place, the three 16-story University Towers co-ops have 275 outdoor parking spaces for the 549 apartments. So far 120 parking spaces have been sold, and the asking price for the remaining 155 is $15,000. "The reason we haven't sold more," said Daniel L. Rosenfield, a principal in University Towers Associates, the sponsor, "is that transportation around there is so convenient. All three subway lines and many buses converge at the buildings." But based on the growth in the borough, Mr. Rosenfield added, "Demand is only going to increase." 
Despite the 187,862 spaces in the city's 1,096 commercial parking garages and the 94,434 spaces in its 855 commercial lots, according to the Metropolitan Parking Association, many if not most New Yorkers, especially Manhattan residents, are not eager to pay to park, which accounts for the daily round robin of searching for a parking space on the street.
Parking space in New York does not come cheap, of course, nor does the real estate for parking garages and lots. A survey late last year of almost 200 licensed parking lots and garages throughout Manhattan found that while parking at some Midtown garages can cost $50 a day or $1,000 a month, including the 18.25 percent parking tax, the average monthly charge ranges from $250 to $450.
It does not help the parking crunch that the ratio of parking spaces to apartments is almost certainly less than it was two decades ago, when developers were required to provide 40 parking spaces for every new 100 apartments. In 1982, however, concerns about traffic and air pollution prompted city planners to limit the number of new garages that could be built and to eliminate the requirement that developers provide parking spaces. The assumption was that this would discourage residents from keeping cars in the city, especially in Manhattan. 
Developers are still not required to provide parking spaces, and in new buildings south of 60th Street they are limited to 20 percent of the number of new apartments or 200 spaces, whichever is less. North of 60th Street, in Community District 7 (roughly 59th to 110th Streets on the Upper West Side) and Community District 8 (the Upper East Side from 59th Street to 96th Street), they are limited to 35 percent or 200 spaces, whichever is less. 
Such limits are a big reason that so many car owners have to search for parking space on city streets, a city where, as Steven Benardo, the president of the Association of Riverdale Cooperatives, put it, "people design their life around parking." 
Scrambling for space still requires spending lots of time circling the block or idling near a spot where parking will be legal after the hours set aside for the street cleaners expire. But people who park on the street were recently given a modicum of relief. For several decades alternate-side parking prohibitions were in effect for three hours at a time, but about 18 months ago they were reduced by half on many residential streets, after the Department of Sanitation determined that 90 minutes was enough time for the street-cleaning machines to do their job.
In the mid-1970's, after almost six years of parking on the streets near his apartment in the mid-80's near Broadway, Les Graifman finally rented a parking space for about $25 a month at 134th Street and Riverside Drive. But rather than take a subway up to or back from the garage, he decided to combine economy with fitness by jogging the 50 or so blocks each way.
"I not only paid a fraction of what garages around my neighborhood would have cost," said Mr. Graifman, the executive director of the Well Spouse Foundation, an organization for husbands and wives of the chronically ill, "it allowed me to still keep in pretty good shape."
BUT the garage was unheated, and he tired of periodically sitting in the winter cold waiting for the automobile club to come start his car. So after six years of using the garage, he sold his car, and these days whenever he needs one, he rents it.
"Between the cost of parking and insurance, it makes more sense to rent a car in Manhattan than to own one," he said, "unless you have a lot of available cash." 
To park a car on New York streets each night, it also helps to have a good memory as well as patience. Mary Ann Rothman, the executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, used to go to Cape Cod every year for six weeks. But by the time she returned to the city to her prewar building that did not have any parking spaces, "I forgot about alternate side parking and those hundreds of hours of circling," she said.
But it did not take long for the inevitable flurry of traffic tickets to remind her and to conclude that "a car is an albatross in Manhattan, especially in Midtown." 
Another albatross, though one that has been removed for certain residents, has been the 18.25 percent parking tax. The tax is still in place at the 830 commercial garages and 406 commercial parking lots in Manhattan, according to Robert Ull, president of UlltraCar Park System, Inc. headquartered in Manhattan. But on Feb. 6 of this year, according to the city's Department of Finance, owners of condos and shareholders in co-ops who park in garages or lots at their buildings were exempted from all parking taxes. Before that, Manhattan residents were exempt from only 10 percent of the 18.25 percent taxes if their parking spaces were managed by the homeowners associations, not by commercial parking companies. 
With an average 1.9 million vehicles entering or leaving Manhattan every day, according to a 1999 survey by the city's Department of Transportation, it is no surprise that the competition for parking spaces is exceedingly intense in the borough. But there is plenty of jockeying for space in those other boroughs as well, even including parts of Staten Island. According to Joel Stahl, the executive director of the Metropolitan Parking Association, Staten Island has just one licensed parking garage with space for 200 cars and five outdoor lots with space for another 1,052.
The scrambling helps explain why perfectly rational New Yorkers are willing, and in some cases eager, to pay so much for a parking space -- a parking space for which in many cases they had to wait for years.
But salespeople say that even tenants who are eligible to buy condo or co-op parking spaces are turned off by the cost, saying they would rather continue circling the block each day than pay what they consider a small fortune.
"Even now people will curse me on the street, saying, 'How do you have the nerve to charge all that money for a parking space?' " said Howard Pronsky, the sponsor of the 145-car condo in Park Slope where Michael Friedman, the lawyer, has parked his car for the past 15 years. "And I say, 'How do you have the nerve to buy a house or apartment for more than a million dollars?' " he added. "But a lot of people have praised me, including people who can't ever find a parking space on the street."
When Mr. Pronsky came up with the idea in the mid-1980's to transform the garage at 841 Union Street into a condo, the structure had already been a garage for more than half a century. "I've been in Park Slope since 1969," he added, "and when I saw that garages were being converted to apartments, I thought why not covert this garage to a condo parking garage for people in the neighborhood."
The first condo garage that Mr. Pronsky heard of opened in Boston, he said, but his was the first in New York state. But Mr. Pronsky acknowledges that his idea did not catch on as fast as he thought it would, in large part because the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's took its toll. But he has sold 118 of the parking spaces, he said, and he rents the remaining 27 by the month for $305. 
To accomplish the sales that have occurred, Mr. Pronsky has lowered the price at various times from the original $29,000; the current price is $25,000. But with the demand for parking space continuing to grow in Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights -- a neighborhood where Christopher Thomas, the senior vice president of the William B. May Company's real estate offices in those Brooklyn neighborhoods, said it is almost impossible to find a parking space, at least one that does not attract an "army of ticket and tow trucks" -- Mr. Pronsky said the price would increase this September to its original $29,000.
MR. PRONSKY said he has had requests to buy a space in order to store a boat, but he decided to limit the parking spaces to cars only. Other parking garage owners, however, have sold parking spaces to people who use the garage for storage. 
Joel Silverman, a stockbroker from Rye Brook in Westchester County, bought one of the Park Slope condo spaces almost 15 years ago and hasn't parked in it yet. "I bought it as an investment," said Mr. Silverman, who bought it when the price was $29,000. "But right after that, in '87, the stock market crashed," he added, "and it dragged down real estate in the '90's."
Although Mr. Silverman usually managed to rent out his space, and therefore managed not to lose money, neither did he make much from his investment. He believes that it is only a matter of time before he will make money from his parking space. Meanwhile, though, whenever he sees Mr. Pronsky, he said, he jokes that "I'm the only guy who owned real estate in New York for 15 years and hardly made a profit."

HEADLINE: Arts Cuts in the North Not Quite as Painful as Predicted 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA KUEHL 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
UNDER a legislative mandate to funnel more money to arts groups in South Jersey, the state arts council at its annual meeting last week cut operating grants to 19 groups in the north and scaled back other projects to come up with the cash.
 The move had been feared in the north but widely expected after lawmakers adopted budget language last month ordering that 25 percent of the arts council's $20 million appropriation for cultural projects, or $5 million, go to groups in the eight southernmost counties. So the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, which budgeted $4.2 million directly to the southern region in the last fiscal year, had to find an additional $800,000. 
 Because the Assembly increased the council's appropriation for salaries and expenses this fiscal year, a chunk of a federal grant that used to pay for administration was freed up to pay for programming, said Kenneth Endick, chairman of the council's grants committee. The council also trimmed or postponed some programs, he said. In the end, 19 northern groups lost $290,000 -- the same amount they had received last year for providing services in the south. 
"The arts council leadership and the grants committee did an amazingly good job to limit the damage," said Lawrence Goldman, president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, which lost $55,000.
Although the cuts were small -- less than 3.7 percent of each group's operating grant -- they were still painful for organizations whose mission is to serve the entire state. "We don't think of ourselves as a northern New Jersey organization," said Donald Edwards, vice president for institutional advancement for the American Boychoir, which tours across the state, nationally and internationally. "But somehow our address seems to put us in that position."
Mr. Edwards said the Princeton-based group, which lost $7,000, spent far more than that to perform in South Jersey every year and would continue to do so. But the implications of the cuts disturbed him. "Let me put it this way: It's not clear to me whether this budget encourages organizations that see themselves as statewide to really function on a statewide basis," he said.
To bolster arts development in the south, budget language since fiscal 1998 specified that 25 percent of the council's grants go to "cultural projects within the eight southernmost counties." Last spring, The Courier-Post newspaper in Cherry Hill reported that direct grants to Atlantic, Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, Ocean and Salem counties fell below the 25 percent level all four years. Instead, some money went to statewide programs that benefited the south and to northern groups providing services there.
Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. supported the council's interpretation of the budget language, but as accusations of regional favoritism escalated, the Legislature stepped in and rewrote the mandate to guarantee that 25 percent go to southern groups and artists.
For now, the south's victory last week appears twofold: the region will receive more money and also will continue to benefit from programming provided by northern groups, like American Boychoir, the Newark Museum and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. The Newark-based orchestra will continue to offer concerts to schools and the public in South Jersey despite a budget cut of almost $58,000, said Jane Harovas, the symphony's marketing director. "It's a tremendous hardship for us, particularly with the difficult economic environment," she said. "But the symphony is very committed to maintaining a statewide presence."
The future of NJPAC's southern programming is less assured. In the last two years, the center has sponsored regional performances by artists from Israel and Mozambique, among others. "We're going to try very hard to continue to be statewide," Mr. Goldman said. "Whether we'll be able to do it this coming season without these funds remains to be seen."
Over all, the arts council approved plans for spending $19.5 million in state and federal money. For the south, the council approved $4.14 million in immediate grants and set aside an additional $870,000 -- $262,500 for fellowships and other awards coming later in the year, and about $607,000 for "regional initiatives," like a survey of the south's cultural facilities and a technical assistance program to help groups there develop.
"We've certainly now come within the mandate of the Legislature," Mr. Endick said.
