HEADLINE: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; 
The Graduate Meets the Slowdown

BYLINE: By ANNA BLUMENTHAL; Anna Blumenthal lives in Manhattan. Submit your account of struggling or succeeding as a worker, consumer, investor or entrepreneur to My Money, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to mymoney@nytimes.com. All submissions become the property of The Times. They may be edited and may be republished in any medium.

 BODY:
DURING my senior year of high school, I was often accosted by neighbors in my apartment building. "Wow! I can't believe you're graduating," they'd say, invariably adding, "Where are you going to college?" For several months, I had to fake a smile, explain that I was still making a decision and act as if I actually remembered who these people were. 
 After choosing a school and moving 200 miles from home, I figured that I was finally free from this inquisition. Little did I realize that after four years of college, I would face a second round. This time the cross-examination sounded like this: "Wow! I can't believe you've graduated. Where will you be working?" My answer was equally uncertain. 
 Since I moved back home after graduation in May, my daily routine has included sitting down at the dining room table with a red pen and a stack of newspapers opened to the help-wanted sections. Between bites of breakfast, I browse the ads. At first I circled only those that interested me -- mostly jobs in the music industry, where I had several internships in college. But as the weeks passed and I remained unemployed, I found myself circling anything containing phrases like "entry level," "college grad," "receptionist" or "no experience required."
I figured that I could always fall back on a temporary-employment agency. During my summer and winter breaks from school, I used to find work that way. I'd come in one day, fill out some paperwork and take a typing test, then come in the next morning on standby and be sent out on whatever assignment came in. I spent the bulk of my vacations working for two agencies, so I decided to call them and spare myself more tedious testing and interviews. 
One agency never returned my calls, and the other told me that it had been a slow summer so far. Fair enough. On to bigger and better, I figured. I called four other agencies -- ones that had the biggest, boldest ads. I went in for interviews and met with friendly faced, nicely dressed 30-somethings who sympathized with my anxieties.
"We'll be in touch," each recruiter piped as I left. 
Well, no one was in touch. When I made follow-up calls, I heard excuse after excuse. On Mondays I was told, "We usually get assignments midweek." When I called at the end of June and even until the middle of this month, I was told that the Fourth of July had made for slow weeks.
I became very skeptical whenever an agency assured me that while nothing had come in, "we'll give you a call as soon as we get something." After all, every time I read the Sunday classifieds, I'd see that big, bold ad from the same temp agency that had said it had nothing for me. And, week after week, I'd also see the same ads for the same positions with the same companies. When I inquired about these jobs, I was told, "Uh, we have a lot of people registered with us for the summer."
What was going wrong? I had graduated from a good college with good grades and a handful of awards and honors; I knew how to answer phones and to use a fax and copy machine, and I was as chipper as could be. Maybe I was just a victim of bad timing. While new graduates with credentials no better than mine seemed to have jumped right from college to a career just a year or two ago, perhaps the slumping economy had made the job market very tight.
How bad, though, can it be? Every newspaper still manages to produce a help-wanted section, and dozens -- if not hundreds -- of temp and other employment agencies are still in business and placing ads. 
I've given up on temp agencies, drawing the line after the sixth one failed me. But I still send my resume by fax and e-mail to companies where I'd like to work. For every 10 that I send out, I receive one response. I come home from many interviews glowing, thinking that I had established dazzling rapport with the interviewer, only to receive a letter a week or two later -- in one case, two days later -- saying another candidate has been chosen. 
MY friends tell me to be persistent and patient. But when neighbors, my parents' friends and even the doorman want to know "if I've found a job yet," it becomes difficult to maintain a perma-grin. 
I have found, however, that my attitude has changed. I'm still sending out dozens of resumes each day. And I still cross my fingers when I'm not typing cover letters. But I've relaxed a lot. It's only been about a month and a half, and something will materialize -- because it has to. Everyone works. I will, too. In time, I will find the place that is the best fit for me. 
And I've also realized how nice it is not to work, at least for the time being. Now that I'm finally happy being unemployed, I'm sure that someone will hire me just because I'm not so sure it's what I want anymore.

HEADLINE: Approaching Energy Needs From a Sensible Perspective 

 BODY:
 The practical consequence of Peter Maniscalco's approach is quite elitist. 
Only those of means will be able to afford the spiraling energy prices and the sharp downturn of the economy that is sure to be the consequence of the policies he advocates. 
 It is clear that California's current energy problems were largely a result of the failure to build sufficient generating capacity and that this failure was as a result of the actions of the same sort of coalition that now works to defeat power plant construction on Long Island. Let's not repeat California's mistakes.

CARL JAEKLE
Nesconset

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Saks to Leave White Plains, Opening Way for Fortunoff

BYLINE:  By Vivian S. Toy 

 BODY:
Saks Fifth Avenue will close its store in White Plains, opening the way for Fortunoff, the Long Island-based retailer, to open its first full-service store in Westchester County on the Saks site.
 Saks officials said they planned to close the store at the end of the year because sales were lower than the company deemed necessary to keep the store open. 
 Fortunoff would demolish the Saks store, which was built in 1954 and which is across the street from The Westchester mall, and build a $50 million store of between 150,000 and 190,000 square feet. The new Fortunoff would probably not open for business until sometime in 2003.
Industry experts said that the time and expense needed to finish the White Plains store would probably absorb all of Fortunoff's expansion efforts for the next few years. Fortunoff now has five locations including its flagship store in Westbury and other stores in Manhattan and Paramus, Wayne and Woodbridge, N.J.
Louis Fortunoff, a vice president of Fortunoff, said that plans for the White Plains store depend on negotiations for business incentives with Westchester officials. But he noted that White Plains and Westchester officials have actively courted the company for years.
"We believe that the Westchester market offers Fortunoff an unprecedented opportunity to further expand our customer base," he said. And County Executive Andrew J. Spano said that his county's development officials "will work very hard to make Westchester the best choice for Fortunoff's next flagship store." Vivian S. Toy

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
PREDICTING A SLOWDOWN

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters 

 BODY:
 New Jersey's economy is beginning to feel the effects of the downturn in the nation's economy, and slow growth will continue at least through the end of next year, according to an analysis by the Rutgers University Economic Advisory Service. New jobs will top out at 40,000 for 2001 and 2002 combined, compared with 100,000 new jobs created in the state in 2000 alone, said Dr. Nancy H. Mantell, director of the service, which is part of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning. The average unemployment rate will go from 3.8 percent last year to 4.3 percent this year to just under 5 percent over the next several years, according to the predictions. Karen DeMasters

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; 
For an Area of Jarring Notes, a Move Toward Melody

BYLINE:  By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
To urban planners, Queens Plaza and the surrounding area of Long Island City is a Rubik's Cube: a bewildering puzzle with an infinite number of incorrect arrangements. 
 This urban space is simultaneously a transit hub, a museum and manufacturing zone, a checkerboard of old houses and artists' studios and an emerging high-tech and white-collar office center. 
 Planners and others have long said that getting these sectors to complement each other rather than clash is the key to making Long Island City the next hot neighborhood. And ever since 1989, when the 48-story Citibank office tower opened just south of Queens Plaza, many have prognosticated -- wrongly -- that this was about to happen. 
But there is a new buzz about a local renaissance, one loud enough to hear above the din of the trains and the 80,000 cars a day that go over the Queensboro Bridge.
On July 17, about 150 architects and designers gathered on the roof of a municipal parking garage opposite the elevated train station to peer down at the visual cacophony of Queens Plaza. They had been invited by the Van Alen Institute to a design ideas competition with a $10,000 first prize for whoever can figure out how to make the place less desolate. The city plans to spend a $1.8 million federal grant on the winning vision, which, if nothing else, will probably "green" the parking spaces of the John F. Kennedy Commuter Plaza under the el. 
There are already signs of renewal. Adam Rubin, the director of special projects for the Long Island City Business Development Corporation, told the group that a former Brooks Brothers warehouse, at 33rd Street and 37th Avenue, is now home to several high-tech companies, and that a former factory for Dannon Yogurt containers, at 11th Street and 45th Avenue, is about to reopen as an art gallery. In the fall, Met Life will move 1,000 of its Manhattan workers into a onetime car factory on Queens Plaza North between 27th and 28th Streets. 
In May, more than 1,000 artists took part in a local festival, Art Frenzy. A month later, the Museum of Modern Art began a shuttle bus loop to some local cultural sites, including Socrates Sculpture Park and the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center. The loop will eventually include the museum itself, which is planning to move temporarily to the former Swingline factory at Queens Boulevard and 33rd Street. 
Another important change came Thursday, when the City Council approved a 37-block rezoning that is expected to create a cluster of tall office buildings around the isolated Citibank tower. This will mean the demise of the parking garage on which the designers stood. City officials want to replace it with an office building.
Kate Dunham of the Department of City Planning said the new zoning is intended to produce that nirvana of urban planners: an active downtown. JIM O'GRADY

GRAPHIC: Photo: Queens Plaza, as seen from 41st Avenue and Northern Boulevard. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) Map of Long Island City highlighting the proposed rezoned area

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Despite Defaults, Junk Bonds Are Jumping

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
OVER all, the economic environment seems sluggish. But things are peppy in the junkyard. More than $64 billion worth of new high-yield bonds were sold in the first half of the year, according to Moody's Investor's Service. That is more than all the junk bonds sold in 2000.
 Investors are snapping up the bonds even though default rates are rising and ratings agencies like Moody's are downgrading more companies than they are upgrading. But there is compensation for the risk: interest rates on high-yield bonds are running at least 7.5 percentage points above Treasury securities of comparable maturity. 
 Bruce H. Monrad, co-manager of Northeast Investors Trust, a Boston-based company with $1.3 billion in high-yield bonds under management, talked about the market on Thursday. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. Conditions in the high-yield market have been deteriorating for some time. Are we close to a bottom?

A. Default rates have been rising since 1997, and rate spreads versus Treasuries have been widening since 1997 and 1998, at the time of the Asian crisis. The default rate is probably peaking now.

Q. Telecommunications company bonds have been troubled over the last year. Have prices fallen to the point where you are beginning to nibble?

A. We were fortunate not to have participated in the telecom sector, and are not involved now. We think conditions in that sector are a long way from the "good company/bad balance sheet" phenomenon of the early 1990's. We are talking about companies that by and large have negative cash flow and have a need to access the capital markets.
I read recently that the $200 billion of face amount in telecom bonds are trading at around $44 billion. You would buy anything for a price, and there have been instances of telecom companies coming back, but we are not purchasing these securities. 

Q. So what bonds are you buying?

A. The average high-yield bond is trading at around 80 cents on the dollar, which gives us a lot of running room. We have positions in most of the industrial parts of the high-yield market. We also have exposures to gaming and energy companies and some of the service companies, like a restaurant or two.
And some of the so-called fallen angels, formerly investment-grade issuers like Finova, Owens-Illinois and Crown Cork and Seal, are on our radar screen now.

Q. Do you have much cash to invest now?

A. We are 95 percent invested right now. Back in 1997, we had 15 percent to 20 percent of the fund in Treasury bills or cash. We have been 100 percent invested in the past, but I'd say we are pretty well invested at this point. This is an expression of our view on the market and on interest rate spreads.

Q. Why should an investor own high-yield bonds?

A. This is an asset that could be a substitute for Treasuries in a bond portfolio. At this point it offers an unusually high yield.
If the economy really does turn around, then default rates are going to come down and price performance of the bonds ought to be pretty good. It is entirely possible that five years from now, people will look at the total return on high-yield bonds with a starting interest rate of 12 percent and it will compare favorably with returns in the stock market, where earnings grow at single digits, with the economy.
We unambiguously suggest individuals buy funds rather than individual bonds. It minimizes the risk and lessens transaction costs. 

Q. How should you shop for a high-yield fund? How long should you own it?

A. There are fund managers out there with very good long-term track records. Get a prospectus and look at the portfolios.
There are higher-risk funds, lower-risk funds, funds that like or don't like telecommunications bonds. If the individual investor has a view on those sorts of things, there are ways to match him up with a fund.
The time horizon on a high-yield fund ought to be comparable to one for a stock or a bond fund, that is to say a few years.
Most of the bonds in our portfolio should convert to cash and mature within six years. But we have investors who have been in our fund for much longer than that. 

Q. Since you are very nearly fully invested, you seem confident that the market is going to move higher. Is that a fair assessment?

A. We are not so optimistic to expect a high-yield fund to replicate the 17 percent annual compound rate of return we had for five years after the last market bottom in 1991. That was a very good period.
The average yield on our portfolio is about 12.5 percent, which compares well with 10-year Treasuries at 5.25 percent. If rate spreads compress, we could realize capital gains on top of that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Monrad

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Chevrolet Avalanche; 
Ride 'em, Urban Cowboy

BYLINE:  By JAMES G. COBB 

DATELINE: DODGE CITY, Kan. 

 BODY:
OUR nose knows when you draw close to this small Great Plains city. Unless you have had the foresight to roll up the windows and set the air-conditioner to "recirc," blocking the outside air, your olfactory senses are treated to the historically accurate aroma of a Wild West cowtown.
 Dodge City was one of the most famous of these towns, as anyone old enough to associate Matt Dillon with the 60's TV marshal, and not the 80's screen heartthrob, will recall. By 1884, some eight million cattle were herded here by cowpokes whose itchy trigger fingers helped to fill the Boot Hill Cemetery downtown. You can pay your respects by turning off Wyatt Earp Boulevard and making a left onto Gunsmoke Street. 
 There is less lawlessness here today, but cattle -- tens of thousands of them -- are still fattened at the feedlots outside town. From there, the animals will visit the slaughterhouse, destined to become chateaubriand, Kansas City strips and all-beef patties on sesame-seed buns. If the wind is right, the sharp aroma of feedlot wastes literally takes your breath away. 
I am here not for the fresh air, but to help celebrate the 80th birthday of my aunt, Thelma Nelson. She, my father and their six siblings grew up on the family farm east of town, scrimping through the Depression and clinging to the soil that didn't blow away in the Dust Bowl. Still, the economics of modern agriculture managed to do what droughts, hailstorms and tornados did not: drive most of the family into other occupations in other places. As part of the Plains diaspora, the family scattered from Seattle to Jacksonville, from El Centro, Calif., on the Mexican border, to New York City.
So it seems fitting that I'm riding into town in the 2002 Chevrolet Avalanche, a citified truck far removed from the battered, dusty farm pickups indispensable to my forebears. A four-door truck with seats for five or six, plus a versatile cargo bed, it is a cross between pickup and sport utility vehicle, and it is intended not so much for heavy cargo and back-breaking labor as for hauling people and playthings.
Is it all hat and no horse? Or has General Motors managed to adapt a big, utilitarian truck to today's suburban lifestyles of people like my cousins, nephews and nieces -- transporting the outfield to a Little League game, hauling mountain bikes to the wilderness, carrying plywood from Home Depot?
Many other vehicles blur the lines between traditional segments, and there are four-door trucks like the Ford F-150 Super Crew and the Dodge Dakota Quad Cab, not to mention the Ford Explorer Sport Trac, an S.U.V. with a small cargo box. The problem, though, is that if you start with four doors and two rows of seats, adding a large and truly useful cargo bed makes a truck about as petite and agile as a Greyhound bus.
Chevrolet has split the difference with the Avalanche, which can handle half a dozen passengers and a moderate amount of stuff, or a couple of passengers and a whole lot of stuff. The back of the passenger cabin consists of a unique bottom-hinged panel that can be opened to expand the the cargo bed to eight feet in length, from about five.
Chevy calls this panel the midgate, and it is a clever idea that works. With the midgate upright, the back seat can accommodate three passengers. If you flip down the seat, you have a large storage area inside the cabin, plus the cargo bed. If you fold the midgate, too, the bed runs from the tailgate to the back of the front seats.
You can leave the back window in place, with the cargo opening beneath it, or remove the window. You can take out the crossbar that separates the window from the midgate, turning the back of the cabin into a yawning cavern. Just make sure you securely tie down any cargo back there, or you could be pummeled by two-by-fours shifting forward in a panic stop -- or, worse yet, have your personal watercraft come crashing into the back of your seat.
The rigid cargo cover provides more flexibility. Consisting of three removable panels that weigh less than 20 pounds each, it is integrated into the locking tailgate and transforms the bed into the world's largest car trunk. A soft tonneau cover is also available.
In the often wasted space behind the wheel wells, Chevy added deep, lockable bins that are handy for tools or camping gear -- or for a tailgate party, given that you can fill them with ice and beverages. (Holes at the bottom provide drainage.) Two-sided lights shine into both the cargo bed and the storage boxes.
Many trucks have steps molded into their bumpers, but they are often unusable, given that they are inaccessible when the tailgate is lowered. The Avalanche's more useful steps are cut into each end of the rear bumper. Hefty grab handles, which can also be used to tie down cargo, are bolted atop the rear fenders. The skin of those fenders is plastic resin that resists dents, and the bed is covered with a thick rubber mat to protect the steel floor. All storage areas are water-tight, Chevy says, thanks to a system of rain channels and drains.
Having carved a new niche, G.M. took pains to make its truck look different. Indeed, the Avalanche is a little like the Plains creature that is said to be the offspring of a jack rabbit and an antelope. The jackalope appears on postcards -- designed, not too convincingly, with pre-Photoshop technology -- as a bunny with a rack of antlers. The look is distinctive though not graceful, which is one way to describe the Avalanche.
It bears a passing resemblance to a Silverado pickup, though the hood is high and prominent and the wheel wells are flattened, as if fitted with 50's-style fender skirts. Slanted headlamps give the front end a pinched look (or, in G.M.'s view, "powerful, sharply chiseled rock-face features.") A triangular sail panel -- it provides structural reinforcement -- connects the cabin to the bed. Geometric shapes abound.
The body seems not so much by Fisher as by Fisher-Price. A good third of the exterior wears plastic cladding that seems to belong, except for its somber gray color, on a kiddie car. Instead of shouting "Tough!" -- which must have been the idea -- the plastic whispers "Cheesy."
One could look at the Avalanche and see, as G.M. hopes, a rugged, distinctive truck. Or one could see the graceless geometry of the Pontiac Aztek on a larger scale. In truth, during my travels around Memorial Day, giving Kansans their first glimpse of the Avalanche, it attracted a lot of mostly positive attention. People out here know their trucks, and the Avalanche never sat for long without drawing curious onlookers and small crowds.
The new Chevy isn't likely to have farmers and ranchers lining up to trade in their Silverados and F-150's, but my traveling companion on this trip is a potential customer: Dave Shandy, a restaurant manager in suburban Kansas City who is married to my niece Ronnita. A Chevy enthusiast -- the couple have a Blazer, a 1500 Series pickup and a vintage Corvette -- Dave has closely followed the Avalanche's development since it appeared as a design study at the 2000 Detroit auto show.
As we head west from Topeka on Interstate 70, Dave and I are both impressed with the stiff structure and supple ride. Because of the midgate, Chevy could not use the architecture of a conventional pickup, with a separate cabin and cargo box. So it turned to the Suburban S.U.V., which provided several additional benefits, including a one-piece cabin-cargo bed and rear coil springs.
Not only does the Avalanche ride smoothly -- so much that you have to remind yourself that you're in a truck -- it is quiet. The silence is especially impressive if you consider all the hinges, latches and movable parts that make it possible to open up the back of the cabin.
All of G.M.'s big trucks handle well for their size, and so does the Avalanche, at least on the open road. With a length of 18.5 feet, the Avalanche is two feet shorter than a Silverado extended-cab truck with a long box, but it is still a big brute, and its size works against it in town.
The steering is light enough for parking maneuvers but weighty enough to inspire confidence at extralegal highway speeds. There is reasonable road feedback, good on-center feel and a reassuring sense of stability. The four-wheel disc brakes, however, feel barely adequate.
Adequate, too, is the engine, a 5.3-liter V-8 used in various G.M. trucks. It is powerful, pulling the Avalanche from a stop to 60 m.p.h. in a little over 8 seconds, and thirsty. (I averaged about 15 m.p.g.) But we noticed that on long upward grades through the Flint Hills, the four-speed automatic transmission had a tendency to kick down to a lower gear. Pulling a trailer, or hauling a load of lumber, would bog it down more.
The Avalanche has a payload capacity of about 1,300 pounds and is rated to tow trailers of up to 8,300 pounds. Two- and four-wheel-drive versions are offered, at prices for standard models of $30,965 to $38,711. A North Face Edition, developed in conjunction with the purveyor of outdoor gear, gets you special trim and waterproof duffel bags and daypacks for $3,500 extra. A heavy-duty 2500 Series, with leaf springs and a 340-horsepower, 8.1-liter V-8, will arrive in dealerships next month at base prices of $32,865 to $35,865.
The same basic configuration will also be the basis for a Cadillac pickup, the Escalade EXT, which will go on sale this fall for over $50,000.
The Avalanche is less lavish, but still well equipped. Standard are keyless locking, front-seat side air bags, power windows and locks, cruise control and CD player. The Z66 (rear drive) and Z71 (four-wheel drive) packages include 17-inch wheels, locking rear differential, special decals and even "aggressive rubber floor mats." (With all the talk about road rage, do we really need attitude in our floor coverings?)
Seating choices include cloth, leather and a cloth-leather combination, with either buckets or a three-person bench up front. There is plenty of room for burly ranch hands and 10-gallon hats.
By the end of our return trip to Topeka, after nearly 10 generally pleasant hours in the Avalanche, Dave delivers his assessment. Having demonstrated the midgate several dozen times and taken a turn at the wheel, he is impressed by the Avalanche, but not yet ready to buy one. He'd like more seating, he says, for hauling around the entourages of his pre-adolescent sons. If gasoline prices remain stable, he'd like to get a Suburban in addition to his big pickup.
And therein lies the dilemma of the Avalanche: It offers a lot of solutions to problems that many people don't know they have. Pickup people tend to remain loyal to what they already drive, and many S.U.V. owners don't really need a cargo box.
Still, Chevy may well meet its goal of 100,000 sales in the first year of production. More cross-bred pickups and S.U.V.'s are inevitable, and some of these -- like the showy Lincoln Blackwood -- will be city slickers with more style than substance.
The Avalanche isn't likely to go on many cattle drives, but at least it is capable of a hard day's work.

INSIDE TRACK: Quick-change artist.

HEADLINE: Big Tobacco's Pull 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Death in the Ashes," by Bob Herbert (column, July 26), about the World Bank study showing the high toll that cigarettes are taking around the world, is a timely reminder to the American people that Big Tobacco is still the only industry that sells a deadly product with impunity. 
 Some critics say that Big Tobacco has bought legitimacy by contributing millions of dollars to the coffers of both political parties. 
But to the honorable men and women of the United States Congress, I say: 
Please tell us that it will not be so. And enact real tobacco legislation to protect our children and grandchildren from the unscrupulous merchants of death.

PETER BUENDIA
New York, July 26, 2001

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Dispelling the Myth That Options Help Shareholders

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
INVESTORS' hard-earned money is not the only thing that has been lost since the technology stock bubble went pfft. Also gone is the credibility of a host of bull-market conceits. They include the hilarious notions that new-economy companies would be invulnerable to the traditional economic cycle, that valuations were not important when it came to buying stocks, that the invention of the Internet rivaled that of electricity. 
 Here's another truism to throw onto the slag heap: Stock options are a boon to shareholders because they motivate management and align the interests of investors with those of executives. 
 The greatest damage to this theory has been done by companies that reduce the strike prices of their stock options after their shares have plummeted. Option repricings, as they are called, are quite simply a gift to management and workers that outside shareholders do not receive.
Companies that reprice their options have typically argued that doing so is necessary to keep treasured executives from leaving for sweeter packages elsewhere. Implicit in this argument is the belief that an exodus of executives would hurt the company. 
But a new academic study, to be presented at the annual meeting of the Academy of Management starting on Aug. 5 in Washington, indicates that companies that reprice options actually show higher levels of executive turnover later. More important, the study found no evidence that the repricing of options was associated with improvement in the financial performance of the company. 
The authors of the study were three academics at Indiana University's Kelley School of Business -- Catherine M. Daily, S. Trevis Certo and Dan R. Dalton. They studied repricings at more than 100 companies in 1997 and 1998 and compared the companies' results with those of similar concerns that did not reprice. 
They found that in the first year after a repricing, chief executive turnover at the companies was 16.3 percent, versus 4.7 percent at companies that had not repriced. By the end of 1998, companies that had repriced options clocked chief executive turnover at 25.5 percent. Those with no repriced options had turnover of 10.5 percent.
Top management turnover below the chief executive level was also much higher at companies that repriced, the study found. By the second year after a repricing, that turnover was nearly 41 percent, versus 28 percent at companies with no repricings. 
Investors who suspect that option repricings are decidedly anti-shareholder will also find confirmation in another study to be presented at the academy's meeting. Timothy G. Pollock, Harald M. Fischer and James B. Wade at the University of Wisconsin at Madison concluded that repricings were more likely at companies with powerful, entrenched chief executives who also head their boards of directors. Repricings are less likely at companies where the chief owns a lot of the stock.
Despite this and other research proving stock option repricings to be an egregious transfer of wealth from shareholders to management, companies and boards continue to approve such plans. The Investor Responsibility Research Center reports that 59 companies repriced options this year, as of June 15. That was far higher than the 31 that repriced in all of 2000, but down from the 312 that did so in 1999.
With the main argument for repricings -- executive retention -- now demonstrably false, it will be fun to see how companies justify these shameful tactics in the future. But justify them they must. For stock options are the drug of choice among American executives. And like any addiction, this one is exceedingly hard to kick.

HEADLINE: Can the Life of the Party Succeed as a City Innkeeper? 

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
LULU DE KWIATKOWSKI, the airplane heiress and fabric designer, loves Jeff Klein. So does Rachel Peters, Irving Berlin's granddaughter and a fledgling film producer. Ditto for Ginny Bond, an actress and heir to a Texas oil fortune, who refers to Mr. Klein as merely "the most incredible human being on the planet."
 Who is Jeff Klein, lucky recipient of all this junior-jet-set adulation? 
 He's the self-described "eternal host" who is putting his skills to the test next month by opening a new 65-room hotel, the City Club, across West 44th Street from the Royalton, the mother of all boutique hotels. 
Not that Mr. Klein cares for the term boutique hotel. He prefers "small luxury hotel." "People have used the term boutique too loosely, and now it's become something cliched," Mr. Klein said. "So if you're going to call your hotel a boutique, I'm not going to call mine that." 
Good enough. Whatever the nomenclature, Mr. Klein, 31, a first-time owner, with two other partners, is off to a pretty good start. The City Club has corralled one of the city's most respected chefs, Daniel Boulud, who opened DB Bistro Moderne, his third restaurant, in the hotel last month; and the celebrity interior designer Jeffrey Bilhuber, who has done the guest rooms in earth tones and the bathrooms in chocolate marble. This development has apparently piqued the interest of Anna Wintour, Vogue's editor in chief, who hired Mr. Bilhuber for her own home. 
"She calls every week," Mr. Klein said, flashing a big smile, "and asks, 'When is it going to be finished?' " 
Perhaps more than Mr. Bilhuber and Mr. Boulud, the people Mr. Klein is banking on to make the City Club a success are his friends, many of them the impeccably groomed, impossibly stylish and, above all, impressively rich young women who populate the city's junior benefit committees and gossip columns. It's not known whether a hotel can become hot by association with the princesses of Park Avenue, but Mr. Klein is giving it a try.
"My friends have told me, 'If we need to sit in your lobby for a week straight so that Page Six will write about it, we will,' " he said. "They're all going to be a part of it."
Among those offering their services as lobby accessories, and more, are Ms. Kwiatkowski, who is designing a fabric for linens at the hotel, and Shoshanna Lowenstein, who is designing some staff uniforms. 
To his friends, Mr. Klein holds an esteemed position as the life of the party. He is known for giving elaborate dinners at his brownstone on West 18th Street. After dinner, guests typically retire to Mr. Klein's roof garden, a spacious, tree-filled deck complete with an outdoor shower and homegrown tomatoes. "He threw me two parties at his house," Ms. Bond said. "I never wanted to leave."
Another heiress in Mr. Klein's set is Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer, of the cosmetics dynasty. Their grandmothers knew each other in Palm Beach. Ms. Zinterhofer was born a day before Mr. Klein in 1970 in the same delivery room, and they have done lunch ever since. 
His special skill may actually be relationship counseling, a much sought-after talent in his rarefied clique. "He's the very first person to bring you chicken soup on a sick day," said Samantha Kluge, the daughter of the billionaire John W. Kluge. "And hold your hand when you need it held," Ms. Kluge added, "and be the shoulder to cry on." Her first, short-lived marriage was to Mr. Klein's friend and former partner in a teddy bear company, Adam Cahan. 
Ms. Peters concurred. "He's the eternal father and brother and son and shrink when it's needed," she said. "Particularly when we're all having boy problems."
Considering his untested record as a hotel developer in a very competitive market, Mr. Klein exudes enormous confidence. Hotel occupancy rates in New York have declined this year to their lowest level since 1996, a function of the winded economy and a pack of newcomers to the field, including the Bryant Park, 60 Thompson, the Dylan and the W Union Square. 
"My favorite part is that I'm opening in a difficult time," Mr. Klein said boldly last week. "This is my opportunity to say, 'Jeff Klein is here, and I'm full, and I'm selling out at $500 a night, and all you wannabes, all you little boutique copycats, are going to go bankrupt.' "
He wasn't finished. "And I'm going to buy you guys up, because you guys are going to be available for about 10 cents on the dollar in about one year. And my hotel, by the way, is going to be so special."
He said he had great respect for the successful players in the game he is joining, like Ian Schrager, owner of the Royalton, Hudson and many others, and Andre Balazs, of the Mercer in New York and the Standard and Chateau Marmont in Los Angeles, but he said that Mr. Schrager's expanding empire is increasingly tired. Mr. Schrager declined to comment. 
Less-known competitors he dismisses out of hand. "They just don't get it," he said. "They don't get the design, they don't get the service, and they don't understand buzz." 
John A. Fox, the senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a hotel advisory firm, said the boutique hotel business was healthy regardless of Mr. Klein's predictions. "We have a lot of boutique hotels, but I don't characterize it as a glut," he said. 
As cocky as Mr. Klein sounds, his personal charm goes a long way toward diffusing his braggadocio. Tall and boyishly handsome, with a wide smile and an irrepressible laugh, he is a common sight on New York's benefits circuit, in whatever regalia is called for, whether it be a turban (for an Arabian Nights gala for the New York City Ballet last month) or as Truman Capote (for a decadent-80's party for the designer Pamela Dennis last year). 
With inherited wealth from both sides of his family, he serves on the junior boards of the Public Theater, the City Ballet and Guild Hall in East Hampton. Catwalking in a fashion show for 
Cynthia Rowley's men's wear this month in the Hamptons, Mr. Klein sported an open shirt and wildly colored pants worthy of Austin Powers. 
Last spring, he gave a Cuban-theme party, complete with South American dancers, Carmen Miranda imitators, scantily clad debutantes and an endless stream of mojitos. 
"I think I saw an episode of 'I Love Lucy' and thought, 'Ricky is so fabulous, let's do a night around him,' " Mr. Klein said with a laugh.
Kevin West, the European editor of W magazine and a friend of Mr. Klein's, said, "If he was blond and looked good in a Chloe dress, he'd be one of those bold-face names." 
Despite all this, he insists that his party boy reputation is overblown. "Everyone thinks I'm like this big party animal," he said. "But I cannot stay up past midnight. Unless it's like the best party of all time." 
Mr. Klein is one of two sons born to Robert Klein, who built Assured Environments, a pest control company on Lexington Avenue, into the Upper East Side's premier killer of rats and other vermin, and Susan Klein, nee Tannenbaum, whose family developed Yonkers Raceway and owned office buildings in Manhattan, including 530 Madison Avenue and 470 Park Avenue. 
Mr. Klein grew up on Park Avenue and 79th Street, surrounded, he said, by "a lot of oak and big stuffy chairs." The family's dining room was done by the society decorator Mark Hampton. 
Looking back, he says, growing up in luxury helped his professional development. "I got to stay in the finest hotels, so I know what they are like," he said. 
Mr. Klein said he was asked to leave the competitive Horace Mann School after the first grade for academic reasons, and that he burned through two more private schools, Riverdale and Dwight, before graduating from Columbia Prep. He was no scholar, but he excelled at making friends, passing time on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum with Lulu and Liz and Rachel and Samantha.
He graduated from Tulane with a degree in French literature. After a brief stint in advertising in France, he returned to New York and got a job with the Gotham Hospitality Group, whose president, Bernard Goldberg, was one of the pioneers of buying distressed small hotels in the 1980's and making them over as stylish boutique hotels.
Mr. Klein worked at Gotham for four years, earning his stripes, he said, as a desk clerk, concierge and even as a housekeeper, before rising to be a manager of the Mansfield and Shoreham hotels. After Mr. Goldberg sold his five hotels in 1998, Mr. Klein decided it was time to start his own place. 
He is in partnership with two other principals, Forthright Development and Metropolitan Hotels, both started by former colleagues at the Gotham Group. They have leased the City Club site at 55 West 44th Street, a onetime men's club (hence the name) dating from 1904. Mr. Klein and his partners plan to spend $10 million on the gut renovation. Mr. Bilhuber's rooms combine modern elements, like couches built into walls, with traditional upholstered chairs with wooden arms. Televisions are hidden behind artwork and, in at least one room, behind a mirror. 
It hasn't been a bump-free project. The hotel's opening has been delayed as construction work drags on, while on the sidewalk across the street, whistle-blowing union representatives have periodically protested the nonunion labor used at the site. Mr. Klein promises that the hotel will open 25 rooms by Aug. 27, with the rest of the rooms to be completed even as guests are staying on other, fully finished floors -- not an unusual arrangement in the hotel business. 
Sipping a glass of wine over lunch, he seemed in his element and perpetually excited, talking about the intricacies of the real estate market and the opening party in September, an event certain to draw dozens of bold-face names, his friends.
"I am the luckiest man in the world in every aspect of my life," he said. "I have the best family, the best job and the best friends. They're the sweetest, best people in the world." He smiled and added: "They're all like my little sisters. I protect them and love them. And they protect and love me."

HEADLINE: Yearning To Be Safe 

BYLINE:  By SASHA ABRAMSKY; Sasha Abramsky is the author of "Hard Time Blues: How Politics Built a Prison Nation," to be published in January by St. Martin's Press.

 BODY:
THAILAND was no good," 8-year-old Pyi Son Aung said, his black hair flopping forward on his forehead, his dark eyes open wide. To explain, he held his palms together and cocked his fingers in the time-honored imitation of a gun. "Brrrr, brrrr, brrrr, brrrr, brrrrrr," he shouted as he sprayed the walls of his living room with bullets from an imaginary weapon.
 The apartment in which Pyi Son is reliving his past is tiny, a one-bedroom fourth-floor walkup on 187th Street, just off the Grand Concourse in the Fordham section of the Bronx. The neighborhood is working class, characterized by bodegas, greasy chicken restaurants and car-repair shops. Pyi Son lives here with his parents, his three sisters and, sometimes, an uncle and a family friend. 
 A decade after the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war, New York is home to large numbers of a special kind of immigrant: refugees from around the globe. 
Pyi Son's family fled to Thailand from the military dictatorship in their native Myanmar (formerly Burma). But the city's refugees come from many other places. Some are from the former Soviet republics or Vietnam. Others have fled messy conflicts and local tyrannies that have spewed forth in this new multipolar world: civil wars in Africa, ethnic strife in the former Yugoslavia, and fundamentalist religious regimes or insurgency movements. 
More than 42,000 of them arrived in the city from 1994 to 2000, according to the State Bureau of Refugee and Immigration Affairs. The numbers of refugees entering New York ballooned in the mid-90's, as tens of thousands escaped the Balkan wars and fighting in central Africa. Today a smaller but steadier stream arrives from around the world.
Unlike many immigrants, refugees often arrive with little property, no money and physical and psychological ills. And while in an age of jet travel it is increasingly easy for immigrants to visit their homeland, for refugees there literally is no going back.
Pyi Son's family came to the Bronx nearly a year ago after years of terror in Southeast Asia. First they endured the political turmoil in Myanmar; then, after fleeing to Thailand in 1998, they spent two devastating years in a refugee camp. What would happen if they returned home? In response, Pyi Son's father, Khin Maung Htwe, drew his fingers across his throat: the family would be slaughtered. 
They had arrived with virtually nothing. Among the few possessions from their former life is a photograph showing Pyi Son with an aunt, a sister and a friend. He is wearing an orange monk's robe and his head is shaved.
What Pyi Son and his family remember mostly is trauma, fear and political disarray. As a result, their adjustment to life in New York is beset by special emotional and practical problems.
To an outsider, their life in the Bronx might seem pinched and their options few. But in their eyes, New York, and America, truly seems like a promised land.

Odyssey From Fear
On Sept. 2 of last year, Khin Maung, his wife, Yin Yin Thein, and four of their six children stepped off a plane at Kennedy International Airport. It was late at night. They were met by a representative from the International Rescue Committee, an organization set up before World War II to bring over refugees from Europe and that now resettles about 500 refugees annually in New York City alone. The family, destitute and dependent on others for financial survival, was driven to its new home. It was crowded. The parents and the three girls shared a bedroom, and Pyi Son and a family friend slept on pullout beds next to a refrigerator in the living room.
Burmese have been coming to this country in greater numbers since 1999, when the United States government approved a program permitting them to be processed by refugee agencies before making the often difficult journey to America. Although statistics on the number of Burmese in New York are sketchy, several hundred have settled in the state, according to the State Bureau of Refugee and Immigration Affairs. Until recently, most went to cities in upstate New York. Since late last year, however, in part because of the efforts of the rescue committee, an increasing number have landed in the Fordham section of the Bronx. 
Khin Maung is a stocky 45-year-old whose right arm and left hand are tattooed with dark green tigers, the animal associated with the year of his birth. After the political crackdown that began in 1988 and led to the creation of the State Law and Order Restoration Committee, known by the Orwellian acronym Slorc, he left his home and trekked for five days through the jungle to join the armed forces of the All Burma Student Democratic Front, a rebel group. Skinny and sick with malaria, Khin Maung, a tailor by trade, began to sew uniforms.
But he eventually quarreled with the group's local leadership. Fearing both the brutal Burmese government and the rebels, he and most of his family slipped across the border into Thailand. At first, things were no better, with Khin Maung spending two months in prison. But after two years, the family was granted official refugee status -- and the documents that would let them come to America.
They flew to Tokyo and then Los Angeles, where they told immigration officials that they had different last names because, like many Burmese, they did not use a common family name. They continued to Detroit and then to New York, an odyssey condensed by air travel into a few dozen hours.
None of them spoke any English and none had ever traveled by plane. A few Burmese friends and Yin Yin's brother had preceded them to New York, but they had just hazy, cinematic ideas about the city: images of large buildings and fast cars, vague impressions garnered from village conversations thousands of miles away. Nevertheless, speaking through an interpreter, Khin Maung said that when he arrived, at close to midnight in the dying days of summer: "I felt freedom. This is my new place."

Ruled by Law, Not Men
It has been nearly a year since the family's flight touched down at Kennedy Airport. In that year the number of Burmese settling in New York has increased. At least a score live in Khin Maung's neighborhood, some in his building, and each week, it seems, more friends or relatives arrive.
For all that is imperfect in their newly adopted homeland, for all the inequality and racial tension and hardship, Khin Maung and his fellow refugees still find something magical about America.
"In our country," said a Burmese friend who arrived the same day as Khin Maung, "there is no law. Everybody is afraid. In the United States, we need to obey just the law. We don't need to obey man to man. It's a very different experience for us."
When Khin Maung's family first arrived, they were deeply fearful. Yin Yin was particularly anxious. She had heard rumors: that Asians were viciously discriminated against, that refugees were shunned. Shopping for food without being able to speak English terrified her. The noise and bustle of the streets confused her. She was afraid that her children would be swallowed up by the anonymity of the city and that their cultural heritage would vanish like a bubble on the breeze.
Within a few months, however, her feelings had changed. The city hadn't rejected her family. Nor had it peeled off its culture. On the contrary: she was developing a network of friends, fellow Burmese refugees, along with people from the rescue committee, with whom the family explored the city. And her children were developing hybrid identities. 
"We will try to keep our children in the Burmese culture as much as we can," Yin Yin said. "But we understand it is not Burma. We will not totally keep the Burmese culture." She has come to accept that one day her family might even ask her to cook a Thanksgiving dinner.
The family's economic situation had also brightened slightly.
Clifford Rames, the committee's director for New York resettlement, said families were eligible for up to eight months of cash assistance. They are also eligible for a month's free rent provided by the committee. Most refugees may also receive Medicaid, food stamps and free school lunches. Refugees who do not have a job after eight months can be moved into the city's workfare program.
Khin Maung was lucky. He found a job quickly. Last December, at the Buddhist temple where he worshiped, he met a Vietnamese man, Thina Nguyen, who worked for a Westchester County company that made sun roofs for cars. Thina Nguyen urged his boss to hire Khin Maung, saying that although Khin Maung spoke virtually no English, he was a hard worker and adept with his hands. The request fit into what Thina Nguyen called the Buddhist "wheel of help."
The boss agreed, and Khin Maung started work. He put up a blackboard in his living room and tried to learn the English words used in his new trade, scrawling Burmese words and, opposite, their English counterparts. The pay was only $7 an hour, and out of his weekly paycheck of $350 Khin Maung, who owned no car, had to pay a friend $15 a week to drive him to and from work. 
The family lived frugally, rarely even using the subway. Yin Yin bought only the most basic staples: the cheapest cuts of meat, lots of rice and noodles. Every stick of furniture in their $600-a-month apartment was provided by the Rescue Committee. But Khin Maung felt that the family could one day buy a house and send the children to college. "And," he added, with a glint in his eye, "if they try hard, maybe they'll graduate."

A Boy With Racing Dreams
Because Yin Yin was one of the few women in a refugee community composed mostly of young men -- fighters weary of fighting -- she had become something of a den mother to the group. On weekends, 10 or more people came to her house to eat coconut rice and spicy ounkow soup, a Burmese specialty, along with American fried chicken. 
They sat cross-legged on her bare living room floor, their shoes piled up in the hallway in traditional Buddhist fashion. Smoking Marlboros and drinking Heineken beer (bought with pooled money from the group), they sang Burmese folk songs while Khin Maung played the guitar. He had pasted a sticker showing a bare-chested Jesse Ventura on his instrument, and his friends were as likely to request American rock anthems as the mournful, yearning folk songs and resistance ballads from home. 
The children watched college basketball and Burmese martial arts videos on the television set while the adults grew merrily tipsy on beer. When the doorbell rang, the youngsters charged downstairs, barefoot, to escort new guests up to the apartment.
Khin Maung's children quickly adjusted to life in America. The eldest, Win Thanda, 13, was less sure of her surroundings and slower to learn English than the younger ones. Sometimes, her siblings yelled at her when she didn't understand an English phrase quickly enough. But Pyi Son and his sisters Soe Sanda, 6, and Thin Zu Hlaing, 3, were thriving. Thanks in part to English classes run by the rescue committee, Soe Sanda and Win Thanda could read English. 
Pyi Son was fascinated by baseball, football and hockey and by computer games like Game Boy. At school he was learning to play the violin and drums. He also had a dream. 
"I like motorcycles and cars and car races," he said. He has already decided he wants to be a race car driver when he grows up.

A Little Lady Liberty
One of the best things that happened to Khin Maung's family is that Annie Smith, a project manager for the rescue committee's youth program, practically adopted them. Ms. Smith, 34, a short, vivacious woman with curly, shoulder-length brown hair, was drawn to the family members, she said, "because they're so open, generous and warm and giving of themselves."
There is almost nothing Ms. Smith won't do for the family. She helps the adults fill in immigration paperwork and navigate the food stamp bureaucracy. She took Khin Maung to the doctor when he hurt his arm at work. She walks the children home from the English language classes.
Ms. Smith often visits the family in their apartment. The adults speak pidgin English combined with miming, while Ms. Smith, like a charades player, teases out what they are trying to say.
"Khin Maung, money?" Khin Maung asked anxiously one day recently, holding up a welfare form. Ms. Smith figured out he was asking whether the government would send him money or was saying he owed money. She reassured him that didn't owe the government money.
She also takes the family on outings, sometimes paying for their subway tokens. One lovely spring day, she took the family to the Statue of Liberty. After being cooped up in the small apartment, the children were eager to run around and play in the grass. Khin Maung was in a particularly good mood because he had got a raise to $7.50 per hour.
Yin Yin packed a huge noodle picnic to eat in the park. The children dressed up for the occasion. Soe Sanda wore a green coat and bright red lipstick; Pyi Son had a new red baseball cap, worn backward.
Ms. Smith bought their tickets. As the boat pushed off from Lower Manhattan, members of the family crowded against the railing, staring back toward the receding skyline and then craning their necks as they approached the huge statue. 
When the boat docked, they hurried down the gangplank. Lying flat on the ground, Khin Maung took out his camera, aimed it at his children and snapped, hoping to catch the size of the statue as it reached up toward the sky. Thin Zu was a small bundle of energy, racing around and squealing with delight. At the sight of the statue, she balled her little hand into a fist and stuck her arm up and forward, looking for all the world like a miniature Liberty with her torch.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Recreational Vehicle Makers See Gold in a Graying Market

BYLINE:  By The International Herald Tribune 

 BODY:
SHARES of many big makers of recreational vehicles have soared recently, and many analysts say the stocks of at least some of the companies are likely to keep climbing.
 The sector is hardly free of risk. Investing in an R.V. maker is a bet on good times ahead, because the industry is enduring its worst downturn in a decade. Shipments are falling because of a slowing economy and fears of rising fuel prices, a major expense for these gas-guzzling road houses. 
 "Even though the industry is not in good shape, stocks are rising in anticipation of an economic rebound and lower interest rates," said Craig Clarke, who follows the industry for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "This year will be the trough, but then the industry will rebound."
He said he believes the business will be driven by a flood of baby boomers approaching retirement age and ready to roam the highways. 
"The retiring 50-and-over age category will take the industry to new heights, and people want to get in while these stocks are cheap," Mr. Clarke said.
While many analysts agree with that idea, R.V. sales remain stagnant. And after the rapid run-up in the stock prices, they are selective about their picks, emphasizing that they should be long-term holdings.
One possibility is the Monaco Coach Corporation in Coburg, Ore. Like all R.V. manufacturers, its sales have fallen, but it has not been hit as hard as some of its competitors because it concentrates on the high end of the market -- bus-sized, diesel-fueled vehicles that have price tags of $100,000 to $1.2 million. Monaco has a solid share of the popular $100,000-to-$200,000 segment, which features extras like satellite television and double slide-outs, walls that expand to create living space when the vehicle is parked. 
"We like them because they have been really strong in the diesel-powered segment, the fastest-growing in the past several years," Mr. Clarke said. He added that Monaco had recently acquired the SMC Corporation, a competitor, making it the biggest maker of high-end motor homes. In recent weeks, Monaco has traded around his target price of $30, but that did not include the SMC acquisition, he said. "If that works out well," he added, "it could add another $4 to $5 to the share price." 
Some analysts are even more positive, predicting $39 a share over the next 12 months. On Friday, Monaco closed at $29.18. 
The other top pick at A. G. Edwards is Winnebago Industries, the industry leader with about one-fifth of the R.V. market in the United States. It appeals to customers who favor gasoline-powered models costing $60,000 to $100,000. 
"Winnebago is better in entry-level mobile homes, especially for first-time buyers," Mr. Clarke said. 
The company, based in Forest City, Iowa, reported earnings of 60 cents a share for the quarter ended May 26. That was down from 74 cents for the corresponding quarter a year earlier, but far ahead of analysts' estimates of 43 cents a share. The stock now trades at $28.50. 
One company whose shares have been particularly volatile is Fleetwood Enterprises of Riverside, Calif. Its revenue is about equally divided between large recreational vehicles and manufactured housing, factory-fabricated homes that stay in one place rather than taking to the road.
Fleetwood's problems were compounded because the manufactured housing and R.V. markets, usually countercyclical, fell apart at the same time, just as it was entering an ambitious expansion. 
"Their big error was trying to build up and open retailers to imitate Champion Enterprises Inc., the biggest player in manufactured housing," said Michael Crawford, an analyst at B. Riley & Company in Los Angeles. When the company said it was in violation of some of its loan covenants, nervous investors bailed out.
BUT Robert Marshall, an analyst at First Union Securities, has a "buy" rating on Fleetwood. He noted that the company had gained new financing, ending fears of a possible bankruptcy. 
"I never thought they were that close to filing anyway," he said. Management has been slashing costs, closing retail operations and eliminating 7,000 jobs, nearly a third of the work force, and the worst is probably over for the manufactured-housing market, Mr. Marshall said.
"On the R.V. side, I draw some degree of comfort that inventories are down about 30 percent since Christmas," he added. "People were cutting prices fast and furious, but that has slowed down." 
Fleetwood's stock closed on Friday at $15.35.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: How Many Miles Per Gallon?; 
It's Easy: Add Safety, Mileage, Pollution. Divide by Dollars.

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
WHEN a panel of the National Academy of Sciences was asked a decade ago to assess federal fuel-economy regulations, it warned that higher gas-mileage standards for cars would make the nation's roads less safe and threaten the financial survival of Detroit's automakers and their workers. 
 But a new panel of the same academy has drafted a completely different report this summer, recommending higher standards, playing down most safety concerns and giving little heed to Detroit's interests. 
 The report is due to be made public on Monday, and while some of its language has been toned down after industry lobbyists objected to a draft copy that was leaked July 17, the final document is still likely to create problems for the industry when the House takes up legislation this week to raise fuel-economy standards.
The report -- and the industry's objections to the first draft -- present an object lesson in the trade-offs facing politicians and auto executives alike. Deciding how many miles a family vehicle should get to a gallon of gasoline affects the environment, public safety, the economy, the nation's trade deficit and even national security -- to the extent that America's dependence on imported oil influences its policies in the Mideast. 
The findings of this year's panel show how much perceptions of the trade-offs have changed over the last ten years.
For example, a decade ago global warming had barely begun to be seen as an automotive issue, but the new report cites global warming as the single most important reason for regulating the fuel economy of new vehicles. When a car engine burns gasoline, it is basically combining carbon from the gasoline with oxygen from the air coming through the grille, producing a remarkable 19.5 pounds of carbon dioxide, an important global-warming gas, for each gallon of gasoline consumed. A full-sized sport utility vehicle belches nearly 11 tons of carbon dioxide a year, almost twice as much as the midsized cars that have long dominated the American road. 
The automotive safety debate has also been transformed since the last report was written in 1991 (and released in 1992). It focused on research suggesting that when automakers reduced the size of cars in the early 1980's to improve gas mileage, the lighter cars provided less protection for occupants during crashes, with deadly results.
But the report paid little attention to sport utility vehicles, even though lenient gas-mileage rules for the tall vehicles were already contributing to soaring sales. It briefly mentioned that research was needed to determine whether the taller vehicles were exacting a heavy toll in crashes with cars. And the report predicted that the problem of rollover crashes of sport utility vehicles would be solved by new rules that federal regulators had just drafted.
The new report takes a much more complex look at safety, with an emphasis on S.U.V.'s and other so-called light trucks, although the final version has been softened somewhat following industry objections. It mentions that lighter vehicles provide less protection, but looks at other problems at the same time. 
The rollover regulations drafted in 1992 were never put into force; automakers complained that they were so strict that they would essentially outlaw S.U.V.'s. Insurers warn, however, that lighter sport utility vehicles are the most likely to roll over, so higher mileage standards for them might actually increase the rollover problem.
A study last month by a Transportation Department researcher found that as the percentage of light trucks on the roads increases, traffic deaths also rise. Light trucks have higher death rates than cars in single-vehicle crashes, but do nothing to make multiple-vehicle crashes less deadly (though they do tend to shift the deaths in multivehicle crashes to car occupants).
The question now is how Congress will balance issues like safety and global warming with consumer choice. Americans have been telling pollsters for years that they want better fuel economy. But upper-income families increasingly dominate the market for new vehicles, especially sport utility vehicles. (Middle-class families now tend to buy reliable late-model cars coming off leases instead.) And upper-income families consistently tell the auto industry's market researchers that gas mileage ranks no higher among vehicle attributes than the quality of the carpets.
THE interplay of all these issues is so complex that, while this year's panel recommends that mileage standards be raised and provides statistics on what increases are feasible, it has steered clear of recommending specific increases in mileage standards, saying that must be left to elected officials.
Paul R. Portney, the economist who is the panel's chairman, said that it might cost $800 to substantially increase the fuel economy of a new car or sport utility with better engine technology, money many consumers might rather spend on making their vehicle fancier. And no scientific panel, he said, should be expected to decide how to balance consumer choice with all the other issues involved in fuel economy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A heavy sport utility vehicle, at left, can maul a lighter, more fuel-efficient car, at right, if they crash. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Slowdown's Other Shoe, Hanging Over The Hudson

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
FRIENDS in Manhattan planning a kitchen remodeling tell me that it is practically impossible to find an available electrician anywhere in the city. In the suburbs of northern New Jersey and in Westchester County, nearly every contractor seems to be booked into the fall.
 Despite the economic slowdown almost everywhere else -- and the first signs of real job losses in the region -- the New York metropolitan area still feels robust. 
 Well, wait a few months. The situation is about to change -- for the worse. Indeed, the odds are that just as the national economy begins to improve somewhat late this year and early in 2002, the New York region will be falling into a slump. And that suggests that the job market, which has been stronger lately in and around New York City than elsewhere in the country, will begin to lag behind. Contractors, though, should start returning phone calls. 
There are several reasons to expect a downturn in the vast metropolitan region, where more than 20 million people live and which generates more than 10 percent of the nation's economic activity.
To begin with, it's no secret that the region's fortunes are closely tied to Wall Street's. While only about 4 percent of the work force is employed in the financial sector, it still accounts for almost 30 percent of the area's total income, according to Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. With much of that income tied to year-end bonuses that are expected to be only about half as large this year as last, the sharpest blows from the market's slide and the drying up of deal-making have yet to be genuinely felt in the region.
And not just those who work on Wall Street will feel its pain. As the wealthiest section of the country, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut contain a disproportionate share of rich people with big stakes in the market.
"People in the area are still a lot wealthier than they were just a few years ago," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com. "But it takes time for it to sink in psychologically that their portfolios are down and that the market isn't going to come roaring back. It hasn't affected spending much yet, but it should this Christmas and next year."
Beyond Wall Street, the region's economy is largely dependent on a vast array of business services, from accounting and law to communications and management consulting. With the exception of a slump in media advertising that is already obvious on Madison Avenue, the nation's economic pain so far has been felt largely by manufacturing industries, which have only a modest presence in the region.
But cuts are coming to New York's service-oriented businesses, too. As soon as summer ends, corporate executives start getting serious about preparing their budgets for the coming year. Even if the overall economic outlook improves, most will still be searching for ways to hold down spending. Some of the easiest things to trim are consulting, public relations and business travel. Already, New York hotels are reporting that occupancies are down as much as 20 percent from a year earlier.
Moreover, New York, as the nation's most important center of global business activity, is vulnerable to an impending slowdown abroad in ways that go beyond the losses that exporters have already suffered.
TO be sure, the economic turbulence ahead is not likely to be anywhere near as severe as the storm that tore into the region in the late 1980's and early 1990's. There has been no rerun of the vast office overbuilding, fueled by reckless bank lending, that took years for both bankers and developers to recover from. The soaring real estate market should come down to earth, but it isn't likely to crash the way it did a decade ago. And in contrast to past out-migration, New York City's extensive growth and immigration of the past decade provide a cushion against a sharp downturn.
"We've had a huge increase in consumer spending, bolstered by 700,000 more people than a decade ago," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University and an adviser to Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayoral candidate. "That will help insulate the city."
In the New Jersey suburbs, the health of the pharmaceutical industry should help counterbalance the collapse of telecommunications spending and layoffs at Lucent Technologies, AT&T and others.
But despite the region's bright long-term future, the immediate road ahead is looking darker. And while many still rest their hopes for New York on the stock market bouncing back to life, that prospect looks more and more remote. "It could happen," Mr. Zandi said, "but I wouldn't bank on it."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Separate and Unequal; 
You Can Come In. You Stay Out.

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
UNITED STATES immigration policy is not fair. Never has been. Probably never will be. 
 Ever since the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 barred Chinese laborers from the country, American immigration history has been littered with laws and policies that have favored some countries and discriminated against others. 
 Instead of adhering to consistent, evenhanded rules, lawmakers and presidents over the years have withheld or doled out green cards, citizenship and other immigration perks based largely on race, economics, domestic politics and foreign policy. Immigrants fleeing Communist Cuba, for instance, are granted permanent legal status faster than other foreigners.
The latest proposal for selective treatment is a recommendation from President Bush's top immigration advisers to allow some of the estimated three million Mexicans living here illegally to earn permanent legal residency over time. 
Advocates for other illegal immigrants howled that other groups deserve equal treatment. They may be here illegally, their advocates argue, but they hold jobs, pay taxes and raise American-born children who are citizens, just as most Mexicans do. Mr. Bush seemed to try to tamp down the growing furor last week when he said he would ultimately "consider all folks here," but immigration specialists say the president is on firm ground in singling out Mexico for starters.
"The lesson to be learned is that U.S. immigration policy has to make choices," said Pamela S. Falk, a professor of international law at City University of New York and a former top House Democratic aide on Latin American issues. "To choose one group over another is a harsh reality, yet it's the fuel for the engine that drives the American economy and American foreign policy." 
In 1997, for example, Congress passed a law that made it easier for Nicaraguans to gain permanent residency, but treated Salvadorans and Guatemalans less generously. Hondurans and Haitians were left out of the deal altogether. 
"These were all people fleeing civil disorder in the 1980's, but we favored people fleeing from former communist regimes," said T. Alexander Aleinikoff, a former general counsel of the Immigration and Naturalization Service who is now a senior associate at the Migration Policy Institute, a new research and policy group here.
It's not just foreign policy that makes the difference. Last year, high-technology employers facing labor shortages persuaded the Republican-controlled Congress to nearly double the annual quota for temporary, high-skilled immigrants, to 195,000. Most of those visas go to immigrants from China and India. 
And this year, a broad coalition of employers from restaurant and hotel owners to landscapers and meat-packing plants are lobbying to expand a temporary worker program to include lesser-skilled laborers in their fields. "People complain about interest groups," said Professor Falk, "but that's the American system." 
In the case of Mexico, the legalization plan would be a crucial component of an ambitious new "guest worker" program that would allow some of the Mexicans living in the United States illegally to earn permanent residency, and give new migrants the chance to apply for green cards over time. The program is part of broader talks between Washington and Mexico City that tie migration to trade, energy, human rights and the fight against drug trafficking. 
"There are very good reasons for crafting a special immigration relationship with Mexico, given its propinquity, its historical ties and Nafta," said Mr. Aleinikoff. "That said, when it comes to the legalization proposal, it's very hard to distinguish long-term undocumented immigrants from Mexico in the United States from long-term undocumented immigrants here from other countries."
BUT let's open the history books. For a variety of reasons, not all them worthy by contemporary standards, American immigration policy has always made distinctions by race, ethnicity and socio-economic class. 
In 1907, under the so-called Gentlemen's Agreement, the United States agreed not to ban all Japanese immigration if Japan promised not to issue passports to Japanese laborers for travel to the continental United States. (They were still welcome to become agricultural workers in Hawaii.)
In 1921, the United States adopted a national-origins quota system that limited admissions from each European country to 3 percent of the foreign-born population here as of the 1910 Census. That had the effect of favoring northern Europeans over southern and eastern Europeans for nearly half a century. Most Asians were still excluded, but there were no limits on migrants from the Western Hemisphere. 
Three years later, President Calvin Coolidge signed an even more restrictive bill governing ethnic quotas, saying, "America must be kept American."
Not until the McCarran-Walter Act in 1952 did Congress crack open America's door slightly wider, maintaining the national-origins systems but for the first time approving minimum annual quotas for all countries.
As part of the civil rights movement, the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1965 eliminated racial criteria and replaced country-by-country quotas with a system that awarded green cards based largely on family or employer sponsorship. Until 1965, for example, the annual quota for Germans was almost 26,000 and the Irish almost 18,000, while the quota for China was 105, for Japan 185 and for the Pacific Islands 100.
Under the 1965 Act, which is still in effect, there is a worldwide ceiling on the number of people who come in through the family-preference system (excluding parents, spouses and minor children of refugees and American citizens). There is also a cap on admissions for individual countries. 
Only a handful of nations reach the annual limits -- Mexico, China, India, the Philippines -- but their nationals wait the longest to get in. Siblings of United States citizens born in the Philippines, for example, now face a 22-year wait for a green card.
"There will never be an ideal, totally fair immigration policy," said Ellis Cose, the author of "A Nation of Strangers: Prejudice, Politics, and the Populating of America." "So the best we can aim for is something that's not blatantly racially discriminatory."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 5, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the history of United States immigration policy misidentified the 1965 law that eliminated race and national origin as criteria for admission. It was the Immigration and Nationality Act, not the Immigration and Naturalization Act.
