HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Satellite Radio's Bet on Dissatisfied Listeners

BYLINE:  By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
After years of audience stability in radio, listeners are now impatiently switching off far more quickly than they used to. Listening has slipped 11 percent since the early 1990's, according to Arbitron audits.
 Critics blame the economics of corporate consolidation and the pressures on managers to take few risks and stick to programming that pleases advertisers by drawing the largest possible audience. Commercials now take up to a third of every hour. There is little room for niche formats like all-opera. 
 Two rival start-ups, XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. and Sirius Satellite Radio Inc., hope listeners -- especially motorists -- are dissatisfied enough with mainstream radio to pay for a 100-channel menu of varied music and talk.
The competing services will each offer a different array of mostly commercial-free music channels, with musicians and D.J.'s who are specialists in genres ranging from symphonic to Tejano music compiling the playlists and serving as hosts.
Each service will also offer an array of commercially sponsored news and information channels devoted to a particular subject like religion, comedy or theater. The nonmusical programming is obtained in alliances with established broadcasters and entertainment sources. Only some of the channels will be original content, like the programming developed by National Public Radio exclusively for Sirius.
By delivering a digital version of an old medium, XM and Sirius hold the promise for signals that never fade from coast to coast.
But succeeding will not be easy. To become profitable, each company says it needs four million subscribers by 2004. Doing so will require matching the growth of satellite television while creating programming with the originality of HBO, cable television's standout programmer.
Also, the business could start more slowly than anticipated if the radio receivers perform poorly or reception crackles in cities. "I think they have a real marketing challenge convincing people to spend $130 a year," said Paul-Jon McNealy, a Gartner Group analyst, who says satellite radio will shortly face competition for dashboard space from other broadband services.
Other analysts, though, are optimistic, forecasting higher profit margins in satellite radio than for cable or satellite television.
"This isn't a slam-dunk, but this is as close as you can get," said Michael Alpert, a Washington satellite consultant.
XM intends to charge subscribers $9.99 monthly, while Sirius will charge $12.95. In addition, customers will be required to buy new radios and receivers costing hundreds of dollars, although satellite-ready radios will become available in some new cars next year.
XM expects to start first, on Sept. 12, with broadcasts from its Washington-based studios to San Diego and the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The New York-based Sirius plans to start by year-end.
Each company expects to spend $100 million over the next 18 months on advertising to build brand awareness. Timed to coincide with holiday purchasing, XM's advertising campaign is to unfold in November featuring the artists Snoop Dogg, B. B. King and David Bowie. No doubt Sirius will counterattack with bragging rights over its alliances, which include Sting, M. C. Lyte and Grandmaster Flash.
The companies promise CD-level quality. To hear it, listeners must retrofit their cars with top-end $300 radios that are equipped to decode the satellite signal along with an antenna and a receiver that together cost about $240. An alternative is the $299 portable home-or-car model that connects through a cassette deck.
Satellite-receiving radios offered as a factory-installed option will first be available in some 2002 Cadillacs. Subscriptions are to be included in the car's financing from General Motors, which owns 12 percent of XM's stock. Sirius's partners, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler, will also offer vehicles equipped with comparable radios early in 2003, but both automakers declined to discuss any details. By 2004, car radios will be available that will receive either company's signal.
The primary audience is commuters and truckers. The companies hope consumers will be won over by programming atypical of commercial radio. At XM, that will include live concerts. At Sirius, music channels will include artist interviews, recordings of live performances and airplay beyond top-selling records.
"I knew what I didn't want," said David Margolese, the founder and chief executive of Sirius. His vow is to keep music channels commercial free. He also rebuffed investments from traditional radio broadcasters.
XM will permit commercials on only about half of its 71 music channels. "We feel there are channels that lend themselves to a commercial-free environment, like jazz and classical," said XM's chief executive, Hugh Panero.
Nine XM channels are to be programmed by Clear Channel Communications Inc., the nation's No. 1 owner of radio stations and the leading concert promoter, an XM investor.
The musical architects behind each company arrived at the same spot from different paths.
XM's programming chief, Lee Abrams, 48, a former programming consultant, has reshaped the formats of 200 stations and his work was widely copied and envied throughout the industry.
"We have to reinvent radio," he said. Part of his formula to draw fans is to hire leading figures as hosts, including Bill Mack, a late-night host well-known among truckers, and Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter.
Joseph S. Capobianco, 52, the programming chief at Sirius, also endured the nomadic career of a radio consultant. In 1991, though, he shaped programming at another start-up, Music Choice, which now provides music channels to 19 million cable television customers.
The biggest loser may be traditional radio, said Robert Unmacht, an independent media analyst. Growth expectations will come up short if XM and Sirius together win a 10 percent market share. "It's too much to lose," Mr. Unmacht said. "Wall Street will cream them."

HEADLINE: A Democratic Primary Is Primarily a Turf War 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 29 

 BODY:
Democrats slightly outnumber Republicans in Pennsylvania, but Republicans have been more adept in recent years at winning elections. The state's governor, lieutenant governor and most cabinet members are Republicans, as are both United States senators and 11 of 21 House members. Republicans also control both houses of the Legislature.
 Yet Democrats figure that if precedent holds, next year will be their turn to elect a governor. Since the end of World War II, Democrats and Republicans have alternated control of the governor's office every eight years. And the current governor, Tom Ridge, is a Republican. 
 Two of the best-known Democrats in Pennsylvania are competing for their party's nomination -- Auditor General Robert P. Casey Jr., the quiet-spoken son of a popular former governor, Robert P. Casey, and Edward G. Rendell, the gruff former mayor of Philadelphia and former chairman and fund-raising leader of the Democratic National Committee.
The primary is still 10 months off. But the two men, moderates on many issues, are already in an aggressive fight, waist deep in the old regional feud between the Philadelphia area (mostly Rendell turf) and the rest of the state (mostly Casey turf).
Republicans also are preparing for a primary between their party's major figures, Attorney General Mike Fisher and Treasurer Barbara Hafer. But the Casey-Rendell fight has the marquee names.
In the Democratic primary, it all comes down to this: Can Mr. Rendell hang onto his base in Philadelphia, the state's largest trove of votes, and then invade Casey territory to find the other votes needed to capture the nomination? Conversely, can Mr. Casey, who comes from Scranton, hang onto his base and find the votes he needs in Philadelphia?
The aversion between Philadelphians and many other Pennsylvanians is genuine. It is not really a city slicker vs. country hicks rivalry -- there are plenty of cities beyond Philadelphia -- but it is nevertheless there, most often finding voice in the Legislature in Harrisburg. That is where Philadelphia says it is not getting its fair share of money and attention and where others say the city is being greedy as usual.
Not since Martin Grove Brumbaugh, a Republican, won in 1914 has a Philadelphian broken the "Philly curse" and been elected governor. 
Mr. Rendell's challenge is to convince voters that he can do for the rest of the state what he did for Philadelphia from 1992 to 2000. What he did was put a city back on its economic feet, an accomplishment that won him national plaudits.
At the moment, Pennsylvania is on wobbly economic footing.
Mr. Casey's challenge is to convince skeptics in Philadelphia that he has learned enough in two terms as state auditor to manage the state and, in particular, to look after Philadelphia's interests.
"It's been a long time since we've seen a more interesting governor's election than this one," said Al Neri, editor of The Pennsylvania Report, a nonpartisan publication that tracks state politics. "There's genuine anticipation and excitement out there, especially among Democrats." 
No independent polls of the primary contests have been taken recently. But most political professionals consider the Democratic contest too close to call. In the Republican primary, the experts give Mr. Fisher the edge, pointing out that because he is a conservative, he is probably more acceptable to his party's rank and file than Ms. Hafer, a moderate. 
Beyond regionalism, the overarching issue in the election is how to get the Pennsylvania economy moving again. But other issues also are in play, notably abortion. On the Democratic side, Mr. Rendell favors abortion rights and Mr. Casey opposes them. On the Republican side, Mr. Fisher opposes abortion rights while Ms. Hafer favors them. 
Mr. Rendell says he is confident he can break the Philly curse.
"I've got the experience," he said the other day at his campaign headquarters here. "People know I can bring in industry, create jobs, improve schools."
He has also been working hard to raise money, more than $6 million by most estimates. The expectation is that because he is such a formidable fund-raiser, he will have well over $10 million to pour into the May 21 primary.
Much of his money almost certainly will go into a statewide television advertising blitz designed to increase his name recognition. Mr. Casey, having won several statewide elections and being the son of a governor, is better known than Mr. Rendell outside of Philadelphia but less well known in Philadelphia.
"I expect to hold my own in Philadelphia and then beat Ed in the rest of the state," Mr. Casey said while touring a child care center in downtown Philadelphia recently. "He may have been a mayor, but he has never held statewide office and he has no feel for statewide issues."
In the Republican primary contest, Mr. Fisher professes to be so confident of victory over Ms. Hafer that he is already concentrating on the fall race.
"Barbara is going to lose because she's way too far over on the left," he said. "She's pro-choice and our party is pro-life, as I am, and as I believe the state is. No way she can win."
Ms. Hafer counters that Republicans in an East Coast state like Pennsylvania are much more moderate than Mr. Fisher wants to admit.
"Republicans in this state are not going to nominate someone from the right wing like Mike Fisher," she said. "That's a sure recipe for defeat in the fall, a guarantee that a Democrat will occupy the governor's office next and the change-chairs-every-eight-years tradition will continue."

HEADLINE: President of Urban League Calls for Review of Inequity 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29 

 BODY:
The head of the National Urban League called on the Bush administration today to conduct a comprehensive review of the "pervasive racism" in the criminal justice system, from racial profiling to the number of blacks on death row.
 Hugh B. Price, president of the Urban League, said at the group's annual conference, "Tonight, I say to President Bush what I once said to President Clinton: race relations won't improve in America until racism in the criminal justice system subsides." Mr. Price praised Mr. Bush and Attorney General John Ashcroft for expressing concern about the issue but asserted, "It's time they move beyond empathy to aggressive corrective action." 
 They could begin, he said, by creating a panel of criminal justice experts to "scrutinize every facet of the federal, state and local criminal justice system" for the influence of race.
He also called on the administration to participate in the United Nations conference on racism in South Africa. Administration officials had indicated that they would not send representatives if organizers focused on reparations for slavery or equating Zionism with racism. "America must not be missing in action at the World Conference come September," Mr. Price said.
The Urban League, a 91-year-old civil rights group with chapters in more than 100 cities, opened a four-day session here that will feature appearances by President Bush and several top administration officials. Mr. Price said he welcomed Mr. Bush's participation and was "deeply honored by it." But he also issued a scathing review of the policies produced by Washington in recent months and years.
"I say it's cruel for Washington to end welfare as we knew it, tell poor people they must work, then argue bitterly year after year about raising the minimum wage and extending the earned income tax credit for the working poor," Mr. Price said to applause. "It's heartless to enact a tax cut that sends $600 rebates to millionaires, yet gives nary a dime to low-wage workers who earn too little to pay federal income taxes, but pay plenty of other taxes."
Such policies only underscore the need for "a development revolution" among black Americans, "to eradicate the economic gaps that separate far too many African-Americans from the American mainstream," Mr. Price said.
"Develop we must because with its shifting ideologies and agendas, government cannot and should not be counted on to do it for us," he said, adding, "We must show America that we have so much value to contribute, educationally, economically and politically, that it's foolhardy to ignore us."
This new revolution should include greater political pressure for "a livable wage" for the working poor; greater responsibility among rap musicians and entrepreneurs to "help illuminate the way out" rather than "dragging impressionable young audiences down into depression and despair"; and a new focus on education.
Part of the answer is more parental involvement at home and higher expectations of the schools, he argued, saying, "we must have zero tolerance for failing schools."
Earlier in the day, Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District of Columbia's delegate to the House, called for a new focus on African-American boys and men. She also said: "Our issues and our people must never depend on who is president of the United States or who controls the Congress of the United States. We must continue to move forward regardless of who's in charge."
